('53', 0, 0, 1, 0) VOL. 53 : 2 JULY, 1931 12 OCTOBER, 1931 1
('53', 0, 1, 2, 42) 1. SUPERSTITIONS DIE HARD
('53', 0, 2, 3, 68) Mr. Henry Eaton writes from California: 1
('53', 0, 3, 4, 110) This letter betrays two superstitions.
('53', 0, 3, 5, 149) One of them is that India is unfit to govern herself because she cannot defend herself and is torn with internal dissensions.
('53', 0, 3, 6, 275) The writer gratuitously assumes that if Britain withdraws Russia is ready to pounce upon India.
('53', 0, 3, 7, 371) This is an insult to Russia.
('53', 0, 3, 8, 400) Is Russia’s one business to rule over those peoples who are not ruled by Britain?
('53', 0, 3, 9, 482) And if Russia has such nefarious designs upon India, does not the writer see that the same power that will oust the British from domination is bound to prevent any other domination?
('53', 0, 3, 10, 664) If the control is handed to India’s representatives by agreement, there must be some condition whereby Britain will guarantee protection from foreign aggression as a penance for her conscious or unconscious neglect during all these past years to fit India for defending herself.
('53', 0, 3, 11, 943) Personally, even under agreement, I should rely more upon the capacity of the nation to offer civil resistance to any aggressor as it did last year with partial success in the case of the British occupier.
('53', 0, 3, 12, 1149) Complete success awaits complete assimilation of non violence in thought, word and deed by the nation.
('53', 0, 3, 13, 1252) An ocular demonstration of the success of nationwide satyagraha must be a prelude to its worldwide acceptance and hence as a natural corollary to the admission of the futility of armament.
('53', 0, 3, 14, 1441) The only antidote to armament which is the visible symbol of violence is satyagraha the visible symbol of non violence.
('53', 0, 3, 15, 1561) But the writer is oppressed also by the fear of our dis sensions.
('53', 0, 3, 16, 1627) In the first place they are grossly exaggerated in transmis sion to the West.
('53', 0, 3, 17, 1705) In the second place, they are hardened during foreign control.
('53', 0, 3, 18, 1768) Imperial rule means divide et impera.
('53', 0, 3, 19, 1806) They must therefore melt with the withdrawal of the frigid foreign rule and the introduction of the warmth giving sunshine of real freedom.
('53', 0, 3, 20, 1946) The second superstition is harder still.
('53', 0, 3, 21, 1987) I mean that about the spinning wheel.
('53', 0, 3, 22, 2025) This is shared by some even in India.
('53', 0, 3, 23, 2063) The writer begs the question when he calls the method of machinery enlightened and that of the hand ignorant.
('53', 0, 3, 24, 2173) It has still to be proved that displacement of the hand by the machine is a blessing in every case.
('53', 0, 3, 25, 2273) Nor is it true that
('53', 0, 4, 26, 2293) 1 The letter is not reproduced here.
('53', 1, 0, 1, 2330) 2 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('53', 1, 1, 2, 2370) that which is easy is better than that which is hard.
('53', 1, 1, 3, 2424) It is still less proved that every change is a blessing or that everything old is fit only to be discarded.
('53', 1, 1, 4, 2532) I hold that the machinery method is harmful when the same thing can be done easily by millions of hands not otherwise occupied.
('53', 1, 1, 5, 2660) It is any day better and safer for the millions spread in the seven hundred thousand villages of India scattered over an area nineteen hundred miles long and fifteen hundred broad that they manufacture their clothing in their own villages even as they prepare their own food.
('53', 1, 1, 6, 2936) These villages cannot retain the freedom they have enjoyed from time immemorial, if they do not control the production of prime necessaries of life.
('53', 1, 1, 7, 3085) Western observers hastily argue from Western conditions that what may be true of them must be true of India where conditions are different in so many material respects.
('53', 1, 1, 8, 3254) Applications of the laws of economics must vary with varying conditions.
('53', 1, 1, 9, 3327) The machinery method is no doubt easy.
('53', 1, 1, 10, 3366) But it is not necessarily a blessing on that account.
('53', 1, 1, 11, 3420) The descent to a certain place is easy but dangerous.
('53', 1, 1, 12, 3474) The method of the hand is a blessing, in the present case at any rate, because it is hard.
('53', 1, 1, 13, 3565) If the craze for the machinery method continues, it is highly likely that a time will come when we shall be so incapacitated and weak that we shall begin to curse ourselves for having forgotten the use of the living machines given to us by God.
('53', 1, 1, 14, 3810) Millions cannot keep themselves fit by games and athletics.
('53', 1, 1, 15, 3870) And why should they exchange the useful, productive, hardy occupations for the useless, unproductive and expensive games and exercises?
('53', 1, 1, 16, 4006) They are all right today for a change and recreation.
('53', 1, 1, 17, 4060) They will jar upon us when they become a necessary occupation in order that we may have the appetite for eating the food in the production of which we had no hand or part.
('53', 1, 1, 18, 4232) Lastly, I do not subscribe to the belief that everything old is bad.
('53', 1, 1, 19, 4301) Truth is old and difficult.
('53', 1, 1, 20, 4329) Untruth has many attractions.
('53', 1, 1, 21, 4359) But I would gladly go back to the very old Golden Age of Truth.
('53', 1, 1, 22, 4423) Good old brown bread is any day superior to the pasty white bread which has lost much of its nutritive value in going through the various processes of refinement.
('53', 1, 1, 23, 4586) The list of old and yet good things can be endlessly multiplied.
('53', 1, 1, 24, 4651) The spinning wheel is one such thing, at any rate, for India.
('53', 1, 1, 25, 4713) When India becomes self supporting, self reliant and proof against temptations and exploitation, she will cease to be the object of
('53', 2, 0, 1, 4845) VOL. 53 : 2 JULY, 1931 12 OCTOBER, 1931 3
('53', 2, 1, 2, 4887) greedy attraction for any power in the West or the East and will then feel secure without having to carry the burden of expensive armament.
('53', 2, 1, 3, 5027) Her internal economy will be India’s strongest bulwark against aggression.
('53', 2, 1, 4, 5102) Young India, 2 7 1931
('53', 2, 2, 5, 5124) 2. POWER NOT AN END
('53', 2, 3, 6, 5144) Satyamurti writes: 1
('53', 2, 4, 7, 5165) I write to you about the article “Substance Not Shadow” by you, in the Young India, of the 18th June.
('53', 2, 4, 8, 5267) The first sentence which causes me some doubt and anxiety is, “My proposition therefore before the Working Committee was that agreed settlement failing, the Congress should give up the hope of winning a swaraj constitution by the way of the present Round Table Conference and should wait till all the communities were satisfied to adopt a purely national solution.” Does this not mean a charter for extreme communalists to go on obstructing?
('53', 2, 5, 9, 5709) But the sentence which causes me grave anxiety is that which ends as follows: “We can gain our end without political power and by directly acting upon the powers that be.” I would add the following sentences also from your article in order to make my doubts clear to you.
('53', 2, 5, 10, 5981) “One form of direct action is adult suffrage.
('53', 2, 5, 11, 6027) The second and more potent form is satyagraha.
('53', 2, 5, 12, 6074) It can easily be shown that whatever is needful and can be gained by political power can perhaps be more quickly and more certainly gained by satyagraha.” I venture to join issue with you.
('53', 2, 5, 13, 6263) I was always and am today under the impression that what the Congress wants is political power more than anything else.
('53', 2, 5, 14, 6383) And, concretely speaking, prohibition can be more easily brought about by State action than by peaceful picketing.
('53', 2, 5, 15, 6498) Khaddar and swadeshi cloth can be spread better and more quickly by State action than by peaceful picketing, and the necessary reforms embodied in the Karachi resolution on Fundamental Rights can be enforced only by a swaraj Government.
('53', 2, 6, 16, 6735) In any case, I do not see why the nation should not concentrate all its energies today, upon the gaining of political power.
('53', 2, 7, 17, 6860) To me, politieal power is the substance, and all other reforms can and ought to wait.
('53', 2, 7, 18, 6946) I am thankful for this letter.
('53', 2, 7, 19, 6977) It enables me more clearly than I have been able to explain my position.
('53', 2, 7, 20, 7050) My implicit faith in non violence does mean yielding to minorities when they are really weak.
('53', 2, 7, 21, 7144) The best way to weaken
('53', 2, 8, 22, 7167) 1 Only extracts are reproduced here.
('53', 3, 0, 1, 7204) 4 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('53', 3, 1, 2, 7244) communalists is to yield to them.
('53', 3, 1, 3, 7278) Resistance will only rouse their suspicion and strengthen their opposition.
('53', 3, 1, 4, 7354) A satyagrahi resists when there is threat of force behind obstruction.
('53', 3, 1, 5, 7425) I know that I do not carry the Congressmen in general with me in this what to me appears as very sensible and practical point of view.
('53', 3, 1, 6, 7560) But if we are to come to swaraj through non violent means, I know that this point of view will be accepted.
('53', 3, 1, 7, 7668) Now for Sjt.
('53', 3, 1, 8, 7681) Satyamurti’s second difficulty.
('53', 3, 1, 9, 7713) To me political power is not an end but one of the means of enabling people to better their condition in every department of life.
('53', 3, 1, 10, 7844) Political power means capacity to regulate national life through national representatives.
('53', 3, 1, 11, 7935) If national life becomes so perfect as to become self regulated, no re presentation is necessary.
('53', 3, 1, 12, 8033) There is then a state of enlightened anarchy.
('53', 3, 1, 13, 8079) In such a state everyone is his own ruler.
('53', 3, 1, 14, 8122) He rules himself in such a manner that he is never a hindrance to his neighbour.
('53', 3, 1, 15, 8203) In the ideal state therefore there is no political power because there is no State.
('53', 3, 1, 16, 8287) But the ideal is never fully realized in life.
('53', 3, 1, 17, 8334) Hence the classical statement of Thoreau that that Government is best which governs the least.
('53', 3, 1, 18, 8429) If then I want political power, it is for the sake of the reforms for which the Congress stands.
('53', 3, 1, 19, 8526) Therefore when the energy to be spent in gaining that power means so much loss of energy required for the reforms, as threatens to be the case if the country is to engage in a duel with the Mussalmans or Sikhs, I would most decidedly advise the country to let the Mussalmans and Sikhs take all the power and I would go on with developing the reforms.
('53', 3, 1, 20, 8877) If we were to analyse the activities of the Congress during the past twelve years, we would discover that the capacity of the Congress to take political power has increased in exact proportion to its ability to achieve success in the constructive effort.
('53', 3, 1, 21, 9132) That is to me the substance of political power.
('53', 3, 1, 22, 9180) Actual taking over of the Government machinery is but a shadow, an emblem.
('53', 3, 1, 23, 9255) And it could easily be a burden if it came as a gift from without, the people having made no effort to deserve it.
('53', 3, 1, 24, 9370) It is now perhaps easy to realize the truth of my statement that the needful can be ‘gained more quickly and more certainly by satyagraha than by political power.’ Legislation in advance of public opinion has often been demonstrated to be futile.
('53', 3, 1, 25, 9617) Legal prohibition of theft in a country in which the vast majority are thieves would be futile.
('53', 3, 1, 26, 9713) Picketing and the other popular activities are therefore the real
('53', 4, 0, 1, 9779) VOL. 53 : 2 JULY, 1931 12 OCTOBER, 1931 5
('53', 4, 1, 2, 9821) If political power was a thing apart from these reforms, we would have to suspend latter and concentrate on the former.
('53', 4, 1, 3, 9941) But we have followed the contrary course.
('53', 4, 1, 4, 9983) We have everywhere emphasized the necessity of carrying on the constructive activities as being the means of.attaining swaraj.
('53', 4, 1, 5, 10110) I am convinced that whenever legal prohibition of drinks, drugs and foreign cloth comes, it will come because public opinion had demanded it.
('53', 4, 1, 6, 10252) It may be said that public opinion demands it today but the foreign Government does not respond.
('53', 4, 1, 7, 10349) This is only partly right.
('53', 4, 1, 8, 10376) Public opinion in this country is only now becoming a vital force and developing the real sanction which is satyagraha.
('53', 4, 2, 9, 10496) Young India, 2 7 1931
('53', 4, 3, 10, 10518) 3. KISAN’S TROUBLES IN THE U.P.
('53', 4, 4, 11, 10550) The reader will recall the allegations published last week 1 against a zamindar of a village in Unao.
('53', 4, 4, 12, 10652) This time I have more serious news involving Government officials in the instigation of zamindars and taluqdars.
('53', 4, 4, 13, 10765) Here are copies of two authentic confidential circulars 2 to zamindars signed by the Deputy Commissioner of Rae Bareli.

('53', 5, 2, 8, 12153) These circulars clearly betray hostility towards the Congress and Kisan Sabhas and invite the taluqdars to strong action against the kisans, promising Government help to them in their measures.
('53', 5, 2, 9, 12347) We all know what such circulars mean.
('53', 5, 2, 10, 12385) They imply much more than the words mean.
('53', 5, 2, 11, 12427) They imply freedom to the addressees to do as they choose.
('53', 5, 2, 12, 12486) And why are these circulars confidential?
('53', 5, 2, 13, 12528) Is there anything for the U.P. Government or the Deputy Commissioner to be ashamed of?
('53', 5, 2, 14, 12615) Or are they confidential because the circulars are a veiled incitement to violence?
('53', 5, 2, 15, 12699) In my opinion the circulars constitute a clear breach of the Settlement.
('53', 5, 2, 16, 12772) These circulars explain why the following extraordi nary notice 3 was served on Congress workers in that district.
('53', 5, 2, 17, 12887) At the time of writing I have information that this notice has been withdrawn.
('53', 5, 2, 18, 12966) This notice would have meant complete stoppage of all Congress activities, as if the Government was at war with the Congress.
('53', 5, 2, 19, 13092) It was a gross and glaring breach of the Settlement.
('53', 5, 2, 20, 13145) For better or for worse there is at present peace between the Government and the Congress.
('53', 5, 2, 21, 13236) And the Provincial Governments and district officials are bound to respect it.
('53', 5, 2, 22, 13315) If they do not like it, or if they think that the Congress is not playing the game, they should ask the Central Government to denounce the Settlement.
('53', 5, 2, 23, 13466) I may inform the reader that even with reference to this order so manifestly contrary to the Settlement, I had advised that, till I had the opportunity of approaching the Central Government and the Working Committee had

('53', 6, 1, 2, 13954) decided, no one should disobey the order.
('53', 6, 1, 3, 13996) I am glad therefore that the U.P. Government have withdrawn the order.
('53', 6, 1, 4, 14067) Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru had drawn in forcible terms the attention of the U.P. Government to the order.
('53', 6, 1, 5, 14170) This withdrawal should be followed by the withdrawals of the confidential circulars and the policy they adumbrate.
('53', 6, 1, 6, 14285) When I was in Nainital, I was reliably informed that the U.P. Government’s policy was not to take sides.
('53', 6, 1, 7, 14390) They had instructed district officers to observe perfect neutrality between the zamindars and the kisans.
('53', 6, 1, 8, 14496) But this policy has evidently been revised as will appear from the following condensed summary 1 of a report before me.

('53', 6, 1, 11, 14919) And all this after the descent of the Deputy Commissioner from Nainital whereto he had been summoned to see H.E. the Governor!
('53', 6, 1, 12, 15046) I hope that there is no connection between the studied terrorism which the foregoing narrative proves and the Nainital visit.
('53', 6, 1, 13, 15172) Be that as it may, there should be no haste on the part of Congressmen, there should be no breaches of orders till the Working Committee has considered the situation.
('53', 6, 1, 14, 15339) It meets on the 7th instant and will consider the extraordinary situation that is developing in several provinces.

('53', 6, 2, 16, 15476) 4. YOUNG EUROPEANS
('53', 6, 3, 17, 15495) It was a matter of pleasure to me as I know it was to Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel to meet the young Europeans in Bombay the other day.
('53', 6, 3, 18, 15627) Several young Europeans have formed themselves into a group for the purpose of studying the Indian situation and then forming their own conclusions and taking their due share in moulding public opinion.
('53', 6, 3, 19, 15830) As behoves earnest students, these gentlemen have eschewed all publicity for their proceedings.
('53', 6, 3, 20, 15926) They invite to their social dinner representatives of all parties and hear their views and ask questions where further elucidation is necessary.
('53', 6, 3, 21, 16071) They pass no resolutions, have framed no policy.
('53', 6, 3, 22, 16120) They approach questions with an open mind.
('53', 6, 3, 23, 16163) These friends deserve congratulations and encouragement in their
('53', 6, 4, 24, 16228) 1 Not reproduced here.
('53', 6, 4, 25, 16251) It described how the Settlement was being violated and the villagers oppressed and terrorized in the Rae Bareli District.
('53', 7, 0, 1, 16373) 8 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('53', 7, 1, 2, 16413) praiseworthy endeavour.
('53', 7, 1, 3, 16437) I venture to suggest to them that if they will come to a decision early, if they intend to affect the present political situation, it is necessary for them to classify the subjects for study and appoint from among themselves certain members who would specially study those particular questions and in that connection interview those who represent different parties which bring their influence to bear on them.
('53', 7, 1, 4, 16847) All this undoubtedly means strenuous work.
('53', 7, 1, 5, 16890) But it is necessary if the studies are to bear fruit in the near future.
('53', 7, 2, 6, 16963) Young India, 2 7 1931

('53', 10, 1, 2, 20466) 11. LETTER TO SIR ERNEST HOTSON 1
('53', 10, 2, 3, 20500) BORSAD, July 3, 1931 I thank you for your letter 2 of the 30th ultimo, which was redirected to me at Borsad.
('53', 10, 2, 4, 20609) I would gladly serve on the Federal Structure Committee of the Round Table Conference, if the way is open for me to sail for England in time.
('53', 10, 2, 5, 20751) Will you please inform His Excellency the Viceroy that the working of the Delhi Settlement is causing me great anxiety and is taking up practically the whole of my time to the exclusion of many other important things I would gladly attend to if I was free?
('53', 10, 2, 6, 21008) I am inundated with complaints from fellow workers, which go to show that the Settlement is not being satisfactorily implemented by local officials.

('53', 11, 6, 24, 24095) They can do so if there is adult suffrage.
('53', 11, 6, 25, 24138) Exercise of the suffrage in favour of those who will carry out their will will be one
('53', 11, 7, 26, 24224) 1 Vide “An Autobiography” and “Interview to Associated Press”, 15 6 1931 2 Lady Cecilia Roberts 3 For Gandhiji’s article entitled “Substance Not Shadow”, 18 6 1931
('53', 12, 0, 1, 24388) VOL. 53 : 2 JULY, 1931 12 OCTOBER, 1931 13
('53', 12, 1, 2, 24431) form of direct action.
('53', 12, 1, 3, 24454) But they may not have adult suffrage.
('53', 12, 1, 4, 24492) They may not be exercising any influence over the legislatures so far as the constitutional position may be concerned, but if they have imbibed the spirit of non violence and suffering, i.
('53', 12, 1, 5, 24681) e., satyagrah, their influence on the legislatures will be more direct and more effective than that exerted through adult suffrage, by simply refusing to assist the Government in the shape of payment of taxes or in various other ways.
('53', 12, 1, 6, 24916) They can bring the existing Government to book and either get their demands fulfilled or bring it to a standstill.
('53', 12, 1, 7, 25031) Is this not clear?
('53', 12, 1, 8, 25050) Now for the boycott.
('53', 12, 1, 9, 25071) It is being constantly dinned into the ears of the public that the boycott has ceased to be used as a political weapon, i.
('53', 12, 1, 10, 25194) e., for exerting political pressure but that it is being now used as an effective economic weapon.
('53', 12, 1, 11, 25293) There is a statement reported to have been made by Jawaharlal appearing in today’s papers.
('53', 12, 1, 12, 25384) I send you herewith a cutting from the daily press.
('53', 12, 1, 13, 25436) But even as an economic weapon it certainly requires intensification.
('53', 12, 1, 14, 25506) Just after the Settlement there was a lull, that is to say, we were all purposely not doing anything to egg the people on to picketing.
('53', 12, 1, 15, 25642) All the Congress committees were left alone even when we, members of the Working Committee, knew that the provincial committees were not keeping picketing up to the mark.
('53', 12, 1, 16, 25813) When the aggressive form ceased all the zest seemed to have disappeared and several committees left off picketing in sullen discontent.
('53', 12, 1, 17, 25949) This state of things could not be permitted to continue, for if this laxity was long overlooked the organization would become inefficient.
('53', 12, 1, 18, 26088) What is more, the Committee could not afford, through it own negligence to see foreign cloth coming in and competing both with khadi and indigenous mill cloth.
('53', 12, 1, 19, 26248) A resolution therefore was absolutely necessary to warn the people that because of the Settlement they were not to neglect their duty of warning the people against buying foreign cloth.
('53', 12, 1, 20, 26434) I see nothing inconsistent with ahimsa in this or with the terms of the Settlement.
('53', 12, 1, 21, 26518) Even an economic boycott requires strict vigilance, if the people are to be weaned from a habit of practically a century.
('53', 12, 1, 22, 26640) They have to be repeatedly reminded that it is a bad habit.
('53', 12, 1, 23, 26700) The test that the boycott now is purely economic lies in this, that there is not boycott of British cloth or British goods as such.
('53', 12, 1, 24, 26832) That boycott was most effectively used during the campaign frankly as a political weapon and stopped as if by magic immediately

('53', 13, 1, 2, 27001) the Settlement was announced.
('53', 13, 1, 3, 27031) This can be proved by producing conclusive evidence that almost the day after the Settlement orders for British machinery, British drugs and the like were despatched.
('53', 13, 1, 4, 27198) Have I made the position clear?
('53', 13, 1, 5, 27230) I can assure you that there is no desire on the part of any member of the Working Committee to use the economic boycott as a political weapon.
('53', 13, 1, 6, 27373) That it has political consequences is not to be denied.
('53', 13, 1, 7, 27429) The fact was before both Lord Irwin and myself during our talks and he recognized that it was inevitable.
('53', 13, 1, 8, 27535) But you can examine the position in this way also.
('53', 13, 1, 9, 27586) Supposing that Lancashire withdrew its trade in piece goods from India which is after all 12%, boycott of foreign cloth will still continue although the competitor will be chiefly Japan.
('53', 13, 1, 10, 27773) To complete the case I am sending you the correspondence bearing on the question between the Central Government and myself.
('53', 13, 1, 11, 27897) Much as I should like to have you by my side here, I would not think of dragging you here from England.

('53', 17, 1, 2, 32368) 19. LETTER TO MURIEL LESTER
('53', 17, 2, 3, 32396) [Before July 5, 1931] 1
('53', 17, 3, 4, 32420) I would rather stay at your settlement 2 than anywhere else, for there I will be living among the same sort of people as those for whom I have spent my life.
('53', 17, 3, 5, 32578) The Hindu, 6 7 1931
('53', 17, 4, 6, 32598) 20. KATHIAWAR POLITICAL CONFERENCE
('53', 17, 5, 7, 32633) At its Bhavnagar session this Conference imposed on itself a restriction not to criticize the affairs of one State in the territory of another State.
('53', 17, 5, 8, 32783) 3 Some had not quite liked this self restraint, but all had willingly or unwillingly accepted it.
('53', 17, 5, 9, 32881) There are now rumours of a move for the removal of the restriction.
('53', 17, 5, 10, 32949) The argument in favour of the removal is this: When we accepted the restriction, we did so because of the people’s weakness; but the time has now changed and hence the restriction should go.
('53', 17, 5, 11, 33140) If the Kathiawar Political Conference wishes to remove the restriction, it has a full right to do so.
('53', 17, 5, 12, 33242) I think either the Conference should be convened to lift it or the Executive Committee should run the risk of exceeding its constitutional authority and rescind the Resolution passed at the Conference.
('53', 17, 5, 13, 33444) It would become the duty of the Executive Committee to act in that manner when its members definitely feel that public opinion demands such a step and that it must be taken immediately.
('53', 17, 5, 14, 33630) Here, however, I wish to discuss only the necessity or otherwise of that self restraint.
('53', 17, 5, 15, 33719) I think that the restraint was not a sign of weakness, but was, and even today is, a mark of civility.
('53', 17, 5, 16, 33822) It was certainly inspired by a recognition of the condition of the Princes.
('53', 17, 5, 17, 33898) It is the duty of the Conference to take account of their condition and the fact that it did so was a sign of its practical wisdom.
('53', 17, 5, 18, 34030) It stands to lose nothing through that restraint and much to gain.
('53', 17, 6, 19, 34097) 1 The letter was released by Reuter from London on July 5. 2 Kingsley Hall, a welfare workers’ settlement in the East End, London 3 It was at the fourth Conference at Porbandar on January 22, 1928 that Gandhiji moved from the chair a resolution adopting the restriction; vide “Speech at Kathiawar Political Conference, Porbandar”, 22 1 1928
('53', 18, 0, 1, 34438) VOL. 53 : 2 JULY, 1931 12 OCTOBER, 1931 19
('53', 18, 1, 2, 34481) Anyone following the path of non violence and truth would willingly observe the restriction.
('53', 18, 1, 3, 34574) I would, therefore, go so far as to say that a satyagrahi would observe it not merely because such is the Resolution of the Kathiawar Political Conference but also because it is necessary in itself.
('53', 18, 1, 4, 34773) It is malicious propaganda to criticize the evils of State A in the territory of State B. It is cowardice to do so.
('53', 18, 1, 5, 34889) Bravery lies in going to State A and exposing its evils there.
('53', 18, 1, 6, 34952) As A and B are on friendly terms, B would be in a difficult position if A is criticized in B’s territory.
('53', 18, 1, 7, 35058) Without sufficient reason, a satyagrahi would not put any person into an embarrassing position.
('53', 18, 1, 8, 35154) It may, however, be argued that when it is not possible to go to A’s State to criticize him, there should be some place where it could be done.
('53', 18, 1, 9, 35298) The reply to this is simple.
('53', 18, 1, 10, 35327) As the Indian States are subject to the authority of the British Government, all such subject States can be criticized, and are criticized, in British Indian territory.
('53', 18, 1, 11, 35496) Hence, even after the experience of so many years, I cling to my view: The self restraint imposed at Bhavnagar is just as necessary now as it was then.
('53', 18, 1, 12, 35648) To a satyagrahi it is binding whether or not he belongs to the Conference.
('53', 18, 1, 13, 35723) If the time has truly changed, we ought to be strong enough to go to the State concerned and compel it to remedy the evils.
('53', 18, 1, 14, 35847) What courage do we show by criticizing the evils of a State outside its borders?
('53', 18, 1, 15, 35928) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 5 7 1931
('53', 18, 2, 16, 35964) 21. INDIA STATES AND SATYAGRAHA
('53', 18, 3, 17, 35996) I have two letters lying with me.
('53', 18, 3, 18, 36030) One is addressed to me and the other is addressed to Kishorelalbhai who has sent it to me for reply.
('53', 18, 3, 19, 36131) The following is the substance of the letter addressed to me: You stop the satyagraha which has been going on in A, in B you blame those who started it, in C you advise them to slacken its pace and in D you permit an inexperienced leader to start it.
('53', 18, 3, 20, 36382) Instead of putting yourself in such a false position, why don’t you advise people to stop satyagraha altogether for the present and take up khadi work only and through it acquire fitness for satyagraha?
('53', 18, 3, 21, 36585) The long letter addressed to Kishorelalbhai is full of anger: The Congress seems to think that it can treat us, workers in
('53', 19, 0, 1, 36708) 20 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('53', 19, 1, 2, 36749) the Indian States, as it likes.
('53', 19, 1, 3, 36781) During the struggle, we suffered beatings and went to jail.
('53', 19, 1, 4, 36841) Now that there is a Settlement, we are treated as mere dirt.
('53', 19, 1, 5, 36902) Our letters are thrown into the dustbin by the secretary.
('53', 19, 1, 6, 36960) If we wish to show our spirit, it will adversely affect the Settlement between the Congress and the Government!
('53', 19, 1, 7, 37072) It does not matter if the authorities of the States crush us.
('53', 19, 1, 8, 37134) When a brave person like Fulchandbhai shows his courage, such orders are issued as would kill his spirit.
('53', 19, 1, 9, 37240) What sort of principle is there behind all this?
('53', 19, 1, 10, 37289) What sort of a Settlement is this?
('53', 19, 1, 11, 37324) Shall we ever be able to win swaraj in this manner?
('53', 19, 1, 12, 37376) I have summarized this long letter from memory.
('53', 19, 1, 13, 37424) The correspondent’s anger seems pardonable.
('53', 19, 1, 14, 37468) He has suffered and in the heat of excitement has made no effort to understand the position carefully.
('53', 19, 1, 15, 37571) I take the first letter first.
('53', 19, 1, 16, 37602) It is true that I gave four seemingly contradictory opinions in regard to four different sets of circumstan ces.
('53', 19, 1, 17, 37715) But really speaking they are not contradictory.
('53', 19, 1, 18, 37763) Life’s experiments are like chemical experiments.
('53', 19, 1, 19, 37813) In a chemical experiment, if the quantity of one ingredient is increased or decreased different results follow.
('53', 19, 1, 20, 37925) If even a drop of one more substance is added an altogether new compound results.
('53', 19, 1, 21, 38007) In the same way in life owing to differences in the characters of workers and local conditions, the situation changes and different opinions are given.
('53', 19, 1, 22, 38159) If this were not so, life would cease to be life and be reduced to a mechanical process.
('53', 19, 1, 23, 38248) What matters is whether the different opinions are based on the same principle.
('53', 19, 1, 24, 38328) In the cases in which the satyagrahis were subject to my control and in which my name was being used, I had to bear in mind the different situations and give opinions accordingly, and they were right.
('53', 19, 1, 25, 38529) In the fourth case the person had taken a pledge to offer satyagraha.
('53', 19, 1, 26, 38599) He did not belong to any organization.
('53', 19, 1, 27, 38638) He relied on his own strength.
('53', 19, 1, 28, 38669) The only drawback in his action was that he had been hasty in taking the pledge.
('53', 19, 1, 29, 38750) If at all, he alone would suffer because of that.
('53', 19, 1, 30, 38800) In these circumstances, how could I, when my opinion was asked, commit the sin of persuading him to violate his pledge?
('53', 19, 1, 31, 38920) How could I discourage him?
('53', 19, 1, 32, 38948) The only right I had was to examine his pledge and say whether it violated any moral principle.
('53', 19, 1, 33, 39044) I therefore expressed the view that there was no moral flaw in the pledge itself and that it was his duty to carry it out.
('53', 19, 1, 34, 39167) The principle is this: A pledge of satyagraha, which is not
('53', 20, 0, 1, 39227) VOL. 53 : 2 JULY, 1931 12 OCTOBER, 1931 21
('53', 20, 1, 2, 39270) against non violence and the consequences of carrying out which are likely to be suffered only by the person taking it, must be kept at any cost, even if that person had not thought about the consequences and had not consulted anybody and had relied on his own strength.
('53', 20, 1, 3, 39541) There have been countless such brave, unknown satyagrahis in the world.
('53', 20, 1, 4, 39613) No one builds monuments in their honour, their names are not recorded in history, nor are their actions reported in newspapers.
('53', 20, 1, 5, 39741) Their names are recorded in God’s book and we may be sure that it is because of their strength that the world endures.
('53', 20, 1, 6, 39860) Anyone who obstructs them in their work is not a wise man.
('53', 20, 1, 7, 39919) He is sunk in the pit of ignorance and, trying to be overwise, obstructs manly effort.
('53', 20, 1, 8, 40006) The principle looks admirable when thus explained, but I have to face difficult moral issues every hour in my life in trying to follow it in practice and guiding my co workers according to it.
('53', 20, 1, 9, 40199) Following the rule that where there are no other trees a castor oil plant is as good as a tree, for want of a leader with greater wisdom, I act as a judge and go on issuing orders to my co workers.
('53', 20, 1, 10, 40397) My experience is that my views have not harmed either my co workers or the public.
('53', 20, 1, 11, 40480) Both have advanced.
('53', 20, 1, 12, 40500) My co workers have often felt unhappy while following my opinions but many of them have also realized that their suffering was ultimately for their good.
('53', 20, 1, 13, 40654) The Settlement between the Congress and the Government has no connection with the Indian States.
('53', 20, 1, 14, 40751) There was no struggle in the States, and so none of the conditions of the Settlement apply to them.
('53', 20, 1, 15, 40851) Even if the Government wanted to do so, it had no right to bind them.
('53', 20, 1, 16, 40921) So, in principle, neither the Rulers nor the subjects are bound by the Settlement in any way.
('53', 20, 1, 17, 41015) It puts no check on either.
('53', 20, 1, 18, 41043) The subjects can offer satyagraha or resort to civil disobedience.
('53', 20, 1, 19, 41110) But to have such a right is one thing and to exercise it is quite another matter.
('53', 20, 1, 20, 41192) Whether in a given case satyagraha is justified and those who wish to offer it are qualified to do so can be decided only after considering the circumstances of the case.
('53', 20, 1, 21, 41363) When my co workers ask for my advice, I have to guide them, and I tell them that though they had a right to offer satyagraha, the time or the occasion was not suitable.
('53', 20, 1, 22, 41532) Generally speaking my opinion today is the same that I have expressed before.
('53', 20, 1, 23, 41610) If the subjects of Indian States are satisfied with such reform as can be secured peacefully and engage themselves in constructive work, they will get all the sooner the status which they desire.
('53', 20, 1, 24, 41806) I am convinced that when British India has won swaraj, most
('53', 21, 0, 1, 41866) 22 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('53', 21, 1, 2, 41907) problems of the Indian States will be automatically solved.
('53', 21, 1, 3, 41967) It is very sad that there are very few constructive workers in the Indian States.
('53', 21, 1, 4, 42049) I feel no hesitation at all in saying that one who has not done some constructive work has not learnt the first lesson of satyagraha.
('53', 21, 1, 5, 42183) According to me constructive work means the spinning wheel and khadi, eradication of untouchability, propaganda against the drink evil and Hindu Muslim unity.
('53', 21, 1, 6, 42342) One whose heart is not filled with the spirit of service and with love, how can he offer satyagraha?
('53', 21, 1, 7, 42443) Even in British India, the number of such workers is small.
('53', 21, 1, 8, 42503) It is smaller still in the Indian States.
('53', 21, 1, 9, 42545) That is why I feel reluctant to advise satyagraha in those States.
('53', 21, 1, 10, 42612) This article is not meant for those who do not feel bound to ask or follow my advice.
('53', 21, 1, 11, 42698) He who by his very nature is non violent, who is a born satyagrahi, who loves truth with all his being and is the very image of service, such a person deserves to be revered by the whole world.
('53', 21, 1, 12, 42892) I need not say that he does not require my advice and is qualified to offer sataygraha whenever he wishes to do so.
('53', 21, 1, 13, 43008) But to those who are full of anger and pride and whose ego is very strong, who cannot think clearly because of excitement, I will definitely say—“Please wait”.
('53', 21, 1, 14, 43168) If they take a hasty step even unintentionally, its result is bound to be bitter.
('53', 21, 1, 15, 43250) Whatever self restraint is observed now will also disappear and the future generations which will suffer from the tyranny of false satyagraha will curse us and blame satyagraha itself.
('53', 21, 1, 16, 43435) Hence every thoughtful person should know the limits of satyagraha.
('53', 21, 1, 17, 43503) Those who do not do so should stop using the name of satyagraha and then act as they wish.
('53', 21, 1, 18, 43594) The world will know where they stand.
('53', 21, 1, 19, 43632) But the things which are done in the name of satyagraha and which are unworthy of it will confuse and perplex the people and they will not know what path to follow.
('53', 21, 1, 20, 43797) Now the second letter.
('53', 21, 1, 21, 43820) Most of the answer to it is contained in what I have stated above.
('53', 21, 1, 22, 43887) The Congress has never come in the way of movements in the Indian States.
('53', 21, 1, 23, 43961) It has not stopped anyone from offering satyagraha in them.
('53', 21, 1, 24, 44021) If anyone has stopped any such movement, it is I. But in every case there was a reason for my doing so.
('53', 21, 1, 25, 44125) Those who took part in the last satyagraha movement have not obliged the Congress or any individual.
('53', 21, 1, 26, 44226) If at all, they have obliged themselves.
('53', 21, 1, 27, 44267) It was the duty of every Indian to take part in it.
('53', 21, 1, 28, 44319) Political rule has divided India into four parts, British India, Indian States, Portuguese India and French India.
('53', 21, 1, 29, 44434) But Nature has made it one.
('53', 22, 0, 1, 44462) VOL. 53 : 2 JULY, 1931 12 OCTOBER, 1931 23
('53', 22, 1, 2, 44505) rulers may distinguish between one part of the country and another but in fact we are one country.
('53', 22, 1, 3, 44604) If the most important part becomes independent, wins swaraj, the other parts will automatically become strong.
('53', 22, 1, 4, 44715) If, therefore, all of us, whether we live in the Indian States or outside, use all our strength in the British part and win swaraj, a good many reforms will come about automatically in the Indian States.
('53', 22, 1, 5, 44919) On the contrary, if we offer untimely satyagraha in the Indian States and waste people’s strength on them, swaraj will recede farther from us.
('53', 22, 2, 6, 45062) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 5 7 1931
('53', 22, 3, 7, 45098) 22. ‘DIGAMBAR’ SADHUS
('53', 22, 4, 8, 45120) I have received many letters of criticism for the views which I have expressed about nakedness.
('53', 22, 4, 9, 45216) Some of the correspondents have written in anger too.
('53', 22, 4, 10, 45270) I have also been advised to withdraw my remarks, as the feelings of Digambar Jains have been hurt.
('53', 22, 4, 11, 45369) I had written my article 1 with a purely religious motive.
('53', 22, 4, 12, 45428) Such articles should not be withdrawn even to soothe the feelings of friends.
('53', 22, 4, 13, 45506) If they are withdrawn, it will not be possible to discuss religious issues in a friendly manner.
('53', 22, 4, 14, 45603) I have stated that Sardar’s words are not law.
('53', 22, 4, 15, 45650) When we have won swaraj, everything will be done according to peoples views.
('53', 22, 4, 16, 45727) Laws which hurt religious sentiments will not be permitted.
('53', 22, 4, 17, 45787) It will, of course, be necessary to consider what is religious sentiment.
('53', 22, 4, 18, 45861) That also will be decided by the courts.
('53', 22, 4, 19, 45902) People like me can only discuss such questions and create public opinion.
('53', 22, 4, 20, 45976) I, therefore, request the Digambar Jains to discuss this subject in an objective manner and permit others also to discuss it in that manner.
('53', 22, 4, 21, 46117) I am so partial to Jainism that many people think that I am a Jain.
('53', 22, 4, 22, 46185) When, in a meeting of Jains whom I did not know, I had to explain that I was not a Jain in order to refuse an honour which I did not deserve, the Jain friends in my circle were surprised and shocked.
('53', 22, 4, 23, 46385) I have regard for the Digambar sect.
('53', 22, 4, 24, 46422) I have read some of their religious books.
('53', 22, 4, 25, 46465) As an ideal, I like the naked state.
('53', 22, 4, 26, 46502) I have deliberately let my children move about naked.
('53', 22, 4, 27, 46556) Hence everyone should take it for granted that my views on the subject have been expressed in a friendly spirit and for the protection of dharma.
('53', 22, 4, 28, 46702) I may be wrong in holding
('53', 22, 5, 29, 46728) 1 Vide “Limits ato Freedom”,31 5 1931
('53', 23, 0, 1, 46766) 24 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('53', 23, 1, 2, 46807) these views.
('53', 23, 1, 3, 46820) Those whose reason does not approve of them may, therefore, certainly reject them.
('53', 23, 1, 4, 46903) But they should not get angry with me.
('53', 23, 1, 5, 46942) Anger hinders a proper understanding of religious or other ideas and should, therefore, be eschewed.
('53', 23, 1, 6, 47043) I now come to the main issue.
('53', 23, 1, 7, 47073) The criticism 1 in the issue of Jain Mitra of Ashadh Vad 4 is inspired by a sincere motive.
('53', 23, 1, 8, 47165) It includes the substance of what others have said and so I will content myself with a reply to it.
('53', 23, 1, 9, 47265) Those who have not read that article may find it difficult to understand my answer, and I therefore request them to get that article and read it.
('53', 23, 1, 10, 47411) Digambar sadhus may be pure minded.
('53', 23, 1, 11, 47447) But I cannot accept the claim that all of them are so.
('53', 23, 1, 12, 47502) I believe that no one should claim to be a sadhu.
('53', 23, 1, 13, 47552) The fact that a person is a sadhu should be self evident to others.
('53', 23, 1, 14, 47620) A person is not a sadhu if it is necessary to prove or claim that he is one.
('53', 23, 1, 15, 47697) A true sadhu requires no protection.
('53', 23, 1, 16, 47734) Digambar sadhus should represent the highest state which a sadhu can attain.
('53', 23, 1, 17, 47811) Why should they require anyone’s help to uphold their status?
('53', 23, 1, 18, 47873) Such an ideal Digambar sadhu needs no protection from the law or from a court.
('53', 23, 1, 19, 47952) It is surprising that such natural innocence should even attract the attention of others.
('53', 23, 1, 20, 48042) But in the present age, it need not be surprising that such a person does draw the attention of others and if he has to appear in a court or is sent to jail, he should regard that as a God sent opportunity to demonstrate the greatness of the Digambar ideal.
('53', 23, 1, 21, 48300) There are real sadhus and fake ones too.
('53', 23, 1, 22, 48341) There is no limit to the number of the latter.
('53', 23, 1, 23, 48388) Who will differentiate between the two?
('53', 23, 1, 24, 48428) Should we not stop anyone moving around naked?
('53', 23, 1, 25, 48475) Will no harm result if we do not?
('53', 23, 1, 26, 48509) It is not true to say that a person with an impure mind cannot remain naked.
('53', 23, 1, 27, 48586) Once you disregard social restraints, why should an impure minded person not abandon decency?
('53', 23, 1, 28, 48680) Why should anyone feel ashamed of remaining naked even when he may be impure?
('53', 23, 1, 29, 48758) The advocates of nudity as a normal state think that there is no harm if men and women remain naked even though they may have impure thoughts.
('53', 23, 1, 30, 48901) They also hold that the attraction of sex is the normal condition for human beings and that, if nudity increases such attraction, there is nothing wrong in it.
('53', 23, 1, 31, 49061) If the sex urge is a normal condition, then its gratification should also be accepted as normal.
('53', 23, 1, 32, 49158) So there is nothing wrong in remaining naked.
('53', 23, 1, 33, 49204) That is the view of these lovers of sense pleasures, who believe in the religion of enjoyment.
('53', 23, 1, 34, 49299) Are those Digambar Jains who have regard for decency and believe in self control ready to support this view?
('53', 23, 1, 35, 49408) Are they ready to see society
('53', 23, 2, 36, 49438) 1 By Paramesthidas; vide “Notes”, p.
('53', 23, 2, 37, 49475) 24, sub title, “Nudity and Society”.
('53', 24, 0, 1, 49512) VOL. 53 : 2 JULY, 1931 12 OCTOBER, 1931 25
('53', 24, 1, 2, 49555) turned into a scene of sensuality?
('53', 24, 1, 3, 49590) Would they like to be responsible for such a state of affairs?
('53', 24, 1, 4, 49653) I am sure they feel disgusted even as they read this.
('53', 24, 1, 5, 49707) Thus, if they go deep into the matter, they will see that it is our duty in this age to observe the custom of covering the private parts.
('53', 24, 1, 6, 49845) The Digambar sadhus, therefore, should wear a codpiece for a little while out of regard for society, or, if they move naked, they should be ready to suffer for doing so and not raise an outcry about it.
('53', 24, 1, 7, 50048) If we believe in the necessity of social restraints.
('53', 24, 1, 8, 50101) irrespective of whether or not we are Jains, we cannot follow the ideal of nudity in practice.
('53', 24, 1, 9, 50196) If we try to make exceptions, we invite difficulties and therefore we should make no exception.
('53', 24, 1, 10, 50292) “Why do we let children move naked?
('53', 24, 1, 11, 50328) Does anyone force a child not to remain naked.” There is a fallacy in this comparison.
('53', 24, 1, 12, 50415) A child is by, nature innocent.
('53', 24, 1, 13, 50447) Out of crores of sadhus, hardly one attains such a state after a long discipline.
('53', 24, 1, 14, 50529) Everywhere in the world children remain naked, but even among sadhus the naked state is exceptional.
('53', 24, 1, 15, 50630) In a child, impure thoughts are impossible but all the sadhus are not free from them.
('53', 24, 1, 16, 50716) A blind person can make out a child, but even those who can see can hardly distinguish a true sadhu from a false one.
('53', 24, 1, 17, 50834) So the example of a child remaining naked does not help us in coming to a decision in this matter.
('53', 24, 1, 18, 50933) On the contrary, it shows that nakedness, which befits a child, does not only seem improper when we have grown out of childhood but is positively shameful.
('53', 24, 1, 19, 51089) For these reasons, though I worship the ideal of nakedness for a pure sadhu, I do believe that the leaders of Digambar sadhus should think more deeply on this matter and find out a way for those sadhus who move about in public to cover themselves.
('53', 24, 1, 20, 51337) By doing so, they will safeguard dharma and win greater respect for sadhus.
('53', 24, 1, 21, 51413) Even if they cannot find such a way, an outcry over the issue will certainly do harm.

('53', 29, 1, 2, 59386) 29. INTERVIEW TO THE PRESS
('53', 29, 2, 3, 59413) BOMBAY, July 7, 1931
('53', 29, 3, 4, 59434) Referring to Sir Samuel Hoare’s recent speech that the Conservatives would make the acceptance of the safeguards and the non raising of the issue of Indepen dence as conditions for their participation in the next Round Table Conference, Gandhiji said: I know nothing about this.
('53', 29, 3, 5, 59713) The Settlement leaves the Congress free to press for any claim it chooses.
('53', 29, 3, 6, 59788) The mandate given to me by the Congress is unequivocal.
('53', 29, 3, 7, 59844) The principle of safeguards is undoubtedlyaccepted.
('53', 29, 3, 8, 59896) The contents are a matter for discussion, and there also the Settlement is quite clear.
('53', 29, 3, 9, 59984) Safeguards must be demonstrably in the interests of India.
('53', 29, 4, 10, 60043) Asked about the report current that he proposed to ask the Government to agree to refer all the outstanding disputes regarding the implementing of the Truce terms to an arbitration board, Gandhiji said: 1 don’t want to make any statement on this matter at this stage.
('53', 29, 5, 11, 60311) The talk then turned on the foreign cloth re export scheme.
('53', 29, 5, 12, 60371) Gandhiji said he had no doubts whatsoever that the scheme would be a success.
('53', 29, 5, 13, 60449) The problem could be solved in no time if the merchants were favourably inclined.
('53', 29, 5, 14, 60531) It was wrong to say that the Ahmedabad millowners were not contributing their share.
('53', 29, 5, 15, 60616) There had been some delay, and he had no doubt that the Ahmedabad millowners would contribute their share.
('53', 29, 5, 16, 60723) The whole scheme was a bona fide one, and intended to give as much relief as possible to those merchants who were prepared to give up trade in foreign cloth and take to swadeshi.

('53', 30, 4, 5, 61460) 31. IS IT CRUMBLING?
('53', 30, 5, 6, 61481) Complaints are pouring in from many parts that the local officials are breaking the Delhi Pact to pieces and that it almost looks as if the Government was at war with the Congress and therefore every Congressman almost was a suspect.
('53', 30, 5, 7, 61715) From the dates I shall give of the events about to be described the reader will see that for long I suppressed publication in the hope that the cases brought to my notice were isolated instances and that the complainants would receive relief on application to their respective Provincial Governments.
('53', 30, 5, 8, 62016) My hope however was disappointed.

('53', 33, 3, 9, 68034) 32. A COUNTRYMAN’S ADVICE
('53', 33, 4, 10, 68060) Many American friends write to me on the American visit which reporters had planned for me.
('53', 33, 4, 11, 68152) Those Americans who are in close touch with me have earnestly dissuaded me from it.
('53', 33, 4, 12, 68236) Others, also friendly, have with equal earnestness asked me to go.
('53', 33, 4, 13, 68303) Now comes an extremely well reasoned appeal from a countryman residing in America 2. It deals with three matters of importance.
('53', 33, 4, 14, 68431) But I must let the letter speak for itself of which the relevant portion is given below: 3
('53', 33, 5, 15, 68522) I venture to make an humble suggestion and that is to request you to give up your idea of visiting the United States of America.
('53', 33, 6, 16, 68651) I will venture to put in a couple of reasons as to why I think your visit to the United States will serve no useful purpose where our national affairs are concerned.
('53', 33, 7, 17, 68817) This country is a very peculiar country in many respects and the Americans as a rule are so materialistically inclined, and this fact is more or less conceded by all, that they can hardly see anything in terms other than dollars and cents.
('53', 33, 8, 18, 69057) Of course this is a broad statement to make and I fully realize that there are exceptions here and there.
('53', 33, 9, 19, 69163) Your visit to this country, in my opinion, will be absolutely misunder stood and if I am not mistaken the wonderful hold that you have today on some of the imaginative Americans, will be lost in a way.
('53', 33, 9, 20, 69365) And I am further of the opinion that your visit to America instead of enlisting greater sympathy for our national cause may work quite the other way.
('53', 33, 10, 21, 69515) Hardly anyone could come to this country and travel about and give a
('53', 33, 11, 22, 69584) 1 Vide “Kisan’s Troubles in the U. P. ”, 19 6 1931 2 Vide “Letter to J. J. Singh”,24 6 1931 3 Only extracts are reproduced here.
('53', 34, 0, 1, 69713) VOL. 53 : 2 JULY, 1931 12 OCTOBER, 1931 35
('53', 34, 1, 2, 69756) few lectures here and there without having a “business manager”.
('53', 34, 1, 3, 69821) That will make your visit a business one and there will be scores of sections of people and Press who will criticize your visit and suggest that you came here to make money.
('53', 34, 2, 4, 69995) Probably you are aware of the fact that such a noble soul and true philosopher like Tagore has been openly criticized in American papers and insinuations have been made that he visits America to make money out of the Americans and yet has the cheek to criticize the so called civilization or lack of it in this country.
('53', 34, 3, 5, 70315) In other words I feel that not on account of anything that you may say or do, but on account of the mentality of an average American, you are bound to be misunderstood in this country and thus your visit is likely to prove more a failure than a success.
('53', 34, 4, 6, 70569) Therefore my conclusions are based upon the information that I have gathered from time to time from an average well to do American family, whose interest is casual in what is happening in India, and as I have said before, such Americans are in greater numbers than anti or proIndian Americans.
('53', 34, 5, 7, 70863) Your visit to London is entirely a different thing.
('53', 34, 5, 8, 70915) In my humble
('53', 34, 6, 9, 70928) opinion it will serve a great purpose, because if there is any nation on this
('53', 34, 7, 10, 71006) world who is truly sportsmanlike and will give the devil his due, it is the
('53', 34, 8, 11, 71082) English nation.
('53', 34, 9, 12, 71098) I have also a word to add regarding this much talked of question of your
('53', 34, 10, 13, 71171) attire when visiting England or America.
('53', 34, 11, 14, 71212) It will be simply ironical if you could not find some form of Indian
('53', 34, 12, 15, 71281) dress which may be quite suitable and desirable.
('53', 34, 12, 16, 71330) None of the three things worry me.
('53', 34, 12, 17, 71365) The proposal to visit America has been with me for the past five years or longer.
('53', 34, 12, 18, 71447) But I have lacked the inner urge or courage to go.
('53', 34, 12, 19, 71498) The very allurements some of the writers have held out have but confirmed the original decision based on nothing better than intuition.
('53', 34, 12, 20, 71634) The same is true of the English visit more or less.
('53', 34, 12, 21, 71686) There, too, if I am to go the way will be clear and open for me.
('53', 34, 12, 22, 71751) At the present moment the subtle and growing resistance to the Delhi Pact by the officials leaves me no room for thinking of anything else.
('53', 34, 12, 23, 71891) My contribution to the movement of India’s freedom just now consists in making every effort humanly possible to prevent the Settlement from being wrecked.
('53', 34, 12, 24, 72046) As to the dress I have had many advisers.
('53', 34, 12, 25, 72088) But here too my position is simple.
('53', 34, 12, 26, 72124) If I go to England I shall go as a representative and
('53', 35, 0, 1, 72178) 36 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('53', 35, 1, 2, 72219) nothing more, nothing less.
('53', 35, 1, 3, 72247) I must, therefore, appear not as the English would have me but as my representative character demands.
('53', 35, 1, 4, 72350) I represent the Congress because and in so far as it represents Daridranarayana, the semi starved almost naked villager.
('53', 35, 1, 5, 72471) And if I represent the landed or monied or educated Indians, I do so to the extent that they identify themselves with Daridranarayana and desire to promote his interest.
('53', 35, 1, 6, 72641) I can therefore appear neither in English costume nor in that of the polished Nehrus.
('53', 35, 1, 7, 72727) In spite of the closest bond between us it would have been just as ludicrous for me to dress as Pandit Motilalji did as it would have been for him to appear in loin cloth.
('53', 35, 1, 8, 72899) My loin cloth is an organic evolution in my life.
('53', 35, 1, 9, 72949) It came naturally, without effort, without premeditation.
('53', 35, 1, 10, 73007) My duty, as I conceive it, will then be, if I succeed in reaching London, to add nothing more to the loin cloth than the climate peremptorily demands.
('53', 35, 1, 11, 73158) I should be guilty of discourtesy to the English if I deceived them by appearing not as I am but as I may think or friends may think they would have me to be.
('53', 35, 1, 12, 73317) I should fail at the very beginning of my mission, if I commenced by deception.
('53', 35, 1, 13, 73397) It may please for the time being, it must offend in the end.
('53', 35, 1, 14, 73458) If I am to win their hearts as I want to, I can do so only by being cent per cent truthful.
('53', 35, 1, 15, 73550) Truth is like the sun.
('53', 35, 1, 16, 73573) It will melt the icy mountain of suspicion and distrust.

('53', 40, 0, 1, 80531) VOL. 53 : 2 JULY, 1931 12 OCTOBER, 1931 41
('53', 40, 1, 2, 80574) 42. CULTIVATOR’S ACCOUNT BOOK
('53', 40, 2, 3, 80604) There is no limit to the cultivators’ carelessness or ignorance.
('53', 40, 2, 4, 80669) Not only do they themselves have to suffer for their ignorance, but it results in a loss of crores of rupees as the cultivators constitute more than 80% of India’s population.
('53', 40, 2, 5, 80845) The most serious aspect of their carelessness is perhaps their indifference to keeping accounts.
('53', 40, 2, 6, 80942) If a merchant kept no books of account, he would soon become bankrupt.
('53', 40, 2, 7, 81013) A house holder would become poor if he went on spending without keeping an account of his expenditure.
('53', 40, 2, 8, 81116) Even Lord Kubera’s 1 treasure would soon be exhausted if he went on spending from it without keeping an account.
('53', 40, 2, 9, 81229) How, then, can the cultivator escape?
('53', 40, 2, 10, 81267) But it is a fact universally known that the Indian cultivator carries his account in his memory and never enters it in a book.
('53', 40, 2, 11, 81394) As a result, he is always in debt, and, though no one has been able to gather the full statistics, it is estimated that his debt runs into crores or hundreds of crores of rupees.
('53', 40, 2, 12, 81573) This means that the cultivator has been carrying on his occupation at a loss.
('53', 40, 2, 13, 81651) To remedy this deficiency, a proforma book of accounts has been advised by the Vidyapith and made available.
('53', 40, 2, 14, 81760) The book is based on the experiences of Mahadev and Narahari during the Bardoli Satyagraha.
('53', 40, 2, 15, 81852) The type of information which they often required at that time can be gathered from this book whenever one wants it.
('53', 40, 2, 16, 81969) The book has been so designed that the farmer also should be able to know his position from day to day.
('53', 40, 2, 17, 82073) This book is not intended for free distribution.
('53', 40, 2, 18, 82122) Only a cultivator who wishes to keep accounts should buy it.
('53', 40, 2, 19, 82183) It will be sold at cost price, and volunteers trained for the purpose will explain how to use it to persons who may not know how to keep accounts.
('53', 40, 2, 20, 82330) As for those cultivators who do not know how to read or write, wherever possible a volunteer will write their accounts for them.
('53', 40, 2, 21, 82459) I would advise every cultivator to acquire enough knowledge of Gujarati language to be able to keep his accounts.
('53', 40, 2, 22, 82573) The volunteer will help him in that too.
('53', 40, 2, 23, 82614) Though a cultivator may not just now be able to realize the benefit of keeping accounts in this manner, he will discover at the end of the
('53', 40, 3, 24, 82753) 1 God of wealth
('53', 41, 0, 1, 82769) 42 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('53', 41, 1, 2, 82810) year how much money he has saved with a little labour and an expense of two annas.

('53', 43, 1, 2, 85564) 47. LETTER TO MIRABEHN
('53', 43, 2, 3, 85587) [July 13, 1931] 1
('53', 43, 3, 4, 85605) MIRA, As ever, in Bombay I get no time for correspondence, The thing commenced this time also at 4.30 a.m.
('53', 43, 3, 5, 85712) and went on till 11 p.m.
('53', 43, 3, 6, 85737) I never retired before then—nevertheless the health remained quite good.
('53', 43, 3, 7, 85810) Today we reached Surat early morning.
('53', 43, 3, 8, 85848) I had over an hour’s sleep and feel rested.
('53', 43, 3, 9, 85892) I have been left alone.
('53', 43, 3, 10, 85916) The weather is cool.
('53', 43, 3, 11, 85937) The sky overcast.
('53', 43, 3, 12, 85955) Fresh breeze blowing all the time.
('53', 43, 3, 13, 85990) Of course it was the same in Bombay.
('53', 43, 3, 14, 86027) I wonder how it is faring with you and how Father Elwin is standing the Ashram life and climate.
('53', 43, 3, 15, 86124) We are off to Simla tonight.
('53', 43, 3, 16, 86153) Ba goes with me.
('53', 43, 3, 17, 86170) I don’t expect to have to give more than three days to Simla.
('53', 43, 3, 18, 86232) I should know there definitely whether we are to go to London or not.
('53', 43, 3, 19, 86302) Here comes Mahadev to give me news about you all and interrupt this letter.
('53', 43, 3, 20, 86378) So Mother is gone.
('53', 43, 3, 21, 86397) I read your suppressed grief in every line of your letter.
('53', 43, 3, 22, 86456) After all we are very human.
('53', 43, 3, 23, 86485) The ability to suppress is the preliminary to eradication.
('53', 43, 3, 24, 86544) God give you the strength.
('53', 43, 3, 25, 86571) So far as Mother herself was concerned, it is as you say welcome news.
('53', 43, 3, 26, 86642) Let this death of one whom you loved so, be a means of enriching your faith in the future and in the oneness of all life.
('53', 43, 3, 27, 86764) If this oneness was not a fact, we would not have been blessed with the capacity to forget the death of dearest ones.
('53', 43, 3, 28, 86882) Let this death also spur you to greater dedication to service.
('53', 43, 3, 29, 86945) I wonder if you get the dates you wanted.
('53', 43, 3, 30, 86987) But let them not grow on you.
('53', 43, 3, 31, 87017) I find that raisins are not a bad change.

('53', 46, 5, 20, 90716) As I am writing in the moving train I cannot write in ink.

('53', 46, 5, 24, 91030) If living outside the Ashram makes workers lazy and self indulgent, the vow will be kept by returning to the Ashram.
('53', 46, 5, 25, 91147) One ought not to return to the Ashram for selfish reasons.

('53', 46, 5, 27, 91296) I would like it if Chandra stays without you in the Ashram.

('53', 46, 5, 29, 91413) But you should not keep him with you if his presence hinders you in your work.
('53', 46, 5, 30, 91492) Do you now understand what I mean?
('53', 46, 5, 31, 91527) If you don’t, write again and ask me.

('53', 47, 6, 18, 92631) 55. INTERVIEW TO THE PRESS
('53', 47, 7, 19, 92658) [Before July 15, 1931] 1
('53', 47, 8, 20, 92683) I cannot say even now if I am going to England.
('53', 47, 8, 21, 92731) I should know it in Simla.
('53', 47, 9, 22, 92758) Mahatmaji said that he had not booked his passage for London so far.
('53', 47, 9, 23, 92827) It was true that someone else had booked for him but he had sent a letter to the P. & O. Company asking that the same be cancelled.
('53', 47, 9, 24, 92959) The Company had informed him that in case booking was delayed, space in the s.s.
('53', 47, 9, 25, 93040) Mooltan, may become overcrowded.
('53', 47, 9, 26, 93073) Mahatmaji had, however, said that he would take his chance.
('53', 47, 10, 27, 93133) The correspondent then showed Gandhiji a copy of The Statesman in which the special representative of that paper had expressed the view that Mahatma Gandhi had asked the Government to increase the Congress delegation to the Round Table Conference and was insisting on having some members of the Nationalist Muslim group included in that delegation.
('53', 47, 11, 28, 93482) 1 From the reference in the first paragraph to Simla which Gandhiji reached on the 15th
('53', 48, 0, 1, 93570) VOL. 53 : 2 JULY, 1931 12 OCTOBER, 1931 49
('53', 48, 1, 2, 93613) Mahatma Gandhi said that the report in question was a tissue of falsehoods.
('53', 48, 1, 3, 93689) He said: It does not injure my reputation, but my heart is injured to find that responsible journalists utter such palpable falsehoods.
('53', 48, 2, 4, 93825) Gandhiji further said that there are persons who are determined to wreck the Truce and were carrying on such propaganda but he did not mind this, as it did not hurt him.
('53', 48, 2, 5, 93995) He said smilingly: In fact I flourish on this propaganda.
('53', 48, 2, 6, 94053) This news is absurd and I know how these lies are manufactured.
('53', 48, 2, 7, 94117) These things, however, diminish the estimation in which journalism should be held.
('53', 48, 2, 8, 94200) If my intention were to ask the Viceroy for additional nominations, I would have proclaimed this from the housetops.
('53', 48, 3, 9, 94317) He said he was very sorry that English journalists were not playing the game, and were indulging in a vicious type of propaganda.
('53', 48, 4, 10, 94447) Asked if he will be taking some advisers, Mahatmaji said: My adviser is God.
('53', 48, 4, 11, 94524) I am going to take no advisers.
('53', 48, 4, 12, 94556) If I had any idea to take advisers, I would have taken them as dele gates.
('53', 48, 5, 13, 94631) Mahatmaji said the position with regard to Congress representation at the Round Table Conference was exactly the same as at Karachi, and Mahatmaji thought it was a most proper decision.
('53', 48, 5, 14, 94817) In conclusion, he said: I would take with me my son Devdas Gandhi, Mahadev Desai, Pyarelal, Miss Slade and none else.

('53', 49, 6, 7, 96124) 57. NOTES
('53', 49, 7, 8, 96134) LIQUOR DEALERS BEWARE
('53', 49, 8, 9, 96156) Auctions for liquor licences are now in season.
('53', 49, 8, 10, 96204) In the face of what I have already published it is too much to expect local authorities to stop auctions or restrict them.
('53', 49, 8, 11, 96327) But is it too much to expect liqour dealers to foresee the future?
('53', 49, 8, 12, 96394) They ought to know that prohibition of liquor and foreign cloth is the permanent policy of the nation?
('53', 49, 8, 13, 96497) The one is a moral necessity, the other is an economic necessity.
('53', 49, 8, 14, 96563) Both produce political results.
('53', 49, 8, 15, 96595) But they are a by product.
('53', 49, 8, 16, 96622) Picketing no doubt of the most peaceful character will continue without remission till the State is converted to the policy of prohibition.
('53', 49, 8, 17, 96762) It is an effective method of education.
('53', 49, 9, 18, 96802) SALT CONCESSION
('53', 49, 10, 19, 96818) I hear that in Mirpur and Kalabagh in the salt range the people having abused the salt concession under the Delhi Pact, it has been withdrawn by the Government.
('53', 49, 10, 20, 96979) The people are reported to have carried maunds of salt on camel back.
('53', 49, 10, 21, 97049) If such was the case, it was a distinct breach of the Settlement.
('53', 49, 10, 22, 97115) Whether the action taken by the Government is not too drastic for the breach, it is difficult to judge without a fuller knowledge of facts.

('53', 55, 2, 8, 109849) CONGRESS SCHEME
('53', 55, 3, 9, 109865) However much it may have failed in the realisation, the Congress has, from its very inception, set up pure nationalism as its ideal.
('53', 55, 3, 10, 109998) It has endeavoured to break down communal barriers.
('53', 55, 3, 11, 110050) The following Lahore resolution1 was the culminating point in its advance towards nationalism:
('53', 55, 4, 12, 110145) Hence the Congress is precluded from setting forth any communal solution of the communal problem.
('53', 55, 4, 13, 110243) But at this critical juncture in the history of the nation, it is felt that the Working Committee should suggest for adoption by the country a solution though communal in appearance, yet as nearly national as possible and generally acceptable to the communities concerned.
('53', 55, 4, 14, 110516) The Working Committee therefore after full and free discussion unanimously passed the following scheme:
('53', 55, 5, 15, 110620) I (a) The article in the constitution relating to Fundamental Rights
('53', 55, 6, 16, 110689) shall include a guarantee to the communities concerned of the protection of
('53', 55, 7, 17, 110765) their cultures, languages, scripts, education, profession and practice of
('53', 55, 8, 18, 110839) religion, and religious endowments.
('53', 55, 9, 19, 110875) (b) Personal Laws shall be protected by specific provisions to be
('53', 55, 10, 20, 110941) embodied in the constitutions.
('53', 55, 11, 21, 110972) (c) Protection of political and other rights of minority
('53', 55, 12, 22, 111029) communities in the various provinces shall be the concern and be within the
('53', 55, 13, 23, 111105) jurisdiction of the Federal Government.
('53', 55, 14, 24, 111145) 2. The franchise shall be extended to all adult men and women.
('53', 55, 15, 25, 111208) The Working Committee is committed to adult franchise by the Karachi resolution of the Congress2 and cannot entertain any alter native
('53', 55, 16, 26, 111343) 1 Not reproduced here.
('53', 55, 16, 27, 111366) Vide “Speech at Subjects Committee, A. I. C. C. III”, 1 1 1930 2 Held in March 1931.
('53', 56, 0, 1, 111451) VOL. 53 : 2 JULY, 1931 12 OCTOBER, 1931 57
('53', 56, 1, 2, 111494) franchise.
('53', 56, 1, 3, 111505) In view, however, of misapprehensions in some quarters the Committee wishes to make it clear that in any event the franchise shall be uniform and so extensive as to reflect in the electoral roll the proportion in the population of every community).
('53', 56, 2, 4, 111754) 3. (a) Joint electorates shall form the basis of representation in the future constitution of India.
('53', 56, 3, 5, 111855) (b) That for the Hindus in Sind, the Muslims in Assam and the Sikhs in the Punjab and N.W.F.P., and for Hindus and Muslims in any province where they are less than 25% of the population, seats shall be reserved in the Federal and Provincial Legislatures on the basis of population with the right to contest additional seats.
('53', 56, 4, 6, 112180) 4. Appointments shall be made by non party Public Service Commissions which shall prescribe the minimum qualification, and which shall have due regard to the efficiency of the Public Service as well as to the principle of equal opportunity to all communities for a fair share in the public services of the country.
('53', 56, 5, 7, 112495) 5. In the formation of Federal and Provincial Cabinets interests of minority communities should be recognized by convention.
('53', 56, 6, 8, 112620) 6. The N.W.F. Province and Baluchistan shall have the same form of government and administration as other provinces.
('53', 56, 7, 9, 112737) 7. Sind shall be constituted into a separate province provided that the people of Sind are prepared to bear the financial burden of the separated province.
('53', 56, 8, 10, 112893) 8. The future constitution of the country shall be federal.
('53', 56, 8, 11, 112953) The residuary powers shall vest in the federating units, unless, on further examination, it is found to be against the best interests of India.
('53', 56, 8, 12, 113097) The Working Committee has adopted the foregoing scheme as a compromise between the proposals based on undiluted communalism and undiluted nationalism.
('53', 56, 8, 13, 113248) Whilst on the one hand the Working Committee hopes that the whole nation will endorse the scheme, on the other, it assures those who take extreme views and cannot adopt it that the Committee will gladly, as it is bound to by the Lahore resolution, accept without reservation any other scheme if it commands the acceptance of all the parties concerned.
('53', 56, 9, 14, 113600) Young India, 16 7 1931
('53', 57, 0, 1, 113623) 58 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('53', 57, 9, 13, 114945) 62. SOME POSERS
('53', 57, 10, 14, 114961) Here are some posers for lovers of khaddar:
('53', 57, 11, 15, 115005) Will you kindly explain to me how the resolution passed at Karachi Congress in connection with khadi propaganda is going to help that object?
('53', 57, 11, 16, 115147) The indigenous mill owners have been appealed to give their moral support to the supplementary village industry of hand spinning by themselves using hand spun.
('53', 57, 11, 17, 115307) Now if the mill owners enjoy the unrestricted privilege of carrying on their present mills with a view to develop them, will the mere use of hand spun be construed into moral support to khaddar?
('53', 57, 11, 18, 115502) In my humble opinion there is no moral support unless mill owners discover the antagonism between mill and charkha and honestly try graduallyto restrict their activity.
('53', 57, 11, 19, 115671) Then it passes one’s comprehension how khaddar can hold its own if mills go on
('53', 58, 0, 1, 115750) VOL. 53 : 2 JULY, 1931 12 OCTOBER, 1931 59
('53', 58, 1, 2, 115793) producing finer and cheaper stuff to be used in place of khaddar.
('53', 58, 1, 3, 115859) Then again, asking the mill owners to keep down the prices of cloths will be a sure means of killing khaddar.
('53', 58, 1, 4, 115969) These are all good questions.
('53', 58, 1, 5, 115999) There is no doubt that if the personal use by mill owners of khaddar is not a token of their inner conviction it is of no use and may well be a token of hypocrisy.
('53', 58, 1, 6, 116163) If there is inner conviction they will conduct their mills so as never to harm khaddar even as a gardener so disposes his hardy plants as not to harm saplings.
('53', 58, 1, 7, 116323) The Congress toleration of mills is based on the belief that the mills can serve a useful purpose during the transition stage.
('53', 58, 1, 8, 116450) Immediate exclusion of foreign cloth becomes easier through the indigenous mills if they work in sympathy with the movement.
('53', 58, 1, 9, 116575) It is easier for khaddar to deal and compete with the indigenous mills alone than to do so with them plus English, Japanese, Italian and other mills.
('53', 58, 1, 10, 116725) The increase in the number of indigenous mills need not frighten khaddarites.
('53', 58, 1, 11, 116803) The increase is no doubt proof that the econo mic influence of khaddar is not yet fully felt.
('53', 58, 1, 12, 116897) When khaddar becomes universal, many mills may find their occupation gone.
('53', 58, 1, 13, 116972) It is needless to speculate whether khaddar will obtain such a hold on the people.
('53', 58, 1, 14, 117055) It will depend upon the faithfulness of the workers.
('53', 58, 1, 15, 117108) There is no flaw in the reasoning applied to khaddar.
('53', 58, 1, 16, 117162) It is merely a question of giving a true education to the millions of villagers, of changing national taste, of realizing the tremendous power of the wheel to banish pauperism from the land.
('53', 58, 1, 17, 117353) It is no small thing to be able to show a way the adop tion of which will be an insurance against starvation and its attendant results.
('53', 58, 1, 18, 117489) As to the second poser, the necessity of the mills producing finer cloths cannot be questioned.
('53', 58, 1, 19, 117585) In the khaddar age the people had fine khaddar.
('53', 58, 1, 20, 117633) It is produced even now but not in such quantity, not so cheap as to be available to all who desire it.
('53', 58, 1, 21, 117737) Again therefore during the transition stage the mills may be encouraged to manufacture fine cloths.
('53', 58, 1, 22, 117837) And it is easy enough to see that restriction of mill production to finer counts is wholly beneficial to khaddar.
('53', 58, 1, 23, 117951) The pity of it is that the mills do not respond sufficiently to the national demand.
('53', 58, 1, 24, 118036) Lastly as to the prices.
('53', 58, 1, 25, 118061) Surely the writer does not suggest that mills should charge high prices in order to let khaddar live.
('53', 58, 1, 26, 118163) As the author of the revival of khaddar I must confess that it never entered my head that I should wish for high prices of mill manufactures for the protection of khaddar.
('53', 58, 1, 27, 118335) It is one thing to seek protection against
('53', 59, 0, 1, 118378) 60 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('53', 59, 1, 2, 118419) killing competition, wholly another to wish for higher prices of commodities produced by a few for many even for the protection of an analogous industry.
('53', 59, 1, 3, 118573) Khaddar economics is wholly different from the ordinary.
('53', 59, 1, 4, 118630) The latter takes no note of the human factor.
('53', 59, 1, 5, 118676) The former wholly concerns itself with the human.
('53', 59, 1, 6, 118726) The latter is frankly selfish, the former necessarily unselfish.
('53', 59, 1, 7, 118791) Competition and therefore prices are eliminated from the conception of khaddar.
('53', 59, 1, 8, 118871) There is no competition between hotels and domestic kitchens.
('53', 59, 1, 9, 118933) It never enters into the head of the queen of the house to calculate the cost of her labour, the floor space, etc.
('53', 59, 1, 10, 119048) She simply knows that to conduct the domestic kitchen is as much her duty as it is to bring up children.
('53', 59, 1, 11, 119153) If she were to count the cost, the logic of facts will irresistibly drive her to the destruction of her kitchen as well as her children.
('53', 59, 1, 12, 119290) Some have done both.
('53', 59, 1, 13, 119311) But thank God the cult makes no promise of appreciable increase.
('53', 59, 1, 14, 119376) It is our innate laziness which prevents us from seeing that we sinned against Indian humanity when we destroyed the domestic wheel.

('53', 62, 3, 6, 124159) In both the cases it was all about the Delhi Pact.

('53', 62, 4, 8, 124367) Asked as regards the spirit of the talk at Ava Lodge 2 as compared with that at Mr. Emerson’s residence, Mahatma Gandhi replied: Just some variations with the variations of the weather.
