('53', 64, 1, 2, 126679) 70. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('53', 64, 2, 3, 126706) July 18, 1931 My attention has been drawn to a leaderette in The Times of India dated the 15th instant, in which Mr. S. W. Powell, writing in The Daily Telegraph (London) of 13th June is reported to have said that “Gandhi himself was not quite the ascetic he is now, for when I met the pair (Mr. Gandhi and his partner a Hindu) in Durban afterwards, we had at least two whiskies in the nearest bar”.
('53', 64, 2, 4, 127106) I am sorry The Times of India, in view of the many misrepresentations current about me, has printed what is a palpable falsehood without referring the quotation to me for verification.
('53', 64, 2, 5, 127291) I remember Mr. Powell, as a member of the European Ambulance Corps and I regret to have to say about his statement that it contains a double falsehood.
('53', 64, 2, 6, 127443) My companion was not a Hindu but Mussalman.
('53', 64, 2, 7, 127487) I never entered any bar in South Africa, and I have never entered any bar anywhere throughout my life.
('53', 64, 2, 8, 127590) What is more, Indians are not allowed to enter European bars in Natal and a European would consider it beneath his dignity to enter an Indian bar no matter how thirsty he might feel.
('53', 64, 2, 9, 127773) The Hindu, 18 7 1931

('53', 65, 13, 19, 129758) 73. ATTACK ON AN ANT
('53', 65, 14, 20, 129779) The following complaint 1 received from Bombay deserves attention: I do not share the correspondent’s hope that my advice will be followed.
('53', 65, 14, 21, 129919) If my advice was universally followed, all of us, grown up or young, women or men, the rich or the poor, would be spinning and wearing khadi, there would be no distinctions of high and low, and no
('53', 65, 15, 22, 130116) 1 Not translated here
('53', 66, 0, 1, 130138) VOL. 53 : 2 JULY, 1931 12 OCTOBER, 1931 67
('53', 66, 1, 2, 130181) untouchables; Hindus, Muslims, Sikhs and others would be living as blood brothers and employers and workers as fathers and sons or as elder brothers and younger brothers.
('53', 66, 1, 3, 130352) In brief we would be enjoying complete swaraj by now.
('53', 66, 1, 4, 130406) But I know that neither my voice nor my pen can reach very far.
('53', 66, 1, 5, 130470) In spite of this fact, as I have been trying to follow the teaching of the Gita in life, I strive to remain free from attachment and, whenever circumstances require that I should write, I do write or speak.
('53', 66, 1, 6, 130677) The complaint quoted above provides such an occasion.
('53', 66, 1, 7, 130731) There is nothing uncommon in the complainant’s experience.
('53', 66, 1, 8, 130790) Which of us living in big cities has had no such experience at some or other time?
('53', 66, 1, 9, 130873) Being weak men ourselves, we fall upon a pickpocket like an army attacking an ant.
('53', 66, 1, 10, 130956) This is not a question of non violence at all.
('53', 66, 1, 11, 131003) A brave man, however violent his inclinations, would not beat up anyone in this manner.
('53', 66, 1, 12, 131091) The ordinary citizens have no right to punish a thief or murderer caught red handed.
('53', 66, 1, 13, 131176) Not even the police has that right.
('53', 66, 1, 14, 131212) It belongs to the judge alone.
('53', 66, 1, 15, 131243) The public may arrest such a culprit and, if they do, they should make him over to the police.
('53', 66, 1, 16, 131338) To beat up any person in this manner is a crime and, if the pickpocket lodges a complaint, it would be the duty of the police to arrest those who beat him and, if the complaint is found true by the judge, it would be his duty to punish the culprits.
('53', 66, 1, 17, 131588) Moreover, if the pickpocket was beaten as described by the correspondent, the offence was one of causing grievous hurt so that the culprit would get sentence of imprisonment.
('53', 66, 1, 18, 131763) However, everyone beating up a thief believes himself safe as it has become customary to do that.
('53', 66, 1, 19, 131861) Who would listen to the appeals of the thief?
('53', 66, 1, 20, 131907) It is true that most of those who beat up a thief are themselves white thugs.
('53', 66, 1, 21, 131985) That is why when in old times some people started stoning a prostitute, Jesus said gently: “He that is pure among you, let him cast the first stone.” The narrator says that none had the courage to cast a stone at her.
('53', 66, 1, 22, 132203) How can a sieve [with a hundred holes] laugh at the jug [with only one]?
('53', 66, 1, 23, 132276) That pickpocket was perhaps starving without a loaf to eat, but the white thug steals to gratify the cravings of the flesh.
('53', 66, 1, 24, 132400) The idea of non violence came into being as an extension of the thought that a sinner had no right to sit in judgment over another.
('53', 66, 1, 25, 132532) It does not matter if we cannot reach the waters of the lake of non violence; it is enough for us to touch the shore of common justice.
('53', 66, 2, 26, 132668) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 19 7 1931
('53', 67, 0, 1, 132705) 68 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('53', 67, 1, 2, 132746) 74. MORVI’S LESSON TO SATYAGRAHIS
('53', 67, 2, 3, 132780) The Morvi Satyagraha is over and it is a matter of joy for all and of credit for both the State and the satyagrahis that all the satyagrahis have left the State.
('53', 67, 2, 4, 132942) Both displayed moderation, the State in uncon ditionally releasing the satyagrahis and the satyagrahis in not persis ting in satyagraha and leaving the State territory.
('53', 67, 2, 5, 133111) When things have ended happily in this manner, it would be improper to enter into the rights and wrongs of the matter or rake up the past.
('53', 67, 2, 6, 133250) But I should like to say this: There was some haste in under taking the satyagraha.
('53', 67, 2, 7, 133334) The improper criticism of the Morvi ruler after the satyagraha had started has brought discredit on us and the fair name of satyagraha has been tarnished.
('53', 67, 2, 8, 133489) The unworthy criticism and the exaggeration which were indulged in afterwards to justify the satyagraha were a cause for shame for the satyagrahis.
('53', 67, 2, 9, 133637) They cannot disown responsibility for them on the ground that all this was done by others.
('53', 67, 2, 10, 133728) When non satyagrahis thus run to the help of satyagrahis, sometimes it becomes necessary to stop the satyagraha.
('53', 67, 2, 11, 133841) When a large number of non satyagrahis join a hand of satyagrahis, the latter should leave the crowd.
('53', 67, 2, 12, 133943) We may have occasions to act thus in our movement too.
('53', 67, 2, 13, 133998) Whether and when such an occasion may be said to have arisen should be determined by examining each case on its merits.
('53', 67, 2, 14, 134118) I did feel that such a stage had been reached in this case, but fortunately the satyagraha ended before it became necessary to take such a decision.
('53', 67, 2, 15, 134267) I would now advise the satyagrahis to make amends by publicly acknowledging the errors which may have been made.
('53', 67, 2, 16, 134380) The confession of an error constitutes sincere atonement for it, and by such confession the satyagrahi increases his strength.
('53', 67, 2, 17, 134507) Satyagraha means purity.
('53', 67, 2, 18, 134532) The higher the degree of purity, the greater the satyagrahi’s strength.
('53', 67, 2, 19, 134604) I have offered my compliments to the Maharaja Saheb, for he readily consented to release the satyagrahis.
('53', 67, 2, 20, 134710) However, I must say that his offi cials have not been altogether above reproach.
('53', 67, 2, 21, 134791) The police constables failed to observe moderation.
('53', 67, 2, 22, 134843) Though there was exaggeration in the accounts of man handling and use of force, there was also an element of truth in them.
('53', 67, 2, 23, 134967) All this was not quite unavoidable.
('53', 67, 2, 24, 135003) I know that the police are never a body of pure men.
('53', 67, 2, 25, 135056) They regard the use of force as a religious duty.
('53', 67, 2, 26, 135106) They believe that a
('53', 68, 0, 1, 135126) VOL. 53 : 2 JULY, 1931 12 OCTOBER, 1931 69
('53', 68, 1, 2, 135169) criminal will understand only the language of force and that all who fall into their hands are criminals.
('53', 68, 1, 3, 135275) It simply passes their understanding that in this age large numbers of innocent men willingly and knowingly put themselves in their hands.
('53', 68, 1, 4, 135414) Hence, in their view at any rate, all such persons deserve nothing but the lathi and abuse.
('53', 68, 1, 5, 135506) This being the state of things, if those in authority wish to act with justice, they should warn the police to behave them selves.
('53', 68, 1, 6, 135637) I think I should stop here.
('53', 68, 1, 7, 135665) For, in Tulsidas’s immortal words:
('53', 68, 2, 8, 135700) God’s whole creation, living and non living, contains both good and evil.
('53', 68, 2, 9, 135774) The wise accept the good and leave the evil, (like the swan) which drinks the milk and leaves water behind.
('53', 68, 2, 10, 135882) Let us pay attention only to the goodness displayed by the Ruler and the satyagrahis and bring about harmony between them.
('53', 68, 2, 11, 136005) A word of personal advice to the Saurashtra satyagrahis.
('53', 68, 2, 12, 136062) You are only a handful, but you have raised high hopes in me.
('53', 68, 2, 13, 136124) Any error on your part, though as tiny as a speck of dust, must appear in my eyes as big as a pikestaff.
('53', 68, 2, 14, 136229) Only then can we work together.
('53', 68, 2, 15, 136261) You should not entertain even the thought of satyagraha as long as you have in you any trace of passion, ill will, violence or untruth.
('53', 68, 2, 16, 136397) Your first duty is to train yourselves and become fit for satyagraha.
('53', 68, 2, 17, 136467) You should not assume that it is your duty to attack immorality or injustice wherever you find them in Kathiawar.
('53', 68, 2, 18, 136581) Instead, silently go on doing constructive work and make yourselves fit for satyagraha.
('53', 68, 2, 19, 136669) Do not launch an invasion.
('53', 68, 2, 20, 136696) When you are attacked, by all means welcome the opportunity for a fight.
('53', 68, 3, 21, 136769) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 19 7 1931
('53', 68, 4, 22, 136806) 75. A SATYAGRAHI’S COMPLAINT
('53', 68, 5, 23, 136835) Shri Virchand of Vanod writes: 1
('53', 68, 6, 24, 136868) I am inviting fresh trouble on myself by publishing this letter, but there is no escape.
('53', 68, 6, 25, 136957) Though the letter concerns only an individual, the issues raised in it are of public importance, and I have been asked to give my opinion on them; I think it is my duty to give it.
('53', 68, 7, 26, 137138) 1 The letter is not translated here.
('53', 68, 7, 27, 137175) It narrated at length how the Durbar (Chief) of Vanod persecuted the correspondent and his relations for their nationalist acti vities.
('53', 69, 0, 1, 137311) 70 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('53', 69, 1, 2, 137352) satyagrahi is patient enough, he will be faced with no case of injustice in which he would be completely helpless.
('53', 69, 1, 3, 137467) One should, however, bear in mind that, if the person who is the victim of injustice has no strength in himself, there is no means of helping him.
('53', 69, 1, 4, 137614) This is a limitation inherent in the nature of satyagraha.
('53', 69, 1, 5, 137673) Satyagraha aims at providing an object lesson to victims of oppression so that they may be roused to struggle and deliver themselves from the oppression.
('53', 69, 1, 6, 137827) The satyagrahi has to keep patience till the victim is so roused.
('53', 69, 1, 7, 137893) If this is a limitation of satyagraha, it is also its special excellence.
('53', 69, 1, 8, 137967) A satyagrahi presumes to be nobody’s guardian.
('53', 69, 1, 9, 138014) He suffers with the victim of oppression and thereby becomes his equal and shares his suffering.
('53', 69, 1, 10, 138111) Now let us turn to the issues raised.
('53', 69, 1, 11, 138149) 1. If the subjects of an Indian State are not ready to co operate in carrying out the constructive programme of the Congress in that State, no one from outside going there can carry it out successfully in the present circumstances.
('53', 69, 1, 12, 138381) It would not be right for anyone to argue that in that case the subjects of Indian States would never be roused.
('53', 69, 1, 13, 138494) It is a law of life that some good work being done at any point in an environment is bound to have its effect on the rest of it.
('53', 69, 1, 14, 138623) It was after this experience that the sages of the world gave it the dictum: “As in oneself, so in the universe.” If outsiders go and try to wake up asuppressed people, the latter are likely to fall into deeper slumber.
('53', 69, 1, 15, 138843) Moreover, one should bear in mind that the subjects of every Indian State frequently go to neutral territory, that is, British India, and imbibe from there the new ideals according to their capacity.
('53', 69, 1, 16, 139043) 2. The subjects of Indian States who go to British territory and join the swaraj yajna being carried on there run the risk of banish ment from their own State and also of having to suffer separation from their parents.
('53', 69, 1, 17, 139262) Further, if the parents have sympathy for their son’s activities, they also should be ready to suffer banishment and lose their goods and property.
('53', 69, 1, 18, 139410) As the poet says, the path of love is enveloped in flames of fire.
('53', 69, 1, 19, 139477) Those who are not ready to be burnt to death in them should not tread that path.
('53', 69, 1, 20, 139558) Those parents who are not ready to be banished from the land of their birth and lose their property ought to be ready to disown their satyagrahi son.
('53', 69, 1, 21, 139708) Everyone should have the faith that any goods and property that will have remained safe when we win swaraj will return to the possession of the original owner or his heirs.
('53', 69, 1, 22, 139881) Durbar Gopaldas is certain that Dhasa will be returned to him when swaraj comes, and he has meanwhile chosen
('53', 70, 0, 1, 139990) VOL. 53 : 2 JULY, 1931 12 OCTOBER, 1931 71
('53', 70, 1, 2, 140033) not to be the Durbar of a handful of men so that he might be the servant of millions, in other words, to be a true Durbar.
('53', 70, 1, 3, 140156) A true satyagrahi renounces a little only to get something far greater.
('53', 70, 1, 4, 140228) 3. What should we do when the authorities in an Indian State challenge us to a fight?
('53', 70, 1, 5, 140314) This question does not at all arise where the restrictions laid down above are observed.
('53', 70, 1, 6, 140403) If, however, such a contin gency does arise, one should submit to the hardship as inevitable.
('53', 70, 1, 7, 140497) 4. Cannot the British Agency intervene in case of oppression by an Indian State?
('53', 70, 1, 8, 140578) It certainly can.
('53', 70, 1, 9, 140596) In my view, it ought to.
('53', 70, 1, 10, 140621) That is to say, if the Agency functions as a real agency, it can certainly do much.
('53', 70, 1, 11, 140705) Hence, the subjects of an Indian State have the right to approach it for redress of grievances, and it is desirable that they should.
('53', 70, 1, 12, 140839) That will test the Agency’s worth.
('53', 70, 1, 13, 140874) 5. While, in British territory, the Congress stands up in defence of a petty watchman, is it to do nothing at all no matter how wilfully authority is exercised in an Indian State?
('53', 70, 1, 14, 141054) Yes, the position is somewhat like that.
('53', 70, 1, 15, 141095) Everyone has first to take the measure of his own strength.
('53', 70, 1, 16, 141155) He who speaks without the strength to follow up his words with action merely prattles.
('53', 70, 1, 17, 141242) The Congress may indeed be eager to do a number of things, but where it lacks the necessary strength for action it chooses to keep quiet.
('53', 70, 1, 18, 141380) And by doing that, it sometimes becomes stronger.
('53', 70, 1, 19, 141430) It is improbable that the Provincial [Congress] Committee should have given no reply.
('53', 70, 1, 20, 141516) If it has deliberately acted in that manner, I must admit that it should be considered to have been guilty of discourtesy.
('53', 70, 1, 21, 141639) I must admit that it must have had compelling reasons for that.
('53', 70, 1, 22, 141703) Now about Vanod in particular.
('53', 70, 1, 23, 141734) I have no information regarding any of the allegations made by Shri Virchand.
('53', 70, 1, 24, 141812) I do not know what the Vanod Durbar has to say about them.
('53', 70, 1, 25, 141871) It would indeed be painful if the allegations are true.
('53', 70, 1, 26, 141927) If the Vanod Durbar sends a reply to the allegations, I will certainly publish it.
('53', 70, 1, 27, 142010) I shall be glad if the reply is satisfactory.
('53', 70, 1, 28, 142056) It will do honour to the Durbar to acknowledge any mistake that may have been made by him or his men.
('53', 70, 1, 29, 142158) Every man is liable to err.
('53', 70, 1, 30, 142186) Princes are no exception to this rule.
('53', 70, 1, 31, 142225) I have already stated my opinion as to what Shri Virchand, his parents and the State subjects should do if his complaint is true.
('53', 70, 1, 32, 142355) If the subjects show their displeasure and migrate in a body, the ruler would become helpless and would have no choice but to come to terms with them.
('53', 70, 1, 33, 142506) An indi vidual or a group, that is, the people as a whole, always have the right
('53', 71, 0, 1, 142587) 72 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('53', 71, 1, 2, 142628) to migrate, and such migration, if undertaken deliberately and carried out peacefully and firmly, is never known to have failed its aim.

('53', 75, 1, 2, 148945) 82. LETTER TO H. W. EMERSON
('53', 75, 2, 3, 148973) SIMLA, July 20, 1931
('53', 75, 3, 4, 148994) DEAR MR. EMERSON, I have a letter from Mian Ahmad Shah enclosing copy of a letter addressed to the Deputy Commissioner, Peshawar and enclosures thereto.
('53', 75, 3, 5, 149147) I send you herewith copies of these papers.
('53', 75, 3, 6, 149191) And below is an extract from a letter just received from Khan Saheb Abdul Ghaffar Khan.
('53', 75, 4, 7, 149279) The Government seems to be bent on repression.
('53', 75, 4, 8, 149326) Two of the Khudai Khidmatgars were shot dead and it is generally believed that the officials had a hand in it.
('53', 75, 4, 9, 149437) We inquired and discovered that those Khudai Khidmatgars had no enemies, nor had they any quarrel with anyone.
('53', 75, 4, 10, 149548) A young man had informed me that a police sub inspector had asked him to take any kind of revenge he wants to take from his uncle, he could even kill him if he liked.
('53', 75, 4, 11, 149715) The sub inspector assured the young man that no action will be taken against him.
('53', 75, 4, 12, 149797) The young man, my informant, and his uncle were not on good terms and the latter is the President of the local Jirga.
('53', 75, 4, 13, 149915) The Government is arresting and punishing people under Sec.
('53', 75, 4, 14, 149975) 40 F.R. Act and they have promulgated Sec.
('53', 75, 4, 15, 150018) 144 Cr.
('53', 75, 4, 16, 150026) P.C. in many places without any reason.
('53', 75, 4, 17, 150066) The police generally threaten and assault Khudai Khidmatgars.
('53', 75, 4, 18, 150128) It is generally believed by the people that the Government is purposely provoking people to create disturbance.
('53', 75, 5, 19, 150240) The police severely assault small boys for crying Inqilab Zindabad.
('53', 75, 5, 20, 150308) On the 13th of June some Europeans were driving in car at Sudoom, Tehsil Mardan, when a small boy cried Inqilab Zindabad.
('53', 75, 5, 21, 150430) The Europeans stopped the car and got down and caught hold of the boy and threw him in the central canal.
('53', 75, 5, 22, 150536) Then again, on the 13th of July at Nevakali, Tahsil Savabi some Europeans severely assaulted a boy for raising the same cry.
('53', 75, 6, 23, 150661) For realizing rent, they put the people to all kinds of torture.
('53', 75, 6, 24, 150726) They are made to sit the whole day under the hot sun and then they are put in small dungeons which have no ventilation.
('53', 75, 7, 25, 150846) I hope you will be good enough to take notice of these facts.
('53', 75, 7, 26, 150908) While our fight was going on there was not so much repression as it is now.
('53', 75, 7, 27, 150984) I have done my best to keep people quiet and once a Government official paid me this compliment, but how long it will be possible for me to make them remain quiet?
('53', 75, 7, 28, 151148) In Kohat, village people were allowed to take away salt free of cost before the fight but now after the Truce even this has been stopped and they are
('53', 76, 0, 1, 151298) VOL. 53 : 2 JULY, 1931 12 OCTOBER, 1931 77
('53', 76, 1, 2, 151341) no longer allowed to take away salt free of cost.
('53', 76, 1, 3, 151391) These statements make confusion worse confounded.
('53', 76, 1, 4, 151441) On the one hand you give me information that the Khudai Khidmatgars nicknamed “Red Shirts” are causing endless trouble.
('53', 76, 1, 5, 151561) On the other there are complaints on behalf of them, as now, that their liberty is unduly being interfered with.
('53', 76, 1, 6, 151674) There ought to be a way out of knowing the real truth.
('53', 76, 1, 7, 151729) Could you please tell me what Malkhand Agency is?
('53', 76, 1, 8, 151779) Is it or is it not within the zone of the Settlement?
('53', 76, 2, 9, 151833) Yours sincerely, Encl.

('53', 78, 3, 7, 154000) We bow to Mother Earth every morning and pray for her forgiveness for touching her with our feet.

('53', 78, 3, 9, 154147) The Earth bears our burden but does not hurt us; she bears the burden uncomplainingly.
('53', 78, 3, 10, 154234) According to modern discoveries, she is hanging in space without support.
('53', 78, 3, 11, 154308) If she were to get angry with us and stray ever so slightly from her path, we would instantly perish.
('53', 78, 3, 12, 154410) For crores of years, however, the Earth has been rot ating in her orbit and has sustained our life.

('53', 78, 3, 14, 154548) We have sprung from this earth and to that shall we return.

('53', 78, 3, 16, 154652) We are but a particle of dust and should remain so.
('53', 78, 3, 17, 154704) Those who wish to kick us or insult us should be welcome to do so; such is the humility which non violence implies.

('53', 79, 8, 14, 155798) This prolonged visit to Simla was unexpected.

('53', 79, 8, 16, 155889) The situation took such a turn that it could not be solved by letter.
('53', 79, 8, 17, 155959) By the time I come to Gujarat, maybe the matter will no longer be of any interest.
('53', 79, 8, 18, 156042) Do not feel disheartened by all this.
('53', 79, 8, 19, 156080) You should regard this as jettisoning of cargo from a ship caught in a storm.
('53', 79, 9, 20, 156158) Blessings from BAPU

('53', 80, 4, 14, 157075) 91. LETTER TO DINKAR MEHTA
('53', 80, 5, 15, 157102) July 20, 1931 I believe that there is not good reason for the antipathy some people have towards the Congress.
('53', 80, 5, 16, 157213) There will always be private property.
('53', 80, 5, 17, 157252) So long as there are persons some personal property is bound to remain.
('53', 80, 5, 18, 157324) I do not wish to see the destruction of capitalists and Indian States.
('53', 80, 5, 19, 157395) I wish to see them reformed.
('53', 80, 5, 20, 157424) In this struggle for purification anything that cannot be purified will automatically be destroyed.
('53', 80, 5, 21, 157524) As imperfect human beings, we can only hope and pray that everything may be purified and all impurity may be wiped out.
('53', 80, 5, 22, 157644) We do not know what is absolutely impure.
('53', 80, 5, 23, 157686) As a sentiment, everyone should accept the principle of economic equality.
('53', 80, 5, 24, 157761) But in practice there will never be such equality.
('53', 80, 5, 25, 157812) There will always be some people who have more wealth and some who have less.
('53', 80, 5, 26, 157890) It will be sufficient if those who have more consider themselves trustees, not owners of their wealth.
('53', 80, 5, 27, 157993) We should spread and foster such a sentiment.
('53', 80, 5, 28, 158039) The Congress means its collective membership.
('53', 80, 5, 29, 158085) It is self evident that the Congress cannot go further than the collective sentiment of its members.
('53', 80, 5, 30, 158186) Complete observance of truth and non violence means economic, political and moral equality.
('53', 80, 6, 31, 158278) [From Gujarati]
('53', 80, 7, 32, 158294) Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. XIV, pp.
('53', 80, 8, 33, 158329) 1 The draft of letter to Lady Willingdon is in English.
('53', 80, 8, 34, 158385) 2 Lord Irwin, the Viceroy

('53', 81, 1, 2, 158452) 92. LETTER TO G. D. BIRLA
('53', 81, 2, 3, 158478) SIMLA, July 20, 1931
('53', 81, 3, 4, 158499) BHAI GHANSHYAMDAS, I have had many letters from you, but I had no time to reply.
('53', 81, 3, 5, 158580) I had instructed Mahadev and Devdas to write something in acknowledgment.
('53', 81, 3, 6, 158654) No news from this end.
('53', 81, 3, 7, 158677) Even if a compromise is reached, it will not make me happy.
('53', 81, 3, 8, 158737) They no longer trust the Congress.
('53', 81, 3, 9, 158772) Everywhere Congress workers are being prosecuted.
('53', 81, 3, 10, 158822) How long can they hold out [empty] promises to me here?
('53', 81, 3, 11, 158878) I ought to go to England but I do not feel like going.
('53', 81, 3, 12, 158933) It is well that I do not worry over this thing.
('53', 81, 3, 13, 158981) I find the fulfilment of life in simply doing the tasks that arise naturally from moment to moment.
('53', 81, 3, 14, 159081) Considering the atmosphere here I would not be surprised if no invitation was extended to you.
('53', 81, 3, 15, 159176) Even if you don’t get one, are you proceeding to America on August 15?
('53', 81, 3, 16, 159247) Regarding the cable from Walchand, I hope you received the reply I had asked Mahadev to send.
('53', 81, 3, 17, 159341) How are you keeping these days?
('53', 81, 3, 18, 159373) I have been unable to read so far the essay sent by you on currency.
('53', 81, 4, 19, 159442) Blessings from BAPU

('53', 81, 6, 21, 159507) 93. INTERVIEW TO ASSOCIATED PRESS
('53', 81, 7, 22, 159541) SIMLA, July 20, 1931
('53', 81, 8, 23, 159562) On Mahatma Gandhi’s attention being drawn by the Associated Press representative to the sentence that “the Prime Minister has nominated members to attend the Federal Structure Subcommittee” and on his being asked whether his consent was implied in the nomination, Mahatma Gandhi said: I have certainly consented to go and attend the Federal Structure Subcommittee subject to the weather conditions (political) being favourable.
('53', 81, 8, 24, 159990) You may depend on it that I shall make a dart for London
('53', 82, 0, 1, 160047) VOL. 53 : 2 JULY, 1931 12 OCTOBER, 1931 83
('53', 82, 1, 2, 160090) as soon as the weather makes it possible.
('53', 82, 2, 3, 160132) Q. How do you find the weather conditions now?
('53', 82, 2, 4, 160179) A. I am not an expert in reading the weather.
('53', 82, 2, 5, 160225) Therefore you must approach the meteorological observatory.
('53', 82, 3, 6, 160285) Q. If you are going to London, can you indicate as to when you would be sailing ?
('53', 82, 3, 7, 160367) A. On the 15th August.
('53', 82, 3, 8, 160390) Maybe even earlier.
('53', 82, 4, 9, 160410) Q. There is an impression in the public mind that you have been shifting your position regarding the conditions of your attending the Round Table Conference.
('53', 82, 4, 10, 160568) For example it is said that at one time you stated that you would not attend the Conference unless the Hindu Muslim question was solved.
('53', 82, 4, 11, 160705) Now you say that you will proceed to London only if the weather conditions, as you put it, are favourable.
('53', 82, 4, 12, 160812) Can you explain yourself ?
('53', 82, 4, 13, 160839) A. I have not shifted my ground.
('53', 82, 4, 14, 160872) My position has all along been absolutely uniform and he who runs may read it.
('53', 82, 4, 15, 160951) It is plain in the resolution 1 of the Congress Working Committee.
('53', 82, 4, 16, 161018) The Committee decided to send me to London, even though the Hindu Muslim question might not be solved, but provided other favourable conditions existed; and I am simply waiting for those favourable conditions to appear.
('53', 82, 5, 17, 161238) Q. Do these conditions apply only to the Pact?
('53', 82, 5, 18, 161285) A. Yes, only to the Pact.
('53', 82, 6, 19, 161311) Q. When do you expect these conditions to appear?
('53', 82, 7, 20, 161361) A. Any more probing will touch the patient to the quick.
('53', 82, 8, 21, 161418) The Tribune, 22 7 1931

('53', 87, 2, 4, 169874) But in several parts of the country all sorts of undertakings are demanded.

('53', 87, 4, 16, 171031) GENERAL
('53', 87, 6, 17, 171039) In Bardoli Rs. 21,00,000 out of Rs. 22,00,000 have been paid out of the current dues.
('53', 87, 6, 18, 171125) 2 It is claimed that Congress workers are responsible for these payments.
('53', 87, 6, 19, 171199) When they began collections it is common knowledge that they told the peasants that they were to pay all they could both of the current dues and arrears.
('53', 87, 6, 20, 171353) The majority declared themselves to be hardly able to pay even the current dues.
('53', 87, 6, 21, 171434) The authorities after hesitation and even flat refusal for some time in some cases accepted payments and gave receipts on account of
('53', 87, 7, 22, 171567) 1 Vide “My Notes”sub title “Student” 2 Young India, 20 8 1931, has: “In Surat Rs. 19,00,000 of Rs. 20,00,000 have been paid out of the current dues.”
('53', 88, 0, 1, 171717) VOL. 53 : 2 JULY, 1931 12 OCTOBER, 1931 89
('53', 88, 1, 2, 171760) current dues.
('53', 88, 1, 3, 171774) Now to demand arrears or current dues from those who plead inability is a breach of faith with the workers and the people.
('53', 88, 1, 4, 171897) So far as the arrears are concerned, it is contended that if the authorized arrears are suspended because of the fall in prices, as they are, the unauthorized arrears deserve the same treatment with greater force, because the men having been civil resisters have in addition to the losses due to low prices suffered severe losses through migration.
('53', 88, 1, 5, 172246) These losses have been estimated and presented to the authorities.
('53', 88, 1, 6, 172313) Nevertheless Congress workers have offered to re examine cases suspected by the authorities.
('53', 88, 1, 7, 172406) What they resent is coercive processes, fines and display of the police who surround people’s houses.
('53', 88, 1, 8, 172508) In Borsad and Anand too the question of balance is not yet quite disposed of, though there may be no difficulties if the understanding arrived at by the Collector with Mr. Gandhi is carried out.
('53', 88, 1, 9, 172703) In Sirsi and Siddhapur (Karnatak) the peasants asked for relief owing to distress.
('53', 88, 1, 10, 172786) There was no no tax campaign.
('53', 88, 1, 11, 172816) The authorities were approached through Mr. Chikodi, a member of the Legislative Council.
('53', 88, 1, 12, 172906) Relief was promised.
('53', 88, 1, 13, 172927) Some was given.
('53', 88, 1, 14, 172943) But now instead of being satisfied with using the services of the Congress workers, coercive processes have been started.
('53', 88, 1, 15, 173065) Articles of daily use, including cooking utensils, have been taken away.
('53', 88, 2, 16, 173138) UNITED PROVINCES
('53', 88, 3, 17, 173155) Congress work as such is being attacked at various places, peaceful meetings being dispersed and Congress workers persecuted, and people treated to a general policy of terrorism.
('53', 88, 4, 18, 173334) INSTANCES.
('53', 88, 4, 19, 173345) (1) Bijhari (Mathura): on May 20th, 1931, three lorry loads of policemen raided the houses of practically all Congress workers, insulted the women and snatched away national flags, tore them and burnt them, children were prohibited from taking part in prabhat pheris.
('53', 88, 4, 20, 173613) 18 persons from the village challaned under Section 107, four charged also under the Dacoity Section.
('53', 88, 4, 21, 173715) Refused bail, without the identification parade being held.
('53', 88, 4, 22, 173775) Entirely false evidence is being cooked up against them.
('53', 88, 4, 23, 173832) (2) At Naujhil (Mathura), a peaceful meeting was forcibly dispersed on the 26th June 1931. Those who refused to disperse were physically dragged away.
('53', 88, 4, 24, 173983) Ghurelal fainted as a result of lathi blows.
('53', 88, 4, 25, 174028) Many other workers assaulted.
('53', 89, 0, 1, 174058) 90 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('53', 89, 1, 2, 174099) (3) At Rayah, Rahimatulla, a Congress volunteer was beaten with shoes by the local police on 10th July, 1931, and ordered to leave the village under various threats.
('53', 89, 1, 3, 174265) About 53 prosecutions of Congress workers including almost all office bearers of the Dt.
('53', 89, 1, 4, 174354) Mathura 1 are going on under Security Section.

('53', 95, 2, 3, 187570) SIMLA, July 21, 1931
('53', 95, 3, 4, 187591) Interviewed by the Associated Press special representative, as he emerged from the Viceregal Lodge, Mahatma Gandhi said that the conversations were inconclusive.
('53', 95, 3, 5, 187753) But I am not staying for any further interviews.

('53', 95, 7, 12, 188336) 98. LETTER TO VICEROY
('53', 95, 8, 13, 188358) SIMLA, July 21, 1931 I have your kind letter of 20th inst.
('53', 95, 8, 14, 188417) inviting me on behalf of the Prime Minister to be a member of the Federal Structure Committee as also a member of the full conference.
('53', 95, 8, 15, 188552) Whilst I appreciate the invitation and would like to respond, as I have already conveyed to you, I have serious difficulties in the way of my proceeding to London.
('53', 95, 8, 16, 188716) I came to Simla in the hope that the difficulties would be removed.
('53', 95, 8, 17, 188784) But our protracted conversations have not advanced matters so as to enable me to come to a positive decision.
('53', 95, 8, 18, 188894) I feel that the way things are moving in India at the present moment, unless they improve, make it impossible for me to leave India.
('53', 95, 8, 19, 189027) Reports pour in upon me from every part showing that Congressmen are being harassed without any justifiable cause.
('53', 95, 8, 20, 189142) In some places they say that they are being harassed much more than during the civil disobedience campaign.
('53', 95, 8, 21, 189250) I know your difficulty especially when things are being done under cover of law.
('53', 95, 8, 22, 189331) I have suggested several ways out.
('53', 95, 8, 23, 189366) But I am sorry that they have not
('53', 96, 0, 1, 189400) VOL. 53 : 2 JULY, 1931 12 OCTOBER, 1931 97
('53', 96, 1, 2, 189443) commended themselves to you.
('53', 96, 1, 3, 189472) In the circumstances the most I can say is that I must watch events and if I find that things have not taken a better turn I must reluctantly come to the conclusion that I must not go.
('53', 96, 1, 4, 189657) I need hardly say that I seek no protection for any Congressman from prosecution for manifest breach of the common or the statutory law of the country.
('53', 96, 1, 5, 189809) My complaint is about acts manifestly outside the law and processes which are demonstrably vexatious.
('53', 96, 1, 6, 189911) It grieves me that I am not able to send you a better letter.
('53', 96, 1, 7, 189973) But I am helpless.
('53', 96, 1, 8, 189992) After much cogitation I have come to the conclusion that I should send my son Devdas Gandhi to the Frontier Province.
('53', 96, 1, 9, 190110) I would feel ill at ease if I could not send anybody at all especially after the information that Mr. Emerson gave me.
('53', 96, 1, 10, 190229) As I said to you during our conversation he will be asked to refrain from making any speeches or accepting any addresses.
('53', 96, 1, 11, 190351) My sole object in sending him is to promote peace and to avoid a catastrophe if it is at all possible.
('53', 96, 1, 12, 190454) His presence would also insure Khan Abdul Ghaffar Khan responding to the Commissioner’s invitation.
('53', 96, 2, 13, 190554) Young India, 20 8 1931
('53', 96, 3, 14, 190577) 99. LETTER TO H. W. EMERSON
('53', 96, 4, 15, 190605) SIMLA, July 21, 1931 In accordance with my promise made at the Viceregal Lodge this evening I reduce to writing my request for an impartial tribunal to decide upon matters of interpretation of the Settlement between the Government and the Congress that might be submitted to it from time to time whether on behalf of the Government or the Congress.
('53', 96, 4, 16, 190954) The following are the matters that require immediate adjudication unless there is agreement between the Government and the Congress as to the interpretation: (1) Whether picketing includes picketing of liquor shop auction sales?
('53', 96, 5, 17, 191183) 1 In reply the Viceroy said: “Thank you very much for your letter of July 21st, and let me say that while I cannot accept as justified in fact the reasons you give for your present inability to intimate your acceptance of the invitations, I do hope that after our talks the apprehensions you now feel will disappear, and that you will be able to go to England as a member of the Federal Structure Committee and of the full Conference.”
('53', 97, 0, 1, 191619) 98 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('53', 97, 1, 2, 191660) (2) Whether it is competent for provincial Governments to prescribe the distance at which picketing can be done so as to render it impossible for picketers to be within sight of the shop picketed?
('53', 97, 1, 3, 191857) (3) Whether it is competent for a Government to limit the number of picketers so as to make it impossible to picket all the entrances of a particular shop?
('53', 97, 1, 4, 192013) (4) Whether it is competent for a Government to defeat peaceful picketing by permitting sale of liquor by the picketed shopkeeper at places other than licensed and during odd hours?
('53', 97, 1, 5, 192195) (5) Interpretation of clauses 13 and 14 in the application of particular cases which provincial Governments have regarded as not coming under those clauses and the Congress has held otherwise.
('53', 97, 1, 6, 192388) (6) Interpretation of the word ‘return’ in clause 16(a).
('53', 97, 1, 7, 192445) (7) Whether a return of guns forfeited after cancellation of licenses for participation in civil disobedience is covered by the Settlement?
('53', 97, 1, 8, 192585) (8) Whether restoration of certain property seized under Ordinance IX and of Watan lands in Karnatak is covered by the Settlement and if it is, is it competent for a Government to impose any conditions upon such restoration?
('53', 97, 1, 9, 192810) (9) The meaning of the word ‘permanent’ in Clause 19. (10) Whether it is competent for the Education Department to impose conditions upon students who took part in the civil disobedience campaign before admitting them or in virtue of perpetual rustication imposed during the civil disobedience campaign to debar the admission of students under the ban?
('53', 97, 1, 10, 193163) (11) Whether it is competent for a Government to punish a person or corporation, by reason of his or its having taken part in the civil disobedience campaign, e.g., forfeiture of pension, or grants and the like to municipalities ?
('53', 97, 1, 11, 193394) These are not to be treated as the only matters to be submitted to the tribunal.
('53', 97, 1, 12, 193475) It is possible that unforeseen cases may arise in future which may be claimed to come under the Settlement.
('53', 97, 1, 13, 193583) The procedure
('53', 98, 0, 1, 193597) VOL. 53 : 2 JULY, 1931 12 OCTOBER, 1931 99
('53', 98, 1, 2, 193640) to be adopted would be that written statements would be submitted both on behalf of the Government and the Congress and the points would be argued by counsel on behalf of the Government as on behalf of the Congress.
('53', 98, 1, 3, 193856) The decision of the tribunal would be binding on both the parties.
('53', 98, 1, 4, 193923) As I told you in the course of our conversation whilst I say nothing at the present moment as to a tribunal for the examination of questions of facts in the event of differences between the Government and the Congress I have not waived the demand.
('53', 98, 1, 5, 194171) Occasions may arise when the differences may be so vital as to make it obligatory on any party to press for a tribunal for the examination of such cases also.
('53', 98, 1, 6, 194330) I should, however, hope that we might be able to settle all points of difference without reference to any tribunal.
('53', 98, 2, 7, 194446) Home Department, Political File No.
('53', 98, 2, 8, 194482) 33/VII/31 Poll/1931. Courtesy: National Archives of India
('53', 98, 3, 9, 194540) 100. INTERVIEW TO “THE PIONEER”
('53', 98, 4, 10, 194572) SIMLA, July 21, 1931 I want to go to London.
('53', 98, 4, 11, 194617) I hope to go to London.
('53', 98, 4, 12, 194641) I would go to Lord Willingdon now and say that I would have accepted the invitation were it not for my mistrust of the activities of the district authorities in certain areas during my absence.
('53', 98, 5, 13, 194835) In these words, Mr. Gandhi summed up his present position at the conclusion of an hour’s conversation tonight.
('53', 98, 6, 14, 194946) Mr. Gandhi will not see the Viceroy again in Simla and he told me that certain communications would be exchanged before he would be in a position to say ‘yes’ or ‘no’.
('53', 98, 6, 15, 195114) Of his anxiety to go, there is no doubt whatever and when I suggested that the general opinion was that he would make a great mistake if he did not go to London he said he saw no reason to disagree with such opinion, but that he had to consider also the people in India.
('53', 98, 7, 16, 195385) “But are you not devoting too much time to details instead of concentrating your attention on the broad issues?” I asked.
('53', 98, 7, 17, 195507) Mr. Gandhi started to talk of South Africa and particularly his experiences at Spion Kopwhen his three officers were incapacitated.
('53', 98, 7, 18, 195639) He explained that he had to assume responsibility for 60 stretcher bearers working over a stretch of more than a score of miles and that he was amazed at the number of details he had attended to personally in order to secure efficient
('53', 98, 8, 19, 195874) 1 For the addressee’s reply, vide “Letter from H. W. Emerson”, 30 7 1931
('53', 99, 0, 1, 195947) 100 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('53', 99, 1, 2, 195989) working and a successful outcome.
('53', 99, 2, 3, 196023) Are you trying to draw a parallel for my benefit between such experiences and your present policy?
('53', 99, 3, 4, 196122) Mr. Gandhi agreed that he was and that only disaster could follow neglect of details.
('53', 99, 3, 5, 196208) Nor did he attempt to hide that the situation in the United Provinces was causing him the most concern.
('53', 99, 4, 6, 196312) He agreed that Sir Malcolm Hailey’s promise of agrarian legislation is an excellent thing for the future but emphasized that what is wanted is immediate relief, and Sir Malcolm Hailey has not indicated that though his speech is conciliatory.
('53', 99, 4, 7, 196554) He gave the instance of Gujarat where he had personally collected nineteen out of the twenty lakhs due and said that though the situation in the United Provinces was somewhat different he had offered during the recent negotiations to go there and do the same thing.
('53', 99, 5, 8, 196820) It is interesting to note that in the brief conversation I had with Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru yesterday afternoon he said he agreed with Sir Malcolm Hailey that the system in the United Provinces had collapsed and that the situation was very bad.
('53', 99, 5, 9, 197065) With this in mind I asked Mr. Gandhi whether he agreed that there was a danger that if the agricultural situation throughout India got very much worse chaos would supervene of a nature with which neither Mr. Gandhi nor the Government of India could successfully cope.
('53', 99, 5, 10, 197333) He emphatically agreed but added that there was no reason why it should reach such a stage.

('53', 103, 5, 7, 204860) I heard a story about me of the Rae Bareli secret circulars reproduced in Young India of 2nd July that the adverbial clause “and at the same time honestly” was omitted from it.
('53', 103, 5, 8, 205037) I saw then an insidious paragraph in a newspaper which but for the previous information in possession, I would not have understood at all.

('53', 103, 5, 12, 205415) These were received by me subsequently to the publication of the circulars.

('53', 103, 5, 14, 205541) I had Mahadev Desai to write to the Manager to send me the manuscript (which is always preserved for some time), or to wire if it was possible the condition in which it was received at the press.

('53', 103, 6, 16, 205792) Your letter.

('53', 103, 6, 19, 205925) The original was sent to the press.
('53', 103, 6, 20, 205961) I have a recollection that the adverb appeared apart from the text and without any indication that it was part of it.
('53', 103, 6, 21, 206079) I have no recollection that I scored it.
('53', 103, 6, 22, 206120) How the manager knows that I scored it, I do not know.
('53', 103, 6, 23, 206175) My duty is to take the reader into confidence about what has happened.
('53', 103, 6, 24, 206246) (Here comes Mahadev Desai to whom as I am writing this I have shown the telegram.

('53', 106, 1, 5, 212391) If and when India takes over charge from the present administration the transaction would be like any ordinary transfer whether it is from seller to buyer or from trustee to his ward or from the wrong doer to the wronged.
('53', 106, 1, 6, 212613) In each one of these transfers there would be a proper stock taking, balance sheet and a taking over subject to audit and adjustment.

('53', 109, 1, 12, 219477) I have no doubt that the authors do not claim infallibility for their conclusions.
('53', 109, 1, 13, 219560) If therefore any flaw is shown to them, they will be the first to acknowledge their error, and so far as the members of the Working Committee and those members of the general public who would care to study this authoritative report are concerned, they would be able to put such enlightened criticism side by side with and formulate their judgment.
('53', 109, 1, 14, 219908) Let me say in conclusion that when the Congress at Gaya 1 and then at Lahore passed a resolution about financial obligations 2 it was seriously meant.
('53', 109, 1, 15, 220059) The appointment of the Committee and its report were the natural corrollary.
('53', 109, 1, 16, 220136) The Congress will seriously follow the matter to the end.
('53', 109, 1, 17, 220194) If the Congress can help, India will not take a leap in the dark.
('53', 109, 1, 18, 220260) She cannot afford to be generous at the expense of the dumb millions who after all have to make the largest contribution towards the payment of any liabilities that may be undertaken.

('53', 110, 1, 2, 220649) 106. WHAT THE MILL OWNERS CAN DO
('53', 110, 2, 3, 220682) The correspondent whose letter about Japanese enterprise I gave last week 1 sends also the following: 2
('53', 110, 3, 4, 220786) Nothing perhaps emerges so clearly from the perusal of the report of the British Cotton Commission to the Far East as the tremendous energy with which Japan has not only excluded practically all imports of foreign piece goods into her territories, but has also captured a number of markets abroad for the products of her own people.
('53', 110, 3, 5, 221119) Japan feels her destiny is bound up with the necessity to build up an ever growing export trade.
('53', 110, 4, 6, 221216) With such sentiments it is no wonder that the Government, no less than the industrialists, count no loss too great in finding fresh markets for the nation’s products.
('53', 110, 4, 7, 221383) One of the most remarkable measures that the Government passed during the last year was a Bill under which the Government on the advice of the responsible Minister will reimburse exporters to the amount of 70% of losses incurred on shipments to certain specified and undeveloped markets.
('53', 110, 4, 8, 221671) But the Government’s active encouragement and support are matched by the readiness of the industrialists of Japan to take risk.
('53', 110, 5, 9, 221799) Here in India we do not wish to capture new markets, we want only to preserve the domestic market for ourselves.
('53', 110, 5, 10, 221912) If the Japanese industrialist can cheerfully write off large sums out of his capital in the effort to find out new markets, cannot the Indian capitalist be persuaded at least to refrain from making profits for a certain period in the interest of India’s more restricted and therefore more laudable effort?.
('53', 110, 5, 11, 222219) It is true as the correspondent says that we do not want to capture new markets.
('53', 110, 5, 12, 222300) But we must dare to suffer to exclude foreign cloth from ours.
('53', 110, 5, 13, 222363) Will the mill owners do it?
('53', 110, 6, 14, 222391) Young India, 23 7 1931

('53', 111, 1, 2, 222529) 107. UNBRIDLED LICENCE
('53', 111, 2, 3, 222552) A correspondent from Trichinopoly writes: 1
('53', 111, 3, 4, 222596) What the correspondent describes is, I am sorry to have to say, a common occurrence nowadays.
('53', 111, 3, 5, 222690) I am trying to do what is possible in terms of the Settlement and am still hoping that what appears to me to be a manifest breach of the Settlement will stop.
('53', 111, 3, 6, 222849) For I have heard it said that these sales are, so far as the law is concerned, legal.
('53', 111, 3, 7, 222935) It is thus a case of unbridled licence.
('53', 111, 3, 8, 222975) Meanwhile I can only advise a continuance of picketing and reliance upon gentle persuasion producing its effect upon those who, in their ignorant selfishness, are corrupting the manners of simple rustics, not excluding even babies.

('53', 111, 5, 10, 223230) 108. WOES OF ‘UNTOUCHABLES’
('53', 111, 6, 11, 223258) DEAR MAHATMAJI,
('53', 111, 7, 12, 223274) I venture to bring to your notice some principles which, I think, must be kept in view in the conduct of the campaign on behalf of the untouchable Hindus.
('53', 111, 8, 13, 223429) Among the numerous disabilities from which they suffer, a clear dis tinction must be made between those which are prima facie civic in their nature and those which are Prima facie non civil or religious or communal in their character.
('53', 111, 9, 14, 223664) The advice you gave to the leaders of a temple entry satyagraha last year, that such satyagraha should be offered by touchable Hindus alone, would be meaningless, unless by such satyagraha you meant a campaign on the part of the touchable sympathizers of the untouchables for a boycott by all worshippers of such temples as do not admit the untouchables, till such time as their managers accept the reform.
('53', 111, 10, 15, 224071) In these days of the incessant talk of protection of minorities who dare deny that if any minority in India needs to have special provisions in the future constitution for itself, it is the untouchables?
('53', 111, 11, 16, 224275) Their want of self assertion, their apathy towards their wrongs, their
('53', 111, 12, 17, 224346) 1 The letter is not reproduced here.
('53', 111, 12, 18, 224383) It stated that liquor shop owners were selling toddy outside their shops and in public places.
('53', 112, 0, 1, 224478) VOL. 53 : 2 JULY, 1931 12 OCTOBER, 1931 113
('53', 112, 1, 2, 224522) ‘pathetic contentment’ with their lot—these, of course, are the greatest obs tacles in the way of their emancipation from the bonds of diabolic custom.
('53', 112, 2, 3, 224674) I remain,
('53', 112, 3, 4, 224684) KARWAR, 17 6 1931 Yours sincerely,
('53', 112, 4, 5, 224719) S. D. NADKARNI The distinction made by Sjt.
('53', 112, 4, 6, 224763) Nadkarni between civil and religious disabilities is unnecessary because useless.
('53', 112, 4, 7, 224845) They are all religious because imposed in the name of religion by co religionists.
('53', 112, 4, 8, 224928) A useful distinction will be between those disabilities which require legislative treatment and those that do not.
('53', 112, 4, 9, 225043) In my opinion the confining at Vaikom of satyagraha to merely Hindus was perfectly sound and absolutely necessary.
('53', 112, 4, 10, 225158) The writer perhaps confounds satyagraha a special remedy with general agitation.
('53', 112, 4, 11, 225239) Whilst all can take part in a general agitation, only the actual victims can adopt the remedy of satyagraha.
('53', 112, 4, 12, 225348) The Hindus have to do penance.
('53', 112, 4, 13, 225379) How can Hinduism be purged by non Hindus doing penance?
('53', 112, 4, 14, 225435) It may easily lead to serious consequences if Mussalmans were to offer satyagraha in a dispute between Hindus and Hindus especially in a matter the latter consider to be religious.
('53', 112, 4, 15, 225616) Nor do I see any reason to alter the opinion that it is the business of touchable Hindus to lead the agitation side by side with the untouchables if only because the latter are today too powerless and too apathetic to their own sufferings.
('53', 112, 4, 16, 225856) It is not so much the inability on the part of untouchables to enter temples that matters as the sinful insolence of the touchables who impose the atrocious disability which matters.
('53', 112, 4, 17, 226039) Hinduism will not be purified by untouchables taking by storm the possession of a temple; it will be purified by the trustees and the worshippers recognizing the sin of prohibition and flinging open the gates to the untouchables.
('53', 112, 4, 18, 226269) It is for the Hindu reformers to multiply and offer satyagraha against blind orthodoxy.

('53', 113, 1, 2, 226459) 109. GANESH SHANKAR MEMORIAL
('53', 113, 2, 3, 226488) This appeal for subscriptions to a Ganesh Shankar Vidyarthi Memorial has been before the public now for a long time.
('53', 113, 2, 4, 226605) It is signed by Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru and others, being personal friends and co workers of the martyr.
('53', 113, 2, 5, 226710) Sri Prakasa, Sevashrama, Benares Cantt., is the Secretary as also Treasurer and all subscriptions should be sent to him.
('53', 113, 2, 6, 226831) The objects of the Memorial are: 1. To erect a fountain or pillar or some similar memorial near the place where Ganesh Shankar gave up his body while offering protection to Hindus and Muslims.
('53', 113, 2, 7, 227024) 2. To assist the “Pratap Trust”.
('53', 113, 2, 8, 227057) Ganesh Shankar formed this Trust to which he entrusted the management of his famous Hindi paper Pratap.
('53', 113, 2, 9, 227161) The chief services of his lifetime were rendered through this paper.
('53', 113, 2, 10, 227230) The Trust is to be helped so that the foundations of Pratap may be strengthened.
('53', 113, 2, 11, 227311) 3. To help the Ashram established by him in the village of Narwal in the Cawnpore District.
('53', 113, 2, 12, 227403) Nearly 200 villages have been organized through this Ashram.
('53', 113, 2, 13, 227464) Spinning and khadi propaganda are the chief factors of Ashram work.
('53', 113, 2, 14, 227532) 4. To hand over the balance to the U.P. Provincial Congress Committee on the condition that Ganesh Shankar National Service shall be established with it.
('53', 113, 2, 15, 227686) This service should be on the same lines as the U.P. National Service, namely, to help whole time national workers in the province.
('53', 113, 2, 16, 227818) The sum asked for by the Memorial Committee is only one lakh of rupees.
('53', 113, 2, 17, 227890) In my opinion it is quite an insignificant amount for the objects of the Memorial as also the memory of the martyr.
('53', 113, 2, 18, 228006) I hope therefore that there would be a quick response so that the Committee may be able to close the list and go on with the work.
('53', 113, 3, 19, 228137) Young India, 23 7 1931
('53', 114, 0, 1, 228160) VOL. 53 : 2 JULY, 1931 12 OCTOBER, 1931 115
('53', 114, 1, 2, 228204) 110. QUESTION OF BAIL
('53', 114, 2, 3, 228226) Owing to the renewed activity of local authorities against Congressmen, I receive many inquiries as to the attitude they should adopt as to defence and bail.
('53', 114, 2, 4, 228384) I appreciate the general reluctance on the part of Congressmen to enter upon defence or being bailed out.
('53', 114, 2, 5, 228490) They have been used now for a long time to no defence and no bail formulae.
('53', 114, 2, 6, 228566) In virtue and in view of the Settlement, it is open to Congressmen both to be bailed out and be defended.
('53', 114, 2, 7, 228672) No one is bound to do either.
('53', 114, 2, 8, 228702) But I can imagine circumstances when it would be, whilst the Settlement lasts, a duty to be bailed out and be defended.
('53', 114, 2, 9, 228822) But it has been discovered that bails are often granted condi tionally upon the parties undertaking not to make speeches, etc.
('53', 114, 2, 10, 228949) Generally speaking, I would say that such conditional bails should not be accepted.
('53', 114, 2, 11, 229033) The same opinion applies and with greater force to security under Section 108. But there may be extraordinary circums tances when it may be deemed in the national interests to give bail.
('53', 114, 2, 12, 229220) The safest course in such cases would be to take the written opinion of one’s immediate superior.
('53', 114, 2, 13, 229318) But I would commend to Congress workers the golden rule followed by Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel in Gujarat.
('53', 114, 2, 14, 229423) He has generally proscribed speech altogether by Congress workers, speeches being confined to him and me.
('53', 114, 2, 15, 229529) As a matter of fact, even he speaks only on such occasions when it becomes absolutely necessary.
('53', 114, 2, 16, 229626) I do not think that Gujarat has suffered for this rule of silence.
('53', 114, 2, 17, 229693) Whether at war or peaces what we need is silent work.
('53', 114, 2, 18, 229747) And work leaves little room for speeches.
('53', 114, 2, 19, 229789) Speeches play the least important part in political education.
('53', 114, 2, 20, 229852) Having been now accustomed for past fifteen years to less speaking we do not notice that the race of orators has almost died out.
('53', 114, 2, 21, 229982) It had its use but when the age of action commenced eloquence naturally took a back seat.
('53', 114, 2, 22, 230072) I have no doubt that if we imposed a self denying ordinance on ourselves we should be the stronger for action and the nation’s response will be wider and more substantial.
('53', 114, 2, 23, 230244) What is wanted is intimate personal contact between the villagers and workers.
('53', 114, 2, 24, 230323) The villagers should know their servants and feel that they, the servants are there not to serve their own ends but the interests of the villagers whom they endeavour to represent.
('53', 114, 2, 25, 230504) Though my advice just now arises out of the present situation,
('53', 115, 0, 1, 230567) 116 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('53', 115, 1, 2, 230609) let the reader know that I have fixed views about silent work and that the Gujarat prohibition had no reference to any legal proceedings.
('53', 115, 1, 3, 230747) The prohibition was due to the conviction that it was good as a general rule for all times.
('53', 115, 1, 4, 230839) Young India, 23 7 1931

('53', 116, 1, 2, 232026) 113. LETTER TO T. T. KOTHAWALA
('53', 116, 2, 3, 232057) Strictly Confidential BARDOLI, July 24, 1931
('53', 116, 3, 4, 232102) DEAR MR. KOTHAWALA, Though after our talk at Surat on 13th inst.
('53', 116, 3, 5, 232167) I had expected some action, I was unprepared for the terrible events of the past ten days.
('53', 116, 3, 6, 232258) You or your subordinates have used not only coercive but repressive measures against the poor villagers and practically forced payments from them.
('53', 116, 3, 7, 232405) In my opinion this is a breach of faith, if not of the Settlement.
('53', 116, 3, 8, 232472) The Government knew that Congressmen were telling the people to pay all they could whether on account of current dues or arrears.
('53', 116, 3, 9, 232602) We found also that it was all the people could do to pay the current dues without having to borrow.
('53', 116, 3, 10, 232702) We made an enquiry into the losses they had sustained.
('53', 116, 3, 11, 232757) I sent you too a note showing the losses suffered by the people.
('53', 116, 3, 12, 232822) Our workers threw themselves heart and soul into the work of collection.
('53', 116, 3, 13, 232895) As you know I was in Bardoli myself for some time doing the work and then it was that Sardar Vallabhbhai took the sole charge here and I went to Borsad.
('53', 116, 3, 14, 233048) Your subordinates knew what we were telling the people.
('53', 116, 3, 15, 233104) For some time payment from Siadla was not accepted until arrears were also paid.
('53', 116, 3, 16, 233185) We could not collect the arrears and ultimately payment was accepted against receipt for current dues without any reservation.
('53', 116, 3, 17, 233312) During all this time it was assumed that there would be no coercive processes and certainly no show of force or police raids to threaten poor people.
('53', 116, 3, 18, 233462) The payment made under these circumstances I regard as payments made under duress and forced in violation of the implied understanding that no processes would be issued except in cases where the Congress workers had no influence and where the people had not taken part in the civil disobedience campaign.
('53', 116, 3, 19, 233767) I do not bring herein the conversations I had with the Commissioner and with you and the impression left on my mind, but I do suggest that it was within your knowledge that we were telling the people that no coercion would be used against them if they paid at least the current dues or unless they could not conclusively show that they were unable to pay even these.
('53', 116, 3, 20, 234134) But in precipitating the crisis and using the extraordinary
('53', 117, 0, 1, 234194) 118 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('53', 117, 1, 2, 234236) measures of the past ten days, without the Congressmen having been even given the opportunity of re examining the cases of the villagers concerned there is a distinct breach of faith.
('53', 117, 1, 3, 234420) In the circumstances I must ask you to refund the monies thus collected and withdraw all attachment notices and stop further coercion and repression.
('53', 117, 1, 4, 234570) I must mention herein the case of the present Patel of Varad whose removal has been demanded for a long time and in whose case no open enquiry has still been held.
('53', 117, 1, 5, 234734) There is also the matter of confiscated lands in five villages in Bulsar taluqa, in respect of which fines are being demanded for non agricultural use before they are restored.
('53', 117, 1, 6, 234911) This is in breach of the Settlement.
('53', 117, 1, 7, 234948) There are other matters which I don’t propose to mention just now.
('53', 117, 1, 8, 235015) Unless satisfaction is given in the matters herein mentioned or an impartial open tribunal is appointed by the Government to examine the complaints herein made and all processes stopped meanwhile, I must regard the Settlement and the implied faith having been broken by the Government and regard myself as free to take such action as may be necessary to protect the interests of the people whom the Congress represents.
('53', 117, 1, 9, 235435) I would ask you please to let me have a reply by Sunday next noon.
('53', 117, 1, 10, 235502) Copies of this letter are being sent to Mr. Garrett, the Govern ment of Bombay and purport telegraphed to H. E. the Viceroy.
('53', 117, 2, 11, 235627) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI T. T. KOTHAWALA, ESQ.

('53', 126, 1, 2, 248894) 126. MADNESS
('53', 126, 2, 3, 248907) By attacking the Acting Governor of Bombay 1 what good could the Fergusson College student have intended to achieve?
('53', 126, 2, 4, 249024) The news papers have reported that the act was inspired purely by a desire for revenge either for the imposition of martial law in Sholapur or something else.
('53', 126, 2, 5, 249183) Even if the attack had resulted in the Governor’s death, it could not have undone what has happened.
('53', 126, 2, 6, 249284) By this attempt to take revenge, the student has only increased the prevailing bitterness.
('53', 126, 2, 7, 249375) He has put education to shame by such misuse of his learning.
('53', 126, 2, 8, 249437) Considering the circumstances in which the assault took place, it was also a form of treachery.
('53', 126, 2, 9, 249533) The student violated his duty to the Governor.
('53', 126, 2, 10, 249580) The latter was a guest of the Fergusson College, and a guest’s person is always held sacred.
('53', 126, 2, 11, 249673) They say that an Arab would not kill even an enemy while the latter was his guest.
('53', 126, 2, 12, 249756) As the student belon ged to the Fergusson College, he was one of the Governor’s hosts.
('53', 126, 2, 13, 249843) And what can be more treacherous than the host killing his own guest?
('53', 126, 2, 14, 249913) Are we to believe that the terrorists respect no limits?
('53', 126, 2, 15, 249970) And what right to protest against the Sholapur martial law or other acts of injustice has anyone who himself respects no limits of decency?
('53', 126, 2, 16, 250110) If someone committed such treachery against us, we would certainly feel indignant.
('53', 126, 2, 17, 250193) How can we do to others what we would not like to be done to us?
('53', 126, 2, 18, 250258) I am convinced that such acts bring no glory to India, but give it a bad name.
('53', 126, 2, 19, 250337) They do not increase but diminish our fitness for swaraj and in consequence, swaraj recedes farther from us.
('53', 126, 2, 20, 250446) A great and ancient country like ours will not win swaraj through treacherous murders.
('53', 126, 2, 21, 250533) We ought to remember that the departure of the British from India will not by itself mean swaraj.
('53', 126, 2, 22, 250631) Swaraj means the capacity to run the Government of the country on behalf of the people and for the people.
('53', 126, 2, 23, 250738) That capacity will not come simply if the British leave or are killed.
('53', 126, 2, 24, 250809) We shall acquire it by going to the millions of dumb peasants, acquainting ourselves with their hardships, serving them and winning their love.
('53', 126, 2, 25, 250953) Suppose that one or two thousand terrorists, or even more, succeed in killing every Englishman in India.
('53', 126, 2, 26, 251058) Will that enable them to run the Government of the country?
('53', 126, 2, 27, 251118) On the contrary, intoxicated by the success of their terrorist methods and in their arrogance, they will go on killing everyone whom they do not
('53', 126, 3, 28, 251263) 1 Sir Ernest Hotson, on July 22, 1931; vide also “Foul Play”,30 7 1931
('53', 127, 0, 1, 251334) 128 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('53', 127, 1, 2, 251376) How will the peasants be benefited thereby?
('53', 127, 1, 3, 251420) Such methods will never reform the many evil practices and customs in India which have made her a subject country.
('53', 127, 2, 4, 251535) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 26 7 1931
('53', 127, 3, 5, 251572) 127. THREE QUESTIONS
('53', 127, 4, 6, 251593) A student writes: 1
('53', 127, 5, 7, 251613) The complaint against pure khadi is a very old one.
('53', 127, 5, 8, 251665) The inconvenience caused by the coarseness of khadi deserves to be tolerated for the sake of swaraj, or, rather, for the sake of our starving brethren.
('53', 127, 5, 9, 251817) From coarse khadi one may make and wear shorts reaching up to the knee or trousers reaching up to the ankle.
('53', 127, 5, 10, 251926) The resulting advantage will be saving of cloth and convenience in washing.
('53', 127, 5, 11, 252002) If dhoti is worn in South Indian style, that is, without being tucked up, that would save half the length of cloth.
('53', 127, 5, 12, 252118) No one should think, through ignorance or contempt or pride that it does not behove a Gujarati to imitate a South Indian.
('53', 127, 5, 13, 252240) Moreover, if any student feels that he is forced to do with shorts of coarse khadi, he has nobody but himself to blame.
('53', 127, 5, 14, 252360) Why should he not spin fine yarn for his own use?
('53', 127, 5, 15, 252410) By doing so, he would get a fine dhoti for the cost of the cotton and the labour charges for weaving, and would also have the satisfaction resulting from the knowledge that he had helped himself.
('53', 127, 5, 16, 252606) He cannot argue, either, that he cannot spare from his studies enough time for spinning His experience will tell him that he wastes many minutes of his time every day in doing nothing or doing useless things.
('53', 127, 5, 17, 252815) It would be enough if he saved some of them and spent them in spinning.
('53', 127, 5, 18, 252887) There is an English saying similar in meaning to the Gujarati saying that a girl not wishing to dance finds fault with the dancing ground.
('53', 127, 5, 19, 253026) One can find a hundred excuses for not using pure khadi.
('53', 127, 5, 20, 253083) If one has faith in khadi, one would find no difficulty insuperable.
('53', 127, 5, 21, 253152) 2. It is possible for the Bombay Provincial [Congress] Commit tee to publish a list of swadeshi goods available, but that is unneces sary.

('53', 128, 3, 8, 253992) 128. MY NOTES
('53', 128, 4, 9, 254006) COMMITTEE FOR REMOVAL OF UNTOUCHABILITY
('53', 128, 5, 10, 254046) The work of the Committee for the Removal of Untouchability had merged in the struggle for swaraj, as hadhappened with several other committees when the struggle was on.
('53', 128, 5, 11, 254216) Untouchability had been quite forgotten at many places there.
('53', 128, 5, 12, 254278) However, now that partial peace reigns the custom seems to be reviving.
('53', 128, 5, 13, 254350) The Congress Working Com mittee has alerted the Committee for the Removal of Untouchability to deal with the situation.
('53', 128, 5, 14, 254470) Shri Jamnalalji has been its President.
('53', 128, 5, 15, 254510) We all know how, through his efforts and those of Swami Anand, the doors of several temples had been thrown open to the so called untouchables.
('53', 128, 5, 16, 254654) There is still much scope for effort in this direction and the effort should be made.
('53', 128, 5, 17, 254740) A practice which has struck deep roots through the centuries is not likely to disappear all at once.
('53', 128, 5, 18, 254841) It is difficult to open the eyes of a person who clings to irreligion taking it to be true religion.
('53', 128, 5, 19, 254942) Such is the difficulty we experience regarding untouch ability.
('53', 128, 5, 20, 255006) All the same the progress achieved in this matter and the awakening noticed among Hindus raise our hopes.
('53', 128, 5, 21, 255112) We do not now find many persons supporting untouchability or believing that the practice is so deeply rooted that it can never be eradicated.
('53', 128, 5, 22, 255254) However, we should not allow ourselves to be deceived by that progress.
('53', 128, 5, 23, 255326) The Untouchability Removal Committee will not let us rest in false hope.
('53', 128, 6, 24, 255399) SALARIES UNDER SWARAJ
('53', 128, 7, 25, 255421) A young correspondent writes: 1
('53', 128, 8, 26, 255453) This correspondent seems to have taken it for granted that, as
('53', 128, 9, 27, 255516) 1 The letter is not translated here.
('53', 128, 9, 28, 255553) It expressed apprehension regarding the consequences of ceilings on salaries recommended at the Karachi Congress.
('53', 129, 0, 1, 255667) 130 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('53', 129, 1, 2, 255709) high salaries will be reduced, the small ones also will go down.
('53', 129, 1, 3, 255774) The existing position is that while the big salaries are excessively high, the small ones are too low for the employees’ livelihood.
('53', 129, 1, 4, 255907) Under swaraj the low salaries will probably be raised, instead of being reduced.
('53', 129, 1, 5, 255988) In one way at any rate they will seem to have increased.
('53', 129, 1, 6, 256045) As a result of the reduction in salaries, there will be simplicity in people’s way of living.
('53', 129, 1, 7, 256139) The effect of this will be felt universally and the earners of small salaries will feel a sense of contentment.
('53', 129, 1, 8, 256251) The fear of increase in corruption expressed by the correspondent will not be shared by those who know the salary scales in Japan and other countries.
('53', 129, 1, 9, 256402) There is very little connection between corruption and the size of salaries.
('53', 129, 1, 10, 256479) When the consciousness of dharma spreads and people are inspired by a sense of public service, they do not demand or accept bribes.
('53', 129, 1, 11, 256611) Giving high salaries for fear of spread of corruption would be, as the saying goes, like killing the buffalo for its skin.
('53', 129, 1, 12, 256734) In other words, it means that for preventing a man from taking a bribe occasionally, he should be paid a permanent bribe in the form of a big salary!
('53', 129, 1, 13, 256884) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 26 7 1931

('53', 130, 4, 7, 257864) 131. LETTER TO V. L. PHADKE
('53', 130, 5, 8, 257892) July 26, 1931
('53', 130, 6, 9, 257906) BHAI MAMA, I understand what you say about Lalji.
('53', 130, 6, 10, 257956) I take this view, that we should not lose sight of the fact that he is an Antyaja and that, therefore, we should help him to earn his living.
('53', 130, 6, 11, 258098) An elephant should not judge an ant by the same standard which he applies to himself.
('53', 130, 6, 12, 258184) How many spinning wheels do you require?
('53', 130, 6, 13, 258225) In Bardoli they have been spinning on the new Gandiva wheel, which gives complete satisfaction.
('53', 130, 6, 14, 258321) Will that type do for you?
('53', 130, 6, 15, 258348) It is very cheap, and one can spin on it with as much speed as on the ordinary type.
('53', 130, 6, 16, 258433) Anyone who can operate it can certainly operate a wheel of any other type.
('53', 130, 7, 17, 258508) Blessings from BAPU [PS.] Write to me at Borsad, though today I am at Bardoli.

('53', 131, 2, 3, 258715) BARDOLI, July 26 1931
('53', 131, 3, 4, 258737) RAMNIKLAL, I got your letter.
('53', 131, 3, 5, 258767) I sent a prompt acknowledgement through Kishorelal yesterday.
('53', 131, 3, 6, 258829) As the complaint made against you at Bulsar had produced no effect on me, I had nothing to say to you.
('53', 131, 3, 7, 258932) However, I asked Godse and got from him whatever explanation I wanted.
('53', 131, 3, 8, 259003) I have nothing to say about your new activity also.
('53', 131, 3, 9, 259055) I know that, wherever you are, you will work honestly and carefully.
('53', 131, 3, 10, 259124) Moreover, at that place you have co workers who co operate with you and the other circumstances also are favourable.

('53', 131, 3, 12, 259301) That is enough for me.
('53', 131, 3, 13, 259324) As for other news, you must have learnt it from Kishorelal.

('53', 133, 2, 3, 261402) BARDOLI, July 6, 1931
('53', 133, 3, 4, 261424) LILAVATI, What a careless girl you are!
('53', 133, 3, 5, 261464) You don’t even mention your address!
('53', 133, 3, 6, 261501) There is nothing wrong in your having gone to Bombay.
('53', 133, 3, 7, 261555) No one is forced to remain in the Ashram.
('53', 133, 3, 8, 261597) Those only will stay on who voluntarily regard themselves as bound to it.
('53', 133, 3, 9, 261671) If a person’s body shakes with cold even in sunshine, he must be covered with a blanket.
('53', 133, 3, 10, 261760) By all means do help your brother.
('53', 133, 3, 11, 261795) Only remember that the help should be in a good cause.
('53', 133, 3, 12, 261850) Boldly ask your father for as much money as you may require for helping him.
('53', 133, 3, 13, 261927) Have no hesitation in accepting jewellery which your brother may pledge with you.
('53', 133, 3, 14, 262009) You may even get things in writing from him.
('53', 133, 3, 15, 262054) You should not mind if he gives you no interest.
('53', 133, 3, 16, 262103) Even if he is in a position to give any, do not accept more than 6 per cent.
('53', 133, 3, 17, 262180) Take care of your health.
('53', 133, 4, 18, 262206) Blessings from BAPU
('53', 133, 6, 19, 262226) I shall be in Borsad on Tuesday.

('53', 134, 9, 19, 263625) 139. LETTER TO PREMABEHN KANTAK
('53', 134, 10, 20, 263657) BARDOLI, July 26, 1931
('53', 134, 11, 21, 263680) PREMA, I got your letter.
('53', 134, 11, 22, 263706) You did not say how many years you had completed.
('53', 134, 11, 23, 263756) I admit that I ought to know.
('53', 134, 11, 24, 263786) But I am stupid in such matters.
('53', 134, 11, 25, 263819) Instead of saying, ‘May you live long’, I will say, ‘May you soon become free from the sway of passion, become pure in heart and an ideal worker.
('53', 134, 11, 26, 263965) May you succeed in your striving.’ You have made your letter rich in both colours.
('53', 134, 11, 27, 264048) It breathes frankness.
('53', 134, 11, 28, 264071) I like it.
('53', 134, 11, 29, 264082) But it is also full of anger and pride.
('53', 134, 11, 30, 264122) I will not, however, comment on it in detail.
('53', 134, 11, 31, 264168) I beg this of you.
('53', 134, 11, 32, 264187) If you have not
('53', 135, 0, 1, 264203) 136 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('53', 135, 1, 2, 264245) been writing up your diary, start doing so.
('53', 135, 1, 3, 264289) With whom did you get angry during the day, whether it was a child or a grown up personwhom did you beat, whom did you abuse?
('53', 135, 1, 4, 264415) I will be satisfied if you note down these details for my information.
('53', 135, 1, 5, 264486) As for the rest, you and Narandas may do what you think best.
('53', 135, 1, 6, 264548) I don’t wish to interfere with what you do.
('53', 135, 1, 7, 264592) It lies outside my sphere.
('53', 135, 1, 8, 264619) For one thing, I would not be able to judge about it; I would not be able to do justice to the parties concerned, nor have I the means of doing so.
('53', 135, 1, 9, 264767) I have assumed the role of your father and mother and, therefore, I can give you but one sided advice.
('53', 135, 1, 10, 264870) A satyagrahi, moreover, never demands justice.
('53', 135, 1, 11, 264917) Justice means “measure for measure”.
('53', 135, 1, 12, 264954) Satyagraha means truth evenagainst cunning, non violence against violence, forbearance against anger and love against hatred.
('53', 135, 1, 13, 265080) Where, in such satyagraha, is room for dealing out justice?
('53', 135, 2, 14, 265140) Blessings from BAPU [PS.] I reach Borsad on Tuesday.
('53', 135, 3, 15, 265193) [From Gujarati]
('53', 135, 4, 16, 265209) Bapuna Patro—5: Ku.

('53', 138, 3, 6, 269260) I have anyway ventured to write to Bhai Bahadurji.

('53', 138, 3, 11, 269587) The time is bound to come.
('53', 138, 3, 12, 269614) I thank you now and hope I can take work from you then.
