('53', 146, 5, 12, 281560) 160. FIVE HUNDRED RUPEE LIMIT
('53', 146, 6, 13, 281590) No item of the Fundamental Rights resolution 2 passed by the Congress at Karachi has come in for so much notice as the resolution limiting the salary of Government servants to not more than Rs. 500 per month or Rs. 6,000 per year.
('53', 146, 6, 14, 281821) Had we not been accustomed by this foreign Government to high salaries for servants in the Public Department, the limit of Rs. 500 would not have produced any shock.
('53', 146, 6, 15, 281987) There is no sanctity about the high ruling salaries.
('53', 146, 6, 16, 282040) All the 46 Congress Presidents and the 46 Congresses have mourned over the ever growing public expenditure both military and civil.
('53', 146, 6, 17, 282172) Many Presidents have laid special emphasis on the high salaries.
('53', 146, 6, 18, 282237) The Karachi Congress gave concrete shape to the half century old complaint.
('53', 146, 6, 19, 282313) The way to examine the justness of the Congress conclusion is to find the proportion between the salaries and the average income of India’s millions, and secondly to compare both with the salaries and the average income of other countries.
('53', 146, 6, 20, 282553) I have been trying to secure the figures for the principal countries of the world.
('53', 146, 6, 21, 282636) The readers of Young India have had the average income of the principal countries but not the salaries.
('53', 146, 6, 22, 282740) I have now before me some figures about the Japanese Public Service, both superior and subordinate.
('53', 146, 6, 23, 282840) Its Governor General
('53', 146, 7, 24, 282861) 1 The letter is not translated here.
('53', 146, 7, 25, 282898) The correspondent had described how Young men of the Marwari community were succeeding in resisting a wasteful custom.
('53', 146, 7, 26, 283017) 2 Vide “Resolaution on Fuandamental a Raights and Economic Changes”, 31 3 1931
('53', 147, 0, 1, 283096) 148 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('53', 147, 1, 2, 283138) gets less than Rs. 1,000 per month, that is to say, anything between Rs. 10,000 and 10,700 per year, a Governor less than Rs. 600 or Rs. 800 per month, the Secretariat staff anything between Rs. 150 and Rs. 500 per month, President of the Supreme Court less than Rs. 1,000 per month, other judges anything between Rs. 150 to Rs. 700 per month, Chief of Police slightly over Rs. 700 per month, subordinate services Rs. 250 to slightly over Rs. 300 per month, a Police Constable from Rs. 60 to Rs. 80 per month, a Police Sergeant from Rs. 70 to Rs. 80. The average daily income of the Japanese per head is about four annas.
('53', 147, 1, 3, 283760) Compared then with the Japan figures, the Rs. 500 limit put by the Congress is over generous.
('53', 147, 1, 4, 283854) But we have been told that the Japanese service is neither so incorruptible nor so efficient as the Indian.
('53', 147, 1, 5, 283962) I came across, the other day, a speech of Mr. Arno Pearse on the working of Japanese mills.
('53', 147, 1, 6, 284054) These mills are gigantic public corporations.
('53', 147, 1, 7, 284100) What is therefore true of them is likely to be true of the other Japanese departments.
('53', 147, 1, 8, 284187) Here is what Mr. Pearse has to say about Japanese business morality:
('53', 147, 2, 9, 284256) Do not believe the old saying that the word of the Chinese is his bond,
('53', 147, 3, 10, 284328) but not so that of the Japanese.
('53', 147, 3, 11, 284361) The modern Japanese will drive a bargain but
('53', 147, 4, 12, 284406) he will stick to it much more than the modern Chinese.
('53', 147, 4, 13, 284461) As to the excellence of Japanese organization, inventiveness, technical skill and industry Mr. Arno Pearse is most enthusiastic, and he claims to speak from personal experience.
('53', 147, 4, 14, 284639) The suggestion therefore that there is a necessary connection between efficiency or morality and high salaries is pure superstition.
('53', 147, 4, 15, 284772) What is true is, that neither morality nor efficiency can be sustained, if less than a living wage is paid to employees.
('53', 147, 4, 16, 284893) And no doubt the scale of living wage will differ to a certain extent with the mode of life of the class to which a person belongs.
('53', 147, 4, 17, 285025) But the mode of life is not an abstract term.
('53', 147, 4, 18, 285071) It is relative, and a man, who has surrounded himself with artificial wants and created conditions out of all proportion to the natural surroundings in which the people of his country live, can claim no exceptional cosideration because of his artificial mode of life.
('53', 147, 4, 19, 285339) Such people unfortunately we have in our midst.
('53', 147, 4, 20, 285387) They will naturally feel the pinch during the transition stage, but they will soon accommodate themselves to the new and natural condition when the maximum of Rs. 500 per month will cease to appear ludicrous as it does today.
('53', 147, 4, 21, 285613) Among the many disservices of the foreign rule will be counted the great disservice the foreign rulers have done by reason of their having
('53', 148, 0, 1, 285752) VOL. 53 : 2 JULY, 1931 12 OCTOBER, 1931 149
('53', 148, 1, 2, 285796) imported for this country wholly unnatural mode of life, and more or less imposed it on their immediate surroundings.
('53', 148, 1, 3, 285914) This importation and imposition have rendered the task of solvent administration most difficult, and we are finding it difficult today to adopt ourselves to the extreme depression that has overtaken the world.
('53', 148, 1, 4, 286124) Had we not had a top heavy administration, we would have been, owing to our geographical position, a country least affected by the universal depression, as today we are perhaps the most affected.
('53', 148, 1, 5, 286320) And it was because I felt in Nainital the seriousness of the artificial condition created for us, that I made an appeal 1 to the business men and professional classes that they should anticipate the future and remodel their lives so as to make it easy for all, when the burden of administration is taken over by the people, to take to the new life.
('53', 148, 1, 6, 286669) It would be wrong to entertain the idea, that whilst the public services would be paid in accordance with the natural condition of the country, professional and business men would continue a mode of life out of all correspondence with their surroundings.
('53', 148, 1, 7, 286924) They must voluntarily lead the way and set the example.
('53', 148, 1, 8, 286980) Young India, 30 7 1931
('53', 148, 2, 9, 287003) 161. NOTES
('53', 148, 3, 10, 287014) MUSHROOM COMPANIES
('53', 148, 4, 11, 287033) With the wave of swadeshi, bogus or mushroom companies and societies were bound to come into being.
('53', 148, 4, 12, 287133) Of these some were even fraudulent.
('53', 148, 4, 13, 287169) Some of the managers or agents of these societies were ‘wanted’ men.
('53', 148, 4, 14, 287238) Sardar Vallabhbhai spotted these and their transactions.
('53', 148, 4, 15, 287295) He saw that simple folk were being duped by these unscrupulous agents.
('53', 148, 4, 16, 287366) The plague was spreading in Gujarat.
('53', 148, 4, 17, 287403) He therefore issued instruction that Congress Committees should inquire into these mushroom organizations and warn the people against them.
('53', 148, 4, 18, 287543) He told them also not to hesitate to summon police aid if it became necessary.
('53', 148, 4, 19, 287622) Eventually through the Sardar’s effort a Vigilance Committee was formed with Sjt.
('53', 148, 4, 20, 287704) Thakorlal P. Thakor as president and Sjt.
('53', 148, 4, 21, 287746) Nandlal Shah as secretary with headquarters at Dhana Suthar’s Poal, Ahmedabad.
('53', 148, 4, 22, 287825) This committee has submitted a report showing how disastrous the consequences are likely to be, if energetic steps are
('53', 148, 5, 23, 287944) 1 Vide “Speech at Zaminadars Meeting, Naintal”, 23 5 1931
('53', 149, 0, 1, 288002) 150 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('53', 149, 1, 2, 288044) not taken in due time to expose the transactions of these organizations.
('53', 149, 1, 3, 288117) Jamshed Mehta is of opinion, that it is highly likely that poor people will be robbed of nearly one crore of rupees if these transactions are not stopped in time.
('53', 149, 1, 4, 288280) The Committee deplores that prominent Congressmen have unwittingly lent their names as directors to these companies.
('53', 149, 1, 5, 288397) People have, therefore, seeing Congressmen as directors, believed in the companies and run into the traps.
('53', 149, 1, 6, 288504) It does not follow that all these companies are fraudulent, but the Committee believes the majority of them to be unsound business propositions.
('53', 149, 1, 7, 288649) They cite in support of their conclusions eminent authorities to show that the promises made by these companies or societies could never be carried out for any length of time.
('53', 149, 1, 8, 288825) Twenty five years ago, this financial plague it was nothing less had broken out.
('53', 149, 1, 9, 288906) It died but not without leaving many a desolated home behind.
('53', 149, 1, 10, 288968) Public memory is short.
('53', 149, 1, 11, 288992) Nearly a generation has gone by.
('53', 149, 1, 12, 289025) And the plague has broken out again in virulent form.
('53', 149, 1, 13, 289079) There are nearly 100 such societies in India of which nearly 40 are to be found in Gujarat.
('53', 149, 1, 14, 289171) It is too much to expect these societies to wind up their affairs, but it is not too much to expect the numerous Congress Committees to acquaint themselves with the existing situation and instruct the public accordirgly.
('53', 149, 1, 15, 289392) The Committee will gladly furnish information to all inquirers.
('53', 149, 1, 16, 289456) That is its special function.
('53', 149, 2, 17, 289486) SALT CONCESSION IN THE PUNJAB
('53', 149, 3, 18, 289516) With reference to the withdrawal of the salt concession in the Punjab a correspondent from Mianwali writes: 1
('53', 149, 4, 19, 289626) I have read your note 2 regarding the collection of salt near Kalabagh mines in the Mianwali district, and find, that the information upon which the note is based is not the whole truth, and presents an exaggerated picture of what really happened at Kalabagh.
('53', 149, 4, 20, 289886) The real facts are as follows:
('53', 149, 5, 21, 289917) The permission to the people to collect salt in terms of the Delhi Pact was kept secret from the public residing in the vicinity of the Kalabagh mines for sufficiently long time and it was not without some stir in the people, that the order was made known to them, and they were allowed to collect salt.
('53', 149, 5, 22, 290221) This permission remained in force for only 5 or 6 days, and during that period the people residing in the vicinity collected some salt, and I would frankly admit that certain people through sheer ignorance collected more than they required
('53', 149, 6, 23, 290461) 1 Only extracts are reproduced here.
('53', 149, 6, 24, 290498) 2 Vide “Notes”, 16 7 1931 , sub title, “Salt Concession”.
('53', 150, 0, 1, 290556) VOL. 53 : 2 JULY, 1931 12 OCTOBER, 1931 151
('53', 150, 1, 2, 290600) or were allowed to do under the terms of the Pact; but the number of such cases was very small, and this could be remedied by giving simple warnings to the people, or making it known to them by beat of drum, etc., that they could not collect more salt than what was allowed to them under the Pact.
('53', 150, 1, 3, 290898) But I regret to bring it to your notice, that the authorities did not do anything of the sort, and at once issued a proclamation by beat of drum, that the people collecting salt would be prosecuted, with the result that the people at once stopped collecting any more salt.
('53', 150, 2, 4, 291171) In the circumstances, I would ask you on behalf of the people of the ilaqa to help them.
('53', 150, 2, 5, 291260) If the facts are as set forth by the correspondent, it is a clear case for relief.
('53', 150, 2, 6, 291343) I shall gladly bring the matter to the notice of the Government of India.
('53', 150, 3, 7, 291417) THE REAL SAFEGUARD
('53', 150, 4, 8, 291436) The Spectator of 4th instant has a reasoned editorial headed “India and the British Commonwealth”.
('53', 150, 4, 9, 291535) Its sub heading is “The Real Safeguard”.
('53', 150, 4, 10, 291576) This is its last paragraph:
('53', 150, 5, 11, 291604) We shall end on the note on which we began.
('53', 150, 5, 12, 291648) Win the goodwill and friendship of the peoples of India, and think only how we can help India to achieve the splendid destiny which we think could be hers, and we shall have created a safeguard which all the friction mongers will be powerless to disturb.
('53', 150, 5, 13, 291903) It is a bold policy and requires men of vision to pull it through.
('53', 150, 5, 14, 291970) Are there enough of them in Great Britain today?
('53', 150, 5, 15, 292019) I should vary the question and ask: Are there enough civilians in India today who have vision enough to win the goodwill and the friendship of the people of India?
('53', 150, 5, 16, 292183) The Editor has ‘peoples’, I know.
('53', 150, 5, 17, 292217) But though we may quarrel and murder one another, though we have numerous languages and still more numerous dialects, India is geographically one, and we are and have been only one people.
('53', 150, 5, 18, 292406) Those speaking the same language have been known before now to belong to different nationalities, and those that have fought among themselves like dogs have been known to belong to one nation.
('53', 150, 5, 19, 292599) The fact is that oneness of speech and absence of internal feuds are no indispensable test of nationality.
('53', 150, 5, 20, 292706) Young India, 30 7 1931
('53', 151, 0, 1, 292729) 152 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('53', 151, 1, 2, 292771) 162. FOUL PLAY 1
('53', 151, 2, 3, 292788) The worst feature of the attempted assassination of Sir Ernest Hotson the Acting Governor of the Bombay Presidency was, that the act was done by a student of the College which had invited His Excellency when as its honoured guest he was being shown round the College premises.
('53', 151, 2, 4, 293065) It was as though a host was injuring his guest under his own roof.
('53', 151, 2, 5, 293132) The canon recognized throughout the world is that the deadliest enemy, when he is under one’s roof as guest, is entitled to protection from all harm.
('53', 151, 2, 6, 293282) The act of the student was therefore essentially foul play without a single redeeming feature.
('53', 151, 2, 7, 293377) For the Acting Governor it was a providential escape, and it was fortunate for India and more so for the student world.
('53', 151, 2, 8, 293497) I tender my congratulations to Sir Ernest Hotson as also to the nation.
('53', 151, 2, 9, 293569) It would be well if the believers in violence will take a lesson from this happy tragedy—happy because no one has suffered but the assailant.
('53', 151, 2, 10, 293711) Has he suffered, is he suffering, or is he deluding himself with the belief that he is a hero?
('53', 151, 2, 11, 293806) Let this event be a warning for the students.
('53', 151, 2, 12, 293852) After all a school or a college is a sanctuary where there should be nothing that is base or unholy.
('53', 151, 2, 13, 293953) Schools and colleges are factories for the making of character.
('53', 151, 2, 14, 294017) Parents send their boys and girls to them so that they may become good men and women It would.
('53', 151, 2, 15, 294112) be an evil day for the nation, if every student is suspected as a would be assassin capable of any treachery.
('53', 151, 2, 16, 294222) The Bhagat Singh worship has done and is doing incalculable harm to the country.
('53', 151, 2, 17, 294303) Bhagat Singh’s character about which I had heard so much from reliable sources, the intimate connection I had with the attempts that were being made to secure commutation of the death sentence carried me away and identified me with the cautious and balanced resolution passed at Karachi.
('53', 151, 2, 18, 294591) 2 I regret to observe that the caution has been thrown to the winds.
('53', 151, 2, 19, 294660) The deed itself is being worshipped as if it was worthy of emulation.
('53', 151, 2, 20, 294730) The result is goondaism and degradation wherever this mad worship is being performed.
('53', 151, 2, 21, 294816) The Congress is a power in the land, but I warn Congressmen
('53', 151, 3, 22, 294876) 1 Vide also “Madness”, 26 7 1931 2 Vide “Resolution on Bhagat Singh and Comrades”
('53', 152, 0, 1, 294958) VOL. 53 : 2 JULY, 1931 12 OCTOBER, 1931 153
('53', 152, 1, 2, 295002) that it will soon lose all its charm if they betray their trust and encourage the Bhagat Singh cult whether in thought, word or deed.
('53', 152, 1, 3, 295136) If the majority do not believe in the Congress policy of non violence and truth, let them have the first article altered.
('53', 152, 1, 4, 295258) Let us understand the distinction between policy and creed.
('53', 152, 1, 5, 295318) A policy may be changed, a creed cannot.
('53', 152, 1, 6, 295359) But either is as good as the other whilst it is held.
('53', 152, 1, 7, 295413) Those therefore who hold non violence only as a policy may not, without exposing themselves to the charge of dishonourable conduct, use the Congress membership as a cover for violence.
('53', 152, 1, 8, 295598) I cannot.
('53', 152, 1, 9, 295608) get rid of the conviction, that the greatest obstacle to our progress towards swaraj is our want of faith in our policy.
('53', 152, 1, 10, 295729) Let this fortunate failure of attempted assassination open our eyes.
('53', 152, 1, 11, 295798) ‘But look at the Governor’s black record.
('53', 152, 1, 12, 295840) Does not the doer himself say he shot because of the Sholapur deeds, because he superseded an Indian and became Acting Governor?’—some hasty youths or even grown up people will argue.
('53', 152, 1, 13, 296024) My answer is: We knew all this when in 1920 we settled the Congress policy of non violence and truth.
('53', 152, 1, 14, 296126) There were, within our knowledge at the time, deeds much blacker than his worst enemies have imputed to Sir Ernest Hotson.
('53', 152, 1, 15, 296249) The Congress deliberately and after full debate came to the conclusion in 1920, that the answer to the vile and violent deeds of the Government was not greater violence on our part, but that it was profitable for us to answer violence with non violence and vileness with truth.
('53', 152, 1, 16, 296527) The Congress saw further, that the worst administrators were not bad inherently, but that they were a fruit of the system of which they were willing or unwilling victims.
('53', 152, 1, 17, 296698) We saw too that the system corrupted even the best from among ourselves.
('53', 152, 1, 18, 296771) And so we evolved a policy of non violent action that should destroy the system.
('53', 152, 1, 19, 296852) Ten years’ experience has shown that the policy of non violence and truth though followed half heartedly has answered phenomenally well, and that we are very near the harbour.
('53', 152, 1, 20, 297028) The record of Sir Ernest Hotson, however bad it may be, is wholly irrelevant and can in no way extenuate, much less excuse the double crime of attempted assassination and treachery.
('53', 152, 1, 21, 297210) The reported hostile demonstration by some students has made the ugly affair uglier still.
('53', 152, 1, 22, 297301) I hope that the students and the teachers throughout India will seriously bestir themselves and put the educational house in order.
('53', 152, 1, 23, 297433) And in my opinion it is the peremptory duty of the forthcoming meeting of the All India Congress Committee to condemn the treacherous outrage and reiterate its policy in unequivocal terms.
('53', 153, 0, 1, 297622) 154 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('53', 153, 1, 2, 297664) One word to the Government and the administrators.
('53', 153, 1, 3, 297715) Retribution and repression will not do.
('53', 153, 1, 4, 297755) These violent outbreaks are portents.
('53', 153, 1, 5, 297793) They may judge those who are immediately guilty.
('53', 153, 1, 6, 297842) But they can deal with the disease only by dealing with the cause.
('53', 153, 1, 7, 297909) If they have neither the will nor the courage to do so, let them leave the rest to the nation.
('53', 153, 1, 8, 298004) It has progressed past repression and retribution.
('53', 153, 1, 9, 298055) It will deal with violence in its own ranks in its own way.
('53', 153, 1, 10, 298115) Any Government action in excess of the demands of the common law will simply intensify the madness, and make the task of believers in non violence more difficult than it already is.
('53', 153, 2, 11, 298297) Young India, 30 7 1931
('53', 153, 3, 12, 298320) 163. CLOTH MERCHANTS AND KHADI
('53', 153, 4, 13, 298351) Whilst millowners have, to a certain extent, ceased to compete unfairly with khadi, cloth merchants seem to pay no heed to the Congress appeal not to injure genuine khadi by selling spurious khadi as if it was genuine.
('53', 153, 4, 14, 298570) A firm in Surat had the hardihood the other day to send its samples of spurious khadi to a khadi depot in Bombay.
('53', 153, 4, 15, 298684) I have the sample before me.
('53', 153, 4, 16, 298713) It is clearly mill khadi, but it is sold to the public as genuine article.
('53', 153, 4, 17, 298788) I have the name too of the firm that has been guilty of such dishonest and unpatriotic practice.
('53', 153, 4, 18, 298885) But I do not propose just yet to give the name to the public.
('53', 153, 4, 19, 298947) The remedy however lies in the hands of the purchasers of khadi—not to buy khadi that does not bear the A.I.S.A. stamp and to buy from a shop certified by the A.I.S.A. wherever such a shop is to be found.
('53', 153, 4, 20, 299152) Intelligent buyers should really find no difficulty in distinguishing genuine from spurious khadi.
('53', 153, 5, 21, 299251) Young India, 30 7 1931
('53', 153, 6, 22, 299274) 164. LANCASHIRE V. JAPAN
('53', 153, 7, 23, 299299) H. P. Mody writes: 1
('53', 153, 8, 24, 299320) I have read with great interest the brief announcement you have made in connection with the rumour that you might visit Lancashire when you go to England for the Round Table Conference.
('53', 153, 8, 25, 299506) I hope you will do so, and will give British manufacturers an opportunity of understanding your position and that
('53', 153, 9, 26, 299620) 1 Only extracts are reproduced here.
('53', 154, 0, 1, 299657) VOL. 53 : 2 JULY, 1931 12 OCTOBER, 1931 155
('53', 154, 1, 2, 299701) of the Congress.
('53', 154, 1, 3, 299718) My view of the matter is that while it is of national importance that the requirements of the people of India should be met by cloth manufactured or made in the country, foreign cloth cannot be kept out unless and until the manufacturing capacity of India is considerably increased.
('53', 154, 1, 4, 300001) The problem then resolves itself into one of ways and means of promoting the indigenous industry.
('53', 154, 1, 5, 300099) One of the greatest obstacles in the way of such expansion is the organized competition which the industry is experiencing from Japan.
('53', 154, 1, 6, 300234) It may be that .
('53', 154, 1, 7, 300251) the competitive capacity of India may develop to an extent which would do away with the necessity of special measures of protection; but until that stage is reached, India must pursue a vigorous tariff policy.
('53', 154, 2, 8, 300461) And if I understand the purport of your recent announcement correctly, your attitude might be, that while you would not have a yard of Lancashire or any other foreign cloth in this country, if you could help it, you would not in certain circumstances mind Lancashire deriving some advantage over Japan owing to the special measures which it might be necessary to take to meet Japanese competition.
('53', 154, 2, 9, 300859) Will you kindly let me know if I have understood your position correctly?
('53', 154, 2, 10, 300933) My position is clear.
('53', 154, 2, 11, 300955) 1. If I had my way, India would be clothed in khadi to the exclusion of all other cloth even made in indigenous mills.
('53', 154, 2, 12, 301074) 2. Whilst India is unwilling (there is no question of inability) to manufacture all the khadi she needs, I should allow indigenous mill cloth to supplement it.
('53', 154, 2, 13, 301234) 3. There is picketing of foreign cloth because foreign cloth competes with both khadi and Indian mill cloth.
('53', 154, 2, 14, 301343) It is irrelevant, whether the competition is fair or unfair in the sense whether the cloth manufactured in the respective countries is fairly produced and brought here or not.
('53', 154, 2, 15, 301519) 4. If there was no competition, and if it became clear that some foreign cloth had to come to India, and if England was in partnership with India freed, I would give preference to England over all other countries.
('53', 154, 2, 16, 301733) But my belief is, that when India becomes free, she will manufacture within a short time enough khadi for her wants, supplementing it during the transition with indigenous mill cloth.
('53', 154, 2, 17, 301917) Young India, 30 7 1931
('53', 155, 0, 1, 301940) 156 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('53', 155, 1, 2, 301982) 165. WHAT WE CAN DO TODAY
('53', 155, 2, 3, 302008) The much criticized Fundamental Rights Resolution of the Karachi Congress has twenty items.
('53', 155, 2, 4, 302100) Item one has nine sub clauses.
('53', 155, 2, 5, 302131) I have just glanced through the innocent resolution, and I have made what is for me an amazing discovery which I am impatient to share with the reader.
('53', 155, 2, 6, 302283) I find that fifteen out of twenty we can enforce today more or less fully and five sub clauses of item one can be similarly treated.
('53', 155, 2, 7, 302416) Here they are for the convenience of the reader: 1
('53', 155, 3, 8, 302467) Those 2 omitted have reference to the things that can only be done by the legislature.
('53', 155, 3, 9, 302554) They are: Freedom of association and combination; Freedom of speech and Press; Right to bear arms; Right of personal liberty and possession of property without executive interference.
('53', 155, 3, 10, 302738) Religious neutrality by the State; Removal of salt duty; Control of currency for the benefit of the people; Control of key industries etc.
('53', 155, 3, 11, 302877) The reader will see that these last are really less vital than those we can do now without State assistance.
('53', 155, 3, 12, 302986) It will be seen further, that if we succeed in doing the things mentioned in the first list, those mentioned in the second will follow as a matter of course.
('53', 155, 3, 13, 303144) In other words national control of the Government is mostly dependent upon ourselves.
('53', 155, 3, 14, 303230) Conversely if we do not do the things we ought to today, when the power comes to us we shall be found unready for them.
('53', 155, 3, 15, 303350) Thus if we do not respect one another’s religions, do not treat women as absolute equals, do not remove untouchability, do not dot villages with free primary schools, do not honestly manage the Congress suffrage which is practically adult suffrage, do not treat labour decently, do not spare children factory labour, do not encourage labour unions, do not reduce agricultural rents, do not pay for
('53', 155, 4, 16, 303748) 1 Not reproduced here; the Clauses cited were: I (c), (d), (e), (f), (g), 3 to 12, 14 to 16 and 20; vide also “Resolution on Fuandamental Rights and Economic Changes”, 31 3 1931 2 Sub clauses (a), (b), (h) and (i) of Clause I and Clauses 2,13,17,18 and 19
('53', 156, 0, 1, 304004) VOL. 53 : 2 JULY, 1931 12 OCTOBER, 1931 157
('53', 156, 1, 2, 304048) national purposes a fixed percentage of our incomes, do not voluntarily reduce our salaries or set apart for a national purpose more than the minimum required, do not abjure foreign cloth and drink and do not reduce the heavy rates of interest which even respectable people charge, I prophecy that the State will be powerless to impose these reforms on an unwilling people.
('53', 156, 1, 3, 304422) A popular State can never act in advance of public opinion.
('53', 156, 1, 4, 304482) If it goes against it, it will be destroyed.
('53', 156, 1, 5, 304527) Democracy disciplined and enlightened is the finest thing in the world.
('53', 156, 1, 6, 304599) A democracy prejudiced, ignorant, superstitious will land itself in chaos and may be self destroyed.
('53', 156, 1, 7, 304700) The Fundamental Rights Resolution is not premature.
('53', 156, 1, 8, 304752) It is not so formidable as it reads, if the nation is prepared, as I hold it is prepared, for orderly self government.
('53', 156, 1, 9, 304871) Let every Congressman therefore think out a programme of work for himself or herself in terms of the items first mentioned.
('53', 156, 1, 10, 304995) We need not be overpowered by the list.
('53', 156, 1, 11, 305035) Each one may take up the item and the area of work for which he or she is best fitted.
('53', 156, 1, 12, 305122) Needless to say the full working of the items requires the co operation of capitalists, landowners and the like.
('53', 156, 1, 13, 305235) They will all fall in line if a good beginning is made.
('53', 156, 2, 14, 305291) Young India, 30 7 1931

('53', 159, 6, 9, 308260) 171. INTERVIEW TO THE PRESS
('53', 159, 7, 10, 308288) July 31, 1931
('53', 159, 8, 11, 308302) Asked about the situation in Borsad and Bardoli, Mr. Gandhi said: So far as Borsad is concerned, the Collector and I have exchanged communications after a prolonged conversation, but I am unable to give them to the public.
('53', 159, 8, 12, 308525) I am, however, hoping that most, if not all, the outstanding questions will be adjusted fairly and satisfac torily.
('53', 159, 8, 13, 308641) So far as Bardoli is concerned, communications are still going on with the Collector, but I am not without hope as to the final result.
('53', 159, 9, 14, 308777) Asked whether it was true, as reported in the Press, that the situation in U.P. was unlikely to interfere with his participation in the Round Table Conference,
('53', 159, 10, 15, 308937) Mr. Gandhi said: I hope the newspaper report about the U.P. situation is well warranted.
('53', 159, 10, 16, 309026) I have not yet heard directly from Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru.
('53', 159, 11, 17, 309086) Asked whether he could now say if his going to the R.T.C. was in any way certain, Mr. Gandhi said: It is more than I can say, but I can say that I am trying my very best.
('53', 159, 12, 18, 309257) Asked his opinion about the article in The Manchester Guardian, a summary of which was published in the papers, Mr. Gandhi said: I have seen the Press summary of the Manchester Guardian article.
('53', 159, 12, 19, 309452) I can reciprocate much of what is said there.
('53', 159, 12, 20, 309498) Past experience however shows that one ought not to treat summaries as if they were the whole.
('53', 159, 12, 21, 309593) Subject to this caution, I can say that, if I do go to London, I shall not disappoint the hope entertained by Manchester Guardian.
('53', 160, 0, 1, 309724) VOL. 53 : 2 JULY, 1931 12 OCTOBER, 1931 161
('53', 160, 1, 2, 309768) So far as I am concerned, the embargo on foreign cloth is not and cannot be by way of reparation.
('53', 160, 1, 3, 309866) I dislike this repeated emphasis on British cloth.
('53', 160, 1, 4, 309917) British cloth is not objected to because it is British.
('53', 160, 1, 5, 309973) It is foreign cloth that is being attacked and in this attack if it becomes more successful, Japan would be the heaviest loser and not Lancashire.
('53', 160, 2, 6, 310120) Asked why he himself did not go to the North West Frontier Province, as desired, but sent his son Devdas Gandhi, Gandhiji said: I did not go to the North West Frontier Province in order to avoid any possible embarrassment to the Government.
('53', 160, 3, 7, 310361) Asked whether he would make any statement on the recent assassination of Mr. Garlick, District and Sessions Judge in Calcutta, Mr. Gandhi said: Coming as it does so soon after the attempted assassination of the Acting Governor of Bombay, it has very naturally caused stir and public resentment.
('53', 160, 3, 8, 310656) I have no doubt the coming All India Congress Committee meeting will deal with the situation.
('53', 160, 3, 9, 310750) I am more than ever convinced that every such murder does infinite injury to the cause of the country’s freedom.
('53', 160, 3, 10, 310863) I wish young men who are resorting to the mad methods of violence would realize the serious and mischievous consequences of their mad deeds.

('53', 161, 1, 2, 311850) 173. LETTER TO R. M. MAXWELL
('53', 161, 2, 3, 311879) AHMEDABAD, August 1, 1931
('53', 161, 3, 4, 311905) DEAR MR. MAXWELL, I thank you for your letter of 28th ult.
('53', 161, 3, 5, 311964) regarding the cases of Pathan Abdul Ghaffar Khan and his son.
('53', 161, 3, 6, 312026) Though the information that you give me about them is instructive, the suspicion haunts me that their black record came to the surface and became relevant only when and because they took an active part in the civil disobedience movement.
('53', 161, 3, 7, 312264) Whether they received money for the part they played I am not aware.
('53', 161, 3, 8, 312333) You will be also interested to know that men with blacker records are at the present moment in the Government service and district officials have been good enough and frank enough to tell me that though they knew that these men had such a record, the Government could not afford to ignore the services that they had rendered to them at a critical time.
('53', 161, 3, 9, 312686) Nor am I able to understand the reasoning behind the decision.
('53', 161, 3, 10, 312749) If these men are such dangerous characters, will they cease to be so outside Bombay?
('53', 161, 3, 11, 312834) After all they are in British governed territories.
('53', 161, 3, 12, 312886) They have not been put outside the British limits.
('53', 161, 4, 13, 312937) Yours sincerely,
('53', 161, 5, 14, 312954) From a photostat: S.N. 17416
('53', 161, 6, 15, 312983) 174. LETTER TO K. B. BHADRAPUR
('53', 161, 7, 16, 313014) AHMEDABAD, August 1, 1931
('53', 161, 8, 17, 313040) DEAR MR. BHADRAPUR,
('53', 161, 9, 18, 313060) I now enclose herewith a report prepared by Sjt.
('53', 161, 9, 19, 313109) Mahadev Desai on the expert report prepared for you about the condition of Ras Khatedars.
('53', 161, 9, 20, 313199) This is how this report was prepared.
('53', 161, 9, 21, 313237) I sent Sjt.
('53', 161, 9, 22, 313249) Chhaganlal Joshi with Sjt.
('53', 161, 9, 23, 313276) Ravishanker to Ras to meet the Khatedars.
('53', 161, 9, 24, 313318) They were there practically a whole day.
('53', 161, 9, 25, 313359) They brought the results to Sjt.
('53', 161, 9, 26, 313392) Mahadev Desai who had previously conducted an exhaustive inquiry into the Ras cases and prepared an account of which an abstract was supplied to Mr. Perry.
('53', 161, 9, 27, 313548) A second exhaustive report was
('53', 162, 0, 1, 313579) VOL. 53 : 2 JULY, 1931 12 OCTOBER, 1931 163
('53', 162, 1, 2, 313623) prepared as a result of discussion with Mr. Perry which it became unnecessary to give to him as there was a sporting settlement.
('53', 162, 1, 3, 313752) This report deals with the crops of Khatedars and will be found annexed to the report sent herewith.
('53', 162, 1, 4, 313853) The present one is prepared in the light of these reports.
('53', 162, 1, 5, 313912) You will see that Schedule F of your report is the most important of all because it contains an examination of 126 Khatedars.
('53', 162, 1, 6, 314038) The annexure to the enclosed report is a complete answer to Schedule F. The other schedules relate to only 66 Khatedars.
('53', 162, 1, 7, 314159) The enclosed report deals with these and it appears to me a conclusive answer.
('53', 162, 1, 8, 314238) In the circumstances I have not the heart to ask any of the Khatedars to pay anything more.
('53', 162, 1, 9, 314330) As I told you, even the Rs. 500 was not exacted by me without some effort.
('53', 162, 1, 10, 314405) The reason is that the Ras Khatedars have been universally admitted to have been the heaviest losers.
('53', 162, 1, 11, 314507) But as I have told you already this does not mean that the Khatedars have no credit.
('53', 162, 1, 12, 314592) On the contrary their credit stands perhaps higher than before.
('53', 162, 1, 13, 314656) But it is common cause between the Government and the Congress that these civil resisters are not to be expected to borrow money in order to pay the revenue dues, whether current or arrears.
('53', 162, 1, 14, 314847) I enclose herewith the schedules you very kindly entrusted to my care.
('53', 162, 2, 15, 314918) Yours sincerely K. B. BHADRAPUR, ESQ.

('53', 163, 5, 12, 315942) 177. LETTER TO C. RAJAGOPALACHARI
('53', 163, 6, 13, 315976) AHMEDABAD, August 1, 1931 I have your telegram from Rangoon.
('53', 163, 6, 14, 316037) You are cruel.
('53', 163, 6, 15, 316052) You say nothing about what happened to your daughter, whether you were leaving her in Rangoon or taking her.
('53', 163, 6, 16, 316161) But that is just like you, and I may not grumble.
('53', 163, 6, 17, 316211) Nothing is certain as yet about my going, but I might have to decide upon going even at the last moment.
('53', 163, 6, 18, 316316) I would therefore like you to come and see me wherever I am even after the All India Congress Committee meeting.
('53', 163, 6, 19, 316429) You can leave me after the 15th whether I stay or whether I go.
('53', 163, 6, 20, 316493) If you accept my proposal, I would then discuss with you your suggestion before adopting it.
('53', 163, 6, 21, 316586) I refer to the suggestion about giving an intimation to the Central Government that wherever picketing is unjustly interfered with, we might have to resist this interference with civil disobedience.
('53', 163, 7, 22, 316785) C. RAJAGOPALACHARI GANDHI ASHRAM TIRUCHENGODU (S. INDIA)

('53', 164, 1, 2, 316915) 178. MY NOTES
('53', 164, 2, 3, 316929) THE BENGAL MURDER 1
('53', 164, 3, 4, 316949) The murder of Judge Garlick coming, as it did, so close upon the assault on the Bombay Governor has naturally caused a great sensation.
('53', 164, 3, 5, 317085) Such assassinations make us hang our heads in shame.
('53', 164, 3, 6, 317138) They bring swaraj no nearer.
('53', 164, 3, 7, 317167) Nor do they help us to get better justice or reduce the prevailing hatred and bitterness.
('53', 164, 3, 8, 317257) The British have never run away for fear and are not likely to do so.
('53', 164, 3, 9, 317327) Such acts do not increase our capacity for constructive work or infuse greater fearlessness in the people.
('53', 164, 3, 10, 317434) The immediate consequences, as we see, are the very opposite.
('53', 164, 3, 11, 317496) For what can one blame Judge Garlick?
('53', 164, 3, 12, 317534) No matter how many persons he sentenced to death, he acted through no malicein doing so.
('53', 164, 3, 13, 317623) Whatever he did he did through a sense of duty.
('53', 164, 3, 14, 317671) Why should he be punished for that?
('53', 164, 3, 15, 317707) The assassin has lost his own life, but he has left behind him a legacy of suffering for others.
('53', 164, 3, 16, 317804) It will not help us in any way to cite the example of assassinations in other countries.
('53', 164, 3, 17, 317893) The evidence before our eyes should be enough to turn us away from the policy of violence.
('53', 164, 3, 18, 317984) That policy will spell our destruction.
('53', 164, 3, 19, 318024) In India we wish to bring about an awakening among the millions of our poor countrymen, for which thousands of us will have to labour ceaselessly and organize constructive work.
('53', 164, 3, 20, 318202) Can assassinations make any contribution to that end?
('53', 164, 3, 21, 318256) They not only cannot, but on the contrary they positively obstruct such efforts.
('53', 164, 3, 22, 318337) Will not the terrorists see this and desist from their activities?
('53', 164, 4, 23, 318404) SATYAGRAHA AND MORVI
('53', 164, 5, 24, 318425) Men from Kathiawar have been showering criticism on my article 2 regarding Morvi.
('53', 164, 5, 25, 318507) Some of the critics are sincere public servants.
('53', 164, 5, 26, 318556) Their enthusiasm is sincere but, I think, ignorant.
('53', 164, 5, 27, 318608) I have given no certificate to Morvi, and in any case who am I to give one?
('53', 164, 5, 28, 318684) Of course, I praised the ruler for what I thought his graceful action.
('53', 164, 5, 29, 318755) That does not, of course, condone the misdeeds of the State authorities, some of which I know and some I may not.
('53', 164, 5, 30, 318869) But that article was not intended to apportion blame, and hence it did not discuss the
('53', 164, 6, 31, 318956) 1 Vide also “The Garlick Murder”, 6 8 1931 2 Vide “Morbi’s Lesson to Satyagrahis”, 19 7 1931.
('53', 165, 0, 1, 319050) 166 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('53', 165, 1, 2, 319092) question whether or not any atrocities on satyagrahis were committed and, if so, how cruel they were.
('53', 165, 1, 3, 319194) Even now I hold the opinion that the satyagrahi march on Morvi was hasty, to say the least.
('53', 165, 1, 4, 319286) That opinion was not based on any one sided evidence; if it was based on any evidence, then it was based on the admissions made by the satyagrahis themselves.
('53', 165, 1, 5, 319445) If the first step was wrong, then, not only should there be no objection to admitting as much, but it should be regarded one’s duty to do so.
('53', 165, 1, 6, 319587) Moreover, it is a satyagrahi’s duty to regard his own errors as big as a mountain though they might be as small as a mole, and another’s as small as a mole though they might be as big as a mountain.
('53', 165, 1, 7, 319786) Such an attitude comes naturally to a satyagrahi and is not the result of a conscious effort.
('53', 165, 2, 8, 319880) ‘HARIJANA’
('53', 165, 3, 9, 319891) I asked serious readers of Navajivan to suggest to me a substitute for the word ‘Antyaja’.
('53', 165, 3, 10, 319982) One of the three or four suggestions received has appealed to me.
('53', 165, 3, 11, 320048) Shri Jagannath Desai writes from Rajkot: 1
('53', 165, 4, 12, 320091) Thus the word is not new, but a beautiful one already used by the father of Gujarati poetry.
('53', 165, 4, 13, 320184) Moreover, as used by him, the word ‘Harijana’ can also mean men of God who are abandoned by society.
('53', 165, 4, 14, 320285) The third advantage of that word is that, probably, Antyaja brethren would lovingly accept that name and try to cultivate the virtues which it connotes.
('53', 165, 4, 15, 320438) Following the example of Kaliparaj becoming Raniparaj, may the Antyajas become Harijana both in name and nature.
('53', 165, 5, 16, 320551) FOREIGN TOYS AND CRACKERS
('53', 165, 6, 17, 320577) The leader of the Surat Children’s Army writes: 2
('53', 165, 7, 18, 320627) Personally, I approve of the boycott of both these.
('53', 165, 7, 19, 320679) Let the children carry out truly peaceful picketing.
('53', 165, 7, 20, 320732) If they secure the consent of the parents, that will be an education for the latter too.

('53', 166, 0, 1, 321017) VOL. 53 : 2 JULY, 1931 12 OCTOBER, 1931 167
('53', 166, 1, 2, 321061) PATIENCE AND PURITY OF CONDUCT
('53', 166, 2, 3, 321092) A correspondent writes: 1
('53', 166, 3, 4, 321118) Nature has not revealed to us any method of immediately solving all our problems.
('53', 166, 3, 5, 321200) But that does not mean that [in an instance like this] there is no remedy.
('53', 166, 3, 6, 321275) The remedy is patience and right conduct.
('53', 166, 3, 7, 321317) One’s sister or brother in law or friend, whoever the person concerned, is sure ultimately to yield to our faith.
('53', 166, 4, 8, 321431) A SILENT WORKER
('53', 166, 5, 9, 321447) A large number of Indians live in Burma and make a living there.
('53', 166, 5, 10, 321512) Some of them also devote themselves to public service.
('53', 166, 5, 11, 321567) One such man was Vrajlal Mehta, whose death occurred a few days ago.
('53', 166, 5, 12, 321636) He carried on Congress work there, though we here have little knowledge of it.
('53', 166, 5, 13, 321715) He was a well to do man and contributed something to every fund and persuaded others to do the same.
('53', 166, 5, 14, 321816) But he sought no credit for doing this.
('53', 166, 5, 15, 321856) He was devoted to the poor, had full faith in the propagation of khadi and represented there the All India Spinners’ Association.
('53', 166, 5, 16, 321986) Those who seek no honour or reward but do service for its own sake deserve the highest honour.
('53', 166, 5, 17, 322081) Shri Vrajlal Mehta was a man of this kind.
('53', 166, 5, 18, 322124) We offer our compliments to his family for having produced such a person.
('53', 166, 6, 19, 322198) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 2 8 1931
('53', 166, 7, 20, 322234) 179. SPEECH AT AHMEDABAD 2
('53', 166, 8, 21, 322261) August 2, 1931 I must say that the service of the so called untouchables does not rank with me as in any way subordinate to any kind of political work.
('53', 166, 8, 22, 322413) 3 Just a moment ago I met two missionary friends who drew the same distinction and therefore came in for some gentle rebuke from
('53', 166, 9, 23, 322542) 1 The letter is not translated here.
('53', 166, 9, 24, 322579) The correspondent had found it impossible to convert his relations and friends to swadeshi.
('53', 166, 9, 25, 322671) 2 At the opening of Sir Chinubhai’s family temple to the untouchables.
('53', 166, 9, 26, 322742) This is a condensed summary by Mahadev Desai which appeared under the caption “Essentially a Reformer”.
('53', 166, 9, 27, 322846) 3 Sir Chinubhai had remarked that ‘whilst Gandhiji was preoccupied with things of great political importance, he should not have been asked to find time for a comparatively small thing’.
('53', 167, 0, 1, 323033) 168 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('53', 167, 1, 2, 323075) I suggested to them that my work of social reform was in no way less than or subordinate to political work.
('53', 167, 1, 3, 323183) The fact is, that when I saw that to a certain extent my social work would be impossible without the help of political work, I took to the latter and only to the extent that it helped the former.
('53', 167, 1, 4, 323379) I must therefore confess that work of social reform or self purification of this nature is a hundred times dearer to me than what is called purely political work.
('53', 167, 1, 5, 323542) For what does service of the ‘untouchables or rendering justice to them mean?
('53', 167, 1, 6, 323620) It means nothing less than redeeming a debt which is centuries overdue, and to expiate in some measure the sin we have been guilty of for ages, viz., that of oppressing and insulting our own kith and kin.
('53', 167, 1, 7, 323825) We have behaved towards these unfortunate brethren of ours nothing better than a man turned monster behaves towards brother man.
('53', 167, 1, 8, 323954) And the programme of removal of untouchability that we have set before us is just some little expiation for a monstrous wrong.
('53', 167, 1, 9, 324081) And as it is essentially by way of expiation or self purification, it cannot be prompted by any fear or favour.
('53', 167, 1, 10, 324193) If we take up this work, fearing that the so called untouchables would go over to another faith, or that they would wreak vengeance on us, or as a sort of political trump card, we shall have betrayed our ignorance of Hinduism and our ungratefulness to those who have served us for ages.
('53', 167, 1, 11, 324480) I admit that it was I who pushed the item to the forefront of the Congress programme, and anyone bent on cavilling at me might say that it was a clever bait held out by me to the untouchables.
('53', 167, 1, 12, 324673) Let me say at once that that charge is idle.
('53', 167, 1, 13, 324718) It grew on me very early in life that those who believed themselves to be Hindus must perform the penance in the shape of wiping out this stain before they could be proud of Hinduism, and as the majority of Congressmen were Hindus, and as the programme then put before the nation was not one of self purification, I put it in the forefront of the Congress programme, in the conviction that unless the Hindus were prepared to wipe out this stain they could not regard themselves as fit for swaraj.
('53', 167, 1, 14, 325215) That conviction has come upon me as a self evident proposition.
('53', 167, 1, 15, 325279) If we came into power, with the stain of untouchability uneffaced, ‘I am positive that the untouchables would be far worse under that ‘swaraj’ than they are now, for the simple reason that our weaknesses and our failings would then be buttressed up by the accession of power.
('53', 167, 1, 16, 325555) That in brief is my position, and I have always held that self purification is an indispensable condition of swaraj.
('53', 167, 1, 17, 325672) It is not a position that I have arrived at today.
('53', 167, 1, 18, 325723) It is as old as when I began to think of swaraj.
('53', 167, 1, 19, 325772) That is
('53', 168, 0, 1, 325780) VOL. 53 : 2 JULY, 1931 12 OCTOBER, 1931 169
('53', 168, 1, 2, 325824) why I thank God for enabling me to participate in this function today.
('53', 168, 1, 3, 325895) I have always prized opportunities for doing this kind of work, and have often put aside so called political work for work of this nature.
('53', 168, 1, 4, 326034) I know that those to whom only the exciting thing called “politics” has an exclusive appeal will laugh at this kind of thing.
('53', 168, 1, 5, 326160) But for me it is nearest and dearest to my heart.
('53', 168, 1, 6, 326210) As for you, Lady Chinubhai, you need no congratulations from me for having done what was an obvious duty and an act of self purification.
('53', 168, 1, 7, 326348) But the occasion for my congratulations may, for aught we can say, soon arise.
('53', 168, 1, 8, 326427) The Brahmin priests in this temple have reconciled themselves today to the position.
('53', 168, 1, 9, 326512) But it is possible that they may one day turn against you and say that they would have nothing to do with worship in your temple.
('53', 168, 1, 10, 326642) Indeed the whole Brahmin community, the whole of the orthodox Nagar community may conspire against you.
('53', 168, 1, 11, 326746) Even then I hope and pray that you will hold fast to your conviction and rejoice in the belief that that day the stone image of Siva in the temple is invested with the living presence of God.
('53', 168, 1, 12, 326938) That will be the acme of your penance, and the day you are excommunicated by your community for having dared to do this necessary act of self purification, I shall congratulate you most heartily.
('53', 168, 1, 13, 327134) Let those who are present here today understand that we have not been able yet to win swaraj because of the load of sin that we are still carrying on our backs.
('53', 168, 1, 14, 327295) If all the so called ‘touchable’ Hindus did real penance for having wronged their ‘untouchable’ brethren, swaraj would be automatically in our hands.
('53', 168, 1, 15, 327445) And pray understand mere removal of physical untouchability does not mean expiation.
('53', 168, 1, 16, 327530) The removal of untouchability means the removal of all distinctions of superiority and inferiority attaching to birth.
('53', 168, 1, 17, 327649) Varnashramadharma 1 is a beautiful institution, but if it is used to buttress up social superiority of one section over another, it will be a monstrosity.
('53', 168, 1, 18, 327804) Let removal of untouchability result from a living conviction that all are one in the eyes of God, that the Father in Heaven will deal with us all with even handed justice.
('53', 168, 1, 19, 327977) This is a private temple, but if the doors of this private temple are thrown open to the ‘untouchables’ how long will the doors of public temples here remain closed?
('53', 168, 1, 20, 328143) Let today’s function be an eye opener to all the Hindus of Ahmedabad.
('53', 168, 1, 21, 328213) Let this be the
('53', 168, 2, 22, 328229) 1 The four castes and the four Stages of life
('53', 169, 0, 1, 328275) 170 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('53', 169, 1, 2, 328317) auspicious beginning of a process which will end in throwing open all the Hindu temples of Ahmedabad to the ‘untouchables’.
('53', 169, 1, 3, 328441) But even there as in every other thing I should ask you to avoid compulsion.
('53', 169, 1, 4, 328518) Untouchability cannot long endure.
('53', 169, 1, 5, 328553) Some years ago we obstinately clung to it, today we are indifferent.
('53', 169, 1, 6, 328622) It will be a thing of the past only when the indifference is translated into a conscious deliberate awakening to a sense of the duty of self purification.
('53', 169, 1, 7, 328777) Even the indifference or sufferance would have been impossible fifteen years ago.
('53', 169, 1, 8, 328859) The willing act of self purification will, let us hope and pray, be the next step.
('53', 169, 1, 9, 328942) Only the other day a friend suggested to me that the word ‘Harijana’ (man of God) be substituted for the word ‘Antyaja’ (the ‘last born’) that is being used for ‘untouchables’.
('53', 169, 1, 10, 329119) It was a word used by the great saint Narasinha Mehta, who by the bye belonged to the Nagar Brahmin community and who defied the whole community by claiming the ‘untouchables’ as his own.
('53', 169, 1, 11, 329307) I am delighted to adopt that word which is sanctified by having been used by such a great saint, but it has for me a deeper meaning than you may imagine.
('53', 169, 1, 12, 329461) The ‘untouchable’, to me, is, compared to us, really a ‘Harijana’—a man of God, and we are ‘Durjana’ (men of evil).
('53', 169, 1, 13, 329577) For whilst the ‘untouchable’ has toiled and moiled and dirtied his hands so that we may live in comfort and cleanliness; we have delighted in suppressing him.
('53', 169, 1, 14, 329736) We are solely responsible for all the shortcomings and faults that we lay at the door of these untouchables.
('53', 169, 1, 15, 329845) It is still open to us to be Harijana ourselves, but we can only do so by heartily repenting of our sin against them.
('53', 169, 1, 16, 329963) Young India, 6 8 1931

('53', 170, 3, 7, 330880) 181. INTERVIEW TO THE PRESS
('53', 170, 4, 8, 330908) August 4, 1931
('53', 170, 5, 9, 330923) Asked by the Associated Press after the interview 1, whether he would now proceed to London for the Round Table Conference, Mr. Gandhi said that he had not yet decided.
('53', 170, 5, 10, 331092) When asked if the situation was hopeful, he smilingly said that he could not say.
('53', 170, 6, 11, 331174) Interviewed [in Bombay], he did not throw any light on the result of his conversations with the Governor of Bombay at Poona.
('53', 170, 6, 12, 331299) He thought, on the other hand, it was really for the Government to say whatever they considered was convenient and proper.
('53', 170, 6, 13, 331422) For himself, he felt neither relieved nor unrelieved after the conversations.

('53', 172, 1, 2, 333660) 185. FURTHER CLEARANCE
('53', 172, 2, 3, 333683) Having read my reply to him in Young India, 1 Sjt.
('53', 172, 2, 4, 333734) Satyamurti thus returns to the charge:
('53', 172, 3, 5, 333773) Your insistence on the statement that political power is not an end in itself disturbs me seriously.
('53', 172, 3, 6, 333874) Even if tomorrow we get all the reforms we want, I would still resist British rule in this country.
('53', 172, 3, 7, 333974) I am also convinced that very few of the reforms we want can be fully or effectively achieved, unless we get political power.
('53', 172, 4, 8, 334100) You must recognize that the ideal of political anarchy, with which I entirely agree, is not practical politics in the world today.
('53', 172, 4, 9, 334231) If the Mussalmans and the Sikhs, therefore, get all the power, the majority community in the country will have to be perpetual civil resisters, leading to civil war.
('53', 172, 5, 10, 334397) I agree that political power can easily become a burden if it came as a gift from without, the people having made no effort to deserve it.
('53', 172, 5, 11, 334536) But I claim that the nation has already shown, and will show increasingly in the next few years, that it fully deserves political power.
('53', 172, 6, 12, 334673) Public opinion, I agree, should support legislation.
('53', 172, 6, 13, 334726) Legislation in advance of public opinion is often futile.
('53', 172, 6, 14, 334784) But public opinion, without legislative sanction, is often very largely impotent.
('53', 172, 6, 15, 334866) I feel that political power is the thing, and that these reforms must follow.
('53', 172, 6, 16, 334944) After all, the freedom of a nation and the liberty of the individual are priceless political privileges; and each nation must be free to decide what is good for itself.
('53', 172, 6, 17, 335113) Once, therefore, we get political power, we can and ought to decide what is good for us.
('53', 172, 6, 18, 335202) And if I understand my countrymen aright, the largest public opinion in India today is in favour of getting political power.
('53', 172, 7, 19, 335327) If you think this letter deserves a further answer from you, I shall be glad to have it.
('53', 172, 7, 20, 335416) But may I again express the hope that you may reconsider your position in the light of what I have stated above?
('53', 172, 8, 21, 335529) As regards my previous letter, I am sorry it has not reached you.
('53', 172, 8, 22, 335595) I have no copy of it.
('53', 172, 8, 23, 335617) I wanted to know in that letter from you what the phrase ‘for presenting the demands of the Congress’, in the resolution 2 of the Working Committee, deputing you to attend the Round Table Conference, meant.
('53', 172, 8, 24, 335824) I take it, it does not mean that you will merely state the Congress case, in the attitude of ‘take it or leave it’.
('53', 172, 8, 25, 335940) But I presume that you will (I) state the
('53', 172, 9, 26, 335982) 1 Vide “Power Not An End”, 2 7 1931 2 Of June 9, vide footnote 1, “Substance Not Shadow”,18 6 1931
('53', 173, 0, 1, 336081) 174 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('53', 173, 1, 2, 336123) Congress case and support it with arguments, (2) meet counter arguments, and answer questions and try to solve difficulties and doubts raised by the other side, and (3) exercise the freedom, given by the Karachi Congress to the Congress Delegation to the Round Table Conference, to accept such adjustments as may be demonstrably necessary in the interests of India.
('53', 173, 1, 3, 336489) There seems to me to be a question of emphasis between Sjt.
('53', 173, 1, 4, 336549) Satyamurti and myself.
('53', 173, 1, 5, 336572) His emphasis is on political power in itself, mine on political power as a weapon for enabling the reformer to achieve his reforms in the quickest manner possible.
('53', 173, 1, 6, 336736) To me therefore all depends upon the way political power is attained.
('53', 173, 1, 7, 336806) If it cannot be attained without the combined exertion of all the communities, I would wait.
('53', 173, 1, 8, 336899) After all a strenuous exertion itself is a getting.
('53', 173, 1, 9, 336951) In that sense political power is daily coming to the nation.
('53', 173, 1, 10, 337012) A constitution will merely be a symbol of the full achievement.
('53', 173, 1, 11, 337076) But it may also be a mirage, if it is not consciously a fruition of a nation’s endeavour.
('53', 173, 1, 12, 337166) Thus supposing by some accident England collapsed all of a sudden and therefore India imagined that she had all she wanted, she would be wholly wrong.
('53', 173, 1, 13, 337317) Virtue therefore lies in our getting political power as a result of our strength, not as a result of the foreign ruler’s weakness.
('53', 173, 1, 14, 337448) But I must not labour the point any further.
('53', 173, 1, 15, 337493) It is enough that just at present, though I may have a different outlook from that of many others, we are all striving for the same thing in the same way.
('53', 173, 1, 16, 337648) I do not share the fear, that if Mussalmans and Sikhs got all the power, the ‘majority community’, i.e., Hindus would have to be ‘perpetual civil resisters’.
('53', 173, 1, 17, 337806) In the first instance this deduction ignores the assumption that Hindus willingly surrendered their right to power, and in the second it ignores the law of civil resistance that it is never needed to be applied perpetually to a cause.
('53', 173, 1, 18, 338041) Its sovereign efficacy lies in the fact that it secures redress within a measurable though previously unascertainable period.
('53', 173, 1, 19, 338167) I can give Sjt.
('53', 173, 1, 20, 338183) Satyamurti a more consoling answer regarding his doubts as to the meaning of the ‘presentation’ of Congress demands.
('53', 173, 1, 21, 338300) Subject of course to permission being granted,—and this, in my opinion, is implicit in the Delhi Settlement,—I am going to present and “support the Congress case with arguments, meet counter argu ments and answer questions and try to solve difficulties and doubts raised by the other side and exercise the freedom given by the Karachi Congress to the Congress Delegation to the Round Table Conference to accept such adjustments as may be demonstrably
('53', 174, 0, 1, 338751) VOL. 53 : 2 JULY, 1931 12 OCTOBER, 1931 175
('53', 174, 1, 2, 338795) necessary in the interests of India”.
('53', 174, 1, 3, 338833) If I reach London, I can make this promise to all concerned, that whilst on the one hand I will not be guilty of selling the national cause, on the other the most reactionary Englishman need have no cause to fear my reputed obstinacy, or worse still, anti British feelings.
('53', 174, 1, 4, 339107) I am not conscious of being obstinate.
('53', 174, 1, 5, 339146) Those who know me, have always credited me with an ample faculty for compromise though they have found me unyielding on matters of principle.

('53', 174, 3, 11, 339610) 186. CONGRESSMEN’S NEGLIGENCE?
('53', 174, 4, 12, 339641) A correspondent from Abiramam writes: Mudukulattur is a fairly big village in the district of Ramnand in the Madras Presidency.
('53', 174, 4, 13, 339769) By 1 a short cut route, 8 miles in distance from the town lies the blue sea.
('53', 174, 4, 14, 339846) After the Settlement the villagers began to carry salt from the sea bed.
('53', 174, 4, 15, 339919) No conveyance was used at first.
('53', 174, 4, 16, 339952) Each man took as much salt as he could conveniently carry.
('53', 174, 4, 17, 340011) Men were not molested by the salt officers.
('53', 174, 4, 18, 340055) Emboldened by the apparent inactivity of salt officers, people used to join in the common purpose of carrying salt in groups consisting of four or five persons.
('53', 174, 4, 19, 340216) From the beginning of last month country bullock carts were requisitioned and used for carrying salt, and the commodity was divided into equal lots by those who brought them to be used for each man’s family consumption.
('53', 174, 4, 20, 340436) At this stage of their activities only did the emissaries of the department think it their duty to interfere.
('53', 174, 4, 21, 340546) After a full consultation, as to the nature of the action to be taken with regard to the people who carried away salt in carts, it was thought fit to arrest certain persons and fine them for the offence of breaking the provisions of the salt law.
('53', 174, 4, 22, 340793) It should be stated that the officers did not at all interfere at the very beginning.
('53', 174, 4, 23, 340879) They wished to check them at a very late hour, and this they did without giving them any notice or even a casual warning.
('53', 174, 5, 24, 341001) 1 The source has “From”, evidently a misprint.
('53', 175, 0, 1, 341048) 176 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('53', 175, 1, 2, 341090) The total number of persons thus arrested is 21. The punishment meted out to them varied.
('53', 175, 1, 3, 341180) Those who admitted the guilt were let off with small fines, while those who refused to admit it were fined heavier than the others.
('53', 175, 1, 4, 341312) The total amount of fines amounted to Rs. 295 which was paid.
('53', 175, 1, 5, 341374) I am quite sure that these prosecutions could have been avoided if the local Congress authorities had done propaganda work and informed the villagers of the limits of the salt concession.
('53', 175, 1, 6, 341562) Can you not wake them up from their lethargy?
('53', 175, 1, 7, 341608) I assure you that the villagers are quite amenable to reason.
('53', 175, 1, 8, 341670) I have condensed the original letter.
('53', 175, 1, 9, 341708) I do not know how far the complaint against the local Congress Committees is justified.
('53', 175, 1, 10, 341796) But one is inclined to agree with the writer that there has been some negligence.
('53', 175, 1, 11, 341878) The salt concession is the most valuable clause of the Delhi Settlement.
('53', 175, 1, 12, 341951) I know that Lord Irwin was moved by the appeal on behalf of the poor.
('53', 175, 1, 13, 342021) I am betraying no confidence when I state that he realized that at least for the poor villagers salt must be free as air and water.
('53', 175, 1, 14, 342153) The argument that it was not so much the amount of tax that positively hurt the people as the deprivation of the right of making it themselves made a forcible appeal to him.
('53', 175, 1, 15, 342327) If it makes the same appeal to Congressmen, they will lose no time in instructing the villagers as to the exact nature of the concession.
('53', 175, 1, 16, 342465) There is no complication about it.
('53', 175, 1, 17, 342500) The villagers within a walking distance of a salt area whether sea bound or inland can make and sell salt for domestic consumption.
('53', 175, 1, 18, 342632) Domestic use includes use for manure, cattle and fish curing as a village industry.
('53', 175, 1, 19, 342716) Therefore salt cannot be carried to towns or bazars outside the walking area.
('53', 175, 1, 20, 342794) It can on no account be carted or carried on camelback.
('53', 175, 1, 21, 342850) Only human agency is permissible.
('53', 175, 1, 22, 342884) Not even hand carts may be used.
('53', 175, 1, 23, 342917) These limitations may look formidable to town dwellers.
('53', 175, 1, 24, 342973) They are no hardships for the villagers who want to work the concession honestly.
('53', 175, 1, 25, 343055) The motive behind the limitation is to prevent trade among the wealthy people and competition with the monopoly salt in areas where people use the monopoly salt without noticing the effect of the tax.
('53', 175, 1, 26, 343256) Whilst the latter lasts, the restriction is perfectly intelligible and reasonable.
('53', 175, 1, 27, 343339) Let us realize, that for tens of thousands who live within walking distance of salt areas salt is free.
('53', 175, 1, 28, 343443) From all I have seen of the working of this concession, I believe that the provincial Governments are
('53', 176, 0, 1, 343545) VOL. 53 : 2 JULY, 1931 12 OCTOBER, 1931 177
('53', 176, 1, 2, 343589) desirous of giving the villagers the full benefit of the concession.
('53', 176, 1, 3, 343658) Having made this admission, I would like to suggest that the fines imposed were heavy.
('53', 176, 1, 4, 343745) A few pice each should surely have sufficed by way of warning.
('53', 176, 1, 5, 343808) Nor can I help feeling that the reported distinction between those who pleaded guilty and those who did not was wholly unnecessary.

('53', 176, 2, 7, 343962) 187. WHAT IS LIBERTY ?
('53', 176, 3, 8, 343985) In the course of a letter eulogizing the non violent character of our struggle, a country clerk writing from Vernon, Texas, says:
('53', 176, 4, 9, 344115) Usually men think of liberty as the absence of restraint.
('53', 176, 4, 10, 344173) That may be liberty, but usually it is licence.
('53', 176, 4, 11, 344221) The absence of negation to personal desire is never liberty.
('53', 176, 4, 12, 344282) Liberty is that which makes a man free in the face of great obstacles.
('53', 176, 4, 13, 344353) It is one of life’s virtues least understood and not often practised.
('53', 176, 4, 14, 344423) Liberty is not a varying quality, but a fixed life principle.
('53', 176, 5, 15, 344485) True liberty often does strange things.
('53', 176, 5, 16, 344525) In fact the actors are frequently called fools.
('53', 176, 5, 17, 344573) At any rate they do not seem to work for their own interest, but when rightly understood, liberty is seen to be an exhibition of service, if not of sacrifice.
('53', 176, 5, 18, 344732) Conscious liberty lifts a man above the sordid and selfish to a view of the common good.
('53', 176, 5, 19, 344821) It puts a premium on larger benefits and teaches her devotee to consider himself part of a great principle working for human uplift.
('53', 176, 5, 20, 344954) His reward lies not in material gains, but in a larger truer self conscious strength.
('53', 176, 5, 21, 345040) Young India, 6 8 1931
('53', 176, 6, 22, 345062) 188. THE GARLICK MURDER
('53', 176, 7, 23, 345086) This murder in Bengal of a judge who was performing his duty according to his lights is a disgrace to the perpetrators.
('53', 176, 7, 24, 345206) We may not wonder at the agitation that has troubled the European community in Calcutta and elsewhere.
('53', 176, 7, 25, 345309) The young men who delight in murdering those whom they dislike, no matter from how patriotic motive, do not advance the cause they claim to espouse.
('53', 176, 7, 26, 345458) And murders planned by secret societies make everyone in their immediate neighbourhood a suspect.
('53', 176, 7, 27, 345556) Indeed one murder of a European official affects the atmosphere in the whole of India.
('53', 176, 7, 28, 345643) It is the duty of every person who sincerely dislikes these
('53', 177, 0, 1, 345703) 178 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('53', 177, 1, 2, 345745) murders to express his strong disapproval of such acts, and wherever he can find the followers of the cult of murder, reason with its members and non co operate with them if they do not listen.
('53', 177, 1, 3, 345939) Satyagraha is no respecter of persons.
('53', 177, 1, 4, 345978) Given a correct atmosphere satyagraha can be far more effectively used against our own friends than against those who regard us as their enemies.
('53', 177, 1, 5, 346124) The nearer the relation, the more effective does satyagraha become.
('53', 177, 1, 6, 346192) We must realize that any toleration or indifference shown towards these activities will not only postpone swaraj, but will make swaraj government difficult, if not impossible.
('53', 177, 1, 7, 346368) For, whilst it may be possible for an overarmed alien Government to carry on adminis tration in spite of the activities of murderous secret societies, an administration based purely on popular will cannot be efficiently conducted in the midst of murderous activities.
('53', 177, 1, 8, 346636) There is no warrant to suppose, that if the idea that it is right to murder officials or persons whom we dislike becomes popular, it will subside the moment we gain swaraj.
('53', 177, 1, 9, 346809) From even the most selfish considerations, therefore, it is necessary for lovers of real freedom to put forth their best endeavour to check this evil before it becomes too late.
('53', 177, 1, 10, 346987) I have had it whispered to me, that violence going on side by side with non violence must help the latter.
('53', 177, 1, 11, 347094) As the author of the non violent programme and as an expert in the line, let me proclaim with all the strength of conviction that it is a serious delusion to think that violence can help non violence.
('53', 177, 1, 12, 347295) On this matter my evidence based on long experience should be regarded as conclusive.
('53', 177, 1, 13, 347381) I can assert that every act of political violence injures the non violent movement.
('53', 177, 1, 14, 347465) Everyone knows how it unnerves me.
('53', 177, 1, 15, 347500) What has been called the Bardoli blunder and what I claim as an act of first class wisdom was due to an ugly outbreak of violence on the part of professing Congressmen at Chauri Chaura 1. But for the postponement of civil disobedience at the time, the country would not have made the phenomenal progress it has made.
('53', 177, 1, 16, 347817) Let everyone concerned understand that if this contagion of murder spreads, without my wishing it or doing it, the active non violent movement may automatically suffer a check.
('53', 177, 1, 17, 347994) Like everything in nature it has its own law to govern it.
('53', 177, 1, 18, 348053) It may not be amiss here to examine the resentment caused in European circles over my article 2 on the attempted assassination of His

('53', 178, 1, 2, 348275) Excellency the Acting Governor of Bombay.
('53', 178, 1, 3, 348317) The resentment was caused by my making a distinction between the murder of a guest by a host and any other murder.
('53', 178, 1, 4, 348432) I thought that I had made my meaning quite clear.
('53', 178, 1, 5, 348482) I heightened the sinfulness of the act because of the additional fact that Sir Earnest Hotson was a guest of the College.

('53', 180, 8, 22, 351479) Write one now.

('53', 180, 8, 24, 351578) What a shame!
('53', 180, 8, 25, 351592) I was glad to read the news that you embraced Maitri.
('53', 180, 8, 26, 351646) 3 But I shall not be satisfied till I get a full description.
