('53', 181, 1, 2, 352137) 194. SPEECH AT A.I.C.C. MEETING, BOMBAY
('53', 181, 2, 3, 352177) August 6, 1931
('53', 181, 3, 4, 352192) Mahatma Gandhi proposed the following resolution: The A.I.C.C. deplores the attempted assassination of H.E the Acting Governor of Bombay and the assassination of Judge Garlick in Bengal.
('53', 181, 3, 5, 352379) While condemning all political murders, 1 the A.I.C.C. regards the attempted assassination of the acting Governor of Bombay as the more condemnable inasmuch as it was an act done by a student of a college that had invited the Acting Governor as its honoured guest.
('53', 181, 3, 6, 352644) The A.I.C.C. warns those who secretly or openly approve of or encourage such murders that they retard the progress of the country.
('53', 181, 3, 7, 352775) The A.I.C.C. calls upon Congress organizations to carry on special propaganda against all acts of public violence even where provocation is given for such deeds.
('53', 181, 3, 8, 352937) Further the A.I.C.C. appeals to the nationalist Press to use all its influence in this behalf.
('53', 181, 4, 9, 353032) Speaking on the resolution Gandhiji said: I hope you all have understood the meaning of this resolution and therefore I do not want to burden you with a Hindustani translation of it.
('53', 181, 4, 10, 353215) I want to tell you that there is much more in my heart than what I have stated here.
('53', 181, 4, 11, 353300) I tell you this because I have framed the resolution myself and because I know how far I can carry you with me.
('53', 181, 4, 12, 353412) I have also to inform you that there was no difference among the members of the Working Committee on this resolution and I hope that in this House also there will be no difference of opinion on it.
('53', 181, 4, 13, 353610) But still I do not want you to accept it without argument or discussion.
('53', 181, 4, 14, 353683) I want you to express your views on it and if you do not agree with it throw it out.
('53', 181, 4, 15, 353768) This resolution has not been brought forward to deceive ourselves or Englishmen or the world at large.
('53', 181, 4, 16, 353871) It has been moved todeclare what is the creed of the Congress.
('53', 181, 4, 17, 353934) The creed of the Congress is to strive for the attainment of ‘purna swaraj’ by non violent and peaceful means.
('53', 181, 4, 18, 354045) We have decided to follow the path of peace, truth and righteousness.
('53', 181, 4, 19, 354115) And so long as we believe in it andwant the world also to believe that that is our way, then it becomes obligatory upon us
('53', 181, 5, 20, 354238) 1 A verbal amendment by Bhaisaheb Kotwal to add here the words “and attempts to murder” was later accepted.
('53', 182, 0, 1, 354346) VOL. 53 : 2 JULY, 1931 12 OCTOBER, 1931 183
('53', 182, 1, 2, 354390) to stick to it scrupulously in thought, word and deed.
('53', 182, 1, 3, 354445) It also becomes our duty to prevent those who want to follow the opposite way.
('53', 182, 1, 4, 354524) We must try to win them over.
('53', 182, 1, 5, 354554) In 1920 when the Congress first adopted non violence as its creed the argument was brought forward why the Congress should take any notice of what those who were not members of the Congress did.
('53', 182, 1, 6, 354749) It was said that while Congress should follow its own way it should allow others to do what they liked.
('53', 182, 1, 7, 354853) It was said that if Congress wanted it should stick to non violence and even submit patiently to violence used against it by its opponents, but it has no business to advise others or come in their way.
('53', 182, 1, 8, 355055) Since the time this controversy started my reply to it has been that the Congress claims to represent and speak in the name of India and the fight it has been carrying on is for the good of every Indian whether he is a Hindu, a Muslim, a Christian or a Parsi.
('53', 182, 1, 9, 355315) We claim to exert influence on them and we represent them and speak in their name.
('53', 182, 1, 10, 355398) Our fight is not for Congressmen alone.
('53', 182, 1, 11, 355438) If it were so our task would have been very simple.
('53', 182, 1, 12, 355490) Last year when we carried on the struggle for freedom against the Government, the whole country was at our back.
('53', 182, 1, 13, 355603) All those who participated in the struggle were not Congress members.
('53', 182, 1, 14, 355673) But our strength is immensely increased by working for them and accepting their help.
('53', 182, 1, 15, 355759) The Government admits the strength of the Congress not because there are some thousand members on the roll of the Congress or there are a few lawyers, doctors or other learned men in the Congress who can very well argue and discuss things.
('53', 182, 1, 16, 355999) The Government recognizes the strength of the Congress because it feels that the voice of the Congress has reached the villages.
('53', 182, 1, 17, 356128) Do you believe that if you declared that you have nothing to do with the masses and your fight was only for the members of the Congress your word will carry the same weight as it does today?
('53', 182, 1, 18, 356319) Our strength has now increased to the extent that even in the remote corners of the country where our voice has not so far reached, where the people have not yet seen the Congress flag, our influence is felt.
('53', 182, 1, 19, 356528) It is true that all the seven hundred thousand villages of India have not Congress organizations but we are confident that when we go there our voice is heard and the people follow our advice.
('53', 182, 1, 20, 356721) Those who commit murders are also our brethren.
('53', 182, 1, 21, 356769) We must exert influence on them.
('53', 182, 1, 22, 356802) When we claim to represent them we also must accept the responsibility for what they do.
('53', 182, 1, 23, 356891) In 1921 we had made it clear that we shall be responsible for the actions of the non Con 
('53', 183, 0, 1, 356981) 184 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('53', 183, 1, 2, 357023) gressmen also.
('53', 183, 1, 3, 357038) You know that I had suspended my work once or twice on former occasions for this reason.
('53', 183, 1, 4, 357127) I will only cite the instance of the Rowlatt Act.
('53', 183, 1, 5, 357177) 1 I am prepared to say that we did not suffer any loss because we suspended our fight on previous occasions.
('53', 183, 1, 6, 357286) On the contrary I believe that we have distinctly gained thereby.
('53', 183, 1, 7, 357352) There is still a large number of people who say that I committed a blunder when I stopped the fight in Bardoli in 1922. They say that if we had continued our fight then by this time we could have been free.
('53', 183, 1, 8, 357559) I believe it is a mistake to think so.
('53', 183, 1, 9, 357598) It is even now my firm belief that what I did in Bardoli in 1922 was right and India has immensely gained by that action.
('53', 183, 1, 10, 357720) The present awakening in the country is due to that action.
('53', 183, 1, 11, 357780) If you do not believe in it, if your opinion differs then say so.
('53', 183, 1, 12, 357846) You must have the courage to say so.
('53', 183, 1, 13, 357883) But if you believe that what we have been doing since 1922 up till now is right then it becomes your duty to adopt this resolution and to work for it.
('53', 183, 1, 14, 358034) On former occasions when we condemned such actions we also praised the spirit of sacrifice among the young men.
('53', 183, 1, 15, 358146) But we praised it so much that I think we reached the limit when we passed the resolution at Karachi about Bhagat Singh and his comrades.
('53', 183, 1, 16, 358284) At that time I felt that for one whose sacrifice was so great and whose character was represented to me to have been spotless we should do all that we can to save him from the gallows and even if we did not succeed in it we should pass the resolution we passed.
('53', 183, 1, 17, 358546) I did so in the belief that it would have sobering effect on the youths but I failed in that attempt.
('53', 183, 1, 18, 358648) I am not unaware of the increased strength of the youths but it is being misused.
('53', 183, 1, 19, 358730) I did not get the least success in that attempt.
('53', 183, 1, 20, 358779) On the contrary it was exploited very badly and I am sorry for it.
('53', 183, 1, 21, 358846) There are those who accuse me of agreeing to that proposition at Karachi dishonestly because I wanted to placate the youths as I had to carry the Congress with me in ratifying the Delhi Pact and attend the R.T.C. My reply to these critics is that you cannot claim to know what is in my mind.
('53', 183, 1, 22, 359138) It is God alone who knows that.
('53', 183, 1, 23, 359170) But I can say this much that I shall never commit such blunder.
('53', 183, 1, 24, 359234) If I do I shall not be true to the Congress.
('53', 183, 1, 25, 359279) For others it may be a question of mere policy but for me it is my dharma.
('53', 183, 1, 26, 359354) How is it possible for me to commit such a grave blunder for a small matter?
('53', 183, 1, 27, 359431) I have never done it in my life.
('53', 183, 2, 28, 359464) 1 In 1919 the Rowlatt Act Satyagraha was suspended because of the outbreak of violence.
('53', 184, 0, 1, 359552) VOL. 53 : 2 JULY, 1931 12 OCTOBER, 1931 185
('53', 184, 1, 2, 359596) do not attach so much value to the R.T.C. as to sacrifice that great principle of my life for it.
('53', 184, 1, 3, 359694) I certainly attach more value to the Delhi Pact.
('53', 184, 1, 4, 359743) We have been benefited by it and I do not even now feel that we were mistaken in agreeing to it.
('53', 184, 1, 5, 359840) I felt that we would profit by its acceptance and I see that we have gained much thereby and will gain more in future.
('53', 184, 1, 6, 359959) You may think that it is worth consigning to the waste paper basket.
('53', 184, 1, 7, 360028) But nothing could convince me that it was a mistake.
('53', 184, 1, 8, 360081) I am also aware of the objection raised, namely, why the crimes of our young men are magnified, while the Government whose faults drive our young men to commit such actions is not criticized.
('53', 184, 1, 9, 360273) I do not know if there is any need on the part of the Congress to do that work.
('53', 184, 1, 10, 360353) Those who demand such condemnation of the Government by the Congress do not understand the Congress.
('53', 184, 1, 11, 360454) The very existence of the Congress is to destroy the present system of Government.
('53', 184, 1, 12, 360537) The Congress wants to put a stop to what has been going on for years in this country.
('53', 184, 1, 13, 360623) The Congress decided it when it first launched the non co operation movement.
('53', 184, 1, 14, 360701) The vices of this Government have not since decreased, on the contrary they have increased.
('53', 184, 1, 15, 360793) The youths who commit such acts do so as a result of their being driven to desperation but that does not mean that we should not say that they are mistaken.
('53', 184, 2, 16, 360950) To recite the wrongs of the Government at the time of condemning political murders is to confuse the issue, and to mislead the hot blooded youth.
('53', 184, 2, 17, 361096) We must tell them in the clearest possible language, that they must cease to murder, no matter how great may be the provocation.
('53', 184, 2, 18, 361225) But how, it is further asked, can you end the present system by the way of non violence?
('53', 184, 2, 19, 361314) Surely the progress made by the country since 1920 is sufficient tangible proof of the success.
('53', 184, 2, 20, 361410) But whether we shall succeed or not is not the question.
('53', 184, 2, 21, 361467) There is the Congress creed, and we have to work it out faithfully.
('53', 184, 2, 22, 361535) Hence we must not in any shape or form identify ourselves with the murderous activities that we witness about us.
('53', 184, 2, 23, 361649) It would be perfectly legitimate for those who do not believe in the Congress creed to agitate for its removal, and there will be no need for such a resolution as the one before you.
('53', 184, 2, 24, 361832) We must not deceive ourselves or the world.
('53', 184, 2, 25, 361876) And now a word to the nationalist newspapers.

('53', 188, 5, 7, 368527) BOMBAY, August 7, 1931
('53', 188, 6, 8, 368550) DEAR MR. BOLTON, I assure you that I am leaving no stone unturned to facilitate my decision.
('53', 188, 6, 9, 368643) My difficulty is this: I do not believe in the public opinion in England being vastly different from the opinion of the civilians here.

('53', 188, 10, 18, 369323) 198. SPEECH AT MEETING OF PARSIS, BOMBAY
('53', 188, 11, 19, 369364) August 7, 1931
('53', 188, 12, 20, 369379) Mahatma Gandhi .
('53', 188, 12, 21, 369396) said that he had not even a spare minute to deliver a lecture, because the time of delivering lectures had already gone.
('53', 188, 12, 22, 369517) Some time ago when he was released from jail 3, Mr. Bharucha took a promise from him to find time to address at least once to the Parsi community.
('53', 188, 12, 23, 369664) After that he came to Bombay many a
('53', 188, 13, 24, 369700) 1 The Governor’s summer residence, near Poona 2 In his article “Foul Play”, 30 7 1931 3 On January 26
('53', 189, 0, 1, 369802) 190 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('53', 189, 1, 2, 369844) time, but somehow or other, Mr. Bharucha did not press him for the fulfilment of the promise.
('53', 189, 1, 3, 369938) Now, perhaps Mr. Bharucha thought that he would be going away to England, and, therefore, he was compelled to fulfil his promise that day.
('53', 189, 1, 4, 370077) Mahatma Gandhi then said that he had to go for his prayer at 7.30 and after prayer he would be busy till 11 p.m.
('53', 189, 1, 5, 370190) and, therefore, he had to be very brief in his speech.
('53', 189, 2, 6, 370245) Coming to his address, he said that there was no doubt that the Parsi community had done much for the country, but he thought that they had not come up to his expectation.
('53', 189, 2, 7, 370417) There were seven lakhs 1 of villages in India and if the Parsi community were to exercise their charity towards these poor starving millions, they should use the clothes made by these poor villagers.
('53', 189, 2, 8, 370617) Then the Parsi community should also try to spin for themselves.
('53', 189, 2, 9, 370682) There was a time in India when every household had a charkha; but they could not make any improvement in it while Lancashire continued to keep its pace with progress and made improvements in their spinning machinery with the result that Indian people who used hand spun cloth discontinued doing so and began to use the Lancashire fine cloth.
('53', 189, 2, 10, 371024) The Parsi community should remember that if they put on khadi, they would support millions of poor people.
('53', 189, 2, 11, 371131) Parsis were well known for their charity.
('53', 189, 2, 12, 371173) But which charity was better, the charity of service or the charity of giving money, asked Mahatmaji.
('53', 189, 2, 13, 371275) If the Parsis put on khadi they would demonstrate to the world two things.
('53', 189, 2, 14, 371350) Firstly, that they suffered for the sake of the poor and secondly, that they served the poor.
('53', 189, 2, 15, 371444) He thought, therefore, that suffering and service were better kind of charities than any other charity.
('53', 189, 3, 16, 371548) The other thing that he wanted to tell the Parsis was in regard to the liquor trade.
('53', 189, 3, 17, 371633) Many Parsis kept liquor shops which was the cause of the suffering of the poor.
('53', 189, 3, 18, 371713) He did not think that it was a very great thing for the Parsis to do away with the liquor traffic.
('53', 189, 3, 19, 371812) The Parsis came from Persia and had adapted themselves in such a way that they could very easily do away with the liquor shops and successfully prosper in any other business.
('53', 189, 3, 20, 371987) The charity which the Parsi community would do by doing away with the liquor trade would be immense to the country and when history is written of this country it would be stated of the Parsis that they made great sacrifices for the country.
('53', 189, 3, 21, 372228) In this regard Mithubehn had served Gujarat for which the Parsi community should be proud.
('53', 189, 3, 22, 372319) What Mithubehn had done for Gujarat every Parsi should do for his country.
('53', 189, 3, 23, 372394) It is for the Parsi community to create an atmosphere that the baneful liquor traffic might be done away with.
('53', 189, 3, 24, 372505) Some might ask what business then the Parsi liquor shopkeepers should get into.
('53', 189, 3, 25, 372585) Mahatma Gandhi said that the Parsi community was so much enterprising that they would be successful in any other business if they stopped the liquor traffic.
('53', 189, 3, 26, 372743) Take the case of Parsi Rustomji in South Africa, he said.
('53', 189, 3, 27, 372801) Rustomji had liquor business first which he closed down and got into other business and amassed great wealth and gave lakhs of rupees in charity.
('53', 189, 3, 28, 372947) He hoped, therefore, the Parsi community would seriously consider that point.
('53', 189, 4, 29, 373025) 1 The source has “60 lakhs”.
('53', 190, 0, 1, 373054) VOL. 53 : 2 JULY, 1931 12 OCTOBER, 1931 191
('53', 190, 1, 2, 373098) The third point was in regard to simplicity of life.
('53', 190, 1, 3, 373151) He did not know whether he would go to England or not.
('53', 190, 1, 4, 373206) People say he was going to England on the 15th, but he was not sure himself.
('53', 190, 1, 5, 373283) Whether he went to England or not he would say one thing to the Parsi community that they need not be afraid of their right and privileges.
('53', 190, 1, 6, 373423) The Parsi community was the smallest community in the whole of India, as it had hardly a population of a lakh.
('53', 190, 1, 7, 373534) They had no reason to fear for the future, because they had been backed up by their self reliance and strength.
('53', 190, 1, 8, 373646) The Parsi community has done no wrong to any other community in India and they should rest assured that no community would harm them.
('53', 190, 1, 9, 373780) But he would appeal to them to exercise simplicity of life.
('53', 190, 1, 10, 373840) The Parsis were accustomed to a standard of life, namely, they wanted costly furniture and other paraphernalia, which other communities did not have.
('53', 190, 1, 11, 373990) In future, they would have to try to exercise simplicity and self control.
('53', 190, 1, 12, 374065) When the National Congress demands that the highest official in India would be paid only Rs. 500, he felt assured that by that time the economic conditions in India would be so changed that everything would be had cheaply.
('53', 190, 1, 13, 374288) For instance, doctors charge one guinea for consultation and lawyers charge thousands of rupees for their fees.
('53', 190, 1, 14, 374400) That also would have to go to a minimum, and it was bound to go because everyone would have a simple life.

('53', 190, 3, 24, 375262) If the idea of establishing a contact with workers in the cause of swadeshi which the organizers had in view succeeded in Bombay then it could be copied at other places also.

('53', 192, 10, 17, 378048) August 8, 1931 I may tell you, that I am doing all that is humanly possible to enable me to go to London.
('53', 192, 10, 18, 378154) The Settlement commits the Congress to participate in the R.T.C. to place the Congress point of view before it.

('53', 193, 1, 6, 379148) That meant a step forward in the direction of London.
('53', 193, 1, 7, 379202) But there were other difficulties, one of them being the implementing of the Truce by Government.

('53', 193, 1, 9, 379396) For instance there are still many in jail who should have been released under the Settlement, there are still prosecutions going on, and still arrests being made.

('53', 196, 3, 5, 387582) 206. TALK WITH SEVA DAL WORKERS, BOMBAY 1

('53', 198, 1, 9, 392470) I have drawn a distinction between a violent and a non violent army.

('53', 198, 1, 11, 392593) The Tommy yields obedience whilst at war, but will yield to wild licence when free from it.
('53', 198, 1, 12, 392685) But a non violent soldier carries discipline in his heart and will carry an atmosphere of restraint in every walk of life.
('53', 198, 1, 13, 392808) Non violence is a trust which has to be zealously guarded by the Seva Dal.
('53', 198, 1, 14, 392883) Your soldiers will not only keep discipline in meetings but in homes and domestic affairs.
('53', 198, 1, 15, 392974) A non violent soldier is non violent in all places and at all times.
('53', 198, 1, 16, 393043) Young India, 13 8 1931

('53', 199, 5, 8, 394485) 209. SPEECH AT HINDUSTANI SEVA DAL CONFERENCE, BOMBAY
('53', 199, 6, 9, 394539) August 9, 1931
('53', 199, 7, 10, 394554) At a special session of the Hindustani Seva Dal Conference held.
('53', 199, 7, 11, 394619) in the Jinnah Hall a resolution was adopted confirming the decision of the Central Board of Volunteers to dissolve all the organizations of the Dal and handing it over to the Working Committee of the Congress.
('53', 199, 8, 12, 394829) Mahatma Gandhi opened the Conference and Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel, the Congress President, presided.
('53', 199, 9, 13, 394930) Mahatma Gandhi .
('53', 199, 9, 14, 394947) said that the Conference was meant not to write the epitaph of the Seva Dal as Mrs. Naidu who was asked to preside but could not do so owing to her departure to Hyderabad had said in her letter.
('53', 199, 9, 15, 395142) On the contrary, it was meant to make the Seva Dal stronger.
('53', 199, 9, 16, 395203) The Congress now wanted to bring the Dal under its direct control because it felt that the time had come when it should organize all the volunteers in the country and bring them under its own control.
('53', 199, 9, 17, 395404) Proceeding, he said: The fight we carried on last year impressed upon me the need for training and discipline among the volunteers.
('53', 199, 9, 18, 395536) The volunteers that we got as the struggle proceeded had not the required training.
('53', 199, 9, 19, 395620) Although we gained much by that struggle we also suffered I certain

('53', 201, 2, 7, 398613) 210. ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS 1
('53', 201, 3, 8, 398641) August 10, 1931
('53', 201, 4, 9, 398657) Q. 1. Will you be ready to give shelter in the Ashram to the three women or to any of them who may wish to join it?
('53', 201, 5, 10, 398773) A. Yes, I shall be very happy to do so.
('53', 201, 5, 11, 398813) But before joining the Ashram, the women should know and understand my views fully.
('53', 201, 6, 12, 398897) Q. 2. What are those views?
('53', 201, 7, 13, 398925) A. My first duty will be to inform the Government as soon as the women arrive and communicate their names and other particulars.
('53', 201, 8, 14, 399054) Q. 3. If you inform the Government, it will immediately arrest them and prosecute them.
('53', 201, 9, 15, 399142) A. Yes, that is possible.
('53', 201, 9, 16, 399168) The women should be ready for this risk when joining the Ashram.
('53', 201, 10, 17, 399233) Q. 4 What, then, will be the advantage to the women of joining the ashram?
('53', 201, 11, 18, 399308) A. It is also possible that, in response to my request, the Government may not prosecute them just now or as long as they live in the Ashram and try to live henceforth in accordance with the Ashram ideals of life.
('53', 201, 12, 19, 399522) Q. 5. Will not the Government try to obtain from them information about all that they have done?
('53', 201, 13, 20, 399619) A. It will certainly want to obtain such information, but I will tell it, and tell the women, too, that they should confess only their own crimes and errors without involving any other person.
('53', 201, 14, 21, 399812) Q. 6. In sum, you desire that the women should join the Ashram ready to face all risks.
('53', 201, 15, 22, 399900) A. Yes, I should like them to join the Ashram ready to face all

('53', 206, 4, 8, 406301) 218. NEED FOR FEELING HELPLESS
('53', 206, 5, 9, 406332) God is great, and we are but dust.
('53', 206, 5, 10, 406367) But thanks to our pride, whilst we say with our lips ‘God is great’, our actions belie the profession and show that we think nothing of God and a ‘mighty lot’ of ourselves.
('53', 206, 5, 11, 406540) But it is time to realize our helplessness.
('53', 206, 5, 12, 406584) The growing goondaism of which Bombay had a bitter experience must furnish all with food for reflection.
('53', 206, 5, 13, 406689) It cannot, it must not be answered with counter goondaism than which nothing is easier.
('53', 206, 5, 14, 406777) What can be easier than to swear harder than one’s opponent or to give two blows against one or to organize ten men against five?
('53', 206, 5, 15, 406907) But this can serve no earthly purpose.
('53', 206, 5, 16, 406946) And if it can serve any celestial purpose, that abode must be worse than the fabled hell.
('53', 206, 5, 17, 407036) Is there then no remedy for the growing evil?
('53', 206, 5, 18, 407082) The time honoured and well tried method is that of prayer and fasting.
('53', 206, 5, 19, 407153) But both have to come from the heart.
('53', 206, 5, 20, 407191) A parrot like repetition of the choicest sentiment and mere starvation of the body would be worse than useless.
('53', 206, 5, 21, 407303) Prayer and fasting avail where there is a definite consciousness of the presence of God in us, even as we have of friends living under the same roof.
('53', 206, 5, 22, 407453) Self deception will not do.
('53', 206, 5, 23, 407481) Jawaharlal uttered the feeling of co workers, when in anguish he said, ‘This will stop political life and may even influence social life.’ The way out is not to give any handle to goondaism.
('53', 206, 5, 24, 407672) The best way would be for peaceful men to withdraw from meetings when the goondas have invaded it.
('53', 206, 5, 25, 407771) Truth will not be suppressed by violence.
('53', 206, 5, 26, 407813) And if those who represent it will suffer without retaliation, they will find that it will spread without effort.
('53', 206, 5, 27, 407927) Difficulty however lies in
('53', 206, 6, 28, 407954) 1 At this time Chhaganlal Joshi was working around Navsari.
('53', 207, 0, 1, 408014) 208 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('53', 207, 1, 2, 408056) knowing where truth lies.
('53', 207, 1, 3, 408082) It is easy enough to accuse one’s opponent of representing untruth.
('53', 207, 1, 4, 408150) But this inherent inability to demonstrate the absolute truthfulness of one’s position makes toleration an imperative necessity for the progress of ordered life.
('53', 207, 1, 5, 408312) Without the freedom to everyone to express his opinion unfettered by interference from those who hold the contrary, ordered life becomes an impossibility.
('53', 207, 1, 6, 408467) Is refusal even to defend oneself the logical outcome of this argument?
('53', 207, 1, 7, 408539) For the moment I do not need to go so far, though for those who believe in non violence through and through, self defence is an impossibility.
('53', 207, 1, 8, 408682) For them not to defend is the best self defence.
('53', 207, 1, 9, 408731) This however is not an artificial or mechanical state that can be imposed from without.
('53', 207, 1, 10, 408819) It does not admit of being argued out.
('53', 207, 1, 11, 408858) One has to grow to it.
('53', 207, 1, 12, 408881) The need of the moment is to realize our helplessness.
('53', 207, 1, 13, 408936) A Tamil proverb truly has it: God is the Help of the helpless.
('53', 207, 1, 14, 408999) This realization will show us a way out of the present impenetrable darkness, without our having to work out the logical outcome of non violence.
('53', 207, 1, 15, 409145) This is the work of philosophers.
('53', 207, 1, 16, 409179) For us helpless men and women who have to serve from day to day and often in the face of gloomy despair, it is enough if we can sing with the Seer: “One step enough for me.”
('53', 207, 2, 17, 409353) Young India, 13 8 1931

('53', 208, 13, 16, 411080) 220. INTERVIEW TO THE PRESS
('53', 208, 14, 17, 411108) August 13, 1931 After the announcement of the decision of the Congress Working Committee, Mahatma Gandhi spoke to a group of Press representatives.
('53', 208, 14, 18, 411256) Mahatmaji said: It is needless to say I am very unhappy that I shall not go to London.
('53', 208, 14, 19, 411343) I know what effect this will have on Lord Irwin, and I also know how disappointed my numerous friends in England will be.
('53', 208, 14, 20, 411465) But this decision against my going there was inevitable.
('53', 208, 14, 21, 411522) I was hoping against hope and expected to the last moment that justice would be done.
('53', 208, 14, 22, 411608) I think I made a very modest request.
('53', 208, 14, 23, 411646) If, there was a Settlement between the Government and the Congress, and if there is a dispute in the interpretation of this Settlement or if either of the parties contravenes the terms of the Settlement, then the same rules that are followed regarding other pacts should be applied to this Settlement too.
('53', 208, 14, 24, 411952) This, in my opinion, is all the more necessary because the present Settlement is between a powerful Government and a mighty Congress, claiming to represent the entire nation.
('53', 208, 14, 25, 412127) The observance of the terms of the present Settlement cannot be enforced by law.
('53', 208, 14, 26, 412208) The Government is
('53', 208, 15, 27, 412226) If however your telegram represents the final word I will at once inform the Prime Minister of your inability to attend the Conference.” 1 In reply the Viceroy wired on August 14: “I have informed the Prime Minister of your decision.
('53', 208, 15, 28, 412460) I am releasing relevant correspondence to the Press.
('53', 208, 15, 29, 412513) You are of course free to do the same.”
('53', 209, 0, 1, 412553) 210 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('53', 209, 1, 2, 412595) therefore doubly bound to place before an impartial tribunal all these points of dispute between itself and the Congress.
('53', 209, 1, 3, 412717) The Government however refused to accept this very modest proposal of the Congress.
('53', 209, 1, 4, 412801) Under these circumstances it would have been very wrong for the Congress to join the Round Table Conference.
('53', 209, 1, 5, 412910) I cannot say anything more than this at this time.
('53', 209, 1, 6, 412961) I hope it would be possible for the Working Committee to publish the relevant correspondence as and when necessary.
('53', 209, 1, 7, 413077) The public will, then, be able to form its own opinion.
('53', 209, 2, 8, 413133) After this, a Press representative asked Mahatma Gandhi: “What is your programme for the future?” Mahatmaji replied: At this moment I am unable to say off hand what the future programme will be.
('53', 209, 2, 9, 413328) It will depend on the steps which the Government will take.
('53', 209, 3, 10, 413388) Q. Will civil disobedience movement be launched and if so when?
('53', 209, 4, 11, 413452) A. As far as I know, there is no idea of starting the satyagraha struggle immediately.
('53', 209, 5, 12, 413539) Q. When will you leave Bombay and what is your destination ?
('53', 209, 6, 13, 413600) A. I intend to leave Bombay tomorrow evening for Ahmedabad.
('53', 209, 7, 14, 413660) Q. Is there any hope of resumption of talks between yourself and the Viceroy about the Settlement?
('53', 209, 8, 15, 413759) A. If you are referring to resumption of talks on the question of representation of the Congress at the Round Table Conference, as far as I know, and as far as the Congress Working Committee is concerned, there is no question of resumption of the talks.
('53', 209, 9, 16, 414013) After this the representative asked whether the Delhi Settlement endured or was abrogated.
('53', 209, 9, 17, 414104) Mahatmaji replied: The breakdown of the present talks does not necessarily mean annulment of the Delhi Pact.
('53', 209, 9, 18, 414213) Refusal to send a representative to the Round Table Conference for breach of the Settlement is one thing; and abrogation of the Settlement itself is another thing.
('53', 209, 9, 19, 414377) I can say this much, namely, Congress is not prepared to do anything drastic in the near future.
('53', 209, 9, 20, 414474) Congress will endeavour its utmost to fulfil the terms of the Settlement.
('53', 209, 9, 21, 414548) But the Government can create intolerable conditions.
('53', 209, 9, 22, 414602) In that case Congress will necessarily act in self defence.
('53', 209, 10, 23, 414662) A representative asked: “Have wholly unbearable conditions been created now?” Mahatma Gandhi replied:
('53', 210, 0, 1, 414764) VOL. 53 : 2 JULY, 1931 12 OCTOBER, 1931 211
('53', 210, 1, 2, 414808) Perhaps wholly unbearable conditions have not been created.
('53', 210, 2, 3, 414868) Q. What did the Viceroy write to you?
('53', 210, 3, 4, 414906) A. I am not in a position to disclose the Viceroy’s reply.
('53', 210, 3, 5, 414965) I am awaiting permission to publish the correspondence.

('53', 211, 25, 30, 417529) 222. LETTER TO VICEROY 1
('53', 211, 26, 31, 417554) August 14, 1931 Events have moved so fast that I have not had the time to acknowledge your very kind personal letter 2 of 31st July.
('53', 211, 26, 32, 417687) I recognize the sincerity running through that communication but the latest developments have made that letter past history, and as I have said in my wire of 13th inst., the sum total of all the circumstances betrays a fundamental difference of outlook between us.
('53', 211, 26, 33, 417952) I can only give you my assurance that it was not without the greatest and most anxious deliberation that I came to the conclusion that in view of your decision I could not, consistently with my obligations here, attend the
('53', 211, 27, 34, 418175) 1 Published under the caption, “Will the Settlement Abide ?” 2 Vide “Letter from Lord Willingdon”, 31 7 1931
('53', 212, 0, 1, 418284) VOL. 53 : 2 JULY, 1931 12 OCTOBER, 1931 213
('53', 212, 1, 2, 418328) Round Table Conference.
('53', 212, 1, 3, 418352) But I was grieved when I heard that your decision was affected by the opinion ascribed to you that I had insisted upon a board of arbitration and that I was trying to set myself up as a head of parallel government.
('53', 212, 1, 4, 418567) As for the board of arbitration it is true that I have claimed it as a matter of right but if you recall our conversation I never insisted upon it.
('53', 212, 1, 5, 418715) On the contrary, I told you that so long as I got the justice to which I was entitled I would be quite satisfied.
('53', 212, 1, 6, 418829) You will agree that this is wholly different from insisting on a board of arbitration.
('53', 212, 1, 7, 418916) As to the alleged parallel government, I thought I had dispelled the illusion when, in reply to a jocular remark by you, I had told you that I did not claim to be a district officer but that my co workers and I had acted as voluntary Patels or village Headmen and that too with the consent and knowledge of district officials.
('53', 212, 1, 8, 419243) I should therefore be sorry if these two opinions which I submit were erroneous had affected your decision.
('53', 212, 1, 9, 419351) The purpose however of writing this letter is to inquire whether you regard the Settlement as now at an end or whether it is to be still continued.
('53', 212, 1, 10, 419499) in spite of the abstention of the Congress from partici pation in the Round Table Conference.
('53', 212, 1, 11, 419593) The Working Committee arrived at the following decision this morning:
('53', 212, 2, 12, 419663) In view of the resolution relating to the Congress non participation in the Round Table Conference passed by the Working Committee on August 13, the Committee desires to make it clear that this resolution should not be construed as ending the Delhi Settlement.
('53', 212, 2, 13, 419924) The Committee therefore advises Congress organizations and all Congressmen to continue to comply, until further instructions, with the terms of the Settlement in so far as they are applicable to the Congress.
('53', 212, 2, 14, 420133) From this you will observe that the Working Committee of the Congress has no desire to embarrass the Government at the present juncture and that therefore it is prepared to continue honourably to work the Settlement.
('53', 212, 2, 15, 420350) But such working must depend upon a reciprocal attitude on the part of Provincial governments.
('53', 212, 2, 16, 420445) As I have told you so often through correspondence and our conversations, this reciprocity has been found to be progressively missing.
('53', 212, 2, 17, 420580) Information continues to be received at the office of the Working Committee of Government activity which can only be interpreted to be token of a design to crush the Congress workers and the normal Congress activities.
('53', 212, 2, 18, 420799) If therefore the Settlement is to abide I venture to think that an early relief in the matter of complaints already filed is necessary.
('53', 212, 2, 19, 420935) More, as I have already said, are coming and co workers are insistent that if relief is
('53', 213, 0, 1, 421023) 214 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('53', 213, 1, 2, 421065) not had in time they should at least get the permission to adopt defensive measures.
('53', 213, 1, 3, 421150) May I request an early reply?

('53', 213, 2, 5, 421203) 223. INTERVIEW TO THE PRESS
('53', 213, 3, 6, 421231) August 14, 1931
('53', 213, 4, 7, 421247) Q. If negotiations are not reopened, will you withhold renewal of the civil disobedience movement until the second Round Table Conference finishes its labour?
('53', 213, 5, 8, 421406) A. It is difficult to give a conclusive answer, but the Congress will make every effort not to renew the civil disobedience movement.
('53', 213, 5, 9, 421540) Much will depend upon the attitude of Government.
('53', 213, 6, 10, 421590) Q. If the second R.T.C. fails to grant your principal demands or substance thereof will you consider the Delhi Pact a dead letter, and will you then renew the struggle?
('53', 213, 7, 11, 421759) A. The renewal of the struggle is a certainty if the Congress demands are not granted.
('53', 213, 8, 12, 421846) Q. If the struggle is resumed, will it be more intensive and upon a wider scale ?
('53', 213, 9, 13, 421928) A. I should hope so.
('53', 213, 9, 14, 421949) Certainly no stone will be left unturned to make the struggle more intensive and extensive.
('53', 213, 10, 15, 422041) Q. In making your decision yesterday, did you pray for divine guidance ?
('53', 213, 11, 16, 422114) A. In all my recent activities and decision 1 yesterday of the Working Committee, the hand of God can be distinctly traced.
('53', 213, 11, 17, 422238) I can assure you that throughout these anxious days, I have searched my heart eagerly for divine guidance.
('53', 213, 12, 18, 422345) Q. If Lord Irwin had been Viceroy, do you think you would have come to terms with him about going to London?
('53', 213, 13, 19, 422454) A. Comparisons are invidious.
('53', 213, 14, 20, 422484) Q. Do you attribute responsibility for the failure of the negotiations to the Provincial authorities, to Earl Willingdon, to the London Government, or to all three?
('53', 213, 15, 21, 422649) A. I attribute responsibility for the failure to the obstinacy of the Provincial authorities, but still more to the force of circum stances.
('53', 213, 16, 22, 422790) Q. Do you believe the Working Committee’s resolution of yesterday leaves the way clear for Government to reopen negotiations, leading to your presence in
('53', 213, 17, 23, 422944) 1 Vide the preceding item.
('53', 214, 0, 1, 422971) VOL. 53 : 2 JULY, 1931 12 OCTOBER, 1931 215
('53', 214, 1, 2, 423015) London?
('53', 214, 2, 3, 423023) A. The Working Committee’s resolution undoubtedly leaves the door open for all kinds of negotiations, so long as they are designed to lead the Congress to its destined goal.
('53', 214, 3, 4, 423197) Q. What in brief are you minimum terms for you going to London?
('53', 214, 4, 5, 423261) A. Satisfactory assurances that the conditions of the Delhi Settlement will be observed by the Provincial governments so far as they are applicable to them.
('53', 214, 4, 6, 423418) Satisfaction must be to the party claiming to be injured, which in this case is the Congress.
('53', 214, 5, 7, 423512) Q. Was failure to settle the Hindu Muslim communal problem or any other
('53', 214, 6, 8, 423584) recent development a contributing factor to your decision not to go to London?
('53', 214, 7, 9, 423663) A. No other happening contributed to my decision except the breakdown of the Delhi Settlement at a most critical period, when, if the Provincial governments had really intended that I should go to London, they would and should have made my way clear.
('53', 214, 8, 10, 423914) Q. Do you think there is any danger of the peasants spontaneously suspending the payment of land revenue when they see that you are not going to London?
('53', 214, 9, 11, 424067) A. I hope not, and certainly not if we have acquired any control over them.

('53', 219, 6, 10, 430157) 234. DIVINE WILL
('53', 219, 7, 11, 430174) All had thought it certain that I would have left on the 15th for England.
('53', 219, 7, 12, 430249) Many persons here, in England and in other parts of the world were eager that I should go.
('53', 219, 7, 13, 430340) However, if a person like Ramachandra had no foreknowledge that at the hour fixed for his coronation he would have to leave for the forest, how can a common man like me or an ordinary organization like the Indian National Congress say with certainty that a certain thing will happen at a certain time?
('53', 219, 7, 14, 430642) God’s will prevails in all matters, and it is always for the best.
('53', 219, 7, 15, 430709) I see nothing but God’s will in the Viceroy’s reply.
('53', 219, 7, 16, 430762) I can certainly state that I sincerely did all that a human being could do to enable me to go to England and take part in the Round Table Conference.
('53', 219, 7, 17, 430912) If, in spite of this I have not been able to go, I am sure that India’s good lies in my not going.
('53', 219, 7, 18, 431011) For myself I see no difference between the officials here and the political leaders in England.
('53', 219, 7, 19, 431107) If we have to struggle hard to secure justice from these officials even in the most trivial matters, and if sometimes we fail to get it despite all our efforts, it is an idle hope that we shall get justice in England in much more important matters.
('53', 219, 7, 20, 431356) The logic of this is quite simple.
('53', 219, 7, 21, 431391) A big sum in arithmetic is the total of small sums.
('53', 219, 7, 22, 431443) What is true of the smallest is true of the biggest.
('53', 219, 7, 23, 431496) If, therefore, it is impossible to secure justice in very small matters, it will also be impossible to get it in a big matter.
('53', 219, 7, 24, 431623) According to this logic, what has happened here is only a warning of what is going to happen in England.
('53', 219, 7, 25, 431728) If this line of reasoning is correct it was best, even from a
('53', 219, 8, 26, 431790) 1 In reply to the addressee’s telegram dated August 15, 1931 which read: “U.P. Government invited Govind Ballabh Pant sit on agrarian committee which considering future revenue policy.
('53', 219, 8, 27, 431975) I consider under present circumstances his joining inadvisable.
('53', 219, 8, 28, 432039) Please wire your opinion to Sherwani Elgin Road Allahabad.”
('53', 220, 0, 1, 432099) VOL. 53 : 2 JULY, 1931 12 OCTOBER, 1931 221
('53', 220, 1, 2, 432143) practical standpoint, that I should not go to England as a repres entative of the Congress.
('53', 220, 1, 3, 432235) However, the fact of my not going has increased the burden of duty on the people.
('53', 220, 1, 4, 432317) I shall now have to ask the nation to work harder and I hope that it will respond.
('53', 220, 1, 5, 432400) Let the people wake up.
('53', 220, 1, 6, 432424) We shall however discuss this further at some other time.

('53', 233, 1, 2, 448946) 261. INTERVIEW TO ASSOCIATED PRESS
('53', 233, 2, 3, 448981) AHMEDABAD, August 18, 1931
('53', 233, 3, 4, 449008) Interviewed .
('53', 233, 3, 5, 449022) in connection with the latest statement made by Pandit Madan Mohan Malaviya 1 Mahatma Gandhi said: I have read Pandit Malaviya’s message.
('53', 233, 3, 6, 449160) Whilst what he says about the immediate demand is substantially true, I am unable to share his opitimism.
('53', 233, 3, 7, 449266) It is perfectly correct for Pandit Malaviya to say that the issue has been narrowed down to one single matter.
('53', 233, 3, 8, 449377) It is so narrowed only for the purpose of enabling me to sail for England, but there is no doubt that underlying the issue there is a big principle which the Government has to face.
('53', 233, 3, 9, 449559) In my opinion, that principle is an integral part of the Settlement, namely, that between the people and the Government the Congress is an intermediary.
('53', 233, 3, 10, 449712) If that fact is not recognized, the Settlement is a nullity, and I fear that it is because the Government do not wish to recognize this natural consequence of the Settlement that Government has broken on the Bardoli matter.
('53', 233, 3, 11, 449936) Whether relief is granted through a board of arbitration or an impartial acceptable inquiry I do not mind.
('53', 233, 3, 12, 450043) There is not the slightest desire to humiliate or embarrass the Government or anybody.
('53', 233, 3, 13, 450130) The only desire is to get justice, somehow or other.
('53', 233, 3, 14, 450183) Let it be after the Government’s manner but it must be justice that would be acknowledged as such by those who are striving for it.
('53', 233, 4, 15, 450315) Asked about the Press report that the Congress was fast preparing for war, that instructions had been sent out to various Congress officials not to obey the orders of the Government calculated to prevent them from enjoying or exercising their lawful rights as regards picketing of foreign cloth and liquor shops, that word had been sent round to the peasants of Kaira and Surat Districts asking them not to pay land revenue more than they could afford and to face the consequences and that the Congress Secretary at Allahabad had been empowered to issue instructions to kisan leaders of the U.P. to resist all measures of repression by zamindars or Government servants,
('53', 233, 5, 16, 450985) 1 In which he had said: “I cannot persuade myself to believe that, where the differences between the Government and the Congress have been reduced to such a small, though important, issue and where the justice of the demand is so clear, the Premier and his colleagues will allow the earnest and arduous labours of the last many months to be defeated, the whole object of which was to secure the representation of the Congress at the Round Table Conference.”
('53', 234, 0, 1, 451443) VOL. 53 : 2 JULY, 1931 12 OCTOBER, 1931 235
('53', 234, 1, 2, 451487) Gandhiji said: This is a deliberate lie.
('53', 234, 1, 3, 451528) No such instructions have been issued to anybody.
('53', 234, 1, 4, 451578) Not only that, instructions have been issued all over the country that the Delhi Pact should be carried out and that nobody should disobey any Government order without the permission of the headquarters.
('53', 234, 1, 5, 451782) I know that the Congress Working Committee is anxious to carry out the Delhi Pact honourably, but if Provincial Governments goad us we shall have to take the defensive.
('53', 234, 1, 6, 451951) I have gathered ample evidence to prove that goading has already begun.
('53', 234, 1, 7, 452023) The Bombay Chronicle, 19 8 1931

('53', 235, 8, 19, 453788) What I feel that I should be going just as I am.

('53', 235, 8, 21, 454005) I am certain that it is the latter with me.

('53', 237, 5, 20, 456500) I did not know that the masses were interested in it.
('53', 237, 5, 21, 456554) I have never, to my recollection, watched any game either in England, South Africa or in India.
('53', 237, 5, 22, 456650) I have never attended cricket matches and only once took a bat and a cricket ball in my hands and that was under compulsion from the head master of the High School where I was studying, and this was over 45 years ago.
('53', 237, 5, 23, 456868) This confession does not in any shape or form mean that I am opposed to games, only I have never been able to interest myself in them.
('53', 237, 5, 24, 457003) In the circumstances it would simply mystify the people if I now came out with a new card even though it might be for the laudable purpose of winning more English friendships and more English sympathy and support for the cause which makes life worth living.

('53', 239, 1, 2, 459027) 271. INTERVIEW TO “THE HINDU”
('53', 239, 2, 3, 459057) AHMEDABAD, August 19, 1931
('53', 239, 3, 4, 459084) Gandhiji’s attention was drawn this morning to an interview given by Sir Prabhashankar Pattani to a Bombay paper and I tried to elicit his views on the proposal enunciated in it, namely, the appointment of a tribunal of three officials with one High Court Judge.
('53', 239, 4, 5, 459347) Although Gandhiji was reluctant to express his opinion on the proposal, I had a long conversation with him from which it could be gathered that Gandhiji does not mind whether it be an enquiry or a tribunal, but what he really wants is the grant of the substance of his demand.
('53', 239, 4, 6, 459624) He said: What is in a name?
('53', 239, 4, 7, 459652) I would be satisfied with anything that gives me the substance.
('53', 239, 5, 8, 459716) Gandhiji said that he would be satisfied if an enquiry on the lines indicated by Sir P. Pattani was given by the Government.
('53', 239, 5, 9, 459841) The Hindu, 19 8 1931
('53', 239, 6, 10, 459862) 272. REPLIES TO QUESTIONS 1
('53', 239, 7, 11, 459890) Wednesday [August 19, 1931]
('53', 239, 8, 12, 459918) Q. Isn’t it tantamount to feeding milk to a serpent if at present an order is placed for British machinery for about half a dozen mills in Ahmedabad ?
('53', 239, 9, 13, 460069) A. Our struggle will gain some strength if an order for British machinery is placed during the Settlement.
('53', 239, 9, 14, 460176) We have no enmity with the British.
('53', 239, 9, 15, 460212) If the struggle is resumed while the order for British machinery is being executed, you should not take exception to goods which have already been ordered.
('53', 239, 9, 16, 460368) We cannot win swaraj by creating enmity in this way.
('53', 239, 9, 17, 460421) You should refuse to accept British goods if the struggle is resumed and they treat you as their enemies.
('53', 239, 9, 18, 460527) One can buy foreign goods so long as Congress has not declared a boycott of foreign goods.
('53', 239, 10, 19, 460618) Q. Will not an increase in the number of mills hinder the progress of khadi ?
('53', 239, 11, 20, 460696) A. The progress of khadi will be hindered not by an increase in the number of mills, but by a decrease in our love for khadi.
('53', 239, 11, 21, 460822) You can

('53', 240, 1, 2, 460911) explain to the people the usefulness of khadi but you cannot stop new mills from being erected.
('53', 240, 2, 3, 461007) [From Gujarati] Gujarati, 23 8 1931
('53', 240, 3, 4, 461043) 273. THE REAL ISSUE
('53', 240, 4, 5, 461063) Though apparently very little difference between the Govern ment and the Congress led to the decision 1 of the Working Committee not to send me to London, really the difference was fundamental.
('53', 240, 4, 6, 461257) This will be clear to everyone who would patiently go through the correspondence published in this issue of Young India.
('53', 240, 4, 7, 461378) In the very first days of the working of the Settlement Mr. Emerson raised the question.
('53', 240, 4, 8, 461467) He contended that the Congress could not act as the intermediary between the Government and the people whom it represented.
('53', 240, 4, 9, 461591) I joined issue on it.
('53', 240, 4, 10, 461613) The legal point was never finally settled.
('53', 240, 4, 11, 461656) I had no desire to embarrass or humiliate the Government.
('53', 240, 4, 12, 461714) I was therefore content so long as in practice the Congress mediation was accepted.
('53', 240, 4, 13, 461798) The reader will see with what reluctance Mr. Garrett reconciled himself to the position.
('53', 240, 4, 14, 461887) 2 But he never pardoned the Congress for presuming to represent the peasantry.
('53', 240, 4, 15, 461966) Had he had his way, it is likely that he would rather have collected what he could through coercion than received all but a few thousand of the current dues in Bardoli and Borsad through the Congress agency.
('53', 240, 4, 16, 462174) The reader will not fail to observe that notices threatening coercion were already issued.
('53', 240, 4, 17, 462265) They were not withdrawn without energetic protest lodged by me on behalf of the Congress.
('53', 240, 4, 18, 462355) It could be shown from documentary proof that occasions were not wanting, as they are not wanting now, to warrant the Congress declaring the Truce to be at an end by reason of the Provincial Governments having failed to carry out its terms.
('53', 240, 4, 19, 462596) I make bold to say that exemplary patience has been shown by the Congress in not terminating the Truce.
('53', 240, 4, 20, 462700) The charge sheet 3 will give a glimpse of breaches alleged by the Congress to have been made by respective Provincial Governments.
('53', 240, 4, 21, 462831) Nor need the reader think that the charge sheet is an exhaustive catalogue of breaches.
('53', 240, 4, 22, 462919) For instance,
('53', 240, 5, 23, 462933) 1 At its meeting on August 13 2 Vide “Letter to J. H. Garrett’ 21 4 1931 & “Letter to J. H. Garrett”, 26 4 1931 3 Vide “A Memorandum”, 21 7 1931
('53', 241, 0, 1, 463078) 242 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('53', 241, 1, 2, 463120) there are several hundred civil resistance prisoners who are still rotting in jail but who according to the opinion of Congress workers are entitled to discharge.
('53', 241, 1, 3, 463283) Strange as it may appear to the reader, these cases are still pending before the Provincial Governments.
('53', 241, 1, 4, 463388) Hence they do not appear on the charge sheet presented at Simla.
('53', 241, 1, 5, 463453) It contains cases about which adverse decisions have already been given by Provincial Governments.
('53', 241, 1, 6, 463552) In fairness to the Central Government I must add that in some few cases mentioned in the charge sheet relief has since been given and it is possible that it may be given in some more.
('53', 241, 1, 7, 463736) But I know that there is little chance of getting relief in the vast majority of the cases.
('53', 241, 1, 8, 463828) Surely it was never contemplated that in cases in which the Congress was not satisfied there should not be an open enquiry.
('53', 241, 1, 9, 463952) If the Settlement was a legalized document the Government would be suable in a court of law.
('53', 241, 1, 10, 464045) The fact however that it is not legalized throws a double responsibility upon the Government of giving the Congress a tribunal where it can prove those breaches or where it can get an authoritative ruling on the interpretation of the several clauses of the Settlement or of its implications.
('53', 241, 1, 11, 464337) The refusal of the Government to concede the very natural implication of the Settlement shows how far the authorities in India are from recognizing the fact that the power is passing to the people, nor are they willing to acknowledge that the Congress represents the people and that its voluntary co operation should be thankfully accepted.
('53', 241, 1, 12, 464678) In their opinion, co operation should mean acceptance of their orders and authority and not mutual trust and accommodation between parties to a contract.
('53', 241, 1, 13, 464832) Everywhere Provincial Governments are looking upon Congressmen with suspicion and in some cases openly treating the Congress as an enemy.
('53', 241, 1, 14, 464970) As I write, I have before me the Bombay Government organ The Gujarat Patrika.
('53', 241, 1, 15, 465048) It contains vilification of Congress and Congressmen, reckless charges against them and in some instances even false allegations.
('53', 241, 1, 16, 465178) If it is said in answer that the Congress has done no better and that it has also committed breaches of the Settlement it will be an unfair charge to make for the simple reason that wherever breaches have been brought to my notice immediate satisfaction or explanation has been given.
('53', 241, 1, 17, 465463) The Congress would welcome an impartial investigation any day of all the charges that can be laid at its door and the Provincial Governments have not hesitated to take proceedings against Congressmen wherever they have thought it necessary.
('53', 241, 1, 18, 465704) My countercharge is that in many cases prosecutions have been persecutions, as for instance in the cases falling under section
('53', 242, 0, 1, 465831) VOL. 53 : 2 JULY, 1931 12 OCTOBER, 1931 243
('53', 242, 1, 2, 465875) 124 A of the Indian Penal Code.
('53', 242, 1, 3, 465907) This is the section dealing with disaffection.
('53', 242, 1, 4, 465954) Now, disaffection has been taken to mean absence of active affection or loyalty.
('53', 242, 1, 5, 466035) Hence anyone who is neutral is guilty of disaffection.
('53', 242, 1, 6, 466090) I must confess that every Congressman is even by reason of his creed guilty of sedition and he did not become less so by reason of the Settlement.
('53', 242, 1, 7, 466237) The Settlement never contemplated that the Congress should alter its goal and its goal is to destroy the existing system of government and to replace it by a wholly national government.
('53', 242, 1, 8, 466423) But I must not prolong this discussion of the Congress position.
('53', 242, 1, 9, 466488) If the Congress was unworthy of confidence, or if its demand was distasteful or unacceptable to the British Government, the Settlement should not have been entered into.
('53', 242, 1, 10, 466658) Further, if the Congress by any action on its part proved itself unworthy of confidence the Settlement should have been repudiated.
('53', 242, 1, 11, 466790) Either would have been an honest course.
('53', 242, 1, 12, 466831) But to have commenced with distrust when the ink had hardly dried on the paper on which the Settlement was written was, and still is, difficult for me to understand.
('53', 242, 1, 13, 466997) In spite, however, of my belief that Provincial Governments had committed serious breaches of the Settlement I was prepared, so far as my departure for London was concerned, to be satisfied merely with securing relief in the matter of the Bardoli collections under coercion, and there too, my submission was either to grant a refund of the collections so made or to have an impartial open enquiry so as to enable me to show that payments were in the vast majority of cases forced from the people, although they were unable to pay and therefore under the Settlement entitled to refund.
('53', 242, 1, 14, 467582) The matter would certainly not have ended there because the Working Committee would have been bound to press for redress in all the other cases.
('53', 242, 1, 15, 467727) This evidently was too much for the Government and therefore they decided to break on Bardoli.
('53', 242, 1, 16, 467822) The inference I have drawn from the conduct of Provincial Governments is that the members of the Civil Service who have the running of the provinces in their hands were really unwilling that I should proceed to London.
('53', 242, 1, 17, 468041) Had they desired otherwise it was open to them, as it is open to them even now, to make the way clear for me by treating the Congress as worthy of their trust and respect and therefore giving it satisfaction through an impartial enquiry where their decisions could not be accepted by the Congress.
('53', 242, 1, 18, 468339) It has been said that in concentrating upon matters of detail I have missed the opportunity of helping decisions on matters of higher
('53', 243, 0, 1, 468473) 244 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('53', 243, 1, 2, 468515) interest.
('53', 243, 1, 3, 468525) I do not look at the two things separately.
('53', 243, 1, 4, 468569) The Government of India is but part of a whole imperial scheme.
('53', 243, 1, 5, 468633) It reflects the position at the centre.
('53', 243, 1, 6, 468673) The centre is therefore very like the Government of India and if the latter is not ready to recognize the right of India to govern herself unfettered by any control from outside, the centre is not likely to think or do otherwise and the closest association with the Government of India during the past four months has left on me the impression that the Civil Service is not ready to recognize the right of India to full freedom.
('53', 243, 1, 7, 469102) I have got too great a regard for their ability, powers of organization, and their influence on British public opinion to think that without their whole hearted co operation and blessing a humble person like me could possibly get anything from London.
('53', 243, 1, 8, 469354) Therefore till the members of that Service are converted there is no scope for the Congress to enter upon negotiations for full freedom.
('53', 243, 1, 9, 469491) It must go through further suffering however costly the process may be.
('53', 243, 1, 10, 469563) Bardoli therefore was for me the acid test.
('53', 243, 1, 11, 469607) It was designed to gauge the Civilian temper.
('53', 243, 1, 12, 469653) Looked at in that light it was not a small thing even as the magnetic needle on an indicator is not a small thing.
('53', 243, 2, 13, 469768) Young India, 20 8 1931
('53', 243, 3, 14, 469791) 274. SWADESHI GOODS
('53', 243, 4, 15, 469811) The Working Committee has now given us a workable definition of swadeshi goods.
('53', 243, 4, 16, 469891) It is as follows:
('53', 243, 5, 17, 469909) Swadeshi goods, not being cloth or yarn, are those goods which are wholly made in India out of raw material whether indigenous or imported by a manufacturer with not less than 75% Indian owned share capital, provided that no goods will be considered swadeshi the manufacture of which is controlled by foreigners.
('53', 243, 6, 18, 470222) For the purposes of this definition the word ‘controlled’ refers to Boards of Directors and/or Managing Agents.
('53', 243, 7, 19, 470334) It shall be open to the Working Committee to publish a list from time to time of goods classed as swadeshi though they may not fully comply with the foregoing definition.
('53', 243, 7, 20, 470505) The definition is open to the objection that it allows of raw materials being imported.
('53', 243, 7, 21, 470593) This latitude was deliberately kept.
('53', 243, 7, 22, 470630) There is no harm in importing raw material when it cannot be found in India.
('53', 243, 7, 23, 470707) It is the skill that has been banished from the land or left undeveloped owing to the absence of the swadeshi spirit.
('53', 243, 7, 24, 470825) A country remains poor in
('53', 244, 0, 1, 470851) VOL. 53 : 2 JULY, 1931 12 OCTOBER, 1931 245
('53', 244, 1, 2, 470895) wealth, both material and intellectual, if it does not develop its handicrafts and its industries and lives a lazy parasitic life by importing all the manufactured articles from outside.
('53', 244, 1, 3, 471082) There was a time when we manufactured almost all we wanted.
('53', 244, 1, 4, 471142) The process is now reversed and we are dependent upon the outside world for most manufactured goods.
('53', 244, 1, 5, 471243) The past year brought forth a remarkable awakening of the swadeshi spirit.
('53', 244, 1, 6, 471318) It has therefore become necessary to define swadeshi goods.
('53', 244, 1, 7, 471378) But in giving a definition care had to be taken not to make the definition so narrow as to make manufacture all but impossible or so wide as to become farcical and swadeshi only in name.
('53', 244, 1, 8, 471565) We do not want to follow the frog in the well policy nor, in seeming to be international, lose our roots.
('53', 244, 1, 9, 471671) We cannot be international, if we lose our individuality, i.e., nationality.
('53', 244, 1, 10, 471748) The reader will also note that cloth or yarn whether cotton, woollen or silken is excluded from the definition.
('53', 244, 1, 11, 471860) One reason is that it is sufficiently known what is swadeshi cloth.
('53', 244, 1, 12, 471928) But the second and for me the most important is that swadeshi cloth for Congressmen means only and exclusively hand spun and hand woven khadi.
('53', 244, 1, 13, 472071) Indigenous mill cloth is meant for those whom the Congress message cannot or does not reach.
('53', 244, 1, 14, 472164) It will also be noticed that since, at the present stage of our evolution, we have to be satisfied about many things being not wholly swadeshi the Working Committee has reserved the right to issue a list from time to time of such articles as may not wholly satisfy the definition and yet to exclude them would be injurious to the best interest of the country.
('53', 244, 1, 15, 472524) Young India, 20 8 1931

('53', 248, 9, 19, 478111) 282. INTERVIEW TO “THE BOMBAY CHRONICLE”

('53', 248, 11, 21, 478179) Interviewed by the Chronicle correspondent this noon, with regard to Mr. Brelvi’s telegram, Mahatmaji gave this following statement: The message you have shown me causes me no surprise.
('53', 248, 11, 22, 478365) There were no negotiations being carried on.
('53', 248, 11, 23, 478410) Therefore, there was no question of closing them.
('53', 248, 11, 24, 478460) My going to London became remote on the 13th instant, when the Viceregal wire was received.
('53', 248, 11, 25, 478552) It is no more remote now than it became then.

('53', 249, 0, 1, 478659) 250 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('53', 249, 1, 2, 478701) to accept my challenge”.

('53', 249, 1, 4, 478754) Whatever I have said has been published in the correspondence.
('53', 249, 1, 5, 478817) If my letter to the Collector of Surat be regarded as a challenge, then that letter undoubtedly stands.
('53', 249, 1, 6, 478921) The material result has been already achieved, that is to say, I could not go to London.
('53', 249, 1, 7, 479010) The honour of the Congress pledge to Bardoli peasants was thereby vindicated.
('53', 249, 1, 8, 479088) The rest is in the lap of the Government.
('53', 249, 1, 9, 479130) Whatever the final decision of the Government may be, I decline to believe that it can possibly be affected by the publication of the charge sheet which was part of the relevant correspondence.
('53', 249, 1, 10, 479324) This publication was authorized by the telegram of 14th from Simla and already published.

('53', 249, 3, 16, 479938) 283. INTERVIEW TO ASSOCIATED PRESS
('53', 249, 4, 17, 479973) AHMEDABAD, August 20, 1931
('53', 249, 5, 18, 480000) Interviewed by a representative of the Associated Press in connection with the Press report that the publication of the charge sheet has removed whatever little chances there were of Government negotiating successfully with him in order to facilitate his proceeding to London, Mahatma Gandhi said: As I stated the other day, I do not share Pandit Malaviya’s optimism, 1 but if there was any chance of the Government of India conceding the just claim for an impartial enquiry, I am unable to understand why that chance is in any way diminished or affected by the publication of the charge sheet.
('53', 249, 5, 19, 480595) Indeed, the reference to it in the Viceroy’s letter to me, which was published at Simla, made it imperative for me to publish the
('53', 249, 6, 20, 480725) 1 Vide “Interview to Associated Press”, 18 8 1931
('53', 250, 0, 1, 480775) VOL. 53 : 2 JULY, 1931 12 OCTOBER, 1931 251
('53', 250, 1, 2, 480819) charge sheet.
('53', 250, 1, 3, 480833) There was an insistent demand for it by many people and I think that demand was reasonable and just.
('53', 250, 1, 4, 480934) Moreover, without publishing the charge sheet, I could not present the Congress case in its completeness.
('53', 250, 1, 5, 481040) Lastly, I published the papers only after getting the permission of the Viceroy.
('53', 250, 1, 6, 481121) I am, therefore, wholly unrepentant regarding the publication of the charge sheet.
('53', 250, 1, 7, 481204) So far as countercharges against the Congress are concerned, I will welcome them and I would like them to be sifted and investigated by an impartial tribunal.

('53', 254, 6, 8, 488620) MY DEAR NARIMAN, I have seen your letter to Mahadev.
('53', 254, 6, 9, 488673) When I mentioned picketing in the charge sheet I certainly did not have Bombay in my mind, whether regarding the molestation of the picketers or regarding laxity of excise administration.
('53', 254, 6, 10, 488861) Bombay therefore is a slip.
('53', 254, 6, 11, 488889) I do not know now how the slip occurred.
('53', 254, 6, 12, 488930) In any event I had the Presidency in my mind and then too I had Ahmedabad, Surat District and Ratnagiri District in mind.
('53', 254, 6, 13, 489052) I am sorry therefore for any inadvertent reflection upon the Bombay police.
('53', 254, 6, 14, 489128) I am glad that so far as the police conduct is concerned you have nothing to complain against them in Bombay.
('53', 254, 6, 15, 489238) You can make what use you like of this letter.
('53', 254, 6, 16, 489285) With reference to Mr. Joshi I had advice from the Bombay Government saying that the orders regarding him had already been withdrawn.
('53', 254, 6, 17, 489418) You will see in the introduction to the correspondence in Young India 1 that acknowledgment has been made that in some cases relief had already been granted.

('53', 256, 2, 3, 490942) AHMEDABAD, August 21, 1931
('53', 256, 3, 4, 490969) MY DEAR TIMMAPPA, Kakasaheb has handed your letter to me for reply.
('53', 256, 3, 5, 491037) I never suggested that any of the Seva Dal people had actually taken a perpetual vow of ahimsa.
('53', 256, 3, 6, 491133) What I said 1 at the morning meeting you refer to was an expression of my own longing as also expectation, and those who were there seemed to assent to the proposition that with the Seva Dal people non violence must not merely be a policy but it should be a creed.
('53', 256, 3, 7, 491398) I quite agree with you that there cannot be a sudden transformation in a minute because I desire something or because the Seva Dal becomes a full fledged Congress organization.
('53', 256, 3, 8, 491575) For me it is enough that you say that the volunteers acquitted themselves creditably during the last struggle and strove to live up to non violence.
('53', 256, 3, 9, 491724) I may however add that Dr. Hardikar had more than one conversation with me and he told me that with him non violence was fast becoming a creed if it had not already become so.
('53', 256, 3, 10, 491900) With reference to boycott I hope to find some time to make my position clear, if it is at all possible, in the pages of Young India.
('53', 256, 3, 11, 492033) You have stated it correctly.
('53', 256, 3, 12, 492063) The information that you received that in emergency volunteers may adopt foreign dress to escape detection is wholly wrong.
('53', 256, 3, 13, 492187) I have never held such a view, much less expressed it.

('53', 261, 1, 2, 497583) challenged this statement and I then promised that I would have the figures collected and published, which I propose to do as soon as I have collected them.
('53', 261, 1, 3, 497740) As monies were distributed by different agencies it may take a little time.

('53', 261, 6, 13, 498370) 300. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('53', 261, 7, 14, 498398) AHMEDABAD, August 21, 1931
('53', 261, 8, 15, 498425) Asked what Gandhiji meant by his statement to the Bombay Chronicle representative, 1 viz., “Indeed I will be prepared to advise the Working Committee to accept even a one sided tribunal, that is, a tribunal that may confine its attention only to investigate the countercharges” Gandhiji replied: I am not prepared to give up my demand for an impartial enquiry into the charges brought by the Congress, but what I said to the Chronicle representative was that I would be prepared to advise the Working Committee to face an enquiry that would only investigate charges against the Congress.
('53', 261, 8, 16, 499013) In other words, I would not make it a condition precedent that the tribunal that goes into the charges against the Congress should also investigate the charges by the Congress against the Provincial Governments.
('53', 261, 8, 17, 499225) The Congress wishes to hide nothing, nor does the Con 
('53', 261, 9, 18, 499280) 1 Vide “Interview to “The Bombay Chronicle”, 20 8 1931
('53', 262, 0, 1, 499335) VOL. 53 : 2 JULY, 1931 12 OCTOBER, 1931 263
('53', 262, 1, 2, 499379) gress wish to shirk its representation at the Round Table Conference, but the condition of going to the Round Table Conference should be fulfilled, namely, satisfactory fulfilment of the terms of the Settlement by the Government.
('53', 262, 1, 3, 499609) That satisfaction can only be given by the Government either conceding the Congress demands or failing that by appointing a tribunal of enquiry.
('53', 262, 1, 4, 499754) I can conceive nothing more just, nothing more simple and nothing more honourable.
('53', 262, 1, 5, 499837) The Bombay Chronicle, 22 8 1931
