('53', 269, 6, 14, 509155) 315. STATEMENT TO ASSOCIATED PRESS
('53', 269, 7, 15, 509190) AHMEDABAD, August 22, 1931 I do not consider the Viceroy’s reply 1 to be at all bad or disappointing.
('53', 269, 7, 16, 509292) In fact I was prepared for some such reply.
('53', 269, 7, 17, 509336) I am glad too that, so far as I can understand the letter, the Government do not intend to terminate the Settlement and as the public is well aware, the Working Committee of the Congress has already passed a resolution to that effect.
('53', 269, 7, 18, 509571) I am therefore hoping that all Congressmen will meticulously observe the Settlement.
('53', 269, 7, 19, 509656) So far as the charges against the Congress are concerned and so far as the denial of the charges by the Congress against the Provincial authorities is concerned, that is a matter of opinion.
('53', 269, 7, 20, 509847) When the expected countercharge sheet against the Congress is published, I shall be able to deal with it.
('53', 269, 7, 21, 509953) For the moment, I can only say that the Working Committee of the Congress has been most anxious that the Congress should present an absolutely clean slate.
('53', 269, 8, 22, 510109) 1 Presumably, to Gandhiji’s letter of August 14, 1931; vide” Letter to Viceroy”, 14 8 1931 According to Dr. Pattabhi Sitaramayya, the Viceroy had stated that “Government would continue to avoid resort to special measures so far as possible restricting action to the requirements of the specific situation”, describing Gandhiji’s not attending the Round Table Conference as “failure of one of the main objects of the settlement”.
('53', 270, 0, 1, 510538) VOL. 53 : 2 JULY, 1931 12 OCTOBER, 1931 271
('53', 270, 1, 2, 510582) I know the belief of the Government regarding the Frontier Province and the U.P. I have always combated that belief, but it has been a tug of war between two beliefs.
('53', 270, 1, 3, 510749) All I can say is that I have done everything I could to ascertain the facts for myself, and I have not been able except in isolated cases to detect any breach on the part of Congressmen.
('53', 270, 1, 4, 510936) Wherever it has been detected I have made admission and amends where possible to the Government.
('53', 270, 1, 5, 511033) So far as charges against Provincial authorities are concerned, I have offered on behalf of the Working Committee to establish them before an impartial tribunal.
('53', 270, 1, 6, 511195) I could not do anything more and it would be a breach of duty to the Congress if I was satisfied with anything less.
('53', 270, 1, 7, 511312) I fully acknowledge and am aware that the refusal of the Congress to be represented at the R.T.C. involves the failure of one of the main objects of the Settlement.
('53', 270, 1, 8, 511477) I regret it as much as the Government, but the Working Committee was helpless.
('53', 270, 1, 9, 511556) Attendance at the Conference was conditional upon the fulfil ment of the Settlement by the Government.
('53', 270, 1, 10, 511659) Rightly or wrongly the Working Committee came to the conclusion, and I associate myself with the conclusion, that the Provincial Governments have in more instances than one failed to implement the Settlement.
('53', 270, 1, 11, 511868) With that belief it is not possible for the Congress to be represented at Round Table Conference unless a way is found, namely, the appointment of a tribunal or reasonable satisfaction to the Congress in some other manner.
('53', 270, 2, 12, 512091) In the midst therefore of conflict of opinion there should be a referee.
('53', 270, 2, 13, 512164) My suggestion for a tribunal is, therefore, the most natural corollary.
('53', 270, 2, 14, 512236) What shape that tribunal should take is undoubtedly a matter for mutual discussion and accommodation.
('53', 270, 2, 15, 512338) Personally, I should be satisfied so long as there is reasonable assurance of impartiality from the tribunal.
('53', 270, 2, 16, 512448) The appointment of such a tribunal can in no way diminish the dignity, prestige or authority of the Government.
('53', 270, 2, 17, 512560) I hold that such an appointment is an ordinary function of a well ordered Government and if this very Government has appointed committees of enquiry for matters outside contractual relations, how much greater there must be the need for such a tribunal when parties to the contract are dissatisfied as to the conduct of each towards the other and arising out of the contract itself ?
('53', 270, 3, 18, 512943) The Hindu, 23 8 1931, and The Times of India, 24 8 1931
('53', 270, 4, 19, 512999) 1 In The Times of India report this and the preceding paragraphs are placed at the end.
('53', 271, 0, 1, 513087) 272 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('53', 271, 1, 2, 513129) 316. ANSWER TO QUESTION
('53', 271, 2, 3, 513153) AHMEDABAD, August 22, 1931
('53', 271, 3, 4, 513180) If instead of replying whether the Truce terminates or continues, the Government arrests leaders, will the Congress renew the fight automatically, or will permission be required?
('53', 271, 3, 5, 513359) This was one of the questions put to Mr. Gandhi this evening at prayer time.
('53', 271, 3, 6, 513436) Mr. Gandhi replied that the fight could not be renewed till the Working Committee gave permission.
('53', 271, 3, 7, 513535) He had, however, received the Viceroy’s reply in which it was stated that the Government did not desire to terminate the Truce.
('53', 271, 3, 8, 513663) The fight could not, therefore, be renewed automatically.
('53', 271, 4, 9, 513721) The Times of India, 24 8 1931
('53', 271, 5, 10, 513751) 317. BURNT ROPE RETAINS TWIST
('53', 271, 6, 11, 513781) Ordinarily, when we burn wood, cloth and such other things, they are reduced to a small heap of ashes.
('53', 271, 6, 12, 513884) About the coir rope, however, people believe and the belief is correct, that when it is burnt its twisted shape remains.
('53', 271, 6, 13, 514005) It will disappear only when we crush the ashes with our hands.
('53', 271, 6, 14, 514068) Something similar may be said about this Government.
('53', 271, 6, 15, 514121) If this were not true, why should it be reluctant to agree to set up an impartial tribunal to resolve the difference that has arisen regarding the implementation of the Settlement signed by the Government and the Congress?
('53', 271, 6, 16, 514344) This Settlement is a kind of contract.
('53', 271, 6, 17, 514383) Any dispute that may arise about a contract is decided by a court, no matter whether we call it a board of arbitrators or a court of law.
('53', 271, 6, 18, 514521) The basic point is that only a disinterested party should decide the issue.
('53', 271, 6, 19, 514597) Is there anything special about the Settlement between the Government and the Congress that the Settlement cannot be submitted to a tribunal?
('53', 271, 6, 20, 514739) If the Government alone could decide in case of difference of opinion between it and the Congress, where was the utility of such a Settlement at all?
('53', 271, 6, 21, 514889) And why should the Congress have accepted such a Settlement?
('53', 271, 6, 22, 514950) The necessity for obtaining the decision of an impartial court or tribunal would arise only when the Congress did not agree with the Government’s interpretation of any of its clauses.
('53', 271, 6, 23, 515134) If, in such an event, the Government itself assumes the role of a judge, what attitude should the Congress adopt?
('53', 271, 6, 24, 515248) What will the world think?
('53', 271, 6, 25, 515275) If the Congress keeps quiet, the only possible interpretation would be that
('53', 272, 0, 1, 515351) VOL. 53 : 2 JULY, 1931 12 OCTOBER, 1931 273
('53', 272, 1, 2, 515395) the Congress had become altogether powerless.
('53', 272, 1, 3, 515441) How can the Congress, an organization acting in the name of and on behalf of millions, tolerate remaining in such a helpless condition?
('53', 272, 1, 4, 515577) It exercised patience and endured the situation.
('53', 272, 1, 5, 515626) It was only when it had no alternative left and saw that injustice was being done to the poor cultivators, that it decided to tolerate the situation no longer and not to send its representative to the Round Table Conference.
('53', 272, 1, 6, 515851) It may be said that by taking that decision it has proved that it truly represents the country.
('53', 272, 1, 7, 515947) The Government’s attitude, revealed at the end of the negotiations, suggests that if we are to get swaraj only through its favour, swaraj is still a long way off.
('53', 272, 1, 8, 516110) To me at least it seems dangerous simple mindedness to believe that the Governmentofficials, who are unwilling today to allow a court of law, set up as part of its own machinery, to inquire into their actions, will tomorrow relinquish power and hand it over to the people.
('53', 272, 1, 9, 516383) Fortunately no nation’s freedom depends on the will of a foreign government or a foreign power.
('53', 272, 1, 10, 516479) It depends only on the people’s own will and their ability to enforce it.
('53', 272, 1, 11, 516553) If the Congress lacks the strength to secure justice in a very simple matter in India, it will be able to secure nothing from England.
('53', 272, 1, 12, 516688) Looking at the matter from this standpoint, it would make no difference whether or not the Congress representative went to England.
('53', 272, 1, 13, 516820) When it becomes necessary for a representative to go there to carry on negotiations for swaraj, his path will be clear.
('53', 272, 1, 14, 516940) The refusal to meet the demands made on behalf of the Bardoli cultivators is in my opinion the plainest and clearest hint to the Congress not to send its representative to England.
('53', 272, 1, 15, 517121) Those who were eager that I should go need not at all be disappointed.
('53', 272, 1, 16, 517192) My view has always been that the nation ought not to look to England or Simla or Delhi for swaraj.
('53', 272, 1, 17, 517291) The right course for the people is to rely on themselves.
('53', 272, 1, 18, 517349) As we advance through our strength we may occasionally have to visit Delhi or Simla or England or any other place, but the people should understand that if we win anything it will be through our own strength and in the measure of our strength.
('53', 272, 2, 19, 517593) [From Gujarati] Navajivan 23 8 1931

('53', 276, 3, 10, 521106) 325. INTERVIEW TO THE PRESS
('53', 276, 4, 11, 521134) NEW DELHI, August 24, 1931
('53', 276, 5, 12, 521161) A Press representative asked Gandhiji:
('53', 276, 6, 13, 521200) Considering that the Government agrees to appoint a tribunal mutually acceptable to enquire into the allegations and counter allegations made by the Congress and the Government, and considering further that the Government disputes the intermediary status of the Congress being implied in the Settlement, will you agree to place this issue also before the tribunal for its decision?
('53', 276, 6, 14, 521582) Mr. Gandhi replied: If the Government appoints such a tribunal and disputes even this elementary question which I consider a part of the Pact, I will have no objection to placing even this before the tribunal and abiding by its decision.

('53', 277, 10, 25, 523802) Gandhiji added that his going to England depended on Government giving satisfaction to the Congress in respect of his demands.

('53', 278, 1, 3, 524292) First, by conceding the Congress demand in full, secondly.

('53', 279, 1, 2, 525679) 331. LETTER TO H. W. EMERSON
('53', 279, 2, 3, 525708) SIMLA, August 26, 1931
('53', 279, 3, 4, 525731) DEAR MR. EMERSON, Through the telephone you have asked me to send you the amendments that I passed over the telephone to the draft communique given me by you this afternoon.
('53', 279, 3, 5, 525905) Those amendments were suggested by my colleagues who are here.
('53', 279, 3, 6, 525968) With slight alterations I give them below: Here is the first amendment: “Mr. Gandhi, while stating that the Congress were desirous that nothing should be done to the prejudice of peaceful conditions, wished to make it clear that this did not imply any undertaking restricting the future action of the Congress in the matter of continuing grievances or in respect of unforeseen developments.” The portion underlined 1 represents the amendment suggested in the first sentence of paragraph 5 by my colleagues.
('53', 279, 3, 7, 526475) I need hardly say that I entirely endorse the suggestion.
('53', 279, 3, 8, 526533) You will observe that with the exception of the portion underlined, we have accepted the amendment telephoned by you.
('53', 279, 3, 9, 526651) I may say that there is no desire to insist upon the wording suggested here.
('53', 279, 3, 10, 526728) All that is sought to be made perfectly clear is that paragraph 3 of the draft communique does not in any way fetter the future action of the Congress.
('53', 279, 3, 11, 526880) Nor does it mean that for every grievance large or small there is to be insistence upon an enquiry by the Congress.
('53', 279, 3, 12, 526996) But the Congress should not be expected to waive the right to seek redress, and failing redress to adopt such measures as may seem to it to be necessary.
('53', 279, 3, 13, 527150) As a matter of fact, this is an elementary principle which does not need any enunciation.
('53', 279, 3, 14, 527240) It is brought in here to avoid any possibility of a charge of breach of faith on the part of the Congress.
('53', 279, 3, 15, 527347) This clearance has become all the more necessary because of the inferences you draw from our conversations at Richmond.
('53', 279, 3, 16, 527467) The Council’s suggestion that the sentence, viz., “To this the Government of India take no exception” be dropped is accepted.
('53', 279, 3, 17, 527593) It is further suggested on behalf of the Congress that the rest of
('53', 279, 4, 18, 527660) 1 Here italicized
('53', 280, 0, 1, 527678) VOL. 53 : 2 JULY, 1931 12 OCTOBER, 1931 281
('53', 280, 1, 2, 527722) paragraph 5 should be dropped.
('53', 280, 1, 3, 527753) You will recognize that the sentence beginning “so long as the Settlement.
('53', 280, 1, 4, 527828) provisions” is a repetition, with slight changes, of para 2 of the communique.
('53', 280, 1, 5, 527907) The remainder of the paragraph giving a long quotation from the letter from H. E. the Viceroy addressed to me and dated the 19th inst.
('53', 280, 1, 6, 528042) torn from its context bears an altogether different meaning.
('53', 280, 1, 7, 528103) My colleagues have pointed out that the bare quotation would seem to carry an interpretation which commits me and the Congress to an endorsement of the claim that the Government of India have hitherto followed the policy of restricting action to the requirements of the specific situation.
('53', 280, 1, 8, 528393) You will agree that neither the Congress nor I have ever endorsed the claim.
('53', 280, 1, 9, 528470) On the contrary we have had the misfortune often to point out to Government that their action has in numerous cases gone beyond the requirements of specific situation.
('53', 280, 1, 10, 528638) I venture to suggest that the reminder, in a communique designed to secure peace and facilitate my departure to London on an errand of peace, that the Government possess certain powers which the Congress may not question is hardly opportune or advisable.
('53', 280, 1, 11, 528893) I do not know that the powers of the Government become any the more emphatic or operative by reason of the recital.
('53', 280, 1, 12, 529009) It had a meaning in a letter which was addressed to me to serve a purpose wholly different from the purpose that we all, I hope, have in view.
('53', 280, 1, 13, 529152) You have, in the course of the last conversation that we had over the phone, told me, on behalf of the Council, something very startling and distressing.
('53', 280, 1, 14, 529306) I can only hope that I have misunderstood your message.
('53', 280, 1, 15, 529362) It sounded very much like a breaking up of the negotiations which His Excellency, you and I had believed, had almost reached their fruition.
('53', 280, 1, 16, 529503) Surely there is nothing extraordinary in the amendments suggested herein as to lead to such a tragic end.
('53', 280, 1, 17, 529609) I can therefore only hope that having come so near, it will not be said of us, no matter whose fault it was, we had come near only in order to separate.
('53', 280, 1, 18, 529762) In my opinion there is ample room for discussion and accommodation if we mean the same thing.
('53', 280, 1, 19, 529856) If we do not, the sooner the agony of suspense ends the better.
('53', 280, 1, 20, 529920) I note your warning that the draft communique is provisional and confidential, Confidence will be respected.
('53', 280, 1, 21, 530029) Yours sincerely, H. W. EMERSON, ESQ.
('53', 280, 1, 22, 530066) HOME SECRETARY TO THE GOVERNMENT OF INDIA SIMLA
('53', 280, 2, 23, 530114) From a Photostat: S. N. 17601
('53', 281, 0, 1, 530144) 282 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('53', 281, 1, 2, 530186) 332. MILLS AND LABOUR
('53', 281, 2, 3, 530208) The Congress lives for the labourer, and for the capitalist in so far as the latter subserves the former’s purpose.
('53', 281, 2, 4, 530324) Therefore the Congress is in alliance with the mill owners in the matter of boycott of foreign cloth, only because boycott is calculated to benefit the labourer and the vast mass of consumers in the very near future.
('53', 281, 2, 5, 530541) The alliance is voluntary and capable of being broken up at the option of either party.
('53', 281, 2, 6, 530629) It can be and will be broken up when the mills find it profitless.
('53', 281, 2, 7, 530696) It may and must be broken up by the Congress if it injures khadi, or if it injures or exploits the labourer, or if it exploits the consumer.
('53', 281, 2, 8, 530837) Khadi may suffer temporary check as perhaps it has.
('53', 281, 2, 9, 530889) The consumer may, for a year or two but no longer, pay a protection duty by way of higher prices, not for the higher profit of the shareholders but for the economic working of mills.
('53', 281, 2, 10, 531072) But the Congress can never allow the labourer to be exploited.
('53', 281, 2, 11, 531135) In other words, his position must not be worse than before the boycott.
('53', 281, 2, 12, 531207) On the contrary, the alliance imposes a greater duty upon the Congress of seeing that the labourer’s position is all the better for it.
('53', 281, 2, 13, 531343) The Congress has to ascertain the condition of the labourers of a particular mill before it enters into any contract with it.
('53', 281, 2, 14, 531469) It was because the Working Committee realized this special obligation, that it passed the following resolution at its last meeting: 1
('53', 281, 3, 15, 531603) The Working Committee draws the attention of owners and managers of mills, especially those recognized by the Congress, to the resolution 2 of the Working Committee dated July 10th, 1931, and draws further attention to the fact, that the Working Committee has received complaints about the treatment of textile labourers and the growing discontent amongst them, as also of proposed reduction of wages in some mills.
('53', 281, 4, 16, 532019) The Committee hopes, that the owners and managers will remove all causes of discontent.
('53', 281, 4, 17, 532107) The Working Committee believes, that representing, as the Congress does predominantly, the interests of millions of agricultural and
('53', 281, 5, 18, 532240) 1 Held in Bombay from August 9 to 14 2 This read: “The Working Committee is of opinion, that the Textile Mills Exemption Committee should endeavour, wherever possible and necessary, to prevent by amicable arrangement any penalization or victimization of labour in the mills which have signed the Congress declaration, and to help in the bettering of labour conditions in these mills.”
('53', 282, 0, 1, 532625) VOL. 53 : 2 JULY, 1931 12 OCTOBER, 1931 283
('53', 282, 1, 2, 532669) industrial workers, any recognition by the Congress of the mills will be inconsistent with the claim, wherever there is previous justification for such complaints.
('53', 282, 1, 3, 532833) Among the private resolutions referred to the Committee by the A.I.C.C. at its last session was one referring to mill workers.
('53', 282, 1, 4, 532960) It was a drastic resolution.
('53', 282, 1, 5, 532989) I have before me a list of mills that are said to have threatened a cut in the wages.
('53', 282, 1, 6, 533075) The Working Committee therefore passed the foregoing mild resolution.
('53', 282, 1, 7, 533145) It enunciates its policy and duty in the matter.
('53', 282, 1, 8, 533194) It constitutes an assurance to the labourers, that the Congress will never be party to any injury to labour and it is a notice to the mill owners of the Congress policy regarding labour.
('53', 282, 1, 9, 533381) It must not on any account be treated as a threat of any kind whatsoever.
('53', 282, 1, 10, 533455) It should be as much the mill owners’ interest as that of the Congress to guard the well being of labour.
('53', 282, 1, 11, 533561) The peaceful road to swaraj lies through a co ordination, not antagonism, of all national effort.
('53', 282, 1, 12, 533659) And this co ordination must move towards one grand consummation— Freedom of Labour, whether on the field or in the factory.
('53', 282, 1, 13, 533783) Young India, 27 8 1931
('53', 282, 2, 14, 533806) 333. NOTES
('53', 282, 3, 15, 533817) THE CONGRESS FLAG
('53', 282, 4, 16, 533835) It was but meet that the All India Congress Committee adopted 1
('53', 282, 5, 17, 533899) a flag by the following resolution almost unanimously passed:
('53', 282, 6, 18, 533961) The National Flag shall be three coloured, horizontally arranged as before, but the colours shall be saffron, white and green, in the order stated here, from top to bottom, with the spinning wheel in dark blue in the centre of the white stripe; it being understood that the colours have no communal significance, but that saffron shall represent courage and sacrifice, white peace and truth, and green shall represent faith and chivalry, and the spinning wheel the hope of the masses.
('53', 282, 6, 19, 534446) The proportions of the flag should be fly to hoist as three to two.
('53', 282, 6, 20, 534514) It should be remembered, that the white, green, and red tricolour flag was never authoritatively adopted by the Congress.
('53', 282, 6, 21, 534636) It was conceived by me, and I had certainly given it a communal meaning.
('53', 282, 6, 22, 534709) It was intended to represent communal unity.
('53', 282, 6, 23, 534754) The Sikhs protested and demanded their colour.
('53', 282, 6, 24, 534801) Consequently a Committee was appointed.
('53', 282, 7, 25, 534841) 1 At its session from August 6 to 8, 1931
('53', 283, 0, 1, 534883) 284 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('53', 283, 1, 2, 534925) collected valuable evidence and made useful recommendations.
('53', 283, 1, 3, 534986) And now we have a flag, which has been authoritatively robbed of any communal meaning, and has a definite meaning assigned to each colour.
('53', 283, 1, 4, 535125) The red has been replaced by saffron colour, and is put first purely from the artistic standpoint.
('53', 283, 1, 5, 535224) White has been put between saffron and green in order to heighten the effect, and to show off the whole flag to advantage.
('53', 283, 1, 6, 535347) The wheel is to be shown on the white strip in blue black.
('53', 283, 1, 7, 535406) There can be no doubt that this is an improvement.
('53', 283, 1, 8, 535457) It is a matter of great joy that the wheel has been retained as ‘the hope of the masses’.
('53', 283, 1, 9, 535547) It has proved itself as such.
('53', 283, 1, 10, 535577) Wherever it has gone, it has brought happiness, and banished pauperism.
('53', 283, 1, 11, 535649) It is now the duty of Congress workers to explain the meaning of the national flag, and let me hope that we shall translate the full meaning into our own lives.
('53', 283, 1, 12, 535810) No doubt it will be defended with our lives, but the true defence will consist in assimilating the qualities represented by the colours and giving the spinning wheel a place in every home.
('53', 283, 1, 13, 535999) Then we shall need no picketing of foreign cloth.
('53', 283, 1, 14, 536049) If we will die for the flag, let us first learn to live for it.
('53', 283, 2, 15, 536113) TO THE PARSIS

('53', 284, 1, 2, 537333) TRIALS BY JURY
('53', 284, 2, 3, 537348) A correspondent reminds me that the A.I.C.C. has omitted from its recital of fundamental rights that of trial by jury.
('53', 284, 2, 4, 537467) I do not know the mind of the other members.
('53', 284, 2, 5, 537512) Personally I would have resisted the inclusion.
('53', 284, 2, 6, 537560) I am unconvinced of the advantages of jury trials over those by judges.
('53', 284, 2, 7, 537632) In coming to a correct decision, we must not be obsessed by our unfortunate experience of the judiciary here, which in political trials has been found to be notoriously partial to the Government.
('53', 284, 2, 8, 537828) At the right moment juries have been found to fail even in England.
('53', 284, 2, 9, 537896) When passions are roused, juries are affected by them and give perverse verdicts.
('53', 284, 2, 10, 537978) Nor need we assume that they are always on the side of leniency.
('53', 284, 2, 11, 538043) I have known juries finding prisoners guilty in the face of evidence and even judge’s summing up to the contrary.
('53', 284, 2, 12, 538157) We must not slavishly copy all that is English.
('53', 284, 2, 13, 538205) In matters where absolute impartiality, calmness and ability to sift evidence and understand human nature are required, we may not replace trained judges by untrained men brought together by chance.
('53', 284, 2, 14, 538404) What we must aim at is an incorruptible, impartial and able judiciary right from the bottom.
('53', 284, 2, 15, 538497) I regard village panchayats as an institution by itself.
('53', 284, 2, 16, 538554) But thanks to the degradation of the caste system and the evil influence of the present system of government and the growing illiteracy of the masses, this ancient and noble institution has fallen into desuetude, and where it has not, it has lost its former purity and hold.
('53', 284, 2, 17, 538829) It must, however, be revived at any cost, if the villages are not to be ruined.

('53', 285, 2, 4, 540026) A SWADESHI PHILANTHROPIC COMPANY
('53', 285, 3, 5, 540059) The Swadeshi Electric Clock Manufacturing Company has its workshop in Sastri Hall, Grant Road.
('53', 285, 3, 6, 540154) Some days ago I had the pleasure of visiting this workshop in Jamnalalji’s company.
('53', 285, 3, 7, 540238) Satishbabu of Khadi Pratishthan was also with me at the time.
('53', 285, 3, 8, 540300) But as he is an expert in these matters, I asked him to visit the works again, and give me his own impressions, which he has done.
('53', 285, 3, 9, 540431) He speaks highly of the possibilities of this enterprise.
('53', 285, 3, 10, 540489) It owes its origin to the educational activities of the Tilak Rashtriya Pathshala of Nipani, a national school in Karnatak.
('53', 285, 3, 11, 540613) The school was established during the Non co operation days of 1921. Industrial education was part of its syllabus.
('53', 285, 3, 12, 540729) In Shri M. D. Joshi, a life member, the school had a technical expert of great ability.
('53', 285, 3, 13, 540817) The management therefore wanted him to take regular training, and he took the engineering course and stood first in the final examination.
('53', 285, 3, 14, 540956) Then he served as an apprentice in the B.B.&C.I. Railway Parel Workshop, and then in the Royal Indian Marine Dockyards.
('53', 285, 3, 15, 541076) During all this time he devoted his spare time to experiments in the manufacture of electric clocks.
('53', 285, 3, 16, 541177) The upshot of all these labours was the present concern which became possible through the voluntary support of Sardar Dajisaheb Patwardhan of Poona.
('53', 285, 3, 17, 541326) He lent Rs. 20,000 as capital to the company without any interest, and without even requiring any security.
('53', 285, 3, 18, 541434) Its directors are Principal Limaye of the Tilak Mahavidyalaya, Poona, Dr. R. N. Datar, Sr.
('53', 285, 3, 19, 541525) Joshi and Sr.Naravane.
('53', 285, 3, 20, 541548) These directors get no remuneration.
('53', 285, 3, 21, 541585) The whole concern is based on the principle of self sacrifice.
('53', 285, 3, 22, 541648) It gives technical education to students from national schools.
('53', 285, 3, 23, 541712) If there are any profits, they are to be devoted to the advancement of education.
('53', 285, 3, 24, 541794) The company sold clocks for nearly Rs. 15,000 last year, and they are said to have given perfect satisfaction.
('53', 285, 3, 25, 541905) The mechanism of these clocks is original and patented.
('53', 285, 3, 26, 541961) “Every part of the machine is manufactured and other processes completed in the workshop.” These clocks are designed not for the use of individuals but for offices, factories and public institutions, which require a number of clocks fitted in the same building.
('53', 285, 3, 27, 542223) They require no winding, and all the clocks in one circuit show exactly the same time.
('53', 285, 3, 28, 542310) There are six students already working in the workshop from the Nipani school.
('53', 285, 3, 29, 542389) But I must not give any more
('53', 286, 0, 1, 542418) VOL. 53 : 2 JULY, 1931 12 OCTOBER, 1931 287
('53', 286, 1, 2, 542462) space to a description of this enterprise.
('53', 286, 1, 3, 542505) I invite those who are interested in genuine swadeshi enterprises to visit the institution and study its working.

('53', 293, 1, 2, 557778) 340. LETTER TO C. RAJAGOPALACHARI
('53', 293, 2, 3, 557812) ON THE FRONTIER DOWN MAIL, August 28, 1931
('53', 293, 3, 4, 557855) DEAR C.R., What shall I write to you?
('53', 293, 3, 5, 557893) Do you know that not a day has passed but I have thought of you and also felt the need of your presence?
('53', 293, 3, 6, 557998) But I was not to have it and as ill luck will have it, I cannot have even a few words with you before sailing.
('53', 293, 3, 7, 558109) There are two men whom I would like by my side in London, you and Jawaharlal.
('53', 293, 3, 8, 558187) But I feel that even if both of you were available I must not have you by me.
('53', 293, 3, 9, 558265) Somehow or other I do feel that you will both be helping me like the others by being here.
('53', 293, 3, 10, 558356) Only your presence with me will have lightened my burden.
('53', 293, 3, 11, 558414) But I must bear the Cross alone and to the fullest extent.
('53', 293, 3, 12, 558473) When I think of myself with all my limitations and ignorance I sink in utter despair but I rise out of it immediately, as I think and feel that it is God within Who is moving me and using me as His instrument.
('53', 293, 3, 13, 558683) He will give me the right word at the right moment.
('53', 293, 3, 14, 558735) That does not mean that I shall make no mistakes.
('53', 293, 3, 15, 558785) But I have come to believe that God as it were purposely makes us commit mistakes if only to humble us.
('53', 293, 3, 16, 558889) I know that this is a dangerous belief which can be utilized to justify any error.
('53', 293, 3, 17, 558972) But I have no doubt about its correctness in respect of all unconscious errors.
('53', 293, 3, 18, 559052) But this is not a letter to air my philosophy.
('53', 293, 3, 19, 559099) This is written to ask you to give me through weekly letters, sent even by air mail, what I cannot get through your presence.
('53', 293, 3, 20, 559225) I would like you also to write for Young India every week.
('53', 293, 3, 21, 559284) I do not think there is any legal necessity for advertising a new editor during my temporary absence.
('53', 293, 3, 22, 559386) If there is a legal necessity I would like you to wear the editorial mantle.
('53', 293, 3, 23, 559463) I would like you to prepare a rejoinder to the Madras Government’s reply to the Madras charge sheet and bring the latter to date and send your rejoinder to the Sardar.
('53', 293, 3, 24, 559631) By way of preliminary send me by air mail your detailed refle ctions on what you expect me to do in London.
('53', 293, 3, 25, 559739) Copies of whatever you send by air mail should be sent through the usual weekly service.
('53', 293, 3, 26, 559828) How is Papa?
('53', 293, 3, 27, 559841) I do hope she is better.
('53', 293, 4, 28, 559866) From a photostat: S.N. 17609
('53', 294, 0, 1, 559895) VOL. 53 : 2 JULY, 1931 12 OCTOBER, 1931 295
('53', 294, 1, 2, 559939) 341. LETTER TO J. C. KUMARAPPA
('53', 294, 2, 3, 559970) Unrevised ON THE FRONTIER DOWN MAIL, August 28, 1931
('53', 294, 3, 4, 560023) MY DEAR KUMARAPPA, Will you please look after the columns of Young India?
('53', 294, 3, 5, 560097) The idea is that there should be no change of name as editor.
('53', 294, 3, 6, 560159) I do not think the law requires such change during the temporary absence of the editor in charge.
('53', 294, 3, 7, 560257) But if such a change is required C. Rajagopala chari should appear as the editor, and in any case whenever you are in doubt or opinion among our own coterie differs, C. Rajagopalachari’s should be the final voice when a reference is at all possible.
('53', 294, 3, 8, 560507) When such is not possible Jairamdas’s should be the final voice and when even that is not possible yours should be the final voice unless Kaka Saheb chooses to decide.
('53', 294, 3, 9, 560675) I do not want him to bear this burden.
('53', 294, 3, 10, 560714) But he has a right whenever he considers intervention necessary.
('53', 294, 3, 11, 560779) I have already written to Rajagopalachari to send something regularly and I am asking Jairamdas too to give you a weekly contribution or contri butions.
('53', 294, 3, 12, 560932) I have asked Jawaharlal also to do likewise and he is likely to send you a weekly budget of U.P. news as also anything else he may wish to write.
('53', 294, 3, 13, 561078) This therefore should not prove too great a strain on you.
('53', 294, 3, 14, 561137) But if all these fail as they may you will fill in the columns somehow or other.
('53', 294, 3, 15, 561218) Of course I expect to be able to send something every week.
('53', 294, 3, 16, 561278) In all your writings I would like you to make as little criticism as possible but give as many facts and figures as possible.
('53', 294, 3, 17, 561404) If you find time you can study the economics of drink and show by facts and figures what a tremendous waste the drink habit means apart from the actual money value of the drink consumed.
('53', 294, 3, 18, 561591) You may also take up the whole subject of economic waste that goes on in our midst through preventable disease, through wrong feeding, through the criminal waste of human excreta as manure.
('53', 294, 3, 19, 561781) This waste has been worked out by Poord.
('53', 294, 3, 20, 561822) I believe his works we have in the Ashram.
('53', 294, 3, 21, 561865) The double waste through wrong feeding has been very partially worked out by Col.
('53', 294, 3, 22, 561947) Macanister—or some such name—the medico who has written on vitamins.
('53', 294, 3, 23, 562016) I have simply thrown together a few hints that should be sufficient for you to make explorations and discoveries, Economics treated in this manner can really become fascinating, interesting and instructive for the masses.
('53', 294, 3, 24, 562238) Nor do these
('53', 295, 0, 1, 562251) 296 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('53', 295, 1, 2, 562293) explorations require very deep or prolonged study for one like you who has studied the science of economics.
('53', 295, 1, 3, 562402) If you find that these are hints thrown out by a man who knows nothing about economics you are at liberty to brush aside the whole of this paragraph.
('53', 295, 1, 4, 562552) Please share this letter with Kaka Saheb.
('53', 295, 1, 5, 562594) I expect to be away not longer than 3 months at the outside and not less than six weeks in any event.
('53', 295, 3, 6, 562696) From a photostat: G.N. 10098
('53', 295, 4, 7, 562725) 342. LETTER TO H. W. EMERSON
('53', 295, 5, 8, 562754) Personal ON THE WAY, August 28, 1931
('53', 295, 6, 9, 562791) DEAR MR. EMERSON, Perhaps H. E. will show you my personal letter 1 to him.
('53', 295, 6, 10, 562866) This is to tell you how grieved I felt in Simla over what appeared to me to be your obstructive tactics.
('53', 295, 6, 11, 562971) I hope I am wrong in my fears and that you were not responsible for the exasperating situation that led to the waste of precious three days.
('53', 295, 6, 12, 563112) The securing of a constitution is nothing to me compared to the joy of discovering human contacts by which one could swear.
('53', 295, 6, 13, 563236) I shall soon forget the sad memories of the past three days and I know you will forgive me if I have unwittingly misjudged you.
('53', 295, 6, 14, 563364) But the future fills me with fear and misgivings.
('53', 295, 6, 15, 563414) If you will distrust Sardar Patel, Pandit Jawaharlal and Abdul Ghaffar Khan an explosion is almost unavoidable.
('53', 295, 6, 16, 563526) You will most certainly avoid it by trusting them.
('53', 295, 6, 17, 563577) I think I know the influence you have.
('53', 295, 6, 18, 563616) May I assume your promise to use it aright?
('53', 295, 6, 19, 563660) I have written thus freely in the exercise of a privilege of friendship and therefore hope not to be misunderstood.
('53', 295, 6, 20, 563776) My right hand needing rest, I have to write with the left hand.
('53', 295, 6, 21, 563840) I could not dictate a personal letter like this.
('53', 295, 7, 22, 563889) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI

('53', 296, 1, 2, 564030) 343. LETTER TO H. W. EMERSON
('53', 296, 2, 3, 564059) ON THE FRONTIER DOWN MAIL, August 28, 1931
('53', 296, 3, 4, 564102) DEAR MR. EMERSON, I had no time to take a statement from Khan Abdul Ghaffar Khan about Akbarpura and the treatment of prisoners whom, for want of a better distinguishing term, I describe as political.
('53', 296, 3, 5, 564303) The Khan Saheb gave me a harrowing description of the prisoners in the Peshawar jail who were convicted in connection with a drama about which you would remember we had a discussion.
('53', 296, 3, 6, 564486) Khan Saheb tells me that the prisoners are kept in irons and given the heavy work of turning the kharas.
('53', 296, 3, 7, 564591) I do not mind heavy work being given to able bodied men, but the ablest bodied men have also limits to their capacity for exertion and it is no joke to work a kharas with irons on one’s legs.
('53', 296, 3, 8, 564783) I enclose herewith a statement made by Shrimati Khurshedbehn regarding what she saw of injured men and women in Akbarpura.
('53', 296, 3, 9, 564906) I would like you not to brush aside all these statements as false or exaggerated.
('53', 296, 3, 10, 564988) Her statement about Dara Ismail Khan which also I enclose herewith is worthy of attention.
('53', 296, 4, 11, 565079) Yours sincerely, H. W. EMERSON, ESQ.
('53', 296, 5, 12, 565116) From a photostat: S.N. 17607
('53', 296, 6, 13, 565145) 344. LETTER TO D. N. BAHADURJI
('53', 296, 7, 14, 565176) ON THE FRONTIER DOWN MAIL, August 28, 1931 DEAR FRIEND, In the Frontier Province, as it appears to me from accounts received, a great deal of repression is going on.
('53', 296, 7, 15, 565342) Only recently in Akbarpura apparently without any justification several hundred men and women were charged by the military and received more or less serious injury.
('53', 296, 7, 16, 565507) In Dara Ismail Khan there was a Hindu Muslim riot and it is said that there was connivance on the part of the police.
('53', 296, 7, 17, 565625) Political prisoners are undergoing harsh treatment.
('53', 296, 7, 18, 565677) Khurshedbehn who will give you this letter knows something about all these things.
('53', 296, 7, 19, 565760) If you could go to the Frontier Province and quietly inquire into these
('53', 297, 0, 1, 565832) 298 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('53', 297, 1, 2, 565874) events and report upon them, your report might be of inestimable value and might ease the situation.
('53', 297, 1, 3, 565975) Whether you should be authoritatively appointed by the Working Committee or not I do not know.
('53', 297, 1, 4, 566070) Such an appointment might conceivably defeat the end in view.
('53', 297, 1, 5, 566132) The Frontier Province is a non regulation province.
('53', 297, 1, 6, 566184) Many things are done there which in our part of India we would believe to be impossible.
('53', 297, 1, 7, 566273) The Government may even prohibit the inquiry and if an appointment made by the Working Committee is thwarted by the Government there might arise an undesirable situation.
('53', 297, 1, 8, 566444) But the first thing is whether you could spare the time to go to the Frontier Province, and if you could, whether you would like to take up this responsibility.
('53', 297, 1, 9, 566605) If you can, you will please confer with Sardar Vallabhbhai and then decide whether a quiet informal enquiry would be preferable to an enquiry authorized by the Working Committee.
('53', 297, 1, 10, 566784) You will not hesitate to say “no” if for any reason whatsoever you find that you cannot shoulder this burden.
('53', 297, 1, 11, 566894) Yours sincerely, SYT.
('53', 297, 1, 12, 566916) D. N. BAHADURJI BOMBAY
('53', 297, 2, 13, 566939) From a microfilm: S.N. 17610

('53', 298, 1, 2, 567963) 346. LETTER TO P. G. MATHEW
('53', 298, 2, 3, 567991) ON THE FRONTIER DOWN MAIL, August 28, 1931
('53', 298, 3, 4, 568034) MY DEAR MATHEW, I was glad to have had even that brief chat.
('53', 298, 3, 5, 568095) You must keep perfectly cheerful and calm.
('53', 298, 3, 6, 568138) You must shed your shyness and begin to speak Hindi freely, no matter how bad or ungrammatical it may be.
('53', 298, 3, 7, 568244) By the time I return I expect you to be able to talk fluently in Hindi and you must write also as often as you can.
('53', 298, 3, 8, 568360) This want of self confidence in you, an educationist, is a terrible drawback and you must get out of it.
('53', 298, 3, 9, 568465) An educationist is always a student.
('53', 298, 3, 10, 568502) Nothing is beyond him and he is never too old to learn a new thing if the learning of it is necessary for the task before him, and you have realized that a competent knowledge of Hindi is indispensable if you are to serve through the Ashram.
('53', 298, 3, 11, 568744) You should write to me.
('53', 298, 3, 12, 568768) If Ratilal is there try to befriend him.
('53', 298, 3, 13, 568809) A good educationist would delight in handling semi lunatics like Ratilal and by his moral force weaning them from their lunacy.
('53', 298, 3, 14, 568937) I do believe that Ratilal is not past praying for.
('53', 298, 3, 15, 568988) He is very responsive to any kind attention that might be given to him.
('53', 298, 3, 16, 569060) Being brainless he has no friends.
('53', 298, 3, 17, 569095) Nobody has taken a loving interest in him.
('53', 298, 3, 18, 569138) Hence he has felt neglected and the feeling of being neglected made him sour, angry and, in the end, mad.

('53', 299, 4, 11, 570276) 348. INTERVIEW TO “THE BOMBAY CHRONICLE”
('53', 299, 5, 12, 570317) ON THE FRONTIER DOWN MAIL, August 29, 1931
('53', 299, 6, 13, 570360) The very first question .
('53', 299, 6, 14, 570386) was as to whether his recent conversations with the Viceroy had been such as to convince him that there has been a “change of heart” on the part of the Government, Mahatma’s decisive reply was: I am afraid not.
('53', 299, 7, 15, 570597) Q. What is your reply to your critics who suggest that you have not been consistent in your demand?
('53', 299, 7, 16, 570697) According to this section you started with a demand for an impartial inquiry into the breaches of the Truce by the Government, then you modified it to an inquiry by a High Court Judge, then you said you would be satisfied with a one sided inquiry, and, finally, you have agreed to no inquiry at all in places other than Bardoli.
('53', 299, 8, 17, 571026) A. The public are justified in thinking that I am inconsistent.
('53', 299, 8, 18, 571090) But I must be allowed to have the same right and to say that I am not inconsistent.
('53', 299, 8, 19, 571174) My insistence was on an inquiry.
('53', 299, 8, 20, 571207) I had suggested many things.
('53', 299, 8, 21, 571236) But the indispensable minimum was an open impartial inquiry into the Bardoli charge.
('53', 299, 8, 22, 571321) And that open inquiry has been granted.
('53', 299, 8, 23, 571361) Whether it will be also impartial or not I do not know.
('53', 299, 8, 24, 571417) Though I had put forth a claim to an inquiry into all the charges that claim is not withdrawn but if the Government do not grant or face an inquiry into other charges that could be no ground for refusing to proceed to London.
('53', 299, 8, 25, 571643) An enquiry is a substitute for civil disobedience.
('53', 299, 8, 26, 571694) That right has been specially reserved as you will see from the correspondence published.
('53', 299, 8, 27, 571784) In my opinion nothing of an essential character has been given up.
('53', 300, 0, 1, 571851) VOL. 53 : 2 JULY, 1931 12 OCTOBER, 1931 301
('53', 300, 1, 2, 571895) Q. In the Charge sheet published by you, you have given a “catalogue” of breaches of the Truce by the Government.
('53', 300, 1, 3, 572009) These have occurred in spite of your presence in the country and your strenuous efforts not to precipitate a crisis.
('53', 300, 1, 4, 572126) Do you expect the same Government to observe the terms of the Delhi Pact while you are away in London?
('53', 300, 2, 5, 572229) A. The fear underlying your question is not groundless.
('53', 300, 2, 6, 572285) Nevertheless as a man of trust I do expect the same Government to observe the terms of the Delhi Pact.
('53', 300, 2, 7, 572388) You will see in the communique 1
('53', 300, 3, 8, 572421) an unequivocal declaration on the part of the Central Government that they will secure observance of the Pact.
('53', 300, 3, 9, 572532) I have also the solemn assurance of the Viceroy himself but to what extent this declaration in the communique and the solemn assurance will be carried out into practice the future alone will show.
('53', 300, 3, 10, 572729) But in any event for a big national organization like the Congress no man’s presence is indispensable however efficient he may be for service.
('53', 300, 3, 11, 572872) An organization that has weathered storms for an unbroken period of nearly fifty years is well able to take care of itself in spite of my absence and I really feel that the Government having sent me to London will make it a point of honour to see that the terms of the Truce are better observed now than before.
('53', 300, 4, 12, 573184) Q. Will you advise Congress organizations to resort to direct action if the Government continues the same policy and does not make amends for the injustice already done?
('53', 300, 4, 13, 573354) A. In the first place you should understand that the Congress has not abandoned any of the charges because the Congress will not get an inquiry into them.
('53', 300, 4, 14, 573509) Negotiations will still proceed and I have not a shadow of doubt that where any grievance is so felt as to make some action absolutely necessary the Congress will adopt it.
('53', 300, 5, 15, 573682) Q. The agrarian situation in the U.P. is becoming more and more acute.
('53', 300, 5, 16, 573753) It is reported that peasants are giving up cultivation of lands and migrating to the cities in search of employment.
('53', 300, 5, 17, 573870) The movement is spreading.
('53', 300, 5, 18, 573897) What remedy do you suggest to ease the situation and what part should the Congress play to secure a better atmosphere ?
('53', 300, 6, 19, 574017) A. I am painfully conscious of the ever worsening situation in the U.P. I had a very long chat with Pandit Jawaharlal over this situation on the train.
('53', 300, 6, 20, 574169) We have together mapped out a course of action and I have ventured to address a communication to Sir Malcolm
('53', 300, 7, 21, 574278) 1 Vide “Athe Second Settlement”, 28 8 1931
('53', 301, 0, 1, 574321) 302 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('53', 301, 1, 2, 574363) Hailey.
('53', 301, 1, 3, 574371) 1 He is one of the strongest Governors we have in India at the present moment.
('53', 301, 1, 4, 574450) And I know he could be strong in action for securing justice.
('53', 301, 1, 5, 574512) I do not despair of his coming to the help of the Congress to avert a crisis.
('53', 301, 2, 6, 574590) Q. Are you optimistic about the results of the Round Table Conference ?
('53', 301, 3, 7, 574662) A. No, if I am to judge the future from the present appearance.
('53', 301, 3, 8, 574726) But being a born optimist I have never lost hope even in the midst of impenetrable darkness.
('53', 301, 3, 9, 574819) But let us take care of the present.
('53', 301, 3, 10, 574856) Let every Congressman do his duty, observe non violence and truth in thought, word and deed and I promise that all will be well.
('53', 301, 4, 11, 574985) Q. What will be your minimum demand at the R.T.C.?
('53', 301, 5, 12, 575036) A. My minimum demand is happily chalked out by the Congress in the mandate given to me.
('53', 301, 5, 13, 575124) To be worthy of the confidence reposed in me I may be expected not to move away from the terms of the mandate by a hair’s breadth.
('53', 301, 6, 14, 575255) Q. Will you reiterate your eleven points?
('53', 301, 7, 15, 575297) A. My eleven points are as dead as Queen Anne.
('53', 301, 7, 16, 575344) But they have revived in an invigorated form in the so called Fundamental Rights resolution 3 of the Congress.
('53', 301, 7, 17, 575455) Whatever of these is to be part of the Constitution will be part of any constitution acceptable to the Congress.
('53', 301, 8, 18, 575568) Q. Will you accept a Constitution which may fall short of the Karachi resolution for Independence, or as you put it “Substance of Independence”?
('53', 301, 9, 19, 575713) A. Nothing short of Substance of Independence will be acceptable to me personally, let alone Congress resolution.
('53', 301, 10, 20, 575827) Asked to state his attitude regarding the National Debt question, Gandhiji said that as ever his attitude was to demand an impartial tribunal to examine it.
('53', 301, 11, 21, 575984) The conversation then turned to the Congress formula for communal solution, 4
('53', 301, 12, 22, 576062) which was not acceptable to a section of Muslims.
('53', 301, 12, 23, 576112) Would Gandhiji accept a compro mise for the sake of presenting a united front at the Conference?
('53', 301, 13, 24, 576209) A. The Congress resolution has left me no room for accepting any compromise not acceptable to the parties concerned.
('53', 301, 13, 25, 576326) The unanimous consent was, therefore, necessary for any compromise.
('53', 301, 14, 26, 576394) 1 Vide “Letter to Sir Malcolm Hailey”, 28 8 1931 2 Vide “Clearing the Issue” 3 Vide “Resolution on Fubdaental Rights and Economic Changes”, 31 3 1931 4 Vide “Proposed Communal Solution”, 16 7 1931.
('53', 302, 0, 1, 576592) VOL. 53 : 2 JULY, 1931 12 OCTOBER, 1931 303
('53', 302, 1, 2, 576636) Gandhiji deplored that this had been rendered foolishly impossible by excluding the official representation of the Nationalist Muslim opinion.
('53', 302, 1, 3, 576779) It may be hopeless minority or it may represent the largest section of enlightened Muslim opinion.
('53', 302, 1, 4, 576878) But whatever the extent of its influence it is not an opinion that can be summarily rejected not at least by me when I know that the Nationalist Muslim Party contains some of my oldest Mussalman comrades and noblest Muslims in all India.
('53', 302, 2, 5, 577116) Q. Have you agreed to visit Lancashire and to explain the character of the boycott movement?
('53', 302, 3, 6, 577209) A. Yes.
('53', 302, 3, 7, 577217) I have promised a visit if it is desired by Lancashire men.
('53', 302, 4, 8, 577277) Questioned whether he proposed to visit any other European country besides England, Gandhiji said: If I can possibly do so I would certainly respond to the invitations I have received from all over Europe.
('53', 302, 4, 9, 577483) But that will depend upon the movement of the political barometer.
('53', 302, 5, 10, 577550) The Mahatma informed that his London hostess was Miss Muriel Lester, who, like him, was a representative of paupers.
('53', 302, 6, 11, 577667) Q. If the R.T.C. concedes the national demand, do you propose to remain in political life?
('53', 302, 6, 12, 577758) Gandhiji smilingly said: If the R.T.C. concedes the National demand I shall only just enter political life.
('53', 302, 7, 13, 577866) Gandhiji was urged to give an “exclusive” message to the country through the Chronicle when he exclaimed.
('53', 302, 7, 14, 577972) I belong to the Chronicle.
('53', 302, 7, 15, 577999) Belonging as I do to the Chronicle, there can be no exclusive message to it from me.
('53', 302, 8, 16, 578084) Gandhiji could not be induced to say anything more and to a valley of questions put to him, he said: You have pumped everything out of me by your 17 points.
('53', 302, 8, 17, 578241) Now you must thank me and run away.
('53', 302, 9, 18, 578277) The Bombay Chronicle, 31 8 1931
('53', 303, 0, 1, 578309) 304 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('53', 303, 1, 2, 578351) 349. LETTER TO VICEROY
('53', 303, 2, 3, 578374) BOMBAY, August 29, 1931 DEAR FRIEND, At the end of our conversation at Simla, I opened the question of Dr. Ansari’s delegation at the Round Table Conference and I wanted to mention the delegation on behalf of the Federated Chambers of Commerce.
('53', 303, 2, 4, 578619) As to Dr. Ansari, as you know, Lord Irwin believed that I should have carried the impression that his delegation would be a certainty.
('53', 303, 2, 5, 578754) As to the delegation on behalf of the Federated Chambers I have the correspondence between Lord Irwin’s Private Secretary and the Chairman of the Federation.
('53', 303, 2, 6, 578912) From this corres pondence it is clear that there were to be three representatives and the correspondence closed with the names being finally submitted by the Federation.
('53', 303, 2, 7, 579082) These were Sir Purushottamdas Thakurdas, Seth Jamal Mohammed and Seth Ghanshyam Das Birla.
('53', 303, 2, 8, 579173) Of these, only Sir Purushottamdas received the invitation and as you are aware, the Federation would not think of sending him without the other two also receiving the invitations.
('53', 303, 2, 9, 579353) Here I think the plighted word of an ex Viceroy is concerned and should, in my opinion, be respected.
('53', 303, 2, 10, 579455) But this is not the point that I wanted to urge.
('53', 303, 2, 11, 579504) The point that I wish to urge is that my usefulness would be largely curtailed if the interests represented by these three gentlemen and the interests represented by Dr. Ansari are not to be represented at the Round Table Conference.
('53', 303, 2, 12, 579738) The Federation is to a certain extent working in conjunction with the Congress and so is the Nationalist Muslim Party of which Dr. Ansari is the head.
('53', 303, 2, 13, 579889) If there were any negotiations in connection with Hindu Muslim question or in connection with Indian Commerce I should be perfectly helpless without the assistance and co operation of these gentlemen and the very purpose for which I am being sent to London is in danger of being defeated.
('53', 303, 2, 14, 580178) I would therefore ask you, if you have authority, to consider the advisability of these nominations from the standpoint I have suggested.
('53', 303, 2, 15, 580316) If you have not, I would like you to telegraph the purport of this to the Prime Minister and if it is at all possible repair what seems to me to be a glaring omission.
('53', 303, 2, 16, 580484) I may add that Pandit Malaviya and Mrs. Sarojini Naidu also are associating themselves with the contents of this letter.
('53', 303, 3, 17, 580605) HIS EXCELLENCY LORD WILLINGDON SIMLA From a photostat: S.N. 17601

('53', 304, 1, 2, 580715) 350. LETTER TO NATIONAL CHRISTIAN PARTY
('53', 304, 2, 3, 580755) MANI BHUVAN, GAMDEVI, BOMBAY, August 29, 1931
('53', 304, 3, 4, 580801) DEAR FRIENDS, I thank you for your address which I must confess I have not been able to read.
('53', 304, 3, 5, 580895) I shall certainly carefully read it, but I can give you this assurance in anticipation that as a representative of the Congress, the interests of the Christian community will be just as dear to me as those of every other community.
('53', 304, 3, 6, 581127) I hope that all the Christian friends, men and women, will carry out the Congress programme personally as you know there are many things that both men and women can easily do.
('53', 304, 3, 7, 581303) For instance, spin in the name of the poor every day, adopt khadi to the exclusion of every other cloth, and those who are given to the drink habit can abstain from drink.

('53', 304, 5, 9, 581532) 351. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, BOMBAY
('53', 304, 6, 10, 581570) August 29, 1931
('53', 304, 7, 11, 581586) Speaking from the balcony of a private house Mr. Gandhi addressed a huge enthusiastic crowd (who stood in drenching rain) for quarter of an hour.
('53', 304, 8, 12, 581732) Mr. Gandhi said he had signed the Second Agreement with the Government.
('53', 304, 8, 13, 581804) They could read it.
('53', 304, 8, 14, 581824) Some of them could ask what this man had gone and done again.
('53', 304, 8, 15, 581886) But Mr. Gandhi himself was aware that the nation had shown enormous trust in him by electing him as the sole delegate to the Round Table Conference.
('53', 304, 8, 16, 582035) In ordinary circumstances, but for their trust he would have refused to go to London, but their trust would support him.
('53', 304, 8, 17, 582156) He knew full well his own shortcomings and weaknesses, but truth and non violence would be his guiding principles and he hoped they would come out in their fullness in his work in London.
('53', 304, 8, 18, 582344) I am a cripple, but it is only natural that a crippled nation should have a crippled delegate who alone can understand the difficulties and miseries of the millions.
('53', 304, 9, 19, 582510) Mr. Gandhi assured his bearers that he would abide by the Congress mandate.
('53', 305, 0, 1, 582586) 306 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('53', 305, 1, 2, 582628) He would deceive nobody, neither Englishmen nor anybody else, much less India’s teeming millions.
('53', 305, 1, 3, 582726) If I deceive you, even to kill me would not be violence.
('53', 305, 1, 4, 582783) I have no enmity with Englishmen, nor with Mohammedans, nor for the matter of that with anyone else.

('53', 305, 3, 7, 582942) S.S. “RAJPUTANA”, August 29, 1931 Though I see nothing on the horizon to warrant hope, being a born optimist, I am hoping against hope.
('53', 305, 3, 8, 583078) My faith is in God and He seems to have made my way clear for me to go to London.
('53', 305, 3, 9, 583160) Therefore I expect He will use me as His instrument for the service of humanity.
('53', 305, 3, 10, 583241) For me service of India is identical with the service of humanity.
('53', 305, 3, 11, 583308) Though Congress may be repudiated by sections of the people of India, it aims at representing the whole of India and, therefore, to deserve the trust that had been reposed in me and imposed upon me, I shall endeavour to represent every interest that does not conflict with the interests of the dumb millions for whom the Congress predom inantly exists.
('53', 305, 3, 12, 583661) I hope that Provincial Governments, the Civil Service and English mercantile houses will help the Congress to realize the mission it has set before itself.
('53', 305, 3, 13, 583817) Representing, as the Congress does, the message of non violence and truth, it can only succeed by the goodwill of all component parts of the nation and I am therefore hoping that goodwill will be extended to the humble representative that is going upon his errand.

('53', 306, 3, 4, 584258) With reference to the revenue collections in Bardoli and Borsad it was from the very beginning a clear understanding that the Khate dars affected by the civil disobedience were to pay only as much as they could without borrowing.

('53', 306, 3, 7, 584719) So far as the terms of reference to the Inquiry Officer are concerned I have distinctly understood that the standard referred to therein means ability to pay without borrowing.

('53', 309, 3, 5, 588652) 359. MESSAGE TO INDIAN PEOPLE
('53', 309, 4, 6, 588682) S.S. “RAJPUTANA”, September 2, 1931 Now that I am drawing away from India’s shores, let me appeal to the Indian people to preserve absolutely a non violent atmosphere during my absence, and let them follow out the constructive progra mme of Congress—namely, remove the fourfold curse of drink, drugs, foreign cloth and untouchability.
('53', 309, 4, 7, 589017) Let them revive the village industry of hand spinning and promote unity among all classes, which is indispensable for India’s freedom.
('53', 309, 4, 8, 589152) I should like, also, to appeal to Englishmen, including officials, to trust the Congress and Congres smen, if they really believe that power must pass from them to India.

('53', 311, 4, 6, 591835) 363. STATEMENT TO REUTER 2
('53', 311, 5, 7, 591862) ADEN, September 3, 1931 I shall strive for a constitution which will release India from all thraldom and patronage, and give her, if need be, the right to sin.
('53', 311, 5, 8, 592022) I shall work for an India in which the poorest shall feel that it is their country in whose making they have an effective voice; an India in which there shall be no high class and low class of people; an India in which all communities shall live in perfect harmony.
('53', 311, 5, 9, 592288) There can be no room in such an India for the curse of untouchability or the curse of intoxicating drinks and drugs.
('53', 311, 5, 10, 592405) Women will enjoy the same rights as men.
('53', 311, 5, 11, 592446) Since we shall be at peace with all the rest of the world, neither exploiting nor being exploited, we should have the smallest army imaginable.
('53', 311, 5, 12, 592590) All interests not in conflict with the interests of the dumb mill ions will be scrupulously respected, whether foreign or indigenous.
('53', 311, 5, 13, 592724) Personally, I hate distinction between foreign and indigenous.
('53', 311, 5, 14, 592787) This is the India of my dreams for which I shall struggle at the next Round Table Conference.
('53', 311, 5, 15, 592881) I may fail, but if I am to deserve the confidence of the Congress, I shall be satisfied with nothing less.
('53', 311, 6, 16, 592988) The Hindustan Times, 5 9 1931
('53', 311, 7, 17, 593018) 1 This sentence is in Gandhiji’s hand.
('53', 311, 7, 18, 593057) 2 A Reuter correspondent had asked Gandhiji what his programme in England would be.
('53', 312, 0, 1, 593141) VOL. 53 : 2 JULY, 1931 12 OCTOBER, 1931 313
('53', 312, 1, 2, 593185) 364. SPEECH AT RECEPTION, ADEN 1
('53', 312, 2, 3, 593218) September 3, 1931 I thank you for the honour you have done me.
('53', 312, 2, 4, 593281) I know that the honour is not meant for me personally or for my friends.
('53', 312, 2, 5, 593354) It is an honour done to the Congress whom I hope to be able to represent at the Round Table Conference.
('53', 312, 2, 6, 593458) I came to know that there was a hitch in your proceedings on account of the national flag.
('53', 312, 2, 7, 593549) Now it is inconceivable for me to find a meeting of Indians, especially where national leaders are invited, without the national flag flying there.
('53', 312, 2, 8, 593697) You know that many people sustained lathi blows and some have lost their lives in defending the honour of the flag, and you cannot honour an Indian leader without honouring the Indian national flag.
('53', 312, 2, 9, 593896) Again there is a Settlement between the Government and the Congress, which is no loger a hostile party but a friendly party.
('53', 312, 2, 10, 594021) It is not enough therefore to tolerate or permit the Congress flag, but it must be given the place of honour where Congress representatives are invited.
('53', 312, 2, 11, 594174) On behalf of the Congress, I give you the assurance that the Congress does not stand merely for isolated independence, which may easily become a menace to the world.
('53', 312, 2, 12, 594340) But the Congress, with its creed of truth and non violence, cannot possibly be a menace to the world.
('53', 312, 2, 13, 594442) It is my conviction that India numbering one fifth of the human race, becoming free through non violence and truth, can be a great force of service to the whole of mankind.
('53', 312, 2, 14, 594615) On the contrary India having no voice in her affairs is today a menace.
('53', 312, 2, 15, 594687) It is a helpless India exciting the jealousy and greed of other countries which must live by exploiting her.
('53', 312, 2, 16, 594796) But when India refuses to be exploited and is well able to take care of herself, and achieves that freedom through non violence and truth, she will be a force for peace and make for peaceful atmosphere in this troubled globe of ours.
('53', 312, 2, 17, 595030) It was therefore natural that the Arabs and others joined the Indians in organizing this function.
('53', 312, 2, 18, 595129) All who desire peace must join together to perpetuate peace.
('53', 312, 2, 19, 595190) This great peninsula, the birth place of
('53', 312, 3, 20, 595231) 1 A reception was held immediately after Gandhiji’s boat reached Aden at 4.50 a.m.
('53', 312, 3, 21, 595314) A purse of 328 guineas was presented to Gandhiji an the occasion.
('53', 312, 3, 22, 595380) Before delivering the speech reproduced here he spoke in Gujarati.
('53', 312, 3, 23, 595447) The text of that speech, however, is not available.
('53', 312, 3, 24, 595499) This report is reproduced from Mahadev Desai’s account of the meeting.
('53', 313, 0, 1, 595570) 314 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('53', 313, 1, 2, 595612) Mahomed and of Islam, can help to solve the Hindu Muslim problem.
('53', 313, 1, 3, 595678) It is a matter of shame to me to confess that we are a house divided against itself.
('53', 313, 1, 4, 595763) We fly at each other’s throats in cowardice and fear.
('53', 313, 1, 5, 595817) The Hindu distrusts the Mussalman through cowardice and fear, and the Mussalman distrusts the Hindu through equal cowardice and imaginary fears.
('53', 313, 1, 6, 595962) Islam throughout history has stood for matchless bravery and peace.
('53', 313, 1, 7, 596030) It can therefore be no matter for pride to the Mussalmans that they should fear the Hindus.
('53', 313, 1, 8, 596122) Similarly it can be no matter for pride to the Hindus that they should fear Mussalmans, even if they are aided by the Mussalmans of the world.
('53', 313, 1, 9, 596265) Are we so fallen that we should be afraid of our own shadows?
('53', 313, 1, 10, 596327) You will be surprised to hear that the Pathans are living in peace with us.
('53', 313, 1, 11, 596403) They stood side by side with us in the last struggle, and sacrified their young men on the altar of liberty.
('53', 313, 1, 12, 596512) I want you, who belong to the country of the Prophet’s birth, to make your contribution to the restoration of peace between Hindus and Muslims in India.
('53', 313, 1, 13, 596665) I cannot tell you how you are to do it, but I may remind you that where there is a will there is a way.
('53', 313, 1, 14, 596769) I want the Arabs of Arabia to come to our rescue and help to bring about a condition of things when the Mussalman will consider it a point of honour to help the Hindu and vice versa.
('53', 313, 1, 15, 596952) For the rest, I would also give you the message of spinning and weaving in your homes.
('53', 313, 1, 16, 597039) Some of the Caliphs led lives which were models of simplicity, and if you help yourself by making your own cloth, there is in it nothing derogatory to Islam.
('53', 313, 1, 17, 597197) There is also the problem of drink which for you should be twice cursed.
('53', 313, 1, 18, 597270) There should be not a drop here, but as there are other communities too, I think the Arabs will have to persuade them to make Aden dry.
('53', 313, 1, 19, 597406) I do hope our relations with one another will now grow richer and closer.

('53', 314, 10, 13, 598091) Provided the Conference does not break down at the start over fundamentals, Mahatma Gandhi expects the session to last until the 1st November.

('53', 316, 6, 15, 600657) 371. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('53', 316, 7, 16, 600689) S.S. “RAJPUTANA”, [September 5, 1931] 2
('53', 316, 8, 17, 600729) Prayer has been the saving of my life.
('53', 316, 8, 18, 600768) Without it I should have been a lunatic long ago.
('53', 316, 8, 19, 600818) My autobiography will tell you that I have had my fair share of the bitterest public and private experiences.
('53', 316, 8, 20, 600928) They threw me into temporary despair, but if I was able to get rid of it, it was because of prayer.
('53', 316, 8, 21, 601028) Now I may tell you that prayer has not been part of my life in the sense that truth has been.
('53', 316, 8, 22, 601122) It came out of sheer
('53', 316, 9, 23, 601143) 1 This is extracted from Mahadev Desai’s account in which he reports: “The morning prayers are too early to attract these friends, but practically all Indians (who number over 40),—Hindus, Mussalmans, Parsis, Sikhs,—and a sprinkling of Europeans attend the evening prayers.
('53', 316, 9, 24, 601417) At the request of some of these friends a fifteen minutes’ talk after prayer and before dinner has become a daily feature.
('53', 316, 9, 25, 601540) A question is asked each evening, and Gandhiji replies to it the next.
('53', 316, 9, 26, 601611) One of the Indian passengers—a Mussalman youth —asked Gandhiji to give his personal testimony on prayer, not a theoretical discourse but a narration of what he had felt and experienced as a result of prayer.” 2 From Diayke Panne by G. D. Birla
('53', 317, 0, 1, 601855) 318 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('53', 317, 1, 2, 601897) necessity, as I found myself in a plight when I could not possibly be happy without it.
('53', 317, 1, 3, 601985) And the more my faith in God increased, the more irresistible became the yearning for prayer.
('53', 317, 1, 4, 602079) Life seemed to be dull and vacant without it.
('53', 317, 1, 5, 602125) I had attended the Christian service in South Africa, but it had failed to grip me.
('53', 317, 1, 6, 602209) I could not join them in prayer.
('53', 317, 1, 7, 602242) They supplicated God, but I could not do so, I failed egregiously.
('53', 317, 1, 8, 602309) I started with disbelief in God and prayer, and until at a late stage in life I did not feel anything like a void in life.
('53', 317, 1, 9, 602432) But at that stage I felt that as food was indispensable for the body, so was prayer indispensable for the soul.
('53', 317, 1, 10, 602544) In fact food for the body is not so necessary as prayer for the soul.
('53', 317, 1, 11, 602614) For starvation is often necessary in order to keep the body in health, but there is no such thing as prayer starvation.
('53', 317, 1, 12, 602734) You cannot possibly have a surfeit of prayer.
('53', 317, 1, 13, 602780) Three of the greatest teachers of the world—Buddha, Jesus, Mahomed—have left unimpeachable testimony that they found illumination through prayer and could not possibly live without it.
('53', 317, 1, 14, 602965) But to come nearer home.
('53', 317, 1, 15, 602990) Millions of Hindus and Mussalmans and Christians find their only solace in life in prayer.
('53', 317, 1, 16, 603081) Either you vote them down as liars or self deluded people.
('53', 317, 1, 17, 603140) Well, then, I will say, that this lying has a charm for me, a truth seeker, if it is ‘lying’ that has given me that mainstay or staff of life, without which I could not bear to live for a moment.
('53', 317, 1, 18, 603336) In spite of despair staring me in the face on the political horizon, I have never lost my peace.
('53', 317, 1, 19, 603433) In fact I have found people who envy my peace.
('53', 317, 1, 20, 603480) That peace, I tell you, comes from prayer.
('53', 317, 1, 21, 603523) I am not a man of learning but I humbly claim to be a man of prayer.
('53', 317, 1, 22, 603592) I am indifferent as to the form.
('53', 317, 1, 23, 603625) Everyone is a law unto himself in that respect.
('53', 317, 1, 24, 603673) But there are some well marked roads, and it is safe to walk along the beaten tracks, trod by the ancient teachers.
('53', 317, 1, 25, 603789) Well, I have given my practical testimony.
('53', 317, 1, 26, 603832) Let everyone try and find that as a result of daily prayer he adds something new to his life, something with which nothing can be compared.
('53', 317, 2, 27, 603972) Young India, 24 9 1931

('53', 320, 1, 2, 606198) 377. STATEMENT TO “AL AHRAM” 1
('53', 320, 2, 3, 606229) [S.S. “RAJPUTANA”, September 6, 1931] Conditions in India are good so far as the strength of civil disobedience is concerned, but they are truly deplorable so far as Hindu Muslim unity is concerned.
('53', 320, 2, 4, 606428) Hitherto all effort at reconciliation has failed and we sorely need the goodwill of the whole world and especially of Mussalmans.
('53', 320, 2, 5, 606558) They can by sheer strength of friendliness shame both the communities into coming to agreement.
('53', 320, 2, 6, 606654) My expectations of the Conference are zero if I am to base them on a survey of the horizon.
('53', 320, 2, 7, 606746) But being an optimist I am hoping that something will turn up to make the conference a success from the national Indian standpoint.
('53', 320, 2, 8, 606878) In the event of failure there can be only one consequence—revival of civil disobedience and suffering for the people of a much bitterer type than last year.
('53', 320, 2, 9, 607035) The Congress is prepared to pay the cost whatever it may be for gaining freedom.
('53', 320, 2, 10, 607116) My message to the Nationalists of Egypt is: Like us you are an ancient people.
('53', 320, 2, 11, 607195) I hope you will not slavishly copy all that is Western.
('53', 320, 2, 12, 607251) If I have understood the events of your country correctly real freedom for Egypt has still to come and I feel sure that if you can appreciate and assimilate the method of non violence and truth in matters political, you will surely reach your goal much quicker than by any other method I know.
('53', 320, 2, 13, 607545) And if I may humbly put it I would like to say that Egypt will come to her own much more quickly if India gains true deliverance in the course of the next twelve months.
('53', 320, 2, 14, 607715) It is my firm belief that if India gains her freedom through non violence and truth it will mean a great deal to the whole world certainly to all the Eastern nations.
('53', 320, 3, 15, 607882) From a photostat: S.N. 17643
('53', 320, 4, 16, 607911) 1 This was issued in writing to a representative of Al Ahram in response to five questions sent to Gandhiji by the Editor in advance.
('53', 320, 4, 17, 608045) These were: (1) the situation in India; (2) the communal question between Hindus and Muslims; (3) what he expects from the Round Table Conference; (4) what would be the consequences if the Round Table Conference failed; (5) his message to the Egyptian nationalists.
('53', 321, 0, 1, 608311) 322 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('53', 321, 1, 2, 608353) 378. INTERVIEW TO “THE DAILY TELEGRAPH”
('53', 321, 2, 3, 608393) S.S. “RAJPUTANA”, Sunday, September 6, 1931
('53', 321, 3, 4, 608437) Working his spinning wheel all the time, Mr. Gandhi said he had enjoyed the voyage.
('53', 321, 3, 5, 608521) He did not appear to be sanguine as to the success of the Round Table Conference.
('53', 321, 3, 6, 608603) He said: On the horizon I see nothing but impenetrable darkness.
('53', 321, 3, 7, 608668) God’s ways are inscrutable.
('53', 321, 3, 8, 608696) I am an optimist.
('53', 321, 3, 9, 608714) There is nothing to warrant hope, but still I do not lose hope.
('53', 321, 4, 10, 608778) He was most indignant at Shaukat Ali’s statement that he was compelled to part from Gandhi, because he only aimed at communal objects, the subjugation of the Moslems to the Hindus.
('53', 321, 4, 11, 608959) He declared: My whole life is a steady testimony against such an accusation.
('53', 321, 4, 12, 609036) There is no trace of communalism in me.
('53', 321, 4, 13, 609076) I would be a party to no settlement subjugating any community to another in India.
('53', 321, 5, 14, 609159) The Mahatma, who is still clothed only in a loin cloth, said he did not fear the alteration in temperature awaiting him in England.
('53', 321, 5, 15, 609291) He would make additions to his apparel if necessary, in the shape of a woollen cloth twisted round his body, and a jacket, but he would not change his diet.
('53', 321, 6, 16, 609448) The co operation of East and West, he remarked, would be a strong means to establish world peace, provided it was not based on brute force.
('53', 321, 7, 17, 609588) Mr. Gandhi was also assailed by Egyptian journalists who endeavoured to draw him out on various questions of general interest to the Orient but directly affecting Egypt.
('53', 321, 7, 18, 609758) To the question: “What is your advice to the peoples of the Near and Middle East in their struggle for independence?” he earnestly replied: They should conduct the struggle on absolutely non violent lines.
('53', 321, 7, 19, 609964) If they so do, they gain their end far quicker than in any other way.
('53', 321, 7, 20, 610034) The Daily Telegraph, 7 9 1931
