('53', 322, 1, 2, 610108) 379. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('53', 322, 2, 3, 610138) S.S. “RAJPUTANA, [September 6, 1931] 1
('53', 322, 3, 4, 610177) Well, it is beyond my power to induce in you a belief in God.
('53', 322, 4, 5, 610239) There are certain things which are self proved, and certain which are not proved at all.
('53', 322, 4, 6, 610328) The existence of God is like a geometrical axiom.
('53', 322, 4, 7, 610378) It may be beyond our heart grasp.
('53', 322, 4, 8, 610412) I shall not talk of an intellectual grasp.
('53', 322, 4, 9, 610455) Intellectual attempts are more or less failures, as a rational explanation cannot give you the faith in a living God.
('53', 322, 4, 10, 610573) For it is a thing beyond the grasp of reason.
('53', 322, 4, 11, 610619) It transcends reason.
('53', 322, 4, 12, 610641) There are numerous phenomena from which you can reason out the existence of God, but I shall not insult your intelligence by offering you a rational explanation of that type.
('53', 322, 4, 13, 610816) I would have you brush aside all rational explanations and begin with a simple childlike faith in God.
('53', 322, 4, 14, 610919) If I exist, God exists.
('53', 322, 4, 15, 610943) With me it is a necessity of my being as it is with millions.
('53', 322, 4, 16, 611005) They may not be able to talk about it, but from their life you can see that it is part of their life.
('53', 322, 4, 17, 611107) I am only asking you to restore the belief that has been undermined.
('53', 322, 4, 18, 611176) In order to do so, you have to unlearn a lot of literature that dazzles your intelligence and throws you off your feet.
('53', 322, 4, 19, 611296) Start with the faith which is also a token of humility and an admission that we know nothing, that we are less than atoms in this universe.
('53', 322, 4, 20, 611436) We are less than atoms, I say, because the atom obeys the law of its being, whereas we in the insolence of our ignorance deny the law of nature.
('53', 322, 4, 21, 611581) But I have no argument to address to those who have no faith.
('53', 322, 4, 22, 611643) Once you accept the existence of God, the necessity for prayer is inescapable.
('53', 322, 4, 23, 611722) Let us not make the astounding claim that our whole life is a prayer, and therefore we need not sit down at a particular hour to pray.
('53', 322, 4, 24, 611857) Even men who were all their time in tune with the Infinite did not make such a claim.
('53', 322, 4, 25, 611943) Their lives were a continuous prayer, and yet for our sake, let us say they offered prayer at set hours, and renewed each day the oath of loyalty to God.
('53', 322, 4, 26, 612097) God of course never

('53', 327, 4, 7, 619300) 389. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('53', 327, 5, 8, 619328) S.S. “RAJPUTANA”, September 8, 1931 If the meeting 3 is held on Monday I shall be placed in a most embarrassing position.
('53', 327, 5, 9, 619450) Monday is my day of silence, and when I took my vow of silence I made three exceptions.
('53', 327, 5, 10, 619538) Whether a meeting of this character is covered by one of them is debatable; I am, however, hoping and praying that I shall not be obliged to reach a final decision, but that a way out of the difficulty will be found.
('53', 327, 6, 11, 619755) Asked to specify the exceptions Gandhiji said: The first is if I am in distress and can only be assisted by speaking; the second if somebody else is in distress who can be helped by my speaking, and the third if exceptional circumstances prevail, such as an unexpected call from the Viceroy or other high official who must be seen in the interest of the cause.
('53', 327, 6, 12, 620116) Thus my appearance at the committee on Monday can only come under the third exception, but only by a considerable stretch of meaning, seeing that it is not a sudden unexpected call.
('53', 327, 6, 13, 620298) In such circumstances people have generously accommodated me.
('53', 327, 6, 14, 620360) What can happen in London I don’t know.
('53', 327, 7, 15, 620400) Gandhiji pointed out that since he must hold himself in readiness for private conferences with two of the highest Government officials on Sunday, he could not anticipate the period of silence, nor postpone it until Tuesday, because the Commit tee would be sitting all the week.

('53', 329, 5, 6, 622478) 394. A FICKLE FRIEND
('53', 329, 6, 7, 622499) [Before September 11, 1931] 2
('53', 329, 7, 8, 622529) Thus writes an English friend who has known me for years:
('53', 329, 8, 9, 622587) No one has for some time told you quite bluntly, and in good English, that you are making an unmitigated fool of yourself, and out of personal vanity and the desire to act the dictator, are descending to lies and subterfuges which even ordinary men, who lay no claim to special sanctity, do not indulge in.
('53', 329, 9, 10, 622894) You know full well, that the main reason for your not attending the Round Table Conference is due to your inability to solve the Hindu Muslim question, and that you have used petty matters as an excuse.
('53', 329, 9, 11, 623097) Your Congress Committee man at Allahabad, Mr. Sundarlal, has publicly made this statement, and you know full well the text of your motion, moved at the Working Committee meeting, when you were turned down by your Committee.
('53', 329, 9, 12, 623321) You admitted in that resolution the failure of Hindu Muslim negotiations and your inability to put forward any political proposals at the Round Table Conference, and that you would confine yourself solely to work for the amelioration of the condition of the masses.
('53', 329, 10, 13, 623587) You, who prate of worshipping at the altar of truth, the same altar that I worship at, are by half truths, cunning words and deliberate deception trying to force the blame of your deliberate pre arranged determination not to go to the Round Table Conference on the Government.
('53', 329, 11, 14, 623864) When, as you now boldly declare, sedition is the creed of Congress and the overthrow of this Government its objectives, are you not, with calculated
('53', 329, 12, 15, 624013) 1 The telegram was in reply to the following message received on September 9, 1931: “Indian Merchants Association anxious meet yourself and party while passing through Paris and respectfully request wire time of arrival.” 2 This and the following three articles were written on board the ship.
('53', 329, 12, 16, 624307) Gandhiji reached Marseilles on September 11.
('53', 330, 0, 1, 624352) VOL. 53 : 2 JULY, 1931 12 OCTOBER, 1931 331
('53', 330, 1, 2, 624396) deliberation, forcing the Government to take action?
('53', 330, 1, 3, 624449) You may throw dust successfully in the eyes of your followers, but at least you do know that you cannot deceive His eyes.
('53', 330, 1, 4, 624571) Go and introspect.
('53', 330, 1, 5, 624590) Call on that inner voice honestly, not as Gandhi the politician, who, without the political guidance of Pandit Motilal Nehru, is making a fool of himself, and forcing events towards an upheaval which will benefit nobody but goondas, but to the other Gandhi, whom millions, and I include myself in that list, respect for his creed of love and the splendid work he is doing for the depressed classes.
('53', 330, 1, 6, 624989) That Gandhi is overpowered.
('53', 330, 1, 7, 625017) Your personal pride and autocratic spirit has vanquished the other Gandhi.
('53', 330, 2, 8, 625092) I want, every European wants, to see India politically free, and the
('53', 330, 3, 9, 625161) Round Table Conference is the constitutional means for that purpose.
('53', 330, 4, 10, 625230) however, deliberately seek her freedom through blood, because your pride
('53', 330, 5, 11, 625303) received an enormous shock when you found that the Conference would go on
('53', 330, 6, 12, 625377) without you, though you will call it ‘passive resistance’ and other names.
('53', 330, 7, 13, 625452) cannot evade these facts.
('53', 330, 8, 14, 625478) Go, I beg of you, and introspect, and after purification come to the altar
('53', 330, 9, 15, 625553) of truth.
('53', 330, 9, 16, 625563) In order that I may not miss his wrath through any mishap, he registered the letter.
('53', 330, 9, 17, 625648) The letter could be handed to me only on board.
('53', 330, 9, 18, 625696) The best answer to the letter is that I am writing this on the steamer that is taking me to London.
('53', 330, 9, 19, 625796) Indeed I might have suppressed the letter.
('53', 330, 9, 20, 625839) But I did not, as it is typical of many I have received in the course of my life.
('53', 330, 9, 21, 625921) When I do something that pleases them, my English friends issue embarrassing certificates.
('53', 330, 9, 22, 626012) And when I do something that displeases them, forgetful of what they said in the past, they swear at me.
('53', 330, 9, 23, 626117) They will not stop to inquire of me why they see an inconsistency between my past conduct and the present.
('53', 330, 9, 24, 626224) They will not have the patience to discover the perfect harmony between two seemingly inconsistent acts.
('53', 330, 9, 25, 626329) When I find such friends, I distrust their praise and its disinterestedness, and hence remain unaffected by their censure.
('53', 330, 9, 26, 626452) Take the writer of the foregoing elegant censure.
('53', 330, 9, 27, 626502) Only a few months ago, I was a good man.
('53', 330, 9, 28, 626543) Now suddenly I have become all that is bad, even a liar, because he suspects that I would not go to London because of my failure to bring about Hindu Muslim unity.
('53', 330, 9, 29, 626707) He will not even condescend to ask me for an explanation, and believes a garbled report of my speech at the last A.I.C.C. meeting.
('53', 330, 9, 30, 626838) Let him and the public know, that I hold in my bag a wire from Pandit Sundarlal, saying that he never made the remark attributed to him.
('53', 330, 9, 31, 626975) But I suggest
('53', 331, 0, 1, 626989) 332 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('53', 331, 1, 2, 627031) that even if Pandit Sundarlal did make the remark attributed to him, that would be no basis for a friend to found an accusation against me.
('53', 331, 1, 3, 627171) A friendship, that cannot bear the slightest strain and would believe any rumour or report against a friend is not worth much, if anything.
('53', 331, 1, 4, 627311) Let those English friends who have sent me wires or letters of congratulations, be warned against rushing to unjust judgments, the moment they hear reports about my doings which may displease them.
('53', 331, 1, 5, 627509) The reports need not always be false, as was the case in the present instance.
('53', 331, 1, 6, 627588) If the common purpose is well understood, friendships formed to advance that purpose should weather all storms of misunderstandings, misreportings and the like.
('53', 331, 1, 7, 627749) I will therefore state the purpose.
('53', 331, 1, 8, 627785) It is complete freedom from the alien yoke in every sense of the term, and this for the sake of the dumb millions.
('53', 331, 1, 9, 627900) Every interest therefore, that is hostile to their interest, must be revised, or must subside if it is not capable of revision.
('53', 331, 1, 10, 628028) This freedom does not, need not, exclude partnership with the English on terms of absolute equality and terminable at the will of either party.
('53', 331, 1, 11, 628172) Those Englishmen, who sincerely desire the immediate consummation of such an event, will never need to repent of their having issued to me a certificate of merit.
('53', 331, 1, 12, 628335) The others will see nothing but evil in my most innocent acts.

('53', 331, 2, 14, 628421) 395. “URDU NAVAJIVAN”

('53', 332, 1, 2, 629257) 396. ‘THE OTHER SIDE’
('53', 332, 2, 3, 629279) [Before September 11, 1931] Under the above mentioned heading a correspondent has written a long letter, protesting against my condemnation, of the attempt made by a student of the Fergusson College on the life of the Acting Governor of Bombay.
('53', 332, 2, 4, 629524) I give below a very much condensed summary of the letter:
('53', 332, 3, 5, 629582) I was extremely pained to read your note in the last issue of Navajivan under the heading ‘madness’ (gandpan).
('53', 332, 3, 6, 629693) I must at the very outset make it clear, that I have been a non violent non co operator since 1921, and accept the Congress creed of non violence by faith as farthest as possible, and as a policy in exceptional circumstances alone, such as the molestation of the honour of women or of the National Flag.
('53', 332, 3, 7, 629997) True non violence is possible even in the most provoking circumstances as long as these two are not in actual danger.
('53', 332, 3, 8, 630115) But whenever women are molested or the National Flag is dishonoured, I fear my non violence will melt away, and if it does not, it would be so not out of any merit in me, but on most occasions owing to the weakness of the flesh, and on exceptional occasions only, on account of studious self restraint.
('53', 332, 3, 9, 630418) I was, if I can say so with modesty, the first to start the idea of offering civil disobedience to the Martial Law at Sholapur and suffer imprisonment after actual disobedience.
('53', 332, 3, 10, 630596) This much by way of personal explanation.
('53', 332, 4, 11, 630638) It is, in my opinion, no use denouncing one who is almost in the jaws of death.
('53', 332, 4, 12, 630718) He deserves pity if anything.
('53', 332, 4, 13, 630748) Violence in action is a merit or demerit, which can neither prosper by mere public praise however great, as it is a question of life and death; nor can it be wiped out by the strongest public denunciation or by Government repression, or by both, as it is the outcome of rebelling emotions.
('53', 332, 4, 14, 631038) Those who fear not the gallows will not be daunted by public opinion.
('53', 332, 4, 15, 631108) Virtue or vice, it is exceptional, bursting out only after severest repression or molestation of women; it can be wiped out permanently, only if the rulers mend their ways or end themselves.
('53', 332, 5, 16, 631299) We may justly wish to remain safe and unhurt till doomsday, only if we are virtuous and sin fearing; but what right have we, after committing the most heinous of sins, to feel pain for treachery practised against us?
('53', 332, 5, 17, 631516) And especially when we have blocked all open, honest, honourable, untreacherous ways of revenge?
('53', 332, 5, 18, 631613) The glory of no country however great, not even of India, lies in meekly suffering injustice, zulum and beastly atrocities.
('53', 332, 5, 19, 631737) ‘Nothing is unfair in love and war’ is a general maxim, and it is the truer, in the case of unequal
('53', 333, 0, 1, 631837) 334 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('53', 333, 1, 2, 631879) parties, for the weaker.
('53', 333, 2, 3, 631904) Now the philosophy of hosts and guests.
('53', 333, 2, 4, 631944) Whose guest was Mr. Hot son?
('53', 333, 2, 5, 631973) Of the Fergusson College?
('53', 333, 2, 6, 631999) Surely of the Principal, and professors’ too; but never of the unwilling students.
('53', 333, 2, 7, 632082) Were the students consulted before inviting such a worthy guest?
('53', 333, 2, 8, 632147) Was not the Prince of Wales too a guest of the Indian Government and consequently, by the same argument, of India?
('53', 333, 2, 9, 632262) But how was he welcomed?
('53', 333, 2, 10, 632287) Sri Gogate in this case therefore is the last to be blamed for not having extraordinary self restraint; the real responsibility or irresponsibility is of Sri Mahajani, and the real offender or rather the real instigator of the offence is the Acting Governor, who ought to be advised to behave better.
('53', 333, 3, 11, 632588) I appreciate the courageous presence of mind shown by the Acting Governor, as well as the extraordinary coolness with which just after the unsuccessful outrage he told Sri Gogate, ‘That was a foolish thing to do, my boy’, and inquired, ‘What made you do a thing like that?’ But this generous and seemingly affectionate mood of the Acting Governor was very short lived.
('53', 333, 3, 12, 632957) Had it been courageously preserved by him a little longer, leaving Sri Gogate to himself as if nothing unusual had happened, what a dramatic effect it would have produced on the revolutionary mentality in the country!
('53', 333, 3, 13, 633175) The Acting Governor, always under the protection of his A.D.C. and the military guards, need not fear foolish things done by stray Gogates.
('53', 333, 3, 14, 633315) The time is not yet gone.
('53', 333, 3, 15, 633341) Trust begets trust.
('53', 333, 3, 16, 633361) Forgiveness melts bitterest enmity.
('53', 333, 3, 17, 633397) But the forgiveness must be of the strong, never of the weak.
('53', 333, 3, 18, 633459) The Acting Governor is the right man to make a beginning in this direction.
('53', 333, 3, 19, 633535) But the signs of the times clearly show there is very little chance that good sense will prevail.
('53', 333, 3, 20, 633633) As this note is being written on board the s.s.
('53', 333, 3, 21, 633681) Rajputana, it will therefore be printed three weeks after it is written.
('53', 333, 3, 22, 633754) The subject matter being unfortunately an evergreen, the note need not be considered stale.
('53', 333, 3, 23, 633846) It is very much to be feared, that the correspondent represents a mentality prevailing amongst many students.
('53', 333, 3, 24, 633956) But the attitude is all the more poisonous and harmful, because it is honestly held.
('53', 333, 3, 25, 634041) It is contrary to experience to say, as the correspondent says, that emotional youth will act on the spur of the moment irrespective of the atmosphere surrounding them.
('53', 333, 3, 26, 634210) There is no doubt about their reckless bearing, but I refuse to believe that they are so devoid of pride as to be wholly indifferent to praise or blame.
('53', 333, 3, 27, 634363) I am quite certain that if they knew that their acts would be universally condemned, they would never throw away their precious lives.
('53', 333, 3, 28, 634498) I have no doubt therefore in my mind that it is the duty of everyone who realizes the immense wrong done to the
('53', 334, 0, 1, 634610) VOL. 53 : 2 JULY, 1931 12 OCTOBER, 1931 335
('53', 334, 1, 2, 634654) cause by such deeds to condemn them unequivocally.
('53', 334, 1, 3, 634705) It is altogether misleading to hold the Acting Governor responsible either for the Sholapur Martial Law or the acts done under it.
('53', 334, 1, 4, 634836) It is the system that is at fault.
('53', 334, 1, 5, 634871) The Congress therefore having realized the central fact is trying to assassinate the system, and not the helpless administrators.
('53', 334, 1, 6, 635001) Even if an angel was put to administer the system based upon the exploitation of a vast country like India by a powerful corporation, that angel would plead helplessness, and on due occasions do exactly what the Acting Governor did.
('53', 334, 1, 7, 635234) The ten headed Ravana was no human monster, but it was the system personified in Ravana, who had new heads popping up as soon as the old ones were cut off.
('53', 334, 1, 8, 635390) It was only when Rama’s attention was drawn to the root from which the heads sprang up, that he was able effectively to deal with Ravana.
('53', 334, 1, 9, 635528) We have had many assassinations, and in the place of each official assassinated another has been posted, and the system has gone on as merrily as ever.
('53', 334, 1, 10, 635680) But if we once succeed in dealing with the root of the mischief, we shall have no more repetitions of Sholapur and the distasteful hangings.
('53', 334, 1, 11, 635821) So far therefore as the condemnation of the many wrongs which rankle in the youthful breasts is concerned, I would be just as strong as they are in condemning them.
('53', 334, 1, 12, 635986) Let them leave aside all specious reasoning, and join hands with the Congress in destroying the system.
('53', 334, 1, 13, 636090) The way of assassination of persons gives it a new lease of life.
('53', 334, 1, 14, 636156) The war of non violence shortens its life and if it can be completely assimilated, it ensures complete eradication of the system.
('53', 334, 1, 15, 636286) Let those who argue like the correspondent remember that the cult of assassination, if it is not checked in its progress, will recoil on our own heads, and our last state may be worse than the first.
('53', 334, 1, 16, 636486) Let us not run the very grave danger of reviving the system under a new garb.
('53', 334, 1, 17, 636564) The same system administered by brown men instead of white men will work the same havoc as now, if not infinitely greater.
('53', 334, 2, 18, 636687) Young India, 24 9 1931
('53', 334, 3, 19, 636710) 397. LEST WE DELUDE OURSELVES
('53', 334, 4, 20, 636740) [Before September 11, 1931] As I get nearer England I find my hopes of meeting with any success there receding.
('53', 334, 4, 21, 636852) I cannot point to any particular reason for this.
('53', 334, 4, 22, 636902) I place before readers the thoughts that arise in my mind.
('53', 334, 4, 23, 636961) I feel ashamed when I think on the one hand, of what the world expects of
('53', 335, 0, 1, 637035) 336 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('53', 335, 1, 2, 637077) India and on the other compare our resources with those expectations.
('53', 335, 1, 3, 637147) I met an educated Arab at Aden.
('53', 335, 1, 4, 637179) He it was who had read out the welcome address in Arabic.
('53', 335, 1, 5, 637237) He said: “Our hopes are pinned upon you—on your non violent struggle.” These are his very words, “We have been watching you.
('53', 335, 1, 6, 637362) May you triumph.” Similar cables have been sent from Egypt by the Muslim journalists there.
('53', 335, 1, 7, 637454) I believe that as we proceed, we shall hear such utterances from the people of Europe also.
('53', 335, 1, 8, 637546) Perhaps the world would not have looked to India the way it is looking now, if we had been waging our war of independence by means of physical force.
('53', 335, 1, 9, 637696) It means that the world is weary of hypocrisy and of rivers of blood.
('53', 335, 1, 10, 637766) Wherever it casts its eyes, it finds falsehood and, though it participates in it, it has come to abhor it.
('53', 335, 1, 11, 637873) And it is for this reason that it accepts India’s claim to truth and non violence and derives consolation from this and desires that India may triumph, that is, become independent with the help of these two weapons.
('53', 335, 1, 12, 638089) How can this expectation be fulfilled?
('53', 335, 1, 13, 638128) While closing this mail, I think of Gujarat, ignoring the other parts of India.
('53', 335, 1, 14, 638208) Gujarat has a leader like Vallabhbhai; Gujarat is the headquarters of satyagraha; nowhere also are as many volunteers working as in Gujarat; everyone, even the Government, agrees that Gujarat has made a sizable contribution to the struggle.
('53', 335, 1, 15, 638449) However, can Gujarat be regarded as having passed the test of truth and non violence one hundred per cent?
('53', 335, 1, 16, 638556) Are the volunteers of Gujarat, both men and women, totally free from greed, malice, anger, fear, fraud, and so on?
('53', 335, 1, 17, 638671) Khadi is a mighty external symbol of non violence.
('53', 335, 1, 18, 638722) Are Congressmen in Gujarat always clad in khadi from head to foot?
('53', 335, 1, 19, 638789) Do they do sacrificial spinning every day for the sake of the poor?
('53', 335, 1, 20, 638857) Has Gujarat succeeded in boycotting untouchability, liquor and foreign cloth?
('53', 335, 1, 21, 638935) These too are external symbols of collective non violence.
('53', 335, 1, 22, 638994) These and similar questions keep coming up in my mind and I feel agitated.
('53', 335, 1, 23, 639069) On the one hand, I make the claim that the country has accepted truth and non violence—there are strong grounds for the claim—on the other, while reflecting on it I also find that this claim does not contain the whole truth.
('53', 335, 1, 24, 639294) I cannot claim that we have properly accepted all that I now regard as the characteristics of truth and non violence.
('53', 335, 1, 25, 639412) Being an optimist, I keep on piloting my boat in the hope that we shall somehow make up for our feelings.
('53', 335, 1, 26, 639518) But I must proclaim that underlying all my expectations is my faith in Gujarat.

('53', 336, 0, 1, 639730) VOL. 53 : 2 JULY, 1931 12 OCTOBER, 1931 337
('53', 336, 1, 2, 639774) well be found in all quarters in England, the sun of hope will shine through that darkness of despair.

('53', 338, 7, 17, 644273) MARSEILLES, September 11, 1931
('53', 338, 8, 18, 644304) Mahatma Gandhi has no intention of visiting the United States because he believes he is “not wanted” there, he said in an interview with The New York Times when he landed here.
('53', 338, 9, 19, 644481) He explained that he refused to contemplate such a visit unless and until he could feel certain that Americans would receive him as the spokesman for India’s cause and not as a social curiosity.
('53', 338, 9, 20, 644676) His American friends had told him, he added that this was not now possible.

('53', 339, 1, 4, 645195) But since such a hope is only based on faith, not on reason, it may prove illusory.

('53', 339, 2, 10, 645954) Asked if he believed the recent change in the Government of Great Britain would change the British policy toward India, Mr. Gandhi said unhesitatingly: No.
('53', 339, 2, 11, 646110) Besides, the new Government has already given me assurances it will carry out the policy of its predecessor, as far as the India Conference is concerned.
('53', 339, 3, 12, 646264) With regard to the critical Hindu Muslim differences, however .
('53', 339, 3, 13, 646328) the Mahatma admitted: I fear the Hindu Muslim question has now become almost insoluble for reasons on which I don’t wish to enlarge.
('53', 339, 3, 14, 646461) But I am still not without hope that a solution may be found.
('53', 339, 3, 15, 646523) It is open to the Muslims to block the way to a settlement of the future of India as it is equally open to the British Government to make their opposition an excuse for not granting India self government.
('53', 339, 3, 16, 646728) But if the British Government is in earnest in its desire to make a friendly settlement with India it should not take shelter behind the Muslims.

('53', 340, 3, 5, 647955) Mr. Gandhi said with the greatest earnestness: Believe me, my attitude on the question of untouchability has never wavered in the slightest degree.

('53', 344, 3, 4, 655057) Since I visited France as a student to see the Exhibition at Paris in 1890 2, some greater and more permanent links between you and me have been formed.
('53', 344, 3, 5, 655210) The forger of those links is your own distinguished countryman Romain Rolland who constituted himself an interpreter of the humble message that I have been trying to deliver to my countrymen for the last 30 years or more.

('53', 344, 9, 12, 656071) explained by taking the example of the muscular Zulu quaking before a European child
('53', 344, 10, 13, 656156) holding a revolver in his hand and contrasting him with the women of India who
('53', 344, 11, 14, 656235) stood lathi blows and lathi charges without quaking.
('53', 344, 11, 15, 656288) To kill and to be killed in
('53', 344, 12, 16, 656316) fighting an enemy is, comparatively speaking, an act of bravery but to stand the
('53', 344, 13, 17, 656397) blows of your adversaries and not to retaliate is a greater form of bravery, and that is
('53', 344, 14, 18, 656486) precisely what India has been training herself for.
('53', 344, 14, 19, 656538) He concluded by touching on
('53', 344, 15, 20, 656566) another aspect of the same question.
('53', 344, 15, 21, 656603) This struggle through non violence has been otherwise described as a process of purification, the underlying idea being that a nation loses its liberty owing to some of its own weaknesses and we find that immediately we shed our weaknesses, we regain our liberty.

('53', 347, 2, 14, 661032) 410. SPEECH AT FRIENDS’ HOUSE, LONDON 1
('53', 347, 3, 15, 661072) September 12, 1931 You will not this evening expect me to take up much of your time, or to say much with reference to my mission , but I wish to say one thing in a general way.
('53', 347, 3, 16, 661249) I am here with my friends on a mission of peace.
('53', 347, 3, 17, 661298) I am, and my friends are, guests of the great English nation.
('53', 347, 3, 18, 661360) I hope that by the time we have finished our work, you will not consider that we have in any way abused your hospitality.
('53', 347, 3, 19, 661482) I hope that, as the days go by, you will understand the scope of the mission on which the Congress has sent me.
('53', 347, 3, 20, 661594) You will also please know that, as an agent holding a power of attorney from the Congress, I shall have my limitations.
('53', 347, 3, 21, 661714) I have to conduct myself within the four corners of the mandate that I have received from the Congress.
('53', 347, 3, 22, 661818) There are some words in that mandate which give to me a little measure of freedom of action, but in all respects, in all fundamental respects, I am hidebound 2. I may not, if I am to be loyal to the trust reposed in me walk outside the four corners of that mandate.
('53', 347, 4, 23, 662084) 1 According to Reuter, Gandhiji arrived in London from Folkstone at 4.10 in the afternoon and though it was raining , the rush of people was so great that police precautions became necessary.
('53', 347, 4, 24, 662276) He was driven straight to Friends’ House at Euston Road .

('53', 347, 4, 28, 662585) You are so simple that you bewilder some of us.
('53', 347, 4, 29, 662633) .” 2 Reuter’s report, published in The Bombay Chronicle, 14 9 1931, The Tribune, 15 9 1931, and The Hindustan Times, 16 9 1931, has here instead: “Gandhiji emphasized that he must conduct himself within the Congress mandate, some words of which left him little freedom, but in all other respects and in all fundamental respects, he was unbound.”

('53', 348, 1, 2, 663023) I venture to feel that Congress stands for a good cause, of which any nation would be proud.
('53', 348, 1, 3, 663116) The Congress wants freedom unadult erated for the dumb and starving millions.
('53', 348, 1, 4, 663194) In order that Congress may represent them, the Congress has chosen, as its means of vindicating this freedom, truth and non violence.
('53', 348, 1, 5, 663328) I am fully aware that not all Congressmen have lived up to the means, and I know that we of the Congress shall deserve the curses of the whole world if, in the name of truth and non violence, we do the contrary.
('53', 348, 1, 6, 663540) But I derive the greatest consolation from the knowledge that I possess that the best workers of the Congress today represent truth and non violence in their essence.
('53', 348, 1, 7, 663707) We have in our midst, I know, a school of violence also.
('53', 348, 1, 8, 663764) I know many of these young men—I have lived with them, I have mixed with them, I have talked to them also.
('53', 348, 1, 9, 663871) I have endeavoured, as several others of my co workers have endeavoured, to win them from what we hold is an error; but, at the same time, I know that there is a common cause, even between them and ourselves.
('53', 348, 1, 10, 664080) They are burning to attain the freedom to which India is entitled, which is India’s birthright.
('53', 348, 1, 11, 664176) I repeat what I have told them in public and in private—that their activities embarrass Congress, their activities set back the hands of the clock of progress.
('53', 348, 1, 12, 664336) The Congressmen who are wedded to this creed realize fully that these young men, who resort to violence for the sake of gaining freedom, do harm not only to themselves but to the country, and most of all to the dumb millions to whom I have referred.
('53', 348, 1, 13, 664586) We may be nationalists, we may be ardent patriots, but immedia tely we apply these means of truth and non violence, our patriotism be comes internationalism.
('53', 348, 1, 14, 664744) Our patriotism is so conceived that we want our freedom not to injure the freedom of any other country or of any single individual.
('53', 348, 1, 15, 664876) We believe not in the law that might is right, or the greatest good of the greatest number, but we believe in the greatest good of all, including the meanest of creatures amongst all God’s creation.
('53', 348, 1, 16, 665075) And if India could vindicate her freedom, attain it through these means, do you not think that it would be well, not only with India, but with the whole world?
('53', 348, 2, 17, 665235) But there is something more.
('53', 348, 2, 18, 665264) There is the Settlement between the Government of India and the Congress.
('53', 348, 2, 19, 665338) That is a sacred thing arrived at through the strivings of that noble Englishman, Lord Irwin.

('53', 352, 3, 13, 672564) 414. BROADCAST TO AMERICA 1
('53', 352, 4, 14, 672592) September 13, 1931 In my opinion, the Indian Conference bears in its consequences not only upon India but upon the whole world.
('53', 352, 4, 15, 672720) India is by itself almost a continent.
('53', 352, 4, 16, 672759) It contains one fifth of the human race.
('53', 352, 4, 17, 672800) It represents one of the most ancient civilizations.
('53', 352, 4, 18, 672853) It has traditions handed down from tens of thousands of years, some of which, to the astonishment of the world, remain intact.
('53', 352, 4, 19, 672980) No doubt the ravages of time have affected the purity of that civilization, as they have that of many other cultures and many institutions.
('53', 352, 4, 20, 673120) If India is to perpetuate the glory of her ancient past, it can do so only when it attains freedom.
('53', 352, 4, 21, 673220) The reason for the struggle having drawn the attention of the world, I know, does not lie in the fact that we Indians are fighting for our liberty, but in the fact that the means adopted by us for attaining that liberty are unique and, as far as history shows us, have not been adopted by any other people of whom we have any record.
('53', 352, 4, 22, 673554) The means adopted are not violence, not bloodshed, not diplomacy as one understands it nowadays, but they are purely and simply truth and non violence.
('53', 352, 4, 23, 673706) No wonder that the attention of the world is directed towards this attempt to lead a successful, bloodless revolution.
('53', 352, 4, 24, 673825) Hitherto, nations have fought in the manner of the brute.

('53', 353, 1, 2, 674264) They have wreaked vengeance upon those whom they have considered to be their enemies.
('53', 353, 1, 3, 674350) We find in searching national anthems adopted by great nations that they contain imprecations upon the so called enemy.
('53', 353, 1, 4, 674470) They have vowed destruction and have not hesitated to take the name of God and seek Divine assistance for the destruction of the enemy.
('53', 353, 1, 5, 674606) We in India have reversed the process.
('53', 353, 1, 6, 674645) We feel that the law that governs brute creation is not the law that should guide the human race.
('53', 353, 1, 7, 674743) That law is inconsistent with human dignity.
('53', 353, 1, 8, 674788) I, personally, would wait, if need be, for ages rather than seek to attain the freedom of my country through bloody means.
('53', 353, 1, 9, 674911) I feel in the innermost recesses of my heart, after a political experience extending over an unbroken period of close upon thirty five years, that the world is sick unto death of blood spilling.
('53', 353, 1, 10, 675106) The world is seeking a way out, and I flatter myself with the belief that perhaps it will be the privilege of the ancient land of India to show that way out to the hungering world.
('53', 353, 1, 11, 675287) I have, therefore, no hesitation whatsoever in inviting all the great nations of the earth to give their hearty co operation to India in her migh ty struggle.
('53', 353, 1, 12, 675446) It must be a sight worth contemplating and treasuring that millions of people have given themselves to suffering without retaliation in order that they might vindicate the dignity and honour of the nation.
('53', 353, 1, 13, 675652) I have called that suffering a process of self purification.
('53', 353, 1, 14, 675713) It is my certain conviction that no man loses his freedom except through his own weakness.I am painfully conscious of our own weaknesses.
('53', 353, 1, 15, 675851) We represent in India all the principal religions of the earth, and it is a matter of deep humiliation to confess that we are a house divided against itself; that we Hindus and Mussalmans are flying at one another.
('53', 353, 1, 16, 676066) It is a matter of still deeper humiliation to me that we Hindus regard several millions of our own kith and kin as too degraded even for our touch.
('53', 353, 1, 17, 676214) I refer to the so called “untouchables”.
('53', 353, 1, 18, 676255) These are no small weaknesses in a nation struggling to be free.
('53', 353, 1, 19, 676320) You will find that, in this struggle through self purification, we have assigned a foremost [part of our] 1 creed to the removal of this curse of untouchability and the attainment of unity amongst all the different classes and communities of India representing the different creeds.

('53', 356, 6, 9, 680665) In an exclusive interview to the Chronicle, Mahatmaji answered a number of questions today.
('53', 356, 6, 10, 680757) Asked whether, at the meeting of the Federal Structure Com mittee on Monday, Lord Sankey announced Government’s new scheme for consideration and whether Mahatmaji felt the Congress would be prepared to accept any scheme which fell short of what it had accepted by ratifying the Delhi Pact, Gandhiji answered : I must not anticipate any scheme that Lord Sankey wishes to bring forward.
('53', 356, 7, 11, 681142) Q. Do you believe that, in a scheme of federation composed of divergent systems of government obtainable in British India and in Indian States, it is possible to find a fusion between democracy and absolute autocracy ?
('53', 356, 8, 12, 681361) A. By mutual give and take I see no difficulty.
('53', 356, 9, 13, 681409) Q. Since the subjects of the Indian States are not represented at the R.T.
('53', 356, 10, 14, 681484) Conference, do you think the Congress can force the Princes to accept a democratic
('53', 356, 11, 15, 681567) form of government for their States ?
('53', 356, 12, 16, 681605) A. The Princes are capable of doing many things, but what they will do actually I do not know.

('53', 356, 14, 18, 681771) believe it is possible to deliberate upon the Hindu Muslim question with any measure
('53', 356, 15, 19, 681856) of success ?
('53', 356, 16, 20, 681869) A. It will be certainly a difficult task if not almost an impossible one.

('53', 358, 3, 4, 683791) LORD CHANCELLOR, YOUR HIGHNESSES AND FRIENDS, I must confess at the outset that I am not a little embarrassed in having to state before you the position of the Indian National Congress.
('53', 358, 3, 5, 683977) I would like to say that I have come to London to attend this Committee, as also the Round Table Conference when the proper time comes, absolutely in the spirit of co operation, and to strive to my utmost to find points of agreement.
('53', 358, 3, 6, 684211) I would like also to give this assurance to His Majesty’s Government that at no stage is it, or will it be, my desire to embarrass authority and I would like to give the same assurance to my colleagues here, that, however much we may differ about our view points, I shall not obstruct them in any shape or form.
('53', 358, 3, 7, 684523) My position, therefore, here depends entirely upon your goodwill, as also the goodwill of His Majesty’s Government.
('53', 358, 3, 8, 684639) If at any time I found that I could not be of any useful service to the Conference, I would not hesitate to withdraw myself from it.
('53', 358, 3, 9, 684772) I can also say to those who are responsible for the management of this Committee and the Conference that they have only to give a sign and I should have no hesitation in withdrawing.
('53', 358, 3, 10, 684955) I am obliged to make these remarks because I know that there are fundamental differences of opinion between the Government and the Congress, and it is possible that there are vital differences between my colleagues and myself.

('53', 358, 4, 14, 685521) Ramsay MacDonald, Prime Minister, was the Chairman of the Conference.
('53', 358, 4, 15, 685591) The second session did not open with a meeting of the full Conference.
('53', 358, 4, 16, 685662) The Federal Structure Committee reassembled on September 7, and the Minorities Committee on September 28, followed by a Plenary Session beginning on November 28, 1931. The other Committees of the Conference did not reassemble.

('53', 359, 1, 5, 686297) You will then extend your sympathy to me, because I know that the burden that rests upon my shoulders is really very great.
('53', 359, 1, 6, 686421) The Congress is, if I am not mistaken, the oldest political organizaton we have in India.

('53', 359, 1, 10, 686741) It claims to represent all Indian interests and all classes.

('53', 360, 1, 3, 688802) And so, if we have no distinctions of class or creed, we have no distinctions of sex either.
('53', 360, 1, 4, 688895) The Congress has, from its very commencement, taken up the cause of the so called untouchables.
('53', 360, 1, 5, 688991) There was a time when the Congress had at every annual session as its adjunct the Social Conference, to which the late Ranade dedicated his energies, among his many other activities.
('53', 360, 1, 6, 689174) Headed by him you will find, in the programme of the Social Confe rence, reform in connection with the untouchables taking a prominent place.
('53', 360, 1, 7, 689316) But in 1920, the Congress took a large step and brought in the question of the removal of untouchability as a plank on the political platform, making it an important item of the political programme.
('53', 360, 1, 8, 689515) Just as the Congress considered HIndu Muslim unity thereby meaning unity amongst all the classes to be indispensable for the attainment of swaraj, so also did the Congress consider the removal of the curse of untouchability as an indispensable condition for the attainment of full freedom.
('53', 360, 1, 9, 689805) The position the Congress took up in 1920 remains the same today; and so you will see the Congress has attempted from its very beginning to be what it described itself to be, namely, national in every sense of the term.
('53', 360, 1, 10, 690025) If Your Highnesses will permit me to say so, in the very early stages the Congress took up your cause also.
('53', 360, 1, 11, 690133) Let me remind this Committee that it was the Grand Old Man of India who sponsored the cause of Kashmir and Mysore; and these two great Houses, I venture in all humility to submit, owe not a little to the efforts of Dadabhai Naoroji and the Congress.
('53', 360, 1, 12, 690383) Even up to now the Congress has endeavoured to serve the Princes of India by refraining from any interference in their domestic and internal affairs.
('53', 360, 1, 13, 690533) I hope, therefore, that this brief introduction that I thought fit to give will serve to enable the Committee, and those who are at all interested in the claims of the Congress, to understand that it has endeavoured to deserve the claim that it has made.
('53', 360, 1, 14, 690788) It has failed, I know, often to live up to the claim but I venture to submit that, if you were to examine the history of the Congress, you would find that it has more often succeeded, and progressively succeeded than failed.
('53', 360, 1, 15, 691013) Above all , the Congress represents, in its essence, the dumb, semi starved millions scattered over the length and breadth of the land in its 700,000 villages, no matter whether they come from what is called
('53', 361, 0, 1, 691221) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 362
('53', 361, 1, 2, 691263) British India or what is called Indian India.
('53', 361, 1, 3, 691309) Every interest which, in the opinion of the Congress, is worthy of protection, has to subserve the interests of these dumb millions; and so you do find now and again apparently a clash between several interests.
('53', 361, 1, 4, 691521) But, if there is a genuine real clash, I have no hesitation in saying on behalf of the Congress that the Congress will sacrifice every interest for the sake of the interests of these dumb millions.
('53', 361, 1, 5, 691719) It is, therefore, essentially a peasant organization, and it is becoming so progressively.
('53', 361, 1, 6, 691810) You will even the Indian members of the Committee perhaps be astonished to find that today the Congress, through its organization, the All India Spinners’ Association, is finding work for nearly 50,000 women in nearly 2,000 villages, and these women are possibly 50 per cent Mussalman women.
('53', 361, 1, 7, 692102) Thousands of them belong to the so called untouchable class.
('53', 361, 1, 8, 692163) We have thus, in this constructive manner, penetrated these villages, and effort is being mde to cover every one of the 700,000 villages.
('53', 361, 1, 9, 692301) It is a super human task; but if human effort can do so, you will presently find the Congress covering all of these villages and bringing to them the message of the spinning wheel.
('53', 361, 1, 10, 692482) That being the representative character of the Congress, you will not be astonished when I read to you the Congress mandate.
('53', 361, 1, 11, 692607) I hope that it may not jar upon you.
('53', 361, 1, 12, 692644) You may consider that the Congress is making a claim which is wholly untenable.
('53', 361, 1, 13, 692724) Such as it is, I am here to put forth that claim on behalf of the Congress in the gentlest manner possible, but also in the firmest manner possible.
('53', 361, 1, 14, 692873) I have come here to prosecute that claim with all the faith and energy that I can command.
('53', 361, 1, 15, 692964) If you can convince me to the contrary and show that the claim is inimical to the interests of these dumb millions, I shall revise my opinion.
('53', 361, 1, 16, 693107) I am open to conviction, but even so I should have to ask my principals to consent to that revision before I could usefully act as the agent of the Congress.
('53', 361, 1, 17, 693265) At this stage I propose to read to you this mandate so that you can understand clearly the limitations imposed upon me.

('53', 363, 1, 16, 698869) If I want that freedom for my country, I would not be deserving of that freedom if I did not cherish and treasure the equal right of every other race, weak or strong, to the same freedom.

('53', 364, 2, 7, 700760) And when I have said this perhaps I have said all; and you will be able to dot the i’s and to cross the t’s, not execting me to fill in all the details, and tell you what I mean by control over the Army, what I mean by control over external affairs, finance, fiscal and economic policy, or even the financial transactions which a friend yesterday considered to be sacrosanct.

('53', 364, 2, 9, 701161) If there is a stock taking between incoming and outgoing partners, their transactions are subject to audit and adjustment; and the Congress will not be guilty of any dishonourable conduct or crime in saying that the nation should understand what it is to take over and what it should not take over.
('53', 364, 2, 10, 701460) This audit, this scrutiny, is asked for not merely in the interests of India; it is asked for in the interests of both.
('53', 364, 2, 11, 701580) I am positive that the British people do not want to saddle upon India a single burden which it should not legitimately bear; and I am here to declare, on behalf of the Congress, that the Congress will never think of repudiating a single claim or a burden that it should justly discharge.
('53', 364, 2, 12, 701869) If we are to live as an honourable nation worthy of commanding credit from the whole world, we will pay every farthing of legitimate debt with our blood.

('53', 365, 1, 2, 702065) I do not think that I should take you any further through the clauses of this mandate an analyse for you the meaning of these clauses as Congressmen give them.

('53', 365, 1, 5, 702487) But I think I have said quite enough in having, with some elaboration and with your generous indulgence, Lord Chancellor, taken the time of this meeting.

('53', 365, 3, 12, 703647) 421. SPEECH AT MEETING OF LABOUR M.P.S 1
('53', 365, 4, 13, 703688) LONDON, September 16, 1931
('53', 365, 5, 14, 703715) Mr. Gandhi addressed the Labour members of the House of Commons this evening.
('53', 365, 5, 15, 703793) In his address he stated that he had been sent to this country to adhere to the pledge he had given, that was, to get complete independence as far as India was concerned.
('53', 365, 5, 16, 703964) This was in the interests of India’s villagers, who were being starved as the result of the administration and the taxes they had to pay.
('53', 365, 6, 17, 704102) 1 This was held in the Grand Committee Room in the House of Commons.

('53', 366, 1, 2, 704305) An observation of his struck his trade union hearers as being remarkable.

('53', 366, 1, 7, 704890) It was the substance he wanted, not the shadow.

('53', 366, 1, 9, 705113) He repeated his demands for complete independence, control of the army, and external affairs.
('53', 366, 1, 10, 705207) In other words, he wanted the identical freedom for India that was enjoyed in Great Britain.

('53', 371, 3, 11, 717807) LONDON, September 17, 1931
('53', 371, 4, 12, 717834) LORD CHANCELLOR, It is not without very great hesitation that I take part in this debate on Head 2 1; and, before I proceed to deal with the several points that are noted down here for discussion, I should like, with your per mission, to disburden myself of an oppressive feeling that has been grow ing on me ever since Monday.
('53', 371, 4, 13, 718162) I have watched with the greatest attention the discussions that have taken place in this Committee.
('53', 371, 4, 14, 718262) I have endea voured to study, as I have not done before, the list of the Delegates; and the first feeling of oppression that has been coming upon me is that we are not the chosen ones of the nation which we should be representing, but we are the chosen ones of the Government.
('53', 371, 4, 15, 718539) I see, as I study the list and as I know the different parties and groups in India from experience, some very noticeable gaps also; and so I am oppressed with a sense of unreality in connection with our composition.
('53', 371, 4, 16, 718755) My second reason for feeling a sense of unreality is that these proceedings seem to me to be interminable and to be leading us practically nowhere.
('53', 371, 4, 17, 718903) If we go on at this rate I do not know that we shall proceed beyond having discussed the various points raised before this Committee threadbare.
('53', 371, 4, 18, 719048) I would therefore, first of all, Lord Chancellor, tender my deepest sympathies to you for the very great patience and, may I add, the unfailing courtesy with which you are handling us; and I really congratulate you upon the great pains that you are taking over the proceedings of this Committee.
('53', 371, 4, 19, 719344) I hope that, at the end of your task and of our task, it will be possible for me to tender my congratulations
('53', 371, 5, 20, 719454) 1 Questions connected with the election of members of the Federal Legislature
('53', 372, 0, 1, 719532) VOL. 53 : 2 JULY, 1931 12 OCTOBER, 1931 373
('53', 372, 1, 2, 719576) on having enabled us, or even compelled us, to show some tangible result.
('53', 372, 1, 3, 719650) May I here lodge a gentle, humble complaints against His Majesty’s advisers?
('53', 372, 1, 4, 719727) Having brought us together from over the seas, and knowing, as I take it they do know, that we are all of us, without exception busy people, as they themselves are, and that we have left our respective posts of duty having brought us together, is it not possible for them to give us a lead?
('53', 372, 1, 5, 720018) Can I not, through you, appeal to them to let us know their mind?

('53', 372, 1, 7, 720273) If some such thing was done, I have no doubt that we should be able to come to some conclusions, good or bad, satisfactory or unsatisfactory; but if we simply resolve ourselves into a debating society, each member of which gives an eloquent discourse upon the points severally raised, I do not think that we shall be serveing or advancing the purpose for which we have been brought together.

('53', 373, 0, 1, 722098) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 374
('53', 373, 1, 2, 722140) sub heads, I would have to offer suggestions or my opinion in terms of that mandate; and if the Committee does not know what it is sailing for, naturally the opinion that I may offer would be of really no value to it.

('53', 373, 1, 5, 722484) With reference to sub head (i), whilst my sympathies, broadly speaking, are with Dr. Ambedkar, my reason is wholly with Mr. Gavin Jones and Sir Sultan Ahmed.
('53', 373, 1, 6, 722642) If we were a homogeneous Committee whose member were entitled to vote and come to a conclusion, I should then sail a very large distance with Dr. Ambedkar; but such is not our position.
('53', 373, 1, 7, 722828) We are an ill assorted group, each member of which is independent of the other and therefore, entitled to give his or her views unfettered by any common rule.
('53', 373, 1, 8, 722987) Hence, we have no right, in my humble opinion , to say to the States what they shall do and what they shall not do.
('53', 373, 1, 9, 723103) Those states have very generously come to our assistance and said that they would federate with us, and perhaps part with some of their rights which they might otherwise have held exclusively.
('53', 373, 1, 10, 723296) That being so, I could not but endorse the opinion given by Sir Sultan Ahmed, which was perhaps emphasized by Mr. Gavin Jones, that the utmost that we can do is to plead with the States, and show them our own difficulties.
('53', 373, 1, 11, 723519) At the same time I feel that we have to recognize their special difficulties also.

('53', 385, 8, 11, 751494) 427. WHAT I WANT
('53', 385, 9, 12, 751511) The Editor has kindly asked me to say in these columns “what I want”.
('53', 385, 9, 13, 751581) The title is a misnomer.
('53', 385, 9, 14, 751606) I am here merely as an agent for the Indian National Congress, and I can want nothing apart from the Congress.
('53', 385, 9, 15, 751717) “What I want”, therefore, means what the Indian National Congress wants.
('53', 385, 9, 16, 751790) Let me then introduce my principal, the Indian National Congress, to the reader.
('53', 385, 9, 17, 751871) It is perhaps the oldest political organizaton in India and claims to represent the whole of India.
('53', 385, 9, 18, 751971) I know that some people would deny this claim.
('53', 385, 9, 19, 752018) I can only say that it is made by right of service.
('53', 385, 9, 20, 752070) The Indian National Congress is over forty seven years old.
('53', 385, 9, 21, 752130) It was conceived by an Englishman, Allan Octavius Hume.
('53', 385, 9, 22, 752186) It has had, besides Hindus, Mohammedan, Parsi and Christian presidents.
('53', 385, 9, 23, 752258) It had two women as presidents, Dr. Annie Besant and Mrs. Sarojini Naidu.
('53', 385, 9, 24, 752332) It has zamindars, too, as its members.
('53', 385, 9, 25, 752371) The Indian National Congress is no respector of persons.
('53', 385, 10, 26, 752428) 1 Editor of the Tea and Coffee Trade Journal of New York.
('53', 385, 10, 27, 752486) In a letter dated September 18 he had asked how Gandhiji’s plans fo a free India were likely to affect the tea industry.
('53', 386, 0, 1, 752607) VOL. 53 : 2 JULY, 1931 12 OCTOBER, 1931 387
('53', 386, 1, 2, 752651) knows no distinction between classes or creeds of the sexes.
('53', 386, 1, 3, 752712) It has always championed the cause of the so called untouchables, and has of recent years appointed an anti untouchability committee for hastening the destruction of untouchability.
('53', 386, 1, 4, 752894) But the unchallenged and unchallengeable claim of the Indian National Congress consists in its representing the millions of dumb paupers living in the seven hundred thousand Indian villages who constitute over 85 per cent of the population.
('53', 386, 1, 5, 753135) It is in the name of this great organization that I claim : (1) Complete independence for India.
('53', 386, 1, 6, 753232) (2) This does not exclude partnership at will and on terms of absolute equality.
('53', 386, 1, 7, 753313) (3) Nor does this exclude Federation or such safeguards as may be demonstrably necessary in the interest of India.
('53', 386, 1, 8, 753428) I hope the readers of The Daily Mail will not be frightened by the claim boldly put forth on behalf of the Congress.
('53', 386, 1, 9, 753545) “Do unto others as you would that others should do unto you.” On the strength of the wise saying nineteen hundred years old, I hope that Englishmen and English women will not grudge India the freedom which she has remained without by reason of British rule.

('53', 386, 4, 18, 754300) September 19, 1931
('53', 386, 5, 19, 754319) Seated on the floor in the centre of the hall at Kingsley Settlement yesterday afternoon, Mr. Gandhi gave a special and strictly private reception to a group of youngsters, none of whom was over twelve, from among the children of Bow.
('53', 386, 5, 20, 754554) Grown ups were strictly excluded with the exception of one or two of Miss Lester’s helpers, and the genial figures of Mr. and Mrs. George Lansbury and the dignified Prime
('53', 387, 0, 1, 754725) 388 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('53', 387, 1, 2, 754767) Minister of Bhavnagar, Sir Prabhashankar Pattani.
('53', 387, 1, 3, 754817) But immediately after the meeting (writes a correspondent) Mr. Gandhi himself told me all about it.
('53', 387, 1, 4, 754917) Questions about the weather in India, about the games the Indian children played, and so on, led to one child asking about the language I spoke.
('53', 387, 1, 5, 755062) This gave me just the opportunity I wanted, and I began talking about the common source of many of our words.
('53', 387, 1, 6, 755172) I took “pater”, “father”, and the Hindu “pita”; and “mater”, “mother”, and our own “mata”.
('53', 387, 1, 7, 755263) When I asked what that showed, they called out, “It shows, we are all of the same breed.” Then we are all one family and ought to be friends, I said, and they agreed.
('53', 387, 1, 8, 755430) I then asked if any of the boys hit back, and ten or twelve brave boys put their hands up.
('53', 387, 1, 9, 755521) So this gave me a chance for a little lesson in the principle of non violence, and I asked what they really should have done instead.
('53', 387, 1, 10, 755655) “Make friends”, they replied, and I told them to remember this.
('53', 387, 1, 11, 755719) I do like the London children so much and it has been so delightful to meet them both here and in some of their homes which I visited this morning.
('53', 387, 2, 12, 755867) As a result of this meeting, some of the children expressed their determination to send a little deputation to Mr. Gandhi with a message of friendship to the children of India.

('53', 388, 5, 8, 756868) 431. GUJARAT KHADI
('53', 388, 6, 9, 756887) If Gujarat does not use Gujarat’s khadi, who else will?
('53', 388, 6, 10, 756943) If the Gujaratis cast aside Gujarat khadi saying that it is coarse, not durable and expensive, who else will use it and why should they?
('53', 388, 6, 11, 757080) It is through similar pretexts that religions have perished, countries have been ruined, and men have suffered a downfall.
('53', 388, 6, 12, 757203) If you find Gujarat’s khadi rough and coarse, have it produced find and smooth.
('53', 388, 6, 13, 757283) If it is expensive, it will certainly become cheap if larger quantities of it are sold.
('53', 388, 6, 14, 757371) Everyone knows that khadi made in Gujarat today is finer, more durable and cheaper than it was ten years ago.
('53', 388, 6, 15, 757481) Its quality will improve even more if its sales are larger.
('53', 388, 6, 16, 757541) Whether this improvement takes place or not rests entirely with the Gujaratis themselves.
('53', 388, 6, 17, 757631) The latter can reject it by regarding it as expensive or, alternatively, they can accept it by looking upon it as something belonging to them despite its high price and, by doing so, bring about an improvement in its quality and variety, beautify it, and make it even inexpensive.
('53', 388, 6, 18, 757912) With this worthy objective, a devotee of khadi suggests that the Provincial Committee should celebrate a Gujarat Khadi Week.
('53', 388, 6, 19, 758037) During that week, the Committee should collect khadi from all those places where stock have accumulated and men and women volunteers should go from door to door and sell it.
('53', 388, 6, 20, 758211) The total quantity of khadi produced in Gujarat is so small that, if it means it, Ahmedabad alone can buy it up.
('53', 388, 6, 21, 758324) It is not for me to say how the Week should be celebrated.
('53', 388, 7, 22, 758383) 1 The addressee in his letter of September 19 had urged Gandhiji to pay a visit to Germany on his way back home.
('53', 389, 0, 1, 758496) 390 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('53', 389, 1, 2, 758538) having collected all the khadi and paying up the respective dues to the various production centres, the Committee should add up the entire amount and find out the average price, and then sell it without incurring any loss.
('53', 389, 1, 3, 758761) Selling it at a loss would be business practice.
('53', 389, 1, 4, 758810) Here the question is not one of business but of patriotism.
('53', 389, 1, 5, 758870) Patriotism can pay any price.
('53', 389, 1, 6, 758900) Just as a mother does not regard her children as expensive or ugly and abandon them but sacrifices herself for their sake, similarly, even if Gujarat does something of this sort, that will be enough.
('53', 389, 1, 7, 759100) Gujarat does not have to sacrifice itself, it may perhaps have to pay a slightly higher price.

('53', 392, 4, 11, 764934) 437. INTERVIEW WITH CHARLIE CHAPLIN 1
('53', 392, 5, 12, 764972) LONDON, September 22, 1931
('53', 392, 6, 13, 764999) Gandhiji had not heard of him, but he had evidently heard of Gandhiji’s spinning wheel and the very first question he asked was why Gandhiji was against machinery.
('53', 392, 6, 14, 765163) The question delighted Gandhiji who explained to him in detail why the six months’ unemployment of the whole peasant population of India made it important for him to restore them to their former subsidiary industry.
('53', 392, 7, 15, 765379) CHARLIE CHAPLIN: Is it then only as regards cloth?
('53', 392, 8, 16, 765430) GANDHIJI : Precisely.
('53', 392, 8, 17, 765452) In cloth and food every nation should be self contained.
('53', 392, 8, 18, 765509) We were self contained and want to be that again.
('53', 392, 8, 19, 765559) England with their large scale production has to look for a market elsewhere.
('53', 392, 8, 20, 765637) We call it exploitation.
('53', 392, 8, 21, 765662) And an exploiting England is a danger to the world, but if that is so, how much more so would be an exploiting India, if she took to machinery and produced cloth many times in excess of its requirements.
('53', 392, 9, 22, 765866) CHARLIE CHAPLIN: So the question is confined only to India?
('53', 392, 9, 23, 765926) But supposing you had in India the independence of Russia, and you could find other work for our
('53', 392, 10, 24, 766023) 1 The interview took place at the house of Dr. Katial in Canning Town.
('53', 392, 10, 25, 766094) The report has been extracted from Mahadev Desai’s “London Letter” and My Autobio graphy by Charlie Chaplin.

('53', 395, 4, 6, 770550) LONDON, September 23, 1931 You will be astonished to hear from me that, although to all appearances my mission is political, I would ask you to accept my assurance that its roots are—if I may use that term—spiritual.
('53', 395, 4, 7, 770767) It is commonly known, though perhaps not believed, that I claim that at least my politics are not divorced from morality, from spirituality, from religion.
('53', 395, 4, 8, 770923) I have claimed—and the claim is based upon extensive experience—that a man who is trying to discover and follow the will of God cannot possibly leave a single field of life untouched.
('53', 395, 4, 9, 771107) I came also, in the course of my service, to the conclusion that if there was any field of life where morality, where truth, where fear of God, were not essential, that field should be given up entirely.
('53', 395, 4, 10, 771311) But I found also that the politics of the day are no longer a concern of kings, but that they affect the lowest strata of society.
('53', 395, 4, 11, 771442) And I found, through bitter experience that, if I wanted to do social service, I could not possibly leave politics alone.
('53', 395, 4, 12, 771564) Do not please consider that I want to speak to you tonightabout politics and somehow or other connect voluntary poverty with politics.
('53', 395, 4, 13, 771699) That is not my intention.

('53', 396, 1, 16, 774410) The possession of anything then became a troublesome thing and a burden.

('53', 397, 0, 1, 774819) 398 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('53', 397, 1, 2, 774861) not merely to divide the thing with me but to dispossess me.

('53', 398, 1, 2, 777288) humbug, because a man or a woman may easily deceive himself or herself and deceive his or her neighbours also, by saying : In spirit I have given up all possessions, and yet externally I am possessing these things; you must not examine my deed, you must examine my intention; and of my intention only I must remain the sole witness.” That is a trap, and a death trap.
('53', 398, 1, 3, 777656) How are you then to justify the possession even of a piece of cloth two or three or four yards, say, in length and a yard in width ?
('53', 398, 1, 4, 777789) How can you justify even the possession of that piece of cloth in order to cover your body somewhat, when you know that, if you left that piece of cloth alone, even that would be taken over by someone—not maliciously again—but because he would want it for he has not even so much as that piece of cloth?

('53', 403, 1, 2, 789888) such thing as magic of that character on this earth.
('53', 403, 1, 3, 789941) It is a painful process, and these men have first of all to have the necessities of life before I can talk to them of voluntary poverty.
('53', 403, 1, 4, 790078) What does happen is this: that a man like me going among them, living in their midst as best he can their life, can bring a ray of hope into their hearts.
('53', 403, 1, 5, 790233) They will accept remedies that a man like me may suggest to them.

('53', 403, 1, 7, 790394) They would say : “He is happy although he possesses nothing; how is it?” I do not need to argue with them; they begin to argue for themselves.

('53', 403, 1, 9, 790622) I could not.
('53', 403, 1, 10, 790635) But today, having under taken to speak on voluntary poverty, I am sharing, to a certain extent only, these treasured experiences of mine not amongst a few hundred people here but amongst millions of people.
('53', 403, 1, 11, 790842) I tell you that it is beyond description, the bliss, the happiness, and the ability that this voluntary poverty gives one.
('53', 403, 1, 12, 790965) I can only say: try it and experiment with it, test it for yourselves.
('53', 403, 1, 13, 791036) I thank you for giving me your undivided attention.
('53', 403, 1, 14, 791088) There are still exactly ten minutes left before the hour of prayer, and if any of you wish to ask me any questions, I shall be glad.
('53', 403, 1, 15, 791221) You need not hesitate to ask anything that is in your mind; you will never offend me by asking any questions, let them be as awkward as they may be.
('53', 403, 2, 16, 791370) Q. Can the Mahatma tell us how he can justify collecting large sums of money when Jesus, the Buddha and other great religious teachers who have practised voluntary poverty have never asked for or received large sums of money ?

('53', 403, 3, 18, 791655) A. Did these great teachers never ask for or receive moneys?

('53', 403, 3, 21, 791936) He could not possibly found institutions without money.
('53', 403, 3, 22, 791992) And it is said that they who gave themselves body, soul and mind gave their riches also and placed them at the feet of the Buddha, who gladly accepted them—but not for himself.

('53', 404, 2, 4, 792579) 442. SPEECH AT MEETING OF M.P.S 1
('53', 404, 3, 5, 792613) LONDON, September 23, 1931 The Congress stand for complete independence, and complete independence does not mean, and has never meant, isolation in any form, and does not exclude partnership on absolutely equal terms to be terminated at the will of either party.
('53', 404, 3, 6, 792876) It has appeared to me strange that this claim should be repudiated or laughed at by Englishmen, who themselves were never satisfied with anything less than complete freedom for themselves.
('53', 404, 3, 7, 793065) I think that any nation or any body of people, after they have become conscious of their national right, would never be satisfied with anything less than complete indepen dence.
('53', 404, 3, 8, 793243) It means to us full control over our defences, full control over our external affairs, and full control over finances, and the discussion on these points gave rise to the much used expression “safeguards” throughout.
('53', 404, 3, 9, 793460) I have no doubt that you know of the safeguards that were provisionally adjusted by the last R.T.C. I do not hesitate to say, on behalf of the Congress, that those safeguards will not be accepted by the Congress.
('53', 404, 3, 10, 793673) Now if we have no control over the army or over he defence—and external affairs are also a reserved subject according to the provisional reservations of the R.T.C.—it is certainly not complete independence: it is not even a moderate form of self government.
('53', 404, 3, 11, 793931) A person does not enjoy self government if he depends on others for his defence.
('53', 404, 3, 12, 794012) I know that it has been contended that India is not able to defend herself.
('53', 404, 3, 13, 794088) Before the British advent I claim that we were able to servive invasions, and there were many invasions made, and we were able to maintain intact the civilization that we had inherited from time immemorial.
('53', 404, 4, 14, 794295) 1 The meeting was held at the House of Commons under the auspices of the Commonwealth of India League.
('53', 404, 4, 15, 794398) Morley, M.P., presided in the absence of Horrabin, Chairman of the League.
('53', 404, 4, 16, 794473) M.P.s of all the three parties were present.
('53', 405, 0, 1, 794518) 406 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('53', 405, 1, 2, 794560) We have disarmament in India not voluntary, but super imposed.
('53', 405, 1, 3, 794623) The Hindus and Muslims are living more in peace in what is called Princes’ India than in British India.
('53', 405, 1, 4, 794727) There have certainly been a few riots, but my claim is that British arms are not strong enough to prevent these.
('53', 405, 1, 5, 794840) If British armies were removed, it would not mean “suicide” for India, as is sometimes stated.
('53', 405, 1, 6, 794935) To take charge of our defence does not mean that we should do away with every British soldier and officer, if British soldiers or officers would be good enough to serve us.
('53', 405, 2, 7, 795108) Mr. Gandhi then said that he could not understand those who said that the British would never serve under India in this way.
('53', 405, 2, 8, 795233) Is this a proper attitude if there is to be any conciliation with India on terms of proper equality ?
('53', 405, 2, 9, 795335) Complete independence must mean complete control of the army.
('53', 405, 2, 10, 795397) It means that the civil power should have absolute control over the military power, that the military would not act without the sanction of the civil power.
('53', 405, 3, 11, 795554) Mr. Gandhi then pointed out that the Indians believed the administration of India to be the most expensive in the world, and India, he said, can no longer afford it.
('53', 405, 3, 12, 795720) I am convinced that it would be suicidal for India to consent to those safeguards and take the mere husk of independence.
('53', 405, 3, 13, 795842) To consent to these safeguards menas farming out our revenue to the extent of 80 per cent.
('53', 405, 3, 14, 795933) Do you suppose that we can pay for our education, hygiene, hospitals, roads and constructive works , which must be undertaken, and should have been undertaken over a generation ago, with only 20 per cent of our revenue left to us?
('53', 405, 3, 15, 796164) I would not touch that independence; I would far rather remain in compulsory subjection and declare myself a rebel than take charge of a government that I know is bound to declare itself bankrupt in, say, five or ten years.
('53', 405, 3, 16, 796388) No Englishman, if he were in our shoes, would accept that; and you will find that I would fight with my blood as a civil resister rather than co operate with you and become a slave, which in my humble opinion is what is meant by these safeguards.
('53', 405, 4, 17, 796635) As regards “Safeguards” for Europeans, Mr. Gandhi said: I can understand the Muslims asking for protection, and the Sikhs, and I can understand still more the untouchables; but for the Europeans, that is to say, the rulers, asking for protection from three
('53', 406, 0, 1, 796892) VOL. 53 : 2 JULY, 1931 12 OCTOBER, 1931 407
('53', 406, 1, 2, 796936) hundred million slaves, or subjects, call them by what sweet name you will, that surpasses my understanding.
('53', 406, 1, 3, 797045) You must live with us on terms of goodwill.
('53', 406, 1, 4, 797089) Do you want protection from the people you serve?
('53', 406, 1, 5, 797139) No protection will protect British trade in India if that trade is inimical to Indian interests.
('53', 406, 1, 6, 797236) Every “interest” British or Indian, will have to pass this acid test: Is it or is it not in the interests of the people?
('53', 406, 1, 7, 797357) Partnership does mean favoured treatment for the partner, but that favoured treatment would naturally carry with it the condition that the goods were goods needed in India and of the standard quality and price.
('53', 406, 1, 8, 797568) I would prefer the British typewriter and the British watch, even though I had a pay a little more, and that will be the attitude of three hundred million partners when this weight, which is gradually sinking them, is lifted from their heads.

('53', 408, 5, 8, 801140) 447. INTERVIEW TO “JOHN BULL”
('53', 408, 6, 9, 801170) LONDON, [On or before September 25, 1931] I was a very ordinary body and had no inkling as to my future destiny.
('53', 408, 6, 10, 801283) I used to run about the streets barefoot and play with the other lads.
('53', 408, 6, 11, 801354) I went to an Indian school, for, of course, I was born in India; not Africa, as people think.
('53', 408, 6, 12, 801448) I had a happy childhood, and was not precocious in any way.
('53', 408, 6, 13, 801508) My father was Prime Minister of the State in which I was born.
('53', 408, 6, 14, 801571) The call to lead India did not come to me in the nature of a sudden revelation.
('53', 408, 6, 15, 801651) It simply came when it came.
('53', 408, 6, 16, 801680) It was rather a gradual realization.
('53', 408, 6, 17, 801717) I prepared for it by fasting and self discipline.
('53', 408, 6, 18, 801767) My political work grew out of my spiritual preparation.
('53', 408, 6, 19, 801823) You ask me to compare the poverty in the East with that of the West?
('53', 408, 6, 20, 801892) It is impossible.
('53', 408, 6, 21, 801910) The two cannot be compared.
('53', 408, 6, 22, 801938) In the East, poverty exists to a degree undreamt of in the West.
('53', 408, 6, 23, 802003) Many thousands are entirely without food, and quite without shelter.
('53', 408, 6, 24, 802072) You ask me how I would fulfil my dreams if I had the power, what I would do to wake the “dumb, starving millions” from their lethargy, make them articulate, and give them food.
('53', 408, 6, 25, 802249) I would make them work.
('53', 408, 6, 26, 802273) At what?
('53', 408, 6, 27, 802282) At the charkha and handlooms.
('53', 408, 6, 28, 802312) I would educate them.
('53', 408, 6, 29, 802334) Yes, on Indian lines.
('53', 408, 6, 30, 802356) I would build new roads—fine roads, that would benefit both man and beast.
('53', 408, 6, 31, 802431) I picture the new India as filled with linked villages, happy in their industries.
('53', 409, 0, 1, 802514) 410 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('53', 409, 1, 2, 802556) If India gets her freedom, I should be guided by circumstances as to whether I should take my place at the head of the nation or return quietly to my Ashram.
('53', 409, 1, 3, 802714) I should love to go back, but I should not hesitate to shoulder the burden of leadership if it came to me.
('53', 409, 1, 4, 802821) I should follow the guidance of my inner voice.
('53', 409, 1, 5, 802869) Shall I go to America?
('53', 409, 1, 6, 802892) Invitations have reached me, but there again I shall do as my inner voice tells me.
('53', 409, 1, 7, 802976) You ask: Is this an actual definite voice?
('53', 409, 1, 8, 803019) it is the voice of conscience.
('53', 409, 1, 9, 803050) I am prepared to compromise on non essential matters, but not on essentials.
('53', 409, 1, 10, 803127) Yes, certainly, I think the co operation of the Indian Princes is necessary for a successful swaraj.
('53', 409, 1, 11, 803228) Enemies of India say that the Hindus and Muslims will fly at each other’s throats as soon as the British rule is withdrawn.

('53', 409, 1, 21, 803850) Not the masses.
('53', 409, 1, 22, 803866) They would continue to live as they do now, in perfect peace.

('53', 409, 1, 24, 803982) I think Britain is bound to concede swaraj.
('53', 409, 1, 25, 804026) Sooner or later it is sure to come.
('53', 409, 1, 26, 804062) My wife has been extraordinarily good to me, and it is she who cares for my physical welfare.
('53', 409, 1, 27, 804156) How did I marry her?
('53', 409, 1, 28, 804177) My parents arranged the marriage, as parents do most marriages in India, but I knew her before and love existed between us.
('53', 409, 1, 29, 804301) I started life as a legal adviser to a Mussalman firm in South Africa, and when I saw that the Indians there were being persecuted, I thought, it was my duty to take up their cause.
('53', 409, 1, 30, 804483) I, thereore, settled in South Africa, and I was successful.
