('53', 410, 6, 13, 805505) 450. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('53', 410, 7, 14, 805533) SPRINGVALE GARDEN VILLAGE, September 26, 1931 I have come to England, and now to Lancashire, in search of a way out of the difficulty.
('53', 410, 7, 15, 805668) Unemployment in any country is always bad, and it would be a matter of the greatest joy to me if I could, in any shape or form, contribute towards relieving that unemployment.
('53', 410, 7, 16, 805844) But I am powerless to do anything without the active co operation of Lancashire and of Englishmen in other parts of Great Britain.
('53', 410, 8, 17, 805975) 1 Gandhiji made the statement after his meeting with Lord Irwin.
('53', 410, 8, 18, 806040) The meeting took place at the latter’s house in Eaton Square and lasted two hours and twenty minutes.

('53', 411, 0, 1, 806270) 412 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('53', 411, 1, 2, 806312) The poverty I have seen distresses me, and it distresses me further to know that in this unemployment I have a kind of a share.
('53', 411, 1, 3, 806440) That distress is relieved, however, by the knowledge that my part was wholly unin tended; that it was as a result of the steps I took, and had to take, as part of my duty towards the largest army of unemployed to be found in the world, namely the starving millions of India, compared with whose poverty and pauperism the poverty of Lancashire dwindles into insignificance.
('53', 411, 1, 4, 806813) I am therefore trying to meet as many Englishmen as possible, and acquaint myself with their mentality and am trying to give them, as I know it, the correct situation in India.

('53', 411, 2, 6, 807021) 451. TALK WITH REPRESENTATIVES OF COTTON INDUSTRY 1
('53', 411, 3, 7, 807073) EDGEWORTH, September 26, 1931
('53', 411, 4, 8, 807103) In his speech Mr. Gandhi outlined at considerable length his economic policy for India, and explained how the khaddar movement also had a social significance, since it was aimed at producing self respect in the Indian villager.
('53', 411, 4, 9, 807331) He drew waht was generally agreed to be a heart rending picture of Indian poverty, and said that though the conditions in Lancashire as he had seen them distressed him, they were infinitely better than those obtaining in India.
('53', 411, 5, 10, 807559) Q. Is it possible, Mr. Gandhi, to divorce boycott for a political purpose from boycott for an economic purpose?
('53', 411, 5, 11, 807671) A. When the sole object was that of punishing Britain as in 1930, when people preferred articles of American or German make to those of British make, it was avowedly of a political purpose.
('53', 411, 5, 12, 807861) Even British machinery was then boycotted.
('53', 411, 5, 13, 807904) But now the original economic
('53', 411, 6, 14, 807934) 1 The meeting was arranged by T. D. Barlow, Chairman of the Joint Committee of Cotton Trade Organizations, at his residence in the afternoon and included several prominent representatives of the cotton trade.
('53', 411, 6, 15, 808143) Gandhiji, according to The Manchester Guardian, spoke for forty minutes, but a full report of the speech is not available since no reporters were present.
('53', 411, 6, 16, 808298) Some of those present, however, sent to The Manchester Guardian their own accounts of what Gandhiji said (vide Appendix “Account of Meeting with Representatives of cotton Trade”).
('53', 411, 6, 17, 808478) The brief report of the speech appearing here is from The Manchester Guardian while the questions and answers the follow are from Mahadev Desai’s account in Young India, “Gandhiji in Lancashire”.
('53', 412, 0, 1, 808674) VOL. 53 : 2 JULY, 1931 12 OCTOBER, 1931 413
('53', 412, 1, 2, 808718) boycott remains.
('53', 412, 1, 3, 808735) You may call it boycott but it is an entirely educative effort or self purificatory endeavour.
('53', 412, 1, 4, 808830) It is an appeal to go back to our former calling, shake off idleness and earn a living, however poor, not on doles but in the sweat of their brow.
('53', 412, 2, 5, 808977) Q. But the political aspect would be there inasmuch as you would give preference to your mills over all other foreign articles.
('53', 412, 3, 6, 809105) A. The boycott was not undertaken on behalf of the mills.
('53', 412, 3, 7, 809163) In fact, it was the first constructive effort begun with our quarrel with the local mill owners, and though the mill owners are supporting our movement, they are not controlling our policy but we are trying to influence them.
('53', 412, 3, 8, 809389) And when we go out to the villages, we do not ask them to wear Indian mill cloth, we ask them to wear khadi or to make their own khadi, and every Congressman is expected to wear khadi.
('53', 412, 4, 9, 809574) Q. Whatever you may say, Mr. Gandhi, you are in for more political power, which you are bound to get, and as soon as you get it, these mill owners, in the unscrupulousness of their greed, will build huge tariff walls and be a graver danger to your villages than even the Lancashire cotton trade.
('53', 412, 5, 10, 809870) A. If I am still living then, and if such a catastrophe happens, I make bold to say that the mills will be destroyed in the process.
('53', 412, 5, 11, 810003) And, with real politcial power, universal adult suffrage will come and it will be impossible for the monied classes to crush the interests of poor villagers.
('53', 412, 6, 12, 810161) Q. Don’t you think people themselves will go back to mill cloth as the Americans are going back to liquor ?
('53', 412, 7, 13, 810269) In America, prohibition was a mighty weapon used by a powerful nation against an unwilling people.
('53', 412, 7, 14, 810368) People were accustomed to drinking.
('53', 412, 7, 15, 810404) Drink was fashionable.
('53', 412, 7, 16, 810427) In India, mill cloth was never a fashion, whereas khadi has become a fashion and a passport to respectable society.
('53', 412, 7, 17, 810543) And, whatever happens I shall fight on for the economic salvation of my people and that, you will agree, is worth living for and dying for.
('53', 412, 8, 18, 810683) Q. It will be an unequal fight.
('53', 412, 8, 19, 810715) The rapacity of economic competition will carry everything before it.
('53', 412, 9, 20, 810785) A. God, you say, has suffered defeat at the hand of Mammon and will continue to do.
('53', 412, 9, 21, 810869) Well, He will not suffer defeat in India.

('53', 413, 1, 2, 811017) 452. TALK WITH REPRESENTATIVES OF COTTON INDUSTRY 1
('53', 413, 2, 3, 811069) DARWEN, September 26, 1931 Pray tell me what I am to do with a fifth of the human race living on the verge of starvation and devoid of all sense of selfrespect.
('53', 413, 2, 4, 811230) It should occupy the attention even of unemployed Lancashire.
('53', 413, 2, 5, 811292) You have told us of the help Lancashire gave us during the famine of 1899 1900. What return can we render but the blessings of the poor?
('53', 413, 2, 6, 811429) I have come to give you fair trade.
('53', 413, 2, 7, 811465) But, if I go without giving it, it will not be through any fault of mine.
('53', 413, 2, 8, 811539) There is no bitterness in me.
('53', 413, 2, 9, 811569) I claim, fellowship with the lowest of animals.
('53', 413, 2, 10, 811617) Why not then with Englishmen with whom we have been bound, for good or ill, for over a century and amongst whom I claim some of my dearest friends?
('53', 413, 2, 11, 811765) You will find me an easy proposition, but if you will repel my advances I shall go away, not in bitterness, but with a sense that I was not pure enough to find a lodgment in your hearts.
('53', 413, 2, 12, 811952) Young India, 15 10 1931
('53', 413, 3, 13, 811976) 453. INTERVIEW TO UNEMPLOYED WORKERS’ DEPUTATION 2
('53', 413, 4, 14, 812027) SPRINGFIELD GARDEN VILLAGE, September 26, 1931 There is no boycott of British cloth, as distinguished from other foreign cloth, since the 5th March when the Truce was signed.
('53', 413, 4, 15, 812202) As a nation we are pledged to boycott all foreign cloth, but in case of an honourable settlement between England and India, i.e., in case of a permanent peace, I should not hesitate to give preference to Lancashire cloth to all other foreign cloth, to the extent that we may need to supplement out cloth and on agreed terms.
('53', 413, 4, 16, 812527) But how much relief that can give you, I do not know.

('53', 414, 3, 8, 813303) I am pained at the unemployment here.
('53', 414, 3, 9, 813341) But here is no starvation or semi starvation.
('53', 414, 3, 10, 813387) In India we have both.
('53', 414, 3, 11, 813410) If you went to the villages of India, you would find utter despair in the eyes of the villages, you would find half starved skeletons, living corpses.
('53', 414, 3, 12, 813561) If India could revive them by putting life and food into them in the shape of work India would help the world.
('53', 414, 3, 13, 813672) Today India is a curse.
('53', 414, 3, 14, 813696) There is a party in my country which would sooner see an end to the lives of these half starved millions in order that the rest may live.
('53', 414, 3, 15, 813834) I thought of a humane method and that was to give them work with which they were familiar, which they could do in their cottages, which required no great investment in implements and of which the product could be easily sold.
('53', 414, 3, 16, 814060) This is a task which is worthy of the attention even of Lancashire.

('53', 415, 2, 5, 815107) 456. PARSIS’ PROTEST About one hundred and seventy five Parsis were signatories to the note of protest expressing profound disapproval of the indignities prepetrated upon Shri Abidali and other Congress picketers on the 10th of August last.
('53', 415, 2, 6, 815348) Among the signatories are barristers, doctors, solicitors and professors also.
('53', 415, 2, 7, 815427) I compliment the signatories on making this protest.
('53', 415, 2, 8, 815480) But at the same time, I should make it clear that this protest will have hardly any effect upon those who had a hand in staging these disturbances.
('53', 415, 2, 9, 815628) The real need is to come into personal contact with those liquor dealers, to formulate a scheme to find some other respectable profession for them and to develop a strong public opinion among the Parsis against this present trade of theirs.
('53', 415, 2, 10, 815869) The argument put forward by these liquor dealers is that, they give up their trade, someone else will take it up.
('53', 415, 2, 11, 815983) What I have suggested to them is that, as a result of their giving up their trade, public opinion will be generated even outside the Parsi community, that it will become impossible even for others to take to that immoral trade.
('53', 415, 2, 12, 816211) In Navajivan, 1 I have already cited the example of the Bhandaris of Ratnagiri district.
('53', 415, 2, 13, 816300) By giving up their hereditary profession of selling liquor, they set out on the war path.
('53', 415, 2, 14, 816390) Many Kolis have done likewise.
('53', 415, 2, 15, 816421) Hence, if the Parsis also adopt this reform , even though they may not be regarded as pioneers they would have emulated a worthy example and they would also have contributed their share to the national welfare work of uprooting a trade which is doing such irreparable harm to labourers.
('53', 415, 2, 16, 816708) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 27 9 1931
('53', 415, 3, 17, 816745) 1 Perhaps a slip for Young India.
('53', 415, 3, 18, 816779) The reference is presumably to the article “Prohibition Work at Malvan” published in Young India, 30 7 1931 which had described the Bhandaris’ abandoning of their traditional profession of toddy tapping under the Civil Disobedience movement.

('53', 416, 6, 11, 817582) 458. SPEECH AT ADULT SCHOOL 1
('53', 416, 7, 12, 817612) WEST BRADFORD, September 27, 1931
('53', 416, 8, 13, 817646) Mr. Gandhi began by accepting the Lancashire view that a part of the country’s unemployment was caused by action taken by him in India.
('53', 416, 8, 14, 817782) He admitted that a great many of the politically minded in India took up the boycott in a spirit of revenge, and found pleasure in hitting England by it.
('53', 416, 8, 15, 817936) It was not a matter of pleasure to him, and his arrest took the campaign in a rather different direction from what it might have done.
('53', 416, 8, 16, 818071) Had the Government understood the strength behind his letter to Lord Irwin 2 laying down the famous eleven points, history might have been written differently.
('53', 416, 8, 17, 818231) When he was arrested, the boycott became a universal cry.
('53', 416, 8, 18, 818289) His own plan, Mr. Gandhi explained, would have been a boycott of foreign cloth, but the people took the law into their own hands, made the boycott one of British goods, and continued to buy Japanese cloth, American typewriters, and so on.
('53', 416, 9, 19, 818528) 1 The meeting was held in the morning at Heys Farm Guest House where the school was conducted and where Gandhiji stayed the night.
('53', 416, 9, 20, 818659) 2 Of March 2, 1930 The eleven points themselves, however, were mentioned in an article in the Young India January 30,1931; vide “Clearing the Issue”, 30 1 1930
('53', 417, 0, 1, 818819) 418 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('53', 417, 1, 2, 818861) When he was released in March 1
('53', 417, 2, 3, 818893) <image: None, width: 3, height: 12, bpc: 1>
('53', 417, 3, 4, 818937) the boycott of British goods stopped, but that of foreign goods remained at his instance.
('53', 417, 3, 5, 819027) Mr. Gandhi spoke of his negotiations with Lord Irwin on the boycotts of liquor and intoxicating drugs and foreign cloth, of Lord Irwin’s anxiety to get the boycott on British cloth lifted, of the arguments used against this, and of Lord Irwin’s final agreement that he would not endanger a settlement by insisting on the removal of the boycotts, which still remain.
('53', 417, 3, 6, 819393) As in his other statements, Mr. Gandhi compared the 3,000,000 British unemployed with India’s 300,000,000. He spoke of doles as taking away self respect, and described how, in conducting strikes in India, he had set his face against doles, and encouraged the strikers to find other employment at much less wages rather than be idle.
('53', 417, 3, 7, 819726) He spoke of some strikers who had been taught to weave and make themselves independent.
('53', 417, 4, 8, 819814) Mr. Gandhi then went on to state his view that Indian poverty is the result of British policy through the overthrowing of India’s old cotton industry by the machines of Lancashire more than a hundred years ago.
('53', 417, 4, 9, 820025) He argued that the descendants of those who destryoed the supplementary means of livelihood (which supplied the butter to the bread which the peasant earned from the soil) could not now complain if the descendants of the dispossessed tried to rehabilitate themselves.
('53', 417, 5, 10, 820293) He declared that it was an impossibility to seek to revive the Lancashire trade on its original foundations, and he could not lend a hand to the process.
('53', 417, 5, 11, 820447) Equally he would not lift a finger to sustain the Indian mills.
('53', 417, 5, 12, 820511) He might some time have to seek their destruction, but at present they did not interfere with the employment of the villagers, and he was tolerating them.
('53', 417, 5, 13, 820666) He did not say to the villagers that they must buy indigenous mill cloth; what he said to them was that they must not buy foreign cloth and that they must make their own cloth.
('53', 417, 6, 14, 820843) Mr. Gandhi described the conditions of the villagers, saying that 7s.
('53', 417, 6, 15, 820913) was their average monthly income; the addition of 3s.
('53', 417, 6, 16, 820967) would add a fortune, and those who had taken up the spinning wheel were free from debt.
('53', 417, 6, 17, 821055) He drew an idyllic picture of little children spinning while they were playing, and contrasted the life of the villagers who lived on a little bit of rice flung by insolent wealth with their position when the glorious work was done in their own homes.
('53', 417, 6, 18, 821307) The only solace he could bring to Lancashire was that these teeming millions had no ill will to Lancashire, and did not know what Lancashire was.
('53', 417, 6, 19, 821453) They had no clothing, but a little bit of rag.
('53', 417, 7, 20, 821500) This led Mr. Gandhi to explain his own choice of costume: he wished to appear as faithfully as could be as the representative of the teeming and naked millions.
('53', 417, 7, 21, 821661) Even, he said, if he had to appear before the King hewould be discourteous if he did
('53', 417, 8, 22, 821746) 1 Gandhiji was released in January; the boycott of British goods was stopped as a result of the Gandhi Irwin agreement .
('53', 417, 8, 23, 821867) Vide “Provisional Settlement’12 3 1931
('53', 418, 0, 1, 821906) VOL. 53 : 2 JULY, 1931 12 OCTOBER, 1931 419
('53', 418, 1, 2, 821950) not appear in his loin cloth.
('53', 418, 1, 3, 821980) He would consider himself indecent if he took a yard of cloth beyond the physical requirements of the teeming millions, whom he described as having but one meal, not knowing milk, and as sometimes being driven in the summer months to live on grass.
('53', 418, 1, 4, 822229) These millions were knocking at our doors, and, in closing, Mr. Gandhi urged that England must not build her happiness on the tombs of millions, as she had done, he feared.
('53', 418, 2, 5, 822402) In the discussion Mr. Gandhi repeated his argument that the boycott may have been the last straw, but was only a contributory factor in Lancashire’s loss of trade.
('53', 418, 2, 6, 822566) He noted the other world causes of Lancashire’s decline.
('53', 418, 2, 7, 822623) He also repeated his suggestion that, assuming that there is a fair settlement with Great Britain, it is possible to have a contract with Lancashire on behalf of the Government for taking, on a decreasing scale from year to year, goods from Lancashire.
('53', 418, 2, 8, 822876) This, he admitted, would simply tide over Lancashire’s difficulty for a little time and no more.
('53', 418, 3, 9, 822973) Mr. Gandhi contested a suggestion that his policy is a dangerous form of nationalism.
('53', 418, 3, 10, 823059) He gave the impression of desiring an India self sufficing in food and clothing, but open to receive other kinds of goods from abroad.
('53', 418, 3, 11, 823194) He left his hearers with some final words about Japanese business methods, and urged that it would be better for Lancashire to divert her attention from India and solve her problems in terms of the world crisis, in which the Indian contribution was only a speck on the screen.
('53', 418, 3, 12, 823471) The Clitheroe Advertiser and Times, 2 10 1931
('53', 418, 4, 13, 823517) 459. INTERVIEW TO UNEMPLOYED WORKERS’ DEPUTATION 1
('53', 418, 5, 14, 823568) WEST BRADFORD, September 27, 1931 I would be untrue to you, I would be a false friend if I were not frank with you.
('53', 418, 5, 15, 823684) I strove with Lord Irwin last March for the liberty to boycott liquor and foreign cloth.
('53', 418, 5, 16, 823773) He suggested that I might give up the boycott for three months as a gesture and then resume it.
('53', 418, 5, 17, 823869) I said I could not give it up for three minutes.
('53', 418, 5, 18, 823918) You have three million unemployed, but we have nearly three hundred million unemployed for half the year.
('53', 418, 5, 19, 824024) Your average unemployment dole is 70 shillings.
('53', 418, 5, 20, 824072) Our average income is 7 shillings and six pence a month.
('53', 418, 5, 21, 824129) That operative was right in saying that he was falling in his own estimation.
('53', 418, 5, 22, 824207) I do believe it is a debasing thing for a human being to remain idle and to live on doles.
('53', 418, 5, 23, 824298) Whilst conducting a strike, I would not brook the
('53', 418, 6, 24, 824348) 1 Extracted from Mahadev Desai’s report, “Gandhiji in Lancashire”
('53', 419, 0, 1, 824414) 420 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('53', 419, 1, 2, 824456) strikers remaining idle for a single day and got them to break the stones or carry sand and work in public streets asking my own co workers to join them in that work.
('53', 419, 1, 3, 824623) Imagine, therefore, what a calamity it must be to have 300 million unemployed, several millions becoming degraded every day for want of employment, devoid of self respect, devoid of faith in God .
('53', 419, 1, 4, 824820) I dare not take before them the message of God.
('53', 419, 1, 5, 824868) I may as well place before the dog over there the message of God as before those hungry millions who have no lustre in their eyes and whose only God is their bread.
('53', 419, 1, 6, 825033) I can take before them a message of God only by taking the message of sacred work before them.
('53', 419, 1, 7, 825128) It is good enough to talk of God whilst we are sitting here after a nice breakfast and looking forward to a nicer luncheon, but how am I to talk of God to the millions who have to go without two meals a day?
('53', 419, 1, 8, 825336) To them God can only appear as bread and butter.
('53', 419, 1, 9, 825385) Well, the peasants of India were getting their bread from their soil.
('53', 419, 1, 10, 825455) I offered them the spinning wheel in order that they may get butter, and if I appear today before the British public in my loin cloth, it is because I have come as the sole representative of those half starved, half naked dumb millions.
('53', 419, 1, 11, 825692) We have prayed that we may bask in the presence of God’s sunshine.
('53', 419, 1, 12, 825759) I tell you it is impossible to do so whilst millions are knocking at your door.
('53', 419, 1, 13, 825839) Even in your misery you are comparatively happy.
('53', 419, 1, 14, 825888) I do not grudge you that happiness.
('53', 419, 1, 15, 825924) I wish well to you, but do not think of prospering on the tombs of the poor millions of India.
('53', 419, 1, 16, 826019) I do not want for India an isolated life at all, but I do not want to depend on any country for my food and clothing.
('53', 419, 1, 17, 826137) Whilst we may devise means for tiding over the present crisis, I must tell you that you should cherish no hope of reviving the old Lancashire trade.
('53', 419, 1, 18, 826286) It is impossible.
('53', 419, 1, 19, 826304) I cannot religiously help in the process.
('53', 419, 1, 20, 826346) 1 Supposing, I have suddenly stopped breathing and I am helped by artificial respiration for a while and begin to breathe again, must I, for ever, depend on artificial respiration and refuse to use my own lungs again ?
('53', 419, 1, 21, 826565) No, it would be suicidal.
('53', 419, 1, 22, 826591) I must try to strengthen my own lungs and live on my own resources.
('53', 419, 1, 23, 826659) You must pray to God that India may strengthen her lungs.
('53', 419, 1, 24, 826717) Do not attribute your misery to India.
('53', 419, 1, 25, 826756) Think of the world forces that are powerfully working against you.
('53', 419, 1, 26, 826823) See things in the daylight of reason.

('53', 420, 1, 2, 826957) 460. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS 1
('53', 420, 2, 3, 826987) WEST BRADFORD, September 27, 1931 I have certainly been very happy here and have experienced nothing but the greatest affection and kindness.
('53', 420, 2, 4, 827129) I have seen various groups of operatives and employers, with whom I have had very friendly discussion.
('53', 420, 2, 5, 827232) I feel that I have learned something of the distress in Lancashire, and my heart has gone out to the suffering operatives.
('53', 420, 2, 6, 827355) I saw Mr. Davies’s mill and the whole shed in which the looms are lying idle.
('53', 420, 2, 7, 827433) I have explained to him my personal and that of the Congress.
('53', 420, 2, 8, 827495) I have shown to him the limited extent to which help from India is possible in the event of a permanent settlement coming through.
('53', 420, 2, 9, 827626) But I am also oppressed with the fact that unemployment is so widespread that the help that can possibly come from India will affect but a small class.
('53', 420, 2, 10, 827778) It has appeared to me that the cause of distress in Lancashire is more largely due to world causes than to the Indian boycott.
('53', 420, 2, 11, 827905) Even before the Indian boycott came in its intense form last year, Lancashire’s trade with India was not much over 15 per cent of the total production.
('53', 420, 2, 12, 828057) I do not think it has been adversely affected by the boycott to more than 3 per cent, or it may be a little over.
('53', 420, 2, 13, 828171) The question, therefore, so far as India is concerned, is limited to a very small compass.
('53', 420, 2, 14, 828262) It would be presumptuous for me to say what can be otherwise done in order to alleviate or entirely remove the present distress in Lancashire.
('53', 420, 2, 15, 828405) And so far as India is concerned, I have already given you an idea of what is at the most possible.
('53', 420, 2, 16, 828505) But whether something ultimately does or does not result, the two days of intimate contact with the employers and employed has shown me that the people of Lancashire have borne their distress very bravely, and it has been a matter of the keenest satisfaction to me that they have not shown any bitterness towards India, which I regard as a happy sign.
('53', 420, 2, 17, 828857) I had never expected anything but courteous treatment from the working people of Lancashire, but I was quite unprepared for the manifestation of deep affection that the crowds of people lining the
('53', 420, 3, 18, 829054) 1 According to the source, Gandhiji received the party of Press reporters at noon.
('53', 421, 0, 1, 829137) 422 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('53', 421, 1, 2, 829179) streets yesterday spontaneously showed to me.
('53', 421, 1, 3, 829225) I shall ever treasure that affection as one of the pleasant recollections of my life.
('53', 421, 1, 4, 829311) That is all.
('53', 421, 2, 5, 829324) Asked if he was in a position to confirm a statement attributed to him that if India secured self government, he would be agreeable to the prohibition of foreign imported cloths, with the exception of Lancashire goods, Mr. Gandhi said : I would agree to the prohibition of all foreign cloths but Lancashire cloths, to the extent that foreign cloth was still necessary to supplement the Indian supply.
('53', 421, 2, 6, 829725) Necessarily, there would have to be conditions about the standard of quality and of price, which, however, could be mutually arranged.
('53', 421, 3, 7, 829860) Asked if India’s policy of manufacturing her own cotton goods would not affect her own exports of raw products, Mr.Gandhi said India would be buying from the other nations of the earth, or from England, under a favoured nation clause, many things besides cotton piece goods.
('53', 421, 3, 8, 830135) He said : India is not, and will not be for a long time to come, entirely self contained for all her wants.
('53', 421, 3, 9, 830243) For instance, India is at present importing large quantities of hardware, sugar, etc.
('53', 421, 4, 10, 830329) Q. Do you agree that a decline in imported goods would result in a corresponding decrease in the demand for Indian raw cotton?
('53', 421, 5, 11, 830456) A. Cotton is not such a special crop that once grown it must always be grown.
('53', 421, 5, 12, 830534) The cultivator would immediately respond to changed conditions and grow other crops which are favourable.
('53', 421, 6, 13, 830640) Asked if he would specifically exclude Japanese cotton goods, Mr. Gandhi said : I would put a prohibitive tariff upon Japanese piece goods, also other piece goods, and any other foreign goods.
('53', 421, 6, 14, 830833) It would not be a question of discriminating against Japan.
('53', 421, 6, 15, 830893) I have no complaint to make against her.
('53', 421, 6, 16, 830934) I would simply take my goods from my partner.
('53', 421, 6, 17, 830980) Japan or any other nation could not complain if I did not take their goods because I was manufacturing those goods myself, nor need they complain if I take them from my partner.
('53', 421, 7, 18, 831158) Q. All that depends on self government?
('53', 421, 8, 19, 831198) A. Yes, it must be absolutely a free will and voluntary thing.
('53', 421, 8, 20, 831261) I would not be conferring a benefit on Lancashire at the expense of India.
('53', 421, 8, 21, 831336) If I do need more foreign cloth, it would be foolish on my part not to take it from England, if England is my partner.
('53', 421, 9, 22, 831455) Q. Supposing these negotiations break down?
('53', 422, 0, 1, 831499) VOL. 53 : 2 JULY, 1931 12 OCTOBER, 1931 423
('53', 422, 1, 2, 831543) A. Then heaven help India!
('53', 422, 1, 3, 831570) India must then go through the fire of suffering.
('53', 422, 1, 4, 831620) There is no question of India finding her peace unless India finds also her freedom.
('53', 422, 1, 5, 831705) That is a settled fact.
('53', 422, 2, 6, 831729) Asked if he was hopeful, Mr. Gandhi said : It is in the hands of God .
('53', 422, 2, 7, 831800) It is very difficult to say.
('53', 422, 3, 8, 831829) Q. Do you feel the prospects of a settlement are endangered by the political situation in England at the moment ?
('53', 422, 3, 9, 831943) A. The prospects will be, or may be, endangered if British statesmen come to the conclusion that the settlement with India is not necessary in order to solve the present porblem.
('53', 422, 3, 10, 832122) If they feel it can be shunted—then there is danger.
('53', 422, 3, 11, 832175) But if they feel that India is a factor in dealing with the domestic problem—then, of course, the Indian question retains the same importance, if it does not gain greater importance because of this domestic problem.
('53', 422, 4, 12, 832391) In response to an inquiry whether, if there is a General Election, he will wait until it finishes, Mr. Gandhi said : I do not want to wait indefinitely here.
('53', 422, 4, 13, 832549) It would be inconvenient for me to wait here marking time.
('53', 422, 4, 14, 832608) If dissolution comes next week, my attitude would be determined by the attitude of the British Ministers as to what they want to do.
('53', 422, 4, 15, 832741) If they want to mark time, to postpone the proceedings of the Conference, or to postpone effective decisions, I certainly would want to go away.
('53', 422, 4, 16, 832886) Whether I returned for a resumption of the Conference depends on the situation that faces me at that time.
('53', 422, 4, 17, 832993) I have certainly not calculated upon any postponement of the Conference, but I had calculated upon a final conclusion being reached.
('53', 422, 5, 18, 833126) Q. Do you think there has been progress or retrogression?
('53', 422, 5, 19, 833184) A. I don’t think there has been any progress or retrogression.
('53', 422, 6, 20, 833247) Q. Do you look for progress?
('53', 422, 6, 21, 833276) A. That is a ticklish problem.
('53', 422, 7, 22, 833307) Q. Has Congress reached any conclusion?
('53', 422, 7, 23, 833347) A. Not any positive conclusion.
('53', 422, 7, 24, 833379) It is difficult.
('53', 422, 8, 25, 833396) Q. Have you acquainted British Ministers with your plans in the event of a General Election being held?
('53', 422, 8, 26, 833500) A. I have no plans.
('53', 422, 8, 27, 833520) I do not know what my plans will be.
('53', 422, 9, 28, 833557) In reply to a question respecting currency, Mr. Gandhi said he did not regard himself as an expert.
('53', 422, 9, 29, 833657) The Clitheroe Advertiser and Times, 2 10 1931
('53', 423, 0, 1, 833703) 424 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('53', 423, 1, 2, 833745) 461. INTERVIEW TO DEPUTATION 1
('53', 423, 2, 3, 833776) WEST BRADFORD, September 27, 1931
('53', 423, 3, 4, 833810) Mr. Gandhi said he had no ill will either against Lancashire or England, and though he might claim to be author of the boycott, the movement was not started in any spirit of bitterness whatever.
('53', 423, 3, 5, 834005) He declared that the boycott was largely a policy of economy.
('53', 423, 3, 6, 834067) His idea was not so much to boycott foreign cloth as to persuade the Indians to stop using machine made cloth of any description.
('53', 423, 3, 7, 834197) While recognizing that that was practically impossible of achievement, he wished to wean them as far as possible from buying machine made cloth.
('53', 423, 3, 8, 834342) Mr. Gandhi pointed out that, owing to the situation in India, for six months in the year the peasant was absolutely without work, for it was not possible to work on the land.
('53', 423, 3, 9, 834517) Therefore, during that six months the peasant was on the verge of starvation.
('53', 423, 3, 10, 834595) His idea was to occupy the interim period with weaving whereby the peasants could earn a little money.
('53', 423, 3, 11, 834698) Thousands of Indians were therefore reverting to the spinning wheel, and within the last year or so there were more than 100,000 peasants spinining or weaving cloth
('53', 423, 4, 12, 834863) The Mahatama declared that politics had no charms for him.
('53', 423, 4, 13, 834922) The only thing he had at heart was the moral welfare of his own class.
('53', 423, 4, 14, 834993) From his own observations since coming to the country, he had realized that Lancashire was certainly suffering from the great trade depression.
('53', 423, 4, 15, 835137) He wanted the people of Lancashire to understand that there were such things as comparisons in poverty, and that we were a long way above the poverty line prevalent in India.
('53', 423, 4, 16, 835312) He started that the income of all the people of India, including the millionaires, averaged at 7s 6d per month per Indian.
('53', 423, 4, 17, 835435) From that it would be recognized how poor the poorest of the poor must be.
('53', 423, 5, 18, 835510) Mr. Brame asked if nothing could be done to alleviate both the suffering in Lancashire and in India.
('53', 423, 6, 19, 835611) Mr. Gandhi said if he could obtain satisfaction at the Round Table Conference, he would promise to do all he could to stop the import of cloth from Japan and Italy into India, and would allow Lancashire to have the first opportunity of providing the Indians with the deficiency between what they supplied themselves and the demand.
('53', 423, 6, 20, 835943) He did not wish them to overlook the fact that Lancashire’s trade with India must ever be a depreciating one.
('53', 423, 6, 21, 836053) The Clitheroe Advertiser and Times, 2 10 1931
('53', 423, 7, 22, 836099) 1 Gandhiji received the deputation from the Clitheroe Weavers’ Association in the afternoon.
('53', 423, 7, 23, 836192) The deputation was led by H.L. Parkinson, the President, and G. Brame, the Secretary and included our unemployed weavers.
('53', 424, 0, 1, 836314) VOL. 53 : 2 JULY, 1931 12 OCTOBER, 1931 425
('53', 424, 1, 2, 836358) 462. MYSELF, MY SPINNING WHEEL AND WOMEN 1
('53', 424, 2, 3, 836401) What am I here for?
('53', 424, 2, 4, 836421) What do I believe in?
('53', 424, 2, 5, 836443) What is the India I would build?
('53', 424, 2, 6, 836476) Well, before all else, I am here to uphold the truth as I see it, for I believe it is the keystone of life.
('53', 424, 2, 7, 836584) On it everything else depends.
('53', 424, 2, 8, 836615) It comes first and last and always.
('53', 424, 2, 9, 836651) And in all things it is possible to put Truth first.
('53', 424, 2, 10, 836704) For myself I have always tried to do it.
('53', 424, 2, 11, 836745) In my political ambitions I eschew all lies and fraud.
('53', 424, 2, 12, 836800) For the attainment of no object would I subscribe to deceit.
('53', 424, 2, 13, 836861) I have read many varying descriptions of myself.
('53', 424, 2, 14, 836910) Some call me a saint.
('53', 424, 2, 15, 836932) Others call me a rouge.
('53', 424, 2, 16, 836956) I am neither the one nor the other.
('53', 424, 2, 17, 836992) All that I aspire to be— and I hope I have in some measure succeeded in being—is an honest, godfearing man.
('53', 424, 2, 18, 837100) But the things I read about myself do not annoy me.
('53', 424, 2, 19, 837152) Why should they?
('53', 424, 2, 20, 837169) I have my own philosophy and my work.
('53', 424, 2, 21, 837207) Everyday I spin for a time.
('53', 424, 2, 22, 837235) While I spin I think.
('53', 424, 2, 23, 837257) I think of many things.
('53', 424, 2, 24, 837281) But always from those thoughts I try to keep out bitterness.
('53', 424, 2, 25, 837342) Study this spinning wheel of mine.
('53', 424, 2, 26, 837377) It would teach you a great deal more than I can—patience, industry, simplicity.
('53', 424, 2, 27, 837457) This spinning wheel is for India’s starving millions the symbol of salvation.
('53', 424, 3, 28, 837535) MY LOIN CLOTH My dress, which is described in the newspapers as a loin cloth, is criticized, made fun of.
('53', 424, 3, 29, 837641) I am asked why I wear it.
('53', 424, 3, 30, 837667) Some seem to resent my wearing it.
('53', 424, 3, 31, 837702) When Englishmen visit India, do they forsake their European clothing and adopt our Eastern dress, which is much more suitable to the climate?
('53', 424, 3, 32, 837844) And there is the answer to those who ask why in England I wear the dress to which I am accustomed, the dress of India.
('53', 424, 3, 33, 837963) If I came here to live and work as an English citizen, then I should conform to the customs of the country and should wear the dress of an Englishman.
('53', 424, 3, 34, 838114) But I am here on a great and special mission, and my loin cloth, if you choose so to describe it, is the dress of my principals, the people of India.
('53', 424, 3, 35, 838264) Into my keeping a sacred trust has
('53', 424, 4, 36, 838299) 1 The title supplied by The Daily Herald for which Gandhiji wrote this exclusive article.
('53', 425, 0, 1, 838389) 426 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('53', 425, 1, 2, 838431) been put.
('53', 425, 1, 3, 838441) A special duty has been given me to perform.
('53', 425, 1, 4, 838486) I must, therefore, wear the symbol of my mission.
('53', 425, 1, 5, 838536) I find these different descriptions of me interesting sometimes amusing but I am just a representative of my people, endeavouring to fulfil the task they have entrusted to me.
('53', 425, 1, 6, 838712) Yes, I believe in complete equality for women and, in the India I seek to build, they would have it.
('53', 425, 1, 7, 838813) The reason I have so many women co workers is, I believe, due to my adoption of celibacy and my instinctive sympathy for women.
('53', 425, 1, 8, 838941) You have probably heard that in my country women occupy a subordinante position.
('53', 425, 1, 9, 839022) This is only so outwardly.
('53', 425, 1, 10, 839049) Actually, their influence has ever been of the strongest.
('53', 425, 1, 11, 839107) For centuries women have worked on an equal footing with men .
('53', 425, 1, 12, 839170) If they ceased work, then many of the men would starve.
('53', 425, 1, 13, 839226) PLAYTHINGS In the cultivation of the crops our men and women toil together.
('53', 425, 1, 14, 839302) Their life is a strenuous one.
('53', 425, 1, 15, 839333) It is in the leisured classes that the difference is more marked.
('53', 425, 1, 16, 839399) Wealth has enabled women to forget and set aside the virtue of usefulness.
('53', 425, 1, 17, 839474) Thus there is a tendency for wealthy women to become mere ornaments playthings.
('53', 425, 1, 18, 839554) What I want to see is the opening of all offices, professions and employments to women; otherwise there can be no real equality.
('53', 425, 1, 19, 839683) But I most sincerely hope that woman will retain and exercise her ancient prerogative as queen of the household.
('53', 425, 1, 20, 839796) From this position she must never be dethroned.
('53', 425, 1, 21, 839844) It would indeed be a dreary home of which a woman was not the centre.
('53', 425, 1, 22, 839914) I cannot, for instance, imagine a really happy home in which the wife is a typist and scarcely ever in it.
('53', 425, 1, 23, 840021) Who would look after the children?
('53', 425, 1, 24, 840056) What, after all, is a home without children, the brightest jewels in the poorest household?
('53', 425, 1, 25, 840148) FAMILY FIRST Cases might be cited in which a clever woman might, by going out into the world to earn her living, make more money and do more for the children, paying someone to look after them.
('53', 425, 1, 26, 840342) Exceptional women make necessarily exceptional cases.
('53', 425, 1, 27, 840396) There are exceptions in every phase of life.
('53', 425, 1, 28, 840441) but we cannot generalize from exceptions.
('53', 425, 1, 29, 840483) Generally, it is the father who should be the bread winner.
('53', 425, 1, 30, 840543) He will work all the better, knowing that he has a happy home.
('53', 425, 1, 31, 840606) And it is aserious injustice to deprive a child of the tender care which only a mother can give.
('53', 426, 0, 1, 840703) VOL. 53 : 2 JULY, 1931 12 OCTOBER, 1931 427
('53', 426, 1, 2, 840747) It is a woman’s work to bring up her little ones and mould their character.
('53', 426, 1, 3, 840823) A precious work, too.
('53', 426, 1, 4, 840845) Equality in status with men, I desire for women, but if the mother fails in her sacred trust towards her children, then nothing can atone for the loss.
('53', 426, 1, 5, 840997) Whatever the race, family life is the first and greatest thing.
('53', 426, 1, 6, 841061) Its sanctity must remain.
('53', 426, 1, 7, 841087) Upon it rests the welfare of the nation.
('53', 426, 1, 8, 841128) For good or for ill home influence persists.
('53', 426, 1, 9, 841173) Of that there can be no possible doubt, and no State can survive unless the sacred security of its home life is preserved.
('53', 426, 1, 10, 841296) Individuals there may be who in pursuit of some great principle or ideal, forgo, like myself, the solace of family life, choosing instead one of self sacrifice and celibacy; but for the mass of the people the preservation of home life is essential.

('53', 433, 1, 3, 850749) G. HAINES
('53', 433, 2, 4, 850759) 88 KNIGHTSBRIDGE, LONDON, W., September 29, 1931

('53', 441, 1, 2, 862440) 487. INTERVIEW WITH RAMSAY MACDONAND 1
('53', 441, 2, 3, 862479) LONDON, September 30, 1931
('53', 441, 3, 4, 862506) Gandhi showed no sign of any intention to break up the Conference.
('53', 441, 3, 5, 862573) What he complained of was that the Conference was futile because the other delegates were only the nominees of Government and he was the sole genuine representative of the people.
('53', 441, 3, 6, 862753) He thought that he could represent the Muslims and the Depressed Classes better than those who purported to do so.
('53', 441, 3, 7, 862868) He and the British Government could settle the whole question if he was treated as representing everybody.
('53', 441, 3, 8, 862975) The Prime Minister said that the Conference had at any rate been successful in so far as it had got Gandhi to come to London and brought him into touch with the Government; and he countered by telling Gandhi that the civil disobedience movement was a mistake and only hindered the British Government from carrying out their intentions towards India.
('53', 441, 4, 9, 863325) From a photostat: C.W. 9381. Courtesy: India Office Library.
('53', 441, 5, 10, 863386) 488. SPEECH AT INDIAN CHAMBER OF COMMERCE 2
('53', 441, 6, 11, 863430) LONDON, September 30, 1931
('53', 441, 7, 12, 863457) Gandhiji said he was well aware of the sacrifices made by the merchants of India in national interests, but, much as they had done, still more was expected by the nation.
('53', 441, 7, 13, 863628) Paying a tribute to Dadabhoy Naoroji and Sir Pherozeshah Mehta, Gandhiji said those great leaders recognized that, unless the merchant princes in India identified themselves with the Congress activities, progress towards freedom would be delayed.
('53', 441, 8, 14, 863875) Gandhiji proceeded to criticize the financial manipulation undertaken by the Government of India at the dictation of the Secretary of State over the heads of those who knew what India wanted and said: I share your fear that, at this time, when we are led to ex pect a transfer of power to ourselves, there does not after all appear to be much of a change at the headquarters.
('53', 441, 8, 15, 864251) I am afraid power is not going to descend on us suddenly, but if really great changes are

('53', 442, 1, 3, 864654) The Congress came deliberately to the conclusion that, without absolute control of the finances, no self governmemt could possibly meet the nation’s needs.
('53', 442, 1, 4, 864810) Part of the mandate given me was that Independence was meaningless unless accompanied by complete control of defence, external affairs and finance.
('53', 442, 1, 5, 864958) I cannot conceive of any government, which can be called responsible, which does not exercise those rights.
('53', 442, 2, 6, 865066) He assured British firms trading in India that, where their interests were legitimately and justly acquired and not conflicting with the vital interests of the masses, they need have no fear from the National Government.
('53', 442, 2, 7, 865287) No safeguard can possibly equal India’s goodwill.

('53', 444, 7, 13, 868911) 492. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('53', 444, 8, 14, 868939) LONDON, October 1, 1931 At this distance it is difficult to understand the implications of the budget, but I am horrified that the poor man’s salt has also come in for increased taxation.
('53', 444, 8, 15, 869127) I know, the Congress will fight this also.
('53', 444, 8, 16, 869170) The remedy for balancing the budget does not lie through increased taxation, but through radical retrenchment in both military and civil expenditure.
('53', 444, 8, 17, 869320) I tender congratulations to H.E. the Viceroy for having voluntarily accepted a cut in his salary, but I cannot escape the feeling that reduction must be on a grand scale if India is to share in real self government.

('53', 445, 0, 1, 869730) 446 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('53', 445, 1, 2, 869772) 493. ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS 1
('53', 445, 2, 3, 869800) LONDON, October 1, 1931
('53', 445, 3, 4, 869824) Mr. Gandhi said that the money would be devoted to the constructive work of the Congress.
('53', 445, 3, 5, 869914) Millions of Indians were so sunk in poverty that it was almost impossible to inspire them with any hope of earning their own livelihood and the task of the Congress was formidable.
('53', 445, 3, 6, 870095) If he could persuade the people to become self sufficient in respect of the second necessity of life, namely, clothing, they would have a real swaraj.
('53', 445, 4, 7, 870246) (1) Complete Independence is the present objective of the Congress.

('53', 450, 4, 6, 881241) 496. INTERVIEW TO “THE JEWISH CHRONICLE”
('53', 450, 5, 7, 881282) LONDON, [Before October 2, 1931] I have a world of friends among the jews.
('53', 450, 5, 8, 881357) In South Africa I was surrounded by Jews, and I have had a Jewish shorthand writer and typist who was regarded more as a member of the family.
('53', 450, 5, 9, 881500) I cannot, however, say that I have made a proper study of the Jewish religion, but I have studied as much as a layman can.
('53', 450, 5, 10, 881623) I think the Jewish religion is a very fine religion, being so closely allied to Christianity in many respects.
('53', 450, 5, 11, 881734) For example, the Prophets of the old Testament are all Jews, and Jesus himself was a Jew.
('53', 450, 5, 12, 881824) I visited the Synagogue at Johannesburg during the Festival of the Passover, and you can almost say I was keeping the Passover with my Jewish friends, because I went to their house every night and I heartily enjoyed, what do you call them now?
('53', 450, 6, 13, 882068) “Matzos”, interjected our representative.
('53', 450, 6, 14, 882110) Yes, matzos, I think matzos are very nice and crisp.
('53', 450, 6, 15, 882163) I have,however, attended two or three Jewish services, which I think are very impressive; but my own feeling is that “the heart was lacking”.
('53', 450, 6, 16, 882305) That is to say, the spirit was lacking.
('53', 450, 6, 17, 882345) They were too ceremonial, although I must say the ceremony was very nice.
('53', 450, 6, 18, 882419) The Jewish Rabbi was a celebrated scholar, and he delivered a learned discourse, but it did not touch my herart .
('53', 450, 6, 19, 882533) My attitude towards Jews is one of great sympathy.
('53', 450, 6, 20, 882584) I am very much attracted to the Jews, firstly, because of selfish motives, since I have very many Jewish friends; secondly,for a far deeper one—they

('53', 452, 1, 2, 885141) 497. INTERVIEW TO HENRY CARTER
('53', 452, 2, 3, 885172) LONDON, [October 2, 1931] 1
('53', 452, 3, 4, 885200) The drink question in India is most urgent.
('53', 452, 3, 5, 885244) The religious teachings of both Hindus and Mohammedans require abstinence from alcoholic liquors.
('53', 452, 3, 6, 885342) The future all India Legislature would certainly regard it as ess ential to prohibit the importation, manufacture, or sale of all alcoholic beverages, subject to an exemption which would permit the supply of alcohol for medicinal, scientific, and industrial uses.
('53', 452, 3, 7, 885606) The supply for medicinal purposes would be dependent on a medical prescription.
('53', 452, 3, 8, 885686) Prohibition must apply equally to distillation in India and to imports of liquor from overseas.
('53', 452, 4, 9, 885782) I asked Mr. Gandhi how he would propose to deal with the question of the substantial revenue which Government in India derives from liquor taxation.
('53', 452, 4, 10, 885931) He replied that this revenue should be replaced “by a corresponding cut in the Indian military budget.”
('53', 452, 5, 11, 886035) We discussed different methods of approach to a solution of the Indian liquor problem.
('53', 452, 5, 12, 886122) I pointed out that in England we stressed the importance of scientific teaching in the schools as to the nature of alcohol and the effect of alcoholic indulgence.
('53', 452, 5, 13, 886285) Mr. Gandhi said that to a limited extent instruction on the subject was given in Indian schools, but he was disposed to rely on the religious sentiment of the country as sufficient to maintain the national protest against the use of drink.
('53', 452, 5, 14, 886525) He regarded the increase of drinking in India as closely associated with industrialization, and stressed the fact that depressing industrial conditions favour the prevalence of alcoholism.
('53', 452, 6, 15, 886714) Local option and national prohibition seem to him to differ in this way : In a country like Britain, where the liquor habit is rooted in history, and where probably the majority of people are users of liquor, local option might be applicable .
('53', 452, 6, 16, 886958) But India needs no intermediate policy; she is ready or the enactment of complete national prohibition.
('53', 452, 6, 17, 887062) The sentiment of the country would unquestionably sustain it.
('53', 452, 7, 18, 887124) With regard to the opium habit, he pointed out that this is not now as widely diffused in India as the alcohol habit.
('53', 452, 7, 19, 887242) The growth of the poppy has diminished in

('53', 453, 1, 5, 887559) Mr. Gandhi said : The opium habit is indigenous, but the moral sense of the Indian people would require early, thoroughgoing prohibitive action in this regard also.

('53', 455, 0, 1, 891921) 456 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('53', 455, 1, 2, 891963) India has fared.
('53', 455, 1, 3, 891980) I have placed two infallible tests : Is it or is it not a fact that India today is the poorest country in the world, having millions of people remaining idle for six months of the year?
('53', 455, 1, 4, 892166) Is it or is it not a fact that India has been rendered emasculated not merely through compulsory disarmament,but also through being denied so many opportunities that members of a free nation are always entitled to?
('53', 455, 1, 5, 892381) If you find upon investigation that in these two cases England has failed, I do not say hopelessly, but to a very large extent, is it not time that England revised her policy?
('53', 455, 1, 6, 892557) As a friend said, and as the late Lokamanya Tilak said repeat edly from thousands of platforms: “Freedom and independence were India’s birthright.” It is not necessary for me to prove that British rule has been in the end British misrule.
('53', 455, 1, 7, 892796) It is only enough for me to state that, misrule or good rule, India is entitled to her independence immediately, there is a demand made for it on behalf of her voiceless millions.
('53', 455, 1, 8, 892976) It is no answer to be told that there are some in India who are afraid of the words ‘freedom’ and ‘independence’.
('53', 455, 1, 9, 893090) There are some of us, and I admit there are some of us, who are afraid of talking about the freedom of India if the British protection so called is withdrawn from India.
('53', 455, 1, 10, 893260) But I assure you that the starving millions and those who have become politically conscious entertain no such fear and they are ready to pay the price for the sake of freedom.
('53', 455, 1, 11, 893436) There are, however, well marked limitations so long as the Congress retains her present workers and her faith in her present policy.
('53', 455, 1, 12, 893569) We do not want the freedom of India if it is to be bought through the sacrifice of the lives of others if it is to be bought by spilling the blood of the rulers.

('53', 459, 3, 4, 900547) LONDON, October 5, 1931
('53', 459, 4, 5, 900571) The unofficial Minorities Conference began its sitting at 3 p.m.
('53', 459, 4, 6, 900636) and was still sitting at 5.45 p.m.
('53', 459, 4, 7, 900671) It is understood that in order to appreciate the full claims of the minority communities, representatives of each community outlined their position and questions discussed mainly concerned with the percentage of representation and weightage and reservation of seats.
('53', 459, 5, 8, 900938) During discussion great importance was laid on settlement of the HIndu Muslim question as the real crux of the minority problem.
('53', 459, 5, 9, 901067) The impression was created that if the Hindu Muslim question was settled, the claims of other minorities would be automatically adjusted.
('53', 459, 6, 10, 901205) The stand against communal representation and separate representation is reported to have been made by Mr. Gandhi towards the close of todays sitting of the unofficial committee after representatives of various minorities had presented their claims for separate representation and the quantum of representation.
('53', 459, 7, 11, 901517) Mr. Gandhi is reported to have given expression to the sense of unreality if all claims were taken at their face value and said that he felt cramped and hemmed in amid a plethora of claims Though he had not been idle, he was hitherto unable to see daylight but if he saw light he would act.
('53', 459, 8, 12, 901808) Mr. Gandhi is reported to have expressed the belief that he was able to help but to have invited the conference to elect another chairman if they thought otherwise, for he would not be ashamed to say that he had tried and failed.
('53', 459, 9, 13, 902038) Urging the need for a spirit of conciliation, Mr. Gandhi is reported to have invited the Conference to take more time if necessary, but declared that he was unable to compromise on fundamentals and, desirous as they were to see India a great nation, the Congress would never agree to communal representation and would be unworthy of its name if it allowed separate representation.

('53', 461, 1, 2, 904324) 506. SPEECH AT MINORITIES COMMITTEE MEETING
('53', 461, 2, 3, 904368) LONDON, October 8,1931
('53', 461, 3, 4, 904391) PRIME MINISTER AND FRIENDS, It is with deep sorrow and deeper humiliation that I have to anno unce utter failure on my part to secure an agreed solution of the commu nal question through informal conversations among and with the repres entatives of different groups.
('53', 461, 3, 5, 904658) I apologize to you, Mr. Prime Minister, and the other colleagues for the waste of a precious week.
('53', 461, 3, 6, 904757) My only conso lation lies in the fact that when I accepted the burden of carrying on these talks, I knew that there was not much hope of success, and still more in the fact that I am not aware of having spared any effort to reach a solution.
('53', 461, 3, 7, 904999) But to say that the conversations have to our utter shame failed is not to say the whole truth.
('53', 461, 3, 8, 905095) Causes of failure were inherent in the composition of the Indian Delegation.
('53', 461, 3, 9, 905172) We are almost all not elected representatives of the parties or groups whom we are presumed to represent; we are here by nomination of the Government.
('53', 461, 3, 10, 905323) Nor are those whose presence was absolutely necessary for an agreed solution to be found here.
('53', 461, 3, 11, 905418) Further, you will allow me to say that this was hardly the time to summon the Minorities Committee.
('53', 461, 3, 12, 905518) It lacks the sense of reality in what we do not know what it is that we are going to get.
('53', 461, 3, 13, 905608) If we knew in a definite manner that we were going to get the thing we want, we should hesitate fifty times before we throw it away in a sinful wrangle, as it would be if we are told that the getting of it would depend on the ability of the present Delegation to produce an agreed solution of the communal tangle.
('53', 461, 3, 14, 905922) The solution can be the crown of the swaraj constitution, not its foundation, if only because our differences have hardened, if they have hardened, if they have not arisen, by reason of the foreign domination.
('53', 461, 3, 15, 906132) I have not a shodow of a doubt that the iceberg of communal differences will melt under the warmth of the sun of freedom.
('53', 461, 3, 16, 906254) I, thereore, venture to suggest that the Minorities Committee be adjourned sine die and that the fundamentals of the constitution be hammered into shape as quickly as may be.
('53', 461, 3, 17, 906429) Meanwhile, the informal work of discovering a true solution of the communal problem will and must continue; only it must not baulk or be allowed to block the
('53', 462, 0, 1, 906587) VOL. 53 : 2 JULY, 1931 12 OCTOBER, 1931 463
('53', 462, 1, 2, 906631) progress of constitution building.
('53', 462, 1, 3, 906666) Attention must be diverted from it and concentrated on the main part of the structure.
('53', 462, 1, 4, 906753) I hardly need point out to the Committee that my failure does not mean the end of all hope of arriving at an agreed solution.
('53', 462, 1, 5, 906879) My failure does not even mean my utter defeat; there is no such word in my dictionary.
('53', 462, 1, 6, 906966) My confession merely means failure of the special effort for which I presumed to ask for a week’s indulgence, which you so generously give.
('53', 462, 1, 7, 907106) I propose to use the failure as a stepping stone to success, and I invite you all to do likewise; but, should all effort at agreement fail, even when the Round Table Conference reaches the end of its labours, I would suggest the addition of a clause to the expected constitution appointing a judicial tribunal that would examine all claims and give its final decision on all the points that may be left unsettled.
('53', 462, 1, 8, 907520) Nor need this Committee think that the time given for enabling informal conversations to be carried on has been altogether wasted.
('53', 462, 1, 9, 907651) You will be glad to learn that many friends not members of the Delegation have been giving their attention to the question.
('53', 462, 1, 10, 907775) Among these I would mention Sir Geoffrey Corbett.
('53', 462, 1, 11, 907825) He has produced a scheme of redistribution of the Punjab which, though it has not found acceptance, is, in my opinion, well worth studying.
('53', 462, 1, 12, 907965) I am asking Sir Geoffrey if he will kindly eleborate and circulate it among the members.
('53', 462, 1, 13, 908054) Our Sikh colleagues have also produced another, which is at least worthy of study.
('53', 462, 1, 14, 908137) Sir Hubert Carr produced last night an ingenious and noval proposal to set up for the Punjab two Legislatures, the lower to satisfy the Muslim claim and the upper nearly satisfying the Sikh claim.
('53', 462, 1, 15, 908334) Though I am no believer in a bicameral Legislature, I am much attracted by Sir Hubert’s proposal, and I would invite him to pursue it further with the same zeal with which, I gratefully admit, he followed and contributed to the informal deliberations.
('53', 462, 1, 16, 908586) Lastly, inasmuch, as the only reason or my appearance at these deliberations is that I represent the Indian National Congress, I must clearly set forth its position.
('53', 462, 1, 17, 908752) In site of appearances to the contrary, especially in England, the Congress claims to represent the whole nation, and most decidedly the dumb millions, among whom are included the numberless untouchables, who are more suppressed than depressed, as also in a way the more unfortunate and neglected classes known as Backward Races.
('53', 463, 0, 1, 909082) 464 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('53', 463, 1, 2, 909124) Here is the Congress position in a nutshell.
('53', 463, 1, 3, 909169) I am reading the Congress resolution on the subject.
('53', 463, 2, 4, 909222) However much it may have failed in the realization, the Congress has, since its inception, set up pure nationalism as its ideal.
('53', 463, 2, 5, 909351) It has endeavoured to break down communal barriers.
('53', 463, 2, 6, 909403) The following Lahore resolution was the culminating point in its advance towards nationalism :
('53', 463, 3, 7, 909498) “In view of the lapse of the Nehru Report it is necessary to declare the policy of the Congress regarding communal questions :
('53', 463, 4, 8, 909625) The Congress believes that in an independent India communal questions can only be solved on strictly national lines; but as the Sikhs in particular, and the Muslims and the other minorities in general, have expressed dissatisfaction over the solution of communal questions, proposed in the Nehru Report, this congress assures the Sikhs, the Muslims and other minorities that no solution thereof in any future constitution will be acceptable to the Congress that does not give full satisfaction to the parties concerned.”
('53', 463, 5, 9, 910146) Hence the Congress is precluded from setting forth any communal solution of the communal problem, but at this critical juncture in the history of the nation it was felt that the Working Committee should suggest for adoption by the country a solution, though communal in appearance, yet as nearly national as possible, and generally acceptable to the communities concerned.
('53', 463, 5, 10, 910519) The Working Committee, therefore, after full and free discussion, unanimously passed the following scheme :
('53', 463, 6, 11, 910627) 1. (a) The article in the constitution relating to fundamental rights shall include a guarantee to the communities concerned of the protection of their cultures, languages, scritps, education, profession and practice of religion and religious endowments;
('53', 463, 7, 12, 910882) (b) Personal laws shall be protected by specific provisions to be embodied in the constitution;
('53', 463, 8, 13, 910978) (c) Protection of political and other rights of minority communities in the various Provinces shall be the concern and be within the jurisdiction of the Federal Government.
('53', 463, 9, 14, 911151) 2. The Franchise shall be extended to all adult men and women—
('53', 463, 10, 15, 911214) And then there is a note to this:
('53', 463, 11, 16, 911248) The Working Committee is committed to adult franchise by the Karachi resolution of the Congress, and cannot entertain any alternative franchise.
('53', 463, 11, 17, 911393) In view, however, of misapprehensions in some quarters, the Committee wishes to make it clear that, in any event, the franchise shall be uniform and so
('53', 464, 0, 1, 911545) VOL. 53 : 2 JULY, 1931 12 OCTOBER, 1931 465
('53', 464, 1, 2, 911589) extensive as to reflect in the electoral roll the proportion in the population of every community.
('53', 464, 2, 3, 911688) 3. (a) Joint electorates shall form the basis of representation in the future constitution of India; (b) That for the Hindus in Sind, the Muslims in Assam and the Sikhs in the Punjab and North West Frontier Province, and for Hindus and Muslims in any province where they are less than 25 per cent of the population, seats shall be reserved in the Federal and Provincial Legislatures on the basis of population, with the right to contest additional seats.
('53', 464, 3, 4, 912143) 4. The appointments shall be made by non party Public Service Commissions, which shall prescribe the minimum qualifications, and which shall have due regard to the efficiency of the Public Service as well as to the principle of equal opportunity to all communities for a fair share in the Public Services of the country.
('53', 464, 4, 5, 912464) 5. In the formation of Federal and Provincial Cabinets, the interests of minority communities shall be recognized by convention.
('53', 464, 5, 6, 912593) 6. The North West Frontier Province and Baluchistan shall have the same form of government and administration as other Provinces.
('53', 464, 6, 7, 912723) 7. Sind shall be constituted into a separate Province provided that the people of sind are prepared to bear the financial burden of the separated Provinces.
('53', 464, 7, 8, 912880) 8. The future constitution of the country shall be Federal.
('53', 464, 7, 9, 912940) The residuary powers shall vest in the federating units unless, on further examination, it is found to be against the best interest of India.
('53', 464, 8, 10, 913082) The Working Committee has adopted the foregoing scheme as a compromise between the proposals based on undiluted communalism and undiluted nationalism.
('53', 464, 8, 11, 913233) Whilst on the one hand the Working Committee hopes that the whole nation will endorse the scheme, on the other it assures those who take extreme views and cannot adopt it, that the Committee will gladly, as it is bound to by the Lahore Resolution, accept without reservation any other scheme if it commands the acceptance of all the parties concerned.
('53', 464, 9, 12, 913585) That is the Congress resolution.
('53', 464, 9, 13, 913618) If, however, a national solution is impossible and the Congress scheme proves unacceptable, I am not precluded from endorsing any other reasonable scheme which may be acceptable to the parties concerned.
('53', 464, 9, 14, 913822) The Congress position on this question, therefore, is one of the greatest possible accommodation.
('53', 464, 10, 15, 913920) 1 Vide “Proposed Communal Solution”, 16 7 1931
('53', 465, 0, 1, 913967) 466 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('53', 465, 1, 2, 914009) Where it cannot help, it will not obstruct.
('53', 465, 1, 3, 914053) Needless to say, the Congress will whole heartedly support any scheme of private arbitration.
('53', 465, 1, 4, 914147) It seems to have been represented that I am opposed to any representation of the untouchables on the Legislature.
('53', 465, 1, 5, 914261) This is a travesty of the truth.
('53', 465, 1, 6, 914294) What I have said, and what I must repeat, is that I am opposed to their special representation.
('53', 465, 1, 7, 914390) I am convinced that it can do them no good, and may do much harm; but the Congress is wedded to adult franchise.
('53', 465, 1, 8, 914503) Therefore, millions of them can be placed on the Voters’ Roll.
('53', 465, 1, 9, 914566) It is impossible to conceive that, with untouchability fast disappearing, nominees of these voters can be boycotted by the others; but what these people need more than election to be Legislatures is protection from social and religious persecution.
('53', 465, 1, 10, 914815) Custom, which is often more powerful than law, has brought them to a degradation of which every thinking HIndu has need to feel ashamed and to do penance.
('53', 465, 1, 11, 914970) I should, therefore, have the most drastic legislation rendering criminal all the special persecution to which these fellow countrymen of mine are subjected by the socalled superior classes.
('53', 465, 1, 12, 915161) Thank God, the conscience of Hindus has been stirred, and untouchability will soon be a relic of our sinful past.
('53', 465, 2, 13, 915275) Indian Round Table Conference(Second Session): Proceedings of Federal Structure Committee and Minorities Committee ,Vol. I, pp.
('53', 465, 3, 14, 915403) 507. EXTRACT FROM A LETTER TO LORD IRWIN October 8, 1931 You will have seen with sorrow the failure of my first effort.

('53', 466, 1, 2, 915811) 508. SPEECH AT CONFERENCE OF MISSIONARY SOCIETIES IN GREAT BRITAIN AND IRELAND 1
('53', 466, 2, 3, 915892) LONDON, October 8, 1931
('53', 466, 3, 4, 915916) The meeting was begun with a brief period of silence and the Rev.
('53', 466, 3, 5, 915982) W. Paton, who presided, welcomed Mr. Gandhi and expressed the appreciation of the missionary societies of the fact that Mr. Gandhi could spare time to meet them in the midst of tremendous pressure of work.
('53', 466, 4, 6, 916188) Mr. Gandhi, after expressing pleasure at being present and at meeting those who represented a much larger audience, said: I am appearing before you like a prisoner at the bar, but my jailors are friends.
('53', 466, 4, 7, 916392) There must be no barrier between us, no harbouring of any grievance on either side.
('53', 466, 4, 8, 916476) From youth upwards I have enjoyed the friendliest relations with missionaries throughout the world, and in South Africa I came into close touch with some of the finest of Christian missionaries.
('53', 466, 4, 9, 916671) I attended your churches most regularly and also private prayer meetings and the views I express now are the views I expressed then.
('53', 466, 4, 10, 916804) A temporary misunderstanding had arisen between you and me.
('53', 466, 4, 11, 916864) When newspaper men pry into the affairs of those leading public lives the latter get misrepresented, sometimes maliciously and at other times unintentionally.
('53', 466, 4, 12, 917023) Responsible men should learn from my very bitter experience not to believe generally what the reporters state.
('53', 466, 4, 13, 917134) The recent report about my attitude to missions was an unconscious misrepresentation, for I got to know the source and the reporter in question.
('53', 466, 4, 14, 917279) I was tired out at the time and was having exercise early in the morning.
('53', 466, 4, 15, 917353) The reporter walked with me and bombarded me with questions.

('53', 469, 3, 5, 923289) This Conference is emphatically of opinion that the utmost freedom of conscience and religion is essential, and condemns any desecration of places of worship to whatsoever faith they may belong, and any persecution or punishment or any person or adopting or reverting to any faith, and further condemns any attempt by compulsion to convert people to one’s faith or to enforce ones’s own religious observance at the cost of the rights of others.

('53', 469, 5, 7, 924006) That every individual or group shall have full liberty to hold and give expression to his or their beliefs and follow any religious practice, with due regard to the feelings of others and without interfering with their rights.

('53', 475, 3, 4, 937845) He discussed the question of the education of the child, listened with rapt attention as Gandhiji gave him the rich experience of a lifetime of the value of self restraint and the great part it plays as much in the life of the child as of the adult.
('53', 475, 3, 5, 938095) “What is the cause of the present chaos?” he asked.
('53', 475, 3, 6, 938147) Gandhiji said: It is exploitation, I will not say of the weaker nations by the stronger, but of sister nations by sister nations.
('53', 475, 3, 7, 938277) And my fundamental objection to machinery rests on the fact that is machinery that has enabled these nations to exploit others.
('53', 475, 3, 8, 938405) In itself it is a wooden thing and can be turned to good purpose or bad.
('53', 475, 3, 9, 938478) But it is easily turned to a bad purpose as we know.
('53', 475, 4, 10, 938531) “Don’t you think”, said Mr. Desmond, “all these people here are overfed?
('53', 475, 4, 11, 938604) How can we teach them to feed less?” Gandhiji said: The force of circumstances.
('53', 475, 4, 12, 938684) They are bound to realize one of these days that England is not going to return to her old prospertiy.
('53', 475, 4, 13, 938787) They must realize that many nations bid fair to divide the spoils with them and, as soon as they do so, they will cut the coat according to their cloth.
('53', 475, 5, 14, 938940) “The crisis therefore”, said Mr. Desmond, with great emphasis, “is a great thing, I have no doubt.”

('53', 478, 1, 2, 941674) 515. SPEECH AT FEDERAL STRUCTURE
('53', 478, 2, 3, 941707) COMMITTEE MEETING
('53', 478, 3, 4, 941725) LONDON, October 9, 1931 Well, Lord Chancellor, I know that I have been somewhat instrumental in postponing the deliberations of this Committee; and, being in that unfortunate position, I now feel some diffidence when I say that we cannot afford to waste a single minute.
('53', 478, 3, 5, 941996) 1 We have come, as you very properly say, all these several thousand miles in order to work, and not in order to seek recreation or holiday; so I would certainly say that, if it is at all possible, we should go through the work of the Federal Structure Committee without waiting for a single minute.
('53', 478, 3, 6, 942296) If at the back of our minds, individually or collectively, the thought is lurking that, even though we might be sitting over the deliberations of the Federal Structure Committee, we would be really marking time until the minorities question is settled if that really is the feeling which we would not or we dare not express then I would suggest that we express that feeling and come to a decision.
('53', 478, 3, 7, 942694) I myself endeavoured to express my own deliberate opinion yesterday that there is not that absolutely vital connection with the work of this Committee.
('53', 478, 3, 8, 942846) The minorities question is undoubtedly a very important, if not the most important, question.
('53', 478, 3, 9, 942940) It has always occupied in my own mind its natural place, but it has never overshadowed the other equally important consideration.
('53', 478, 3, 10, 943070) And, after having laboured at this question for seven days, I saw more clearly than I had seen before that probably the minorities question would not be satisfactorily settled unless the great fundamental questions were settled.
('53', 478, 3, 11, 943299) That being my conviction, I should like the proceedings of this Committee to be clothed with reality, and that, on several heads which you, with your amazing industry, have been piling upon us from day to day and week to week, we should come to summary decisions instead of making speeches.
('53', 478, 3, 12, 943590) Therefore, if I may give my opinion without any mental reservation whatsoever, I would suggest
('53', 478, 4, 13, 943685) 1 The chairman had suggested adjournment of the meeting till Tuesday, October 13.
('53', 479, 0, 1, 943767) 480 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('53', 479, 1, 2, 943809) that, if we really feel, as I feel, that we should consider and face the questions that are before this Committee on their merits, irrespective of what may happen in connection with the minorities question, then I say that we should sacrifice every holiday; and I know that we shall get the strength to go through this work without coming to grief if we mean serious business.
('53', 479, 1, 3, 944186) But I repeat, as I conclude, that if at the back of our minds the impression is that we should continue to work and yet not work, I think that it would not be just to India, it would not be just to ourselves, and it would not be just to the British Ministers either.
('53', 479, 1, 4, 944453) Thereore, I feel most strongly that we do not need any holiday.
('53', 479, 1, 5, 944517) Every minute that we have is really pledged to this work and no other.

('53', 486, 1, 2, 958760) cards on the table, I, like every other delegate, am subjected to certain restrictions which I must observe.
('53', 486, 1, 3, 958869) I am, therefore, not successful in presenting my whole case.
('53', 486, 1, 4, 958930) Even though I believe I may have to go empty handed, in spite of all my efforts for an amicable settlement, I shall have the fullest satisfaction if I have been able to present my case to those who are earnest about India, but unfortunately are not fully informed about the Congress.
('53', 486, 1, 5, 959214) I claim that Congress represents in an overwhelming manner the masses of India, and I ask you to accept it that I have come here to plead for that independence for which thousands and thousands of men and women courted imprisonment, received lathi blows, and for which some even laid down their precious lives.
('53', 486, 1, 6, 959525) Complete independence does not exclude partnership on an absolute equality basis with Great Britain, terminable by either party.
('53', 486, 2, 7, 959654) Mr. Gandhi then stated the Congress claim, and the discretion that he was permitted to exercise in the matter of reservation and safeguards.
('53', 486, 3, 8, 959795) He added that Lord Irwin, of all Englishmen, was able to draw him to England .
('53', 486, 3, 9, 959874) Referring to safeguards in the interest of India, Mr. Gandhi said that the safeguards would be in mutual inerest, as he would not have adjustments that did moral harm to Britain, though some of them might mean material loss.
('53', 486, 3, 10, 960099) We in India have come to the conclusion that some of the transactions of the British Government are of questionable character, causing terrible economic loss to the Indian people.

('53', 486, 4, 12, 960374) Concluding, Mahatma Gandhi expressed the fervent hope that the future historian would say that India fought and won liberty without shedding blood.
('53', 486, 5, 13, 960522) Q. If we withdrew entirely the control of the British Army in India, would
('53', 486, 6, 14, 960597) there not be internecine strife between Hindus and Muslims and would it not
('53', 486, 7, 15, 960673) materialize into a serious and terrible condition?
('53', 486, 7, 16, 960724) People from India assure me that that
('53', 486, 8, 17, 960762) would be the case.
('53', 486, 9, 18, 960781) A. It is a good question and it is a question that has been asked on so many occasions ever since I have come here and in India also.
('53', 486, 9, 19, 960915) My answer is that it is possible.
('53', 486, 9, 20, 960949) It is likely that we the Hindus and Muslims may fight one another if the British Army is withdrawn.
('53', 486, 10, 21, 961049) 1 The report up to this point is from Indian News.
